residence: 5237 Washington Ave. Summer Residence: Roaring Brook, Mich.
fullentry: EVANS, Henry H, director Carleton Dry Goods Co.; born Jonesboro, Ill., Mar. 31,1857; son of John and Mary Ellen Evans; educated in public schools of Jonesboro; married, Anna, Ill., Jan. 8, 1885, Winifred Sanborn; one son: Murray Carleton. Began business career as printer'8 devil in Murphysboro, Ill., 1873; came to St Louis, July, 1874, and secured position with Henry Bell & Co., wholesale dry goods; in 1877 entered employ of Crow-Har-gadine Dry Goods Co. as assistant to S. C. Bunn, who was general sales manager for Southern Illinois territory; in 1878 became connected with J. H. Wear, Boogher & Co., as general salesman for Southern Illinois; was elected a director and admitted as partner, 1887; name changed, 1899, to Carleton Dry Goods Co., of which has continued as member board of directors. Independent in politics. Methodist. Member Illinois Society of St Louis. Club: Glen Echo. Recreation: golf. Office: Carleton Dry Goods Co. Residence: 5237 Washington Ave. Summer Residence: Roaring Brook, Mich.

memberships: ["American Bar Association","Missouri Bar Association","St Louis Bar Association","Society of International Law","etc"]
fullentry: EVANS, William F., general counsel Frisco Lines; born in Monroe Co., Ia., Nov. 16, 1859; son of William and Margaret J. (Vestal) Evans; preliminary education in public schools of Centerville, la.; unmarried. Admitted to the bar, 1886, and began practice at Centerville, Ia.; was assistant general attorney, 1886-1902 (coming to 8t. Louis in 1901), general attorney, 1902-07, Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Ry.; general attorney, March-Decem-ber, 1907, general solicitor, 1907-09, St Louis & San Francisco Railway Co.; general counsel Frisco Lines since Dec. 15, 1909; also general attorney for Rock Island Lines in Missouri. Director Central National Bank, St Louis. Member American Bar Association, Missouri Bar Association, St Louis Bar Association, Society of International Law, etc. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet. Office: Frisco Bldg. Residence: Washington Hotel.

EVERS, Frederick William, president Henry Evers Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 27, 1873; son of Henry and Sophia (Evers) Evers (no relation); graduated Everett (public) School, 1888; married, Dec. 23, 1896, Anna Marie Link, of Kentucky. Began active career as clerk in hardware store, continuing for twenty-one months; at request of father (who was a wood turner), learned wood-turning trade; on account of disagreement with father as to management of business, withdrew after three years and became partner in retail grocery store. Returned to wood-turning business, 1894, and was placed in charge of establishment which father founded, 1878; gave up wood turning, 1896, and has since devoted attention to making wooden tent goods, being the only exclusive manufacturer of tent and awning poles in the United States; also president Kra-Vers Investment Co. Member City Council, 1909-13. Republican. Protestant. Director German Protestant Orphans' Home. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreations: bowling and pool. Office: 1442 N. 8th St. Residence: 3953 Greer Ave.
EVERS, Henry, president Henry Evers Manufacturing Co.; born Feb. 23, 1845; died Mar. 28, 1912.

office: 520-533 Metropolitan Bldg., Grand Ave. and Olive St.
memberships: ["St Louis Academy of Science","St Louis Medical Society","St Louis Ophthalmological Society","American Ophthalmological Society","American Medical Association","American Academy of Medicine","Alumni Society Medical Department of Washington University","Staff of St"]
fullentry: EWING, Arthur Eugene, physician; born near Cartersville, Ga., Apr. 26, 1855; son of Whitley Thomas (A.B., M.D.) and Hannah Jane (Pettingill) Ewing; educated in private schools, Gadsden, Ala., 1862-74, Dartmouth College, 1874-78, A.B., 1878; principal of public school, Gadsden, Ala., 1878-79, and at same time studied law in office of Aiken & Martin; admitted to the bar, Gadsden, Ala., 1879; entered St Louis Medical College, 1880, M.D., 1883; assistant to Drs. John T. Hodgen and Henry H. Mudd, St Louis, 1881, and to Drs. John Green and M. Ill Post, 1882-86; studied at Koenigliche Christian-Albrecht's University, Kiel, Germany, 1886-88; associated with Drs. Green and Post in the practice of medicine since 1889. Married, Chattanooga, Tenn., 1891, Josephine, daughter of Charles Abner and Harriet Frances (Pettingill) Willard; children: Margaret Frances and Charlotte Eugenia. Clinical lecturer on ophthalmology, 1895, clinical professor of ophthalmology since 1902, Medical Department of Washington University; honorary degree of A.M., Washington University, 1912. Member St Louis Academy of Science, St Louis Medical Society, St Louis Ophthalmological Society, American Ophthalmological Society, American Medical Association, American Academy of Medicine, Alumni Society Medical Department of Washington University, Staff of St. Luke's Hospital, Staff of St Louis Skin and Cancer Hospital, Dartmouth Alumni Association; also Sons of Revolution and Greek Letter societies, Theta Delta Chi (academic), Phi Beta Pi (medical), Sigma Xi (post-graduate). Baptist. Republican. Office: 520-533 Metropolitan Bldg., Grand Ave. and Olive St. Residence: 5956 W. Cabanne PI.

EWING, Fayette Clay, physician; born in LaFourche Parish, La., May 28, 1862; son of Dr. Fayette C. and Eliza Josephine (Kit-tredge) Ewing; educated at University of the South, Sewanee, Tenn., 1877; University of Mississippi, 1878-79; Tulane University Medical College, New Orleans, 1882; Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, 1883-84; graduating M.D., 1884; married, Washington, D. C., Oct. 21, 1885, Frances Martha MacDonald; children: Fayette C., Jr., Ephraim M., Presley, Donald. Began general practice of medicine at Washington, I). C., 1885; removed to Kansas City, Mo., 1887; removed family to London, 1893, accepting appointment as assistant physician to London Central Throat and Ear Hospital, and was later attached to London Throat Hospital as assistant; attended London Post-Graduate School, giving special attention to course of instruction at Brompton Chest Hospital, the largest institution in the world for care of such diseases; returned to United States, 1895, and began practice as specialist in diseases of the ear and respiratory passages, in St Louis. On staff of various St Louis hospitals. With one exception, only American fellow of Royal Society of Medicine of Great Britain; formerly fellow of British Rhinological, Laryngological and Oto-logical Association; trustee University of the South. Late co-editor 4‘The Laryngoscope." Delegate to International Medical Congress, Rome, 1893, from American Medical Association; member Western Ophthalmologic and Oto-Laryngologic Academy (ex-vice president), American Medical Association, and other medical societies. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: Kirkwood Monday (ex-president), Beta Theta Pi, of St Louis (president). Frequent contributor to medical journals. Office: 449-450 Century Bldg. Residence: Kirkwood, Mo.

EWING, Mark, lawyer; born St Louis, June 29, 1870; son of Auguste Berthold and Mary Scott (McCausland) Ewing; educated in Stoddard Public School, Christian Brothers College, Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N. Ill, graduating, 1890; graduated from Sheffield Scientific School, Yale University, PhJB., 1893; studied at St Louis Law School. Admitted to bar, December, 1895, and began practice of law, and was in general practice until Jan. 3, 1901, when entered legal department of Terminal Railroad Association of St Louis; continued until Apr. 3, 1903; in bond department Germania Trust Co., April, 1903, to October, 1904, when resumed general practice of law. Member Bar Association of St Louis. Democrat; member of City Council, Apr. 4, 1905-09. Catholic. Clubs: Racquet, Missouri Athletic. Office: 509 Merchants-Laclede Bldg. Residence: St. Regis Apts.

EWING, Samuel Edgar, clergyman; born Sandoval, Ill., May 12, 1865; son of Robert and Minerva J. (Martin) Ewing; came to St Louis with parents, 1877; educated in public schools, St Louis, 1877-81; William Jewell College, A.B., 1893; Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, Louisville, Ky., Th.M., 1896; post-graduate work in same, 1896-97; married, St Louis, Sept. 23, 1896, Martha James Mo-Court; one son: Samuel Edgar, Jr. Associated with father in grocery business until 1881; learned telegraphy and was operator and secretary for superintendent of construction of St Louis Bridge and Terminal Ry., 1881-89, resigning to attend college. Ordained in Baptist ministry, 1889; pastor First Baptist Church, Kansas City, Kan., during school years; pastor Logan Street Baptist Church, Louisville, Ky., 1894-97; First Baptist Church, Holden, Mo., 1897-99; Taylor Avenue Baptist Church, St Louis, 1899-1903, Euclid Avenue Baptist Church, 1903-10; since superintendent St Louis Baptist Mission Board. Prohibition Republican. Mason. Office: 208 Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 5423 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["American Society of Naturalists","American Association of Anatomists","American Association for the Advancement of Science","Biological Society (St Louis)","Medical Science Club (St Louis)","St Louis Academy of Science"]
fullentry: EYCLESHYMER, Albert Chauncey, professor of anatomy; born Cambridge, N. Y., June 16, 1867; son of David C. and Anna M. (Perry) Eycleshymer; educated in public school, Hastings, Mich.; University of Michigan, B.S., 1891; fellow Princeton University, 1891; fellow Clark University (Worcester, Mass.), 1892; fellow University of Chicago, 1893, Ph.D., 1895; student University of Cambridge, England, 1895-96; Austin fellow, Harvard University, 1901 ;M.D., St Louis University, 1911; married, Chicago, Ill., Sept. 23, 1895, Mary Elizabeth Donovan; children: Ethel M., Albert D. and Lois C. Assistant professor of human embryology, Rush Medical College, Chicago, 1897-99; assistant professor of human anatomy, University of Chicago, 1903; now director of anatomical department, St. Loui9 University. Member American Society of Naturalists, American Association of Anatomists, American Association for the Advancement of Science, Biological Society (St Louis), Medical Science Club (St Louis), St Louis Academy of Science. Received grand prize for embryological work from Louisiana Purchase Exposition, 1904. Club: University. Recreation: shooting. Office: Medical Department, St Louis University. Residence: 5929 Julian Ave.

EYSSELL, Moritz, president M. Eyssell Construction Co.; born in Germany, Dec. 11, 1863; son of Otto and Marie (Boedecker) Eyssell; educated in public and private schools of Germany and Spalding's Commercial College, Kansas City, Mo.; married, Kansas City, Oct. 10, 1888, Emma Sieben; children: Carl George and Elsie Marie. Lost father in 1873 and came to America with mother and other members of the family, 1881; engaged in carpenter's trade in Kansas City until 1886, and then in contracting for five years; located in St Louis, 1891; was in business alone until 1907, when organized the M. Eyssell Construction Co., of which has since been president. Mason. Clubs: Union, Liederkranz. Office: 320. 816 Olive St. Residence: 3842 Flora Ave.

FABRICIUS, Henry Herman, president Fabricius Toy and Notion Co.; born, St Louis, Oct. 5, 1865; son of H. P. and Agatha (Martini) Fabricius; education in German Institute, 1872-75, and in Smith Academv, 187680; married, Feb. 21, 1887, Helena Gibhardt, Chicago; children: Laura A., Henry P., Edith C., Edwin A. On leaving Smith Academy, Feb. 1, 1880, entered the Fabricius Toy and Notion Co., established by father in 1861; succeeded him Sept. 3, 1886, and on incorporation of the business, Apr. 23, 1887, became secretary, treasurer and general manager, until Jan. 1, 1903, when was elected to present position as president of the company. Democrat. Christian Scientist. Mason (Blue Lodge). Member Liederkranz. Recreations: athletic exercises and billiards. Office: 907-909 N. Broadway. Residence: 3448 Crittenden Ave.

FABRICIUS, Herman Tilton, vice president Fabricius Toy and Notion Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 19, 1876; son of Henry P. and Agatha (Martini) Fabricius; educated in public schools. Educational Institute and Perkins & Herpel Business College, St Louis; unmarried. Began business career on leaviug school in 1894 in the house established, May 21,1858, by father, Henry P. Fabricius, and now known as the Fabricius Toy and Notion Co., importers and jobbers of general merchandise and season specialties in this line; vice president of the company since January, 1904. Member A. F. & A. M. Democrat. Favorite recreations: baseball, golf. Office: 909 X. Broadway. Residence: 1934 Lami St.

FADELEY, Harry Gordon, treasurer Kin-loch Telephone Co.; born Waterford, Va., Sept. 7, 1870; son of Charles W. and Orra (Orrison) Fadeley; educated in private school at home till 1884, public school, Waterford, Va., till 1888; unmarried. Bookkeeper, Aberdeen Daily Republican, Aberdeen, S. D., 1888; assistant postmaster, Aberdeen, S. D., 188990; with R. J. McLean, lumber. Washington, D. C., 1891-93; bookkeeper, Harrison Telephone Co., New York, 1894, and same company, Chicago, 1895-96; since Jan. 2, 1897, with Kinloch Telephone Co., St Louis, as cashier, 1897, assistant secretary and cashier, 1900, and treasurer and assistant secretary since 1903. Also secretary and director Kinloch Building Co. Club: Missouri Athletic. Office: Kinloch Bldg. Residence: 6108 McPherson Ave.

FAHLEN, Fred, physician; born Memphis, Tenn., Apr. 9, 1882; son of Julius and Caroline Fahlen; educated at Smith Academy, 1892-95; St Louis High School, 1895-99, graduating, 1899; M.D., Washington University, 1903; married, Oct. 10, 1906, Olive M. Cuthbert; children: Eugenia Cuthbert, Frederick, Jr., C. Cuthbert. Engaged in general practice of medicine at St Louis since 1903. Member medical staff Mullanphy Hospital, Medical Department, Washington University. Member St Louis Medical Society, St Louis Society of Internal Medicine, Missouri State Medical Association, Alumni of Medical Department of Washington University. Office: 405 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 5594 Bartmer Ave.

FAIBHAM, George G., retired; born St Louis, Feb. 15, 1855; son of Isaac Fairham; educated in St Louis public schools and at Mt. Olive, Mo.; married, Mt. Olive, Apr. 17, 1880, Emma Meyer, of Hungary; children: Christine, Emma, George E. Was engaged as practical gardener until 1867, when began in the produce business with father in Lucas Market; started for self in same place in 1876, and on May 1, 1881, began in wholesale commission business on Third St., admitting brother, Isaac, to the firm, 1885; on death of brother, 1899, became sole owner of the business; retired Jan. 1, 1911. Member Travelers' Protective Association. Catholic. Residence: 5048 Kensington Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","American Pharmaceutical Association","Missouri 8tate Pharmaceutical Association"]
fullentry: FALK, John Charles, physician; born in Ste. Genevieve Co., Mo., Jan. 23, 1863; son of Jacob and Thekla (Deck) Falk; educated in public and parochial schools, Ste. Genevieve, Mo.; Philadelphia College of Pharmacy, Ph.G., 1884 (gold medallist); St Louis College of Pharmacy, Ph.G., ad eundemt 1890; St Louis Medical College, M.D., 1890; Missouri Medical College, M.D., ad eundemf 1896; married, St Louis, Sept. 6, 1893, Rosa M. Pleus (died, May 15, 1904); children: Oswald Pleus, Dorothy Mary, Lucille Augusta; married, 2d, Sept. 8, 1910, Ida Curtman. Engaged in general practice of medicine in St Louis since March, 1890; medical interne St Louis City Hospital, 1890, having previously been engaged as pharmacist from 1880; instructor in materia medica in 8t. Louis Medical College (Washington University), 1891-94; adjunct professor of therapeutics, Missouri Medical College, 1895-1900; elected president St Louis College of Pharmacy, 1912; president Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, American Pharmaceutical Association, Missouri 8tate Pharmaceutical Association. Democrat. Roman Catholic. Office and Residence: 4568 Page Boul.

FALKENHAINER, Victor Henry, judge; born St Louis, July 4, 1868; son of Henry and Rosa (Stupp) Falkenhainer; educated in St Louis public schools, St Louis Law School (Washington University), graduating, LL.B., 1902; married, St Louis, June 20, 1894, Lulu Schirr; one son: August Henry. Began business career in 1883, held clerkships of various kinds until Jan. 1, 1899, when was appointed clerk in the office of recorder of deeds under William H. Hahn, and three months later was made deputy recorder, and during occupancy of that position attended law school. Admitted to bar, June, 1902, and on Jan. 2, 1903, engaged in general practice of law in St Louis; assistant prosecuting attorney, 1907-11; now judge Court of Criminal Correction, Division No. 2, term ending Jan. 1, 1913. Republican. Mason (32°). Member Concordia Gymnastic Society. Clubs: Liederkranz, Masonic. Recreations: literature and music. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg. Residence: 3523 S. Jefferson Ave.

FARDWELL, Harry Ringgold, civil engineer; born Baltimore, Md., Sept. 6, 1863; son of Isaac and Charlotte (Myers) Fardwell; educated in public schools of Baltimore, and McDonogh Institute, graduating, 1880; married, Glasgow, Mo., Feb. 23, 1887, Mary Elizabeth Lewis; children: Meredith Webb, Harry R., Jr. Began business career in employ of H. 8. War Department headquarters at St Louis under the Missouri River Commission, continuing at intervals from 1882 to 1902; during same period was assistant city engineer of St. Joseph, Mo., 1887; county surveyor of Buchanan Co., Mo., 1888-92; principal assistant engineer of Louisiana Purchase Exposition, 1902-04, and chief of that department, 1904; sewer commissioner of City of St Louis from June 6, 1905, to May 28,1911. Democrat. Member Masonic fraternity. Favorite recreations: hunting and fishing. Residence: 4441 McPherson Ave.

FARIBAULT, William Richard, real estate; born Mendota, Minn., Nov. 29, 1846; son of Alexander and Elizabeth (Graham) Faribault; educated at St. Mary's College, Montreal, Province of Quebec, and Shattuck School, Faribault, Minn.; married, Faribault, Aug. 31, 1874, Mary Josephine Tracy; children: Zoe I. (Mrs. J. Scott Battle), William M. After leaving college was in flour milling business at Faribault for five years; served as volunteer at the time of the Sioux uprising in Minnesota in 1862. Came to St Louis, 1880, and embarked as collector for J. B. C. Lucas; engaged in general real estate and loan business as Mueller & Faribault, 1891-1910; since as W. R. Faribault Realty Co. Is of pioneer Minnesota family, the county of Faribault in that state being named for his grandfather and the town of Faribault for his father. Member St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Secretary St Louis Merchants' Exchange Co. Catholic. Member Royal Arcanum. Office: 806 Chestnut St. Residence: Normandy Heights, Missouri.

FARISH, John Hamilton, real estate; born St Louis, Mar. 5, 1862; son of Edward T. and Lilly G. Farish; educated at St Louis University, 1871; Jesuit College, Montreal, Canada, 1874, Georgetown University, Washington, D. C., graduated, A.B., 1879; A.M., St Louis University, LL.B., Washington University; married, New Orleans, September, 1891, Janet Pierson; children: Dorothy, Frances, John. Engaged in real estate and loan business in St Louis since 1890; with John F. Storm in firm of Storm & Farish, 1892-1912; now John H. Farish & Co. Member Real Estate Exchange. Independent in politics. Catholic. Clubs: Mercantile, Noonday, Racquet. Recreation: traveling. Office: 119 N. 8th St. Residence: 5221 Westminster PI.

FARMER, Joseph Bryant, vice president Blanke-Wenneker Candy Co.; born Wolverhampton, Staffordshire, England, Dec. 31, 1843; son of John S. and Johanna (O'Connor) Farmer; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, May 1, 1872, Katherine Vogel; children: Jennie Louise (died, Apr. 5, 1907), Clarence Arigust, Dr. Percy Joseph, Kathryne May, Eva Marguerite (Mrs. Thomas D. Cleage) and Ruth Corinne. In 1870 began business career with Blanke & Bro., candy manufacturers; the firm name was changed to Blanke & Bro. Candy Co., 1881, and in 1890 he was elected vice president; in 1904 this company consolidated with the Wenneker-Morris Candy Co. under the present firm name of Blanke-Wenneker Candy Co., and he became vice president, which position he still holds, the company being manufacturers and wholesalers of fine confections, cocoa and chocolate. Also president Blanke & Bro. Realty Co. Presbyterian. Mason; Knight Templar (Past Master Missouri Lodge No. 1), Shriner; Past Supreme Chancellor Legion of Honor. Recreation: reading. Office: 608 Market St. Residence: 5329 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","St Louis City Hospital Alumni Association"]
fullentry: FARMER, Percy Joseph, physician; born St Louis, Feb. 3, 1878; son of Joseph B. and Katherine (Vogel) Farmer; graduated from St Louis High School, 1896; M.D., Medical Department of Washington University, 1899; married, St Louis, Jan. 2, 1898, Mabel A. Sanders; one son: George Sanders. Interne City Hospital, 1899-1900; medical superintendent Montezuma Ranch Resort, Romero, N. M., 1905-08; returned to St Louis, 1908; clinician nervous clinic, Washington University, since 1909. Republican. Member St Louis Medical Society, St Louis City Hospital Alumni Association. Office: Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 4393 W. Pine Boul.

FARRAR, Bernard Gaines, real estate; born St Louis, June 14, 1852; son of Benjamin and Anna (Kennett) Farrar; educated in St Louis schools; married, St Louis, 1891, Eliza Howard; children: Ann Kennett, Richard Howard, Dearborn Burnes. Was for fifteen years in the employ of the Simmons Hardware Co., prior to entering, in 1893, upon real estate business, with which has since been continuously connected, now being member of the Scott & Farrar Realty Co., real estate and loans. Office: 819 Chestnut St. Residence: 5320 Waterman Ave.

FARRAR, Charles Thruston, real estate; born St Louis, Aug. 6, 1857; son of John O'Fallon and Sallie (Christy) Farrar; educated at Mr. Hobby'8 Grammar School, New York, and scientific course in Washington University through freshman year; married, St Louis, November, 1884, Nancy Gorman; children: Benedict, J. Thruston, Jerome. Engaged in real estate business in St Louis since 1877, under firm name of Farrar & Tate, until 1912, since alone. Republican. Catholic. Office: 813 Security Bldg. Residence: 4523 W. Pine Boul.

FARRAR, Christy M, lawyer; born Hig-ginsville, Mo., Oct. 31, 1880; son of William Christy and Clara Gano (Jennings) Farrar; fourth generation of family, which settled in St Louis, 1804; educated in Jennings (public) School, Central High School, St Louis, and Collegiate Department of Washington University; LL.B., Law Department, Washington University, 1904; unmarried. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1903, and since engaged in practice at St Louis; assistant circuit attorney, 1909-11. Served as U. S. census official, 1900; lieutenant Company I, First Regiment, Missouri National Guard, December, 1904-06. Republican. Member M. E. Church, South. Member St Louis Bar Association, St Louis Law Library Association, Phi Delta Theta, Phi Delta Phi. Clubs: City, Public Question. Recreations: tennis, horseback riding. Office: 1401-1410 Third National Bank Bldg. Residence: Jennings Heights, 8527 Emma Ave.

FARRELL, Henry Edward, railway official; born Detroit, Mich., Oct. 11, 1864; son of John and Catherine (McLaughlin) Farrell; married, Dallas, Tex., Oct. 16, 1889, Mary Virginia Alston; children: Eulalie Catherine, Doddridge, Henry Edward, William Buchanan. Entered railway service as messenger for Michigan Central R. R., Detroit, 1878; served various railroads in minor capacities until Aug. 1, 1888; then took service with Cotton Belt System as commercial agent at Waco, Tex., and was promoted from time to time until, on Mar. 1, 1901, became freight traffic manager of the St Louis Southwestern Railway Co., vice president same since Apr. 22, 1912; also vice president and director of the St Louis Southwestern Railway Co. of Texas. Independent in politics. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet, Noonday, Liederkranz, Glen Echo (St Louis), Transportation, Fox Hills Golf, and Catholic clubs (New York). Office: 1531 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 6306 McPherson Ave.

FARRINGTON, John Peter, real estate; born South Bend, Ind., June 21, 1858; son of Patrick and Mary Maughen Farrington; educated in public and parish schools at South Bend; married, South Bend, Jan. 29, 1890, Mary T. Lovett; children: Thomas L., John F., Anna L., Richard J. Learned carriage blacksmith trade at works of Studebaker Bros. Manufacturing Co., South Bend; came to St Louis, September, 1880, and went into installment book business; since 1887 in real estate business, now member firm of Farrington & Co. Democrat. Catholic. Member of Legion of Honor, Knights of Columbus. Office: 907 Chestnut St. Residence: 2924 N. Xcwstead Avenue.

FARRINGTON, Patrick Joseph, life insurance; born South Bend, Ind., Jan. 15, 1860; son of Patrick and Mary (Maughen) Farrington; educated in parochial school taught by Brothers of Notre Dame University, Indiana; married, Carlinville, Ill., June 5, 1883, Cassie E. O'Neill; children: Mary E., Grace G., Florence C., Joseph E., Catherine, O'Neill Francis. Came to St Louis, 1882, and was in employ of a publishing company until 1885; in business for self selling publications and other merchandise until 1892; secretary St Louis House Furnishing Co. and St Louis Clothing Co., 1892-1910; now city manager John Hancock Life Insurance Co. Democrat. Roman Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus. Office: Chemical Bldg. Residence: 5189 Vernon Ave.

FASSETT, Leonard Alfred, diamond importer; born 8t. Louis, Aug. 28, 1873; son of Alfred K. and Margaret F. (Watson) Fassett; educated in public schools of 8t. Louis; married, 8t. Louis, May 27, 1896, Mary L. Fisher; children: Howard Field, Margaret, Edna. After leaving school was with Nugent & Co. as cash boy for three years, after that engaged with Jeremiah Murphy, pork packer, for three years; then with A. R. Brooks Jewelry Co., as traveling salesman; subsequently engaged in diamond business for self until 1896, when merged business with that of M. L. Weiss, under firm name of Weiss & Fassett. Republican. Mason (32°), Shriner. Member U. 8. Revolver Association. Clubs: Century, Oasis, and various revolver clubs. Favorite recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 204 Globe-Democrat Bldg. Residence: 5853 Plymouth Avenue.

FAULHABER, Ernest A., vice president Morey-Faulhaber Construction Co.; born Jefferson City, Mo., July 10, 1868; son of George L. and Elizabeth (Grimshaw) Faulhaber; graduated from Sedalia (Mo.) High School, 1884, and from Law School of University of Minnesota, LL.B., 1898; unmarried. Began business in Sedalia (Mo.) postoffice, 1884-86; in motive power department of Missouri, Kansas & Texas R. R., Sedalia, 1886-88; with Northern Pacific R. R., 1888-98, in auditing and purchasing department at St. Paul, Minn., 1888-92, Chicago, Ill., 1892-93, and St. Paul, Minn., 1893-98; treasurer Tennessee Central R. R., St Louis, 1898-1902, Nashville, Tenn., 1902-05; since July, 1905, vice president and treasurer Morey-Faulhaber Construction Co., engaged in construction of railroads; director Appalachicola Northern Railroad Co. Republican. Episcopalian. Club: Racquet. Recreation: golf. Office: 1212 Chemical Bldg. Residence: 4301 Morgan St.

FAULHABER, George Ludwig, life insurance; born Kirchbrombach, Hesse Darmstadt, Germany, Apr. 6, 1838; son of John Henry and Anna Catherine (Zimmer) Faulhaber; educated in common schools; emigrated to United States in 1851, settling in Pittsburgh, Pa.; came to Missouri, 1857; married, Jefferson City, Mo., Jan. 2, 1861, Elizabeth Grim-shaw; children: Catherine Enid, George Grim-shaw (deceased), Gertrude I., Ernst Arthur, Kda Marguerite, Blanche Lillian. With U. S. Express Co., in Jefferson City, 1857-64, and in Sedalia, Mo., 1864-66; established and conducted South Western Express Co., 1866-68; returned to agency in Sedalia, in which continued until 1884; treasurer Missouri Trust Co. and its successor, the Missouri Lincoln Trust Co., 1884-1903; bond officer, 1903-07, in special capacity until 1909; since connected with International Life Insurance Co. Republican. Mayor of Sedalia, Mo., 1878-79; member Sedalia board of education, 1882-84; treasurer City of Sedalia, 1888-89. Episcopalian. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Masonic. Office: 1240 Syndicate Trust Bldg. Residence: 4301 Morgan St.

FAUNTLEROY, Cornelius Hite, lawyer; born Winchester, Va.; son of Thomas Turner and Bettie Smith (Hite) Fauntleroy; graduated from Shenandoah Valley Academy, Winchester, 1876; M.A., University of Virginia, 1884; unmarried. Assistant professor of Greek, University of Virginia, 1881-84; admitted to the bar at St. Paul, Minn., January, 1890; junior member of law firm of Warner, Richardson & Lawrence, St. Paul, 1891-97; came to St Louis in 1897; admitted to Missouri bar, 1898, and since engaged in practice. Democrat. Member Protestant Episcopal Church. Member Missouri Bar Association, Alumni Association of University of Virginia. Club: St Louis. Recreations: tennis, rowing, swimming, walking. Office: 318 Commercial Bldg. Residence: 4148 Morgan St.

memberships: ["St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations"]
fullentry: FAUNTLEROY, Thomas Turner, lawyer; born in Winchester, Frederick Co., Va., Feb. 23, 1862; son of Judge Thomas Turner and Bettie Smith (Hite) Fauntleroy; educated in Shenandoah Valley Academy, Winchester, Va., 1872-79; studied law at University of Virginia, 1881-83; married, St. Paul, Minn., June 3, 1900, Bessie Stuart Lee; children: Bessie Lee and Janet Rankin (twins), Margaret Guion. Began practice of law, Oct. 12, 1883, in St. Paul, Minn., and continued there until July 4, 1896, when on account of ill health of wife was compelled to seek a warmer and milder climate. Practicing in St Louis since duly, 1896; member firm of Barclay, Shields & Fauntleroy, 1903-09, since Barclay, Fauntleroy & Cullen. Member St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Mercantile, Noonday, Masonic. Office: 315 Commercial Bldg. Residence: 4148 Morgan St.

FAUST, Edward Augustus, second vice president Anheuser-Busch Brewing Association; born St Louis, Jan. 13, 1809; son of Anthony E. and Elizabeth (Bischoff) Faust; educated in public schools, Smith Academy and Packard's School, New York; married, St Louis, Mar. 20, 1897, Anna Louise, daughter of Adolphus Busch; children: Leicester Busch, Audrey. Learned the fancy grocery business, wholesale and retail, in New York City with Tode Bros., 1885-87; in business with father in Faust & Sons Oyster and Restaurant Co., 1887-98, vice president and secretary that company, 1893-1902. Elected second vice president and director Anheuser-Busch Brewing Association, 1898, succeeding Adolphus Busch, Jr. (deceased). Also vice president Fourth National Bank; treasurer and general-manager St Louis Refrigerator Car Co.; secretary, treasurer and director Hotel Realty Co. Republican. Member Liederkranz. Clubs: St Louis, Glen Echo, Mercantile, Union, Noonday, City. Office: 9th and Pestalozzi Sts. Residence: 1 Portland PI.

memberships: ["Tower Grove Heights Improvement Association","Tower Grove Citizens' Association","Turners","etc"]
fullentry: FAY, Herman William, president Fay & Schueler Label Co., manufacturers of druggists' glassware; born Nashville, Tenn., Oct. 12, 1860; son of William and Rosalia (Rager) Fay; educated in public schools of Nashville and New Orleans, to fifteen years of age; came to St Louis and attended the Laclede and Madison Grammar schools, the Polytechnic High School, corner 7th and Chestnut Sts., and Washington University; married, St Louis, Feb. 13, 1884, Annie Margaret Engel-brecht; three children: Harold W., Alma M., Clarence H. (deceased). Began active career as a furniture finisher with the Scarrett Furniture Co.; next took charge of finishing work as foreman for William P. Arnd Barber Supply Co., continuing for five years; entered business on own account as H. W. Fay & Co., July, 1883; admitted Richard J. Schueler as partner, 1886, and name of firm was changed to Fay & Schueler; incorporated the Fay & Schueler Label Co., 1910, and has since served as president same; also interested in real estate business as H. W. Fay & J. H. Bendick. Democrat; precinct committeeman Twenty-fourth Ward for several years; elected to House of Delegates from Twenty-fourth Ward, 1907; elected central committeeman from Thirteenth Ward, August, 1910; unanimously chosen chairman Democratic City Central Committee, 1910, which office he still holds. Liberal in religious belief. Past Master Masonic Order; member Knights of Pythias, Royal Arcanum, National Union. Member Tower Grove Heights Improvement Association, Tower Grove Citizens' Association, Turners, etc. Finds a pleasant diversion in his political duties. Office: 222 Walnut St. Residence: 3904 Hartford St.

FAY, William, electrical engineer; born Elgin, Ill., Apr. 5, 1864; son of John and Han-, nah (Welch) Fay; educated in public and private schools, Elgin; Drew's Business College, graduating, 1884; studied engineering for four years under Charles Vanvepole, Chicago; married, St Louis, Aug. 8, 1897, Mrs. Cecilia G. Gray, n£e Annis; one adopted daughter: Carlotta Belle. Was connected with the Chicago gas plant, 1888-91; in charge of lighting and power plants of Pennsylvania Ry. between Chicago and Crestline, O., 189192; was identified with the establishment and incorporation of the Aurora & Elgin Electric Ry., 1892-93; with the Thomson-Houston Electric Co., 1893; came to St Louis, 1890, and was connected with Laclede Power Co., 189699; with the Imperial Light and Power Co. and its successor, the Union Light and Power Co., until 1903; at time of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition was in charge of the World's Fair Automobile and Transit Co.; in business for self since 1905. Republican. Catholic. Office: 1614, 721 Olive St. Residence: 5223 Cabanne Ave.

FEINER, Eugene Joseph, vice president Engelke & Feiner Milling Co.; born St Louis, Mar. 13, 1878; son of Frank and Helena (Klinger) Feiner; educated in public schools of St Louis and Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, St Louis, 1905, Paula Has-sendeubel; one daughter: Eugenia. After leaving school entered offieo of the Engelke & Feiner Milling Cov and was cashier of the company until 1905, when was elected vice president of the company. Also secretary and treasurer of the Frank Feiner Realty Co. Member Merchants' Exchange, Liederkranz. Independent in politics. Office: S16 S. Broadway. Residence: 3963 Flora Boul.

FEINER, Frank, president Engelke & Feiner Milling Co.; born Baden, Germany, February, 1831; educated in schools in Germany; married, St Louis, 1866, Helena Klinger; children: Eugene, Adalia, Lillie. Came from Germany to St Louis, 1855; went to California and engaged in mining, 1855-60; in 1860 returned to St Louis and engaged with John Engelke in the manufacture of white corn products, establishing the Southern Roller Mills under firm name of Engelke & Feiner, which continued, after death of Mr. Engelke in 1889, until 1895, when business was incorporated under present style of Engelke & Feiner Milling Co., merchant millers, of which is president. Also president of Frank Feiner Realty Co. Member Merchants' Exchange. Office: 816 S. Broadway. Residence: 3333 S. 13th St.

FEKETE, Thomas Louis, real estate; born Aviston, Clinton Co., Ill., Apr. 7, 1856; son of Alexander and Kate (Fisher) Fekete; educated in public schools of East St Louis, Ill., and Bryant & Stratton Commercial College, St Louis; married, Jan. 22, 1881, Charlotte J. La Beau; children: Thomas L., Ophelia F., Robert A., Forrest F., George E., Josephine C. Since Aug. 5, 1875, engaged in real estate business; president of Thomas L. Fekete Co., Modern Building and Savings Association; director Illinois State Trust Co., East St Louis & Suburban Railway Co. President East St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Republican; president of board of education of East St Louis, 1893-95; special tax collector of East St Louis, 1894-95; postmaster of East St Louis, 1897-1901, aid-de-camp on general staff of Illinois National Guard, with rank of colonel, 1892-94, appointed by Gov. Richard Yates. Mason (33°), Knight Templar, Shriner; member Knights of Pythias, B. P. O. Elks. Clubs: Missouri Athletic (treasurer), St. Clair Country. Recreations: golf, motoring, fishing. Office: 324 Collinsville Ave., East St Louis. Residence: 1018 Pennsylvania Ave., East St Louis.

memberships: ["Business Men's League; was charter member St Louis School Patrons' Alliance","of which was president","1899-1906; chairman local Michigan Association World's Fair; has been president several local improvement associations","at present of McCausland Avenue Improvement Association"]
fullentry: FELKER, Peter H., president General Printing Co.; born in Park Tp., St. Joseph Co., Mich., June 4, 1850; son of Philip and Sarah (Hoats) Felker; educated in “Little Red School House," St. Joseph Co., to 1868, then entered State Agricultural College of Michigan, at Lansing, graduating Nov. 13, 1871, degree of B.S., and for efficiency in botanical studies received M.S., in 1873; married, Grand Rapids, Mich., Nov. 1, 1877, Kate M. Bertsch; two children: Ruth Katherine and Paul Henry. Engaged on farm until 1868; taught in county district schools, winters of 1868 and 1869; after graduation, principal in Ward School, Lansing, Mich., 1872 and 1873; instructor in history, and foreman Horticultural Department, Michigan College, 1874-75; engaged in grocery business, Grand Rapids, Mich., 187677; became associate editor American Grocer, New York City, 1878, and continued until 1880; removed to St Louis, 1880, and editor St Louis Grocer to 1892; editor St Louis Dry Goods Reporter, 1892-1902; engaged in printing business as president Shultz Printing Co.; firm name changed to General Printing Co., 1905, of which is still president. Member Business Men's League; was charter member St Louis School Patrons' Alliance, of which was president, 1899-1906; chairman local Michigan Association World's Fair; has been president several local improvement associations, at present of McCausland Avenue Improvement Association. Republican. Member Royal Arcanum. Author of Grocer's Manual, 1879 (seven editions); also Letters to a Young Merchant and Talks to Clerks, 1880 (three editions). Recreations: fishing, gardening, study of plant and animal life. Office: 1017 Morgan St. Residence: 6949 Mitchell Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Missouri State Bar Association"]
fullentry: FEMMER, Henry William, lawyer; born near Herman, Mo., Aug. 9, 1871; son of August and Anna (Stocker) Femmer; educated in public schools of Truxton, Mo., and business course at Perkins & Herpel Business College (night school); graduated from Valparaiso (Ind.) Normal School as LL.B.; married, Kankakee, Ill., June, 1898, Cora Snyder; one daughter: Beatrice. Came to St Louis from Valparaiso, Ind., in 1897, and engaged in general civil practice; was a member of the law firm of Peers, Femmer & Peers, 1898-1902; since practicing alone. Member St Louis Bar Association, Missouri State Bar Association. Republican. Member Christian Church. Member Royal League. Favorite recreations: literature and music. Office: Central National Bank Bldg. Residence: 6145 Gambleton PI.

FENSKY, Charles, lawyer; born St Louis, Jan. 22, 1867; son of Herman and Margaret (Nagel) Fensky, the former of Swedish and the latter of German parentage; educated in public schools and Jones Commercial College, St Louis; studied law in office of H. S. Senator Charles Curtis, of Topeka, Kan.; married, Osage City, Kan., Sept. 27, 1891, Jennie No-penz; three children: Alviena M., Charles P. and Edouard A. Admitted to Kansas bar, 1890; practiced about four years with preceptor and one year in office of attorney general of Kansas; admitted to Missouri bar, June, 1895; practiced two years with Gov. Charles P. Johnson; acted as assistant prosecuting attorney at the Four Courts, about six years under Col. Richard M. Johnson; member firm of Fensky & Fickeisen about two years; then as Nolan & Fensky about two years; since in practice alone (the first twelve years devoted to criminal law, since in civil courts). Trustee American Medical College. Republican. German Lutheran. Mason (Erwin Lodge No. 121, R. A.; Beliefontaine Chapter No. 25); member Knights and Ladies of Security. Clubs: Masonic, West St Louis Turn Verein. Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: 903-904 Times Bldg. Residence: 2725A Madison St.

FERGUSON, Forrest, president Ferguson-McKinney Dry Goods Co.; born Dyersburg, Tenn., Oct. 29, 1861; son of Dr. Floyd and Mary (Wynne) Ferguson; educated in public schools; married, Trenton, Tenn., May 15, 1890, Grace Elder. Came to St Louis in 1881 and entered service of Wear & Boogher Dry Goods Co. as traveling salesman, covering Tennessee and Kentucky, until 1891, when became general salesman with Ely-Walker Dry Goods Co., until 1899; organized, 1899, the Ferguson-McKinney Dry Goods Co., of which has since been president. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday. Office: Washington Ave. and 12th St. Residence: 4944 Lindell Ave.

FERGUSON, John David, lumberman; born Texarkana, Ark., Feb. 22, 1876; son of William T. and Eliza Ferguson; educated in public school, Texarkana, and the University of Arkansas, at Fayetteville, Ark.; married, St Louis, Dec. 10, 1907, Betty Donaldson; one daughter: Elizabeth Washington. Entire business career in the lumber business, at first in association with father (who, with headquarters at Texarkana, was one of the largest lumber manufacturers and dealers in Arkansas and the South), until came to St Louis, February, 1902, and joined in organizing the Fer-guson-McDaris Lumber Co.; was president until March, 1908, when he became vice president Sabine Lumber Co. of Missouri; also director Thompson Ford Lumber Co., Crayburg, Tex., and Louisiana Saw Mill Co.; stockholder Sabine Lumber Co., Zwolle, La., and director Zwolle & Eastern R. R. Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo. Recreations: golf and fishing. Residence: 6325 Washington Boul. Office: 1514 Wright Bldg.

FERGUSON, Joseph William, lumberman; born in Miller Co., Ark., Sept. 14, 1873; son of William Thomas and Eliza Jane (Ingram) Ferguson; married Belle Martin, of Siloam Springs, Ark., July 15, 1903; three children: William Thomas, Margaret, Joseph Clark. Began in lumber business with E. W. Frost & Co., Genoa, Ark., 1893; became connected with the W. T. Ferguson Lumber Co., of Texarkana, Ark., 1895; engaged in lumber business at Cleveland, O., under firm name of Ferguson & Collins, 1896; purchased interest in Kress City (Ark.) Lumber Co., 1897; sold out in 1900 and founded the Sabine Lumber Co., of Zwolle, La.; president Sabine Lumber Co. of Louisiana, Sabine Lumber Co. of Missouri, Fairview Lumber Co. (retail yards in Missouri and Oklahoma), Zwolle & Eastern Ry. Co.; director Big Pine Lumber Co., Thompson & Ford Lumber Co. Member Christian Church. Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo Country, St Louis Automobile. Recreation: golf. Office: 1514 Wright Bldg. Residence: 6232 McPherson Ave.

FERGUSON, William Thomas, yellow pine lumber; born in Bowie Co., Tex., May 13, 1847; son of Joseph and Margarette (Johnson) Ferguson; educated in common country school; married, Bowie Co., Tex., 1865, Eliza Ingram; children: Margaret I., Mary E. (Mrs. M. D. Tilson), Susan M. (Mrs. N. B. Sanderson), Joseph W. and John D.; married, 2d, Dec. 10, 1894, Elizabeth Bartlett. Served in Confederate Army eighteen months; farmer from 1866 to 1881; organized the Frost & Ferguson Lumber Co., 1882, the E. W. Frost Lumber Co., Genoa, Ark., 1885; incorporated, 1887, the Bodcaw Lumber Co., of Stamps, Ark., of which was vice president; organized, 1893, the Kress City Lumber Co. of Kress City, Ark., of which was president; organized, 1894, the Pine Woods Lumber Co., of Spring Hill, La., of which was vice president, and in 1897 the Louisiana & Arkansas R. R., of which was vice president; now member of firm of W. T. Ferguson Lumber Co., wholesale yellow pine lumber, established in 1893 at Texarkana, Tex.; president Livingston Lumber Co., of Buck, Tex. Mason. Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo Country, Maine Fishing and Hunting, Aero, Automobile. Recreation: golf. Office: 1710 Wright Bldg. Residence: 5203 Washington Ave.

FERNANDEZ, Gonzalo de A., Mexican consul; born Mexico City, Dec. 31, 1880; son of Jose and Guadalupe (Serrano) Fernandez; educated in Guanajuato State College, graduating, 1900; and Commercial College of Mexico City, 1901; married, Bilbao, Spain, June 22, 1907, Maria Diaz de Mendivil; one child: Humberto Horacio. In office of minister of foreign relations, Mexico City, chancellor of Consulate, Havre, France, 190104; consul of Mexico at Bilbao, Spain, 1904-11; since Jan. 26, 1911, consul at St Louis, jurisdiction including Missouri, Iowa and Arkansas. Office: 320-321 Chemical Bldg. Residence: 4187 Washington Boul.

FERRENBACH, Edward J., grocer; born St Louis, June 13, 1857; son of Thomas and Katherine (Klock) Ferrenbach; educated, St. Joseph (parochial) School; Christian Brothers College, two years; St Louis University, graduating from commercial course, 1875; maj-ried, St Louis, Apr. 26, 1881, Mary Osterholt; seven children: Edward A., Eugene C., Thomas R., Lee N., Isabel C., Marie, Florence. After leaving college visited Europe; remained nine months abroad and upon return became connected with father in grocery business, incorporated, 1895, as the Thomas Ferrenbach Grocery Co., of which is president. Catholic. Member Catholic Knights. Office: 1800 Franklin Ave. Residence: 5441 Bartmer Ave.

office: President board of education, Moberly, 1896-1902; president Missouri State School Board Association, 1897-98; member Moberly Public Library Board, 1901-04. Republican; delegate Republican National Convention, 1904; member Republican State Committee, 1906-08. Member St Louis Bar Association, State Historical Society of Missouri, National Geographic Society, Modern Woodmen of America, Independent Order of Foresters. Recreation: baseball. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg.
memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","State Historical Society of Missouri","National Geographic Society","Modern Woodmen of America","Independent Order of Foresters"]
fullentry: FERRIS, Forrest G., assistant circuit attorney; born Hillsdale Co., Mich., July 31, 1860; son of Augustus H. and Sylvia (Beed) Ferris; educated, Chillicothe (Mo.) High School; LIi.B., University of Missouri, 1882; married, Moberly, Mo., Aug. 14, 1884, Bessie, daughter of Hon. G. F. Rothwell; five children: Elizabeth, Franklin Rothwell (deceased), Ruth, Forrest G., Frances. Teacher in Moberly (Mo.) public schools, 1883-85; admitted to Missouri bar, 1882, and practiced at Moberly until 1907; assistant attorney general of Missouri, 1907-08, and was actively identified with prosecution of cases instituted by Attorney General Hadley, known as the insurance trust, the lumber trust and the harvester trust cases; assistant circuit attorney for City of St Louis since Jan. 1, 1909, as such having charge of the civil business of the circuit attorney's office. President board of education, Moberly, 1896-1902; president Missouri State School Board Association, 1897-98; member Moberly Public Library Board, 1901-04. Republican; delegate Republican National Convention, 1904; member Republican State Committee, 1906-08. Member St Louis Bar Association, State Historical Society of Missouri, National Geographic Society, Modern Woodmen of America, Independent Order of Foresters. Recreation: baseball. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg. Residence: 4965 Lotus Ave.

FERRIS, Wheaton Cravens, real estate; born Clarksville, Ark., May 15, 1878; son of Joseph Wheaton and Susie (Reid) Ferris; educated public schools, Conway, Ark.; Hendrix College, Conway, two years; married, Little Rock, Ark., Oct. 17, 1900, Ruby Bernice Hoshall. Reporter Daily Light, Tahlequah, I. T., 1897; treasurer Sandefer Julian Co., Little Rock, 1899; president Ferris & White Co., Plumerville, Ark., 1901, Arkansas Investment Co., Little Rock, 1906; came to St Louis November, 1906; president Olive Street Terrace Realty Co., St Louis, since 1907; also president Kinloch Land Co. Democrat. Member Business Men's League. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Algonquin Golf. Recreations: tennis and books. Office: 216 Merchants-Laclede Bldg. Residence: 10 N. King's Highway.

memberships: ["of Citv Council","1893-97; elected circuit judge","Eighth Judicial Circuit","Missouri","1898","resigned","1903","to accept appointment as general counsel Louisiana Purchase Exposition Co"]
fullentry: FERRISS, Franklin, judge; born Peru, N. Y., Sept. 22, 1849; son of Charles and Mercy (Macomber) Ferriss; educated Cornell University, B.S., 1873, St Louis Law School, 1875; married, St Louis, Feb. 10, 1880, Elizabeth Simon; children: Henry T., Margery (wife of N. M. Semple, M.D.), Hugh. Began practice of law in St Louis, 1875; was member firm of Rowell & Ferriss. Member of Citv Council, 1893-97; elected circuit judge, Eighth Judicial Circuit, Missouri, 1898, resigned, 1903, to accept appointment as general counsel Louisiana Purchase Exposition Co.; also director of same company. In 1907 appointed by H. S. Government special examiner in case of United States vs. Standard Oil Co.; appointed, December, 1910, by Governor Hadley judge of the Supreme Court of Missouri to fill vacancy caused by death of Judge Burgess; term expires June 1, 1913. Member Business Men's League. Republican. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Normandie Park, King's Lake Hunting and Fishing. Recreations: music, golf and fishing. Office: 820 Rialto Bldg. Residence: 5828 Cabanne Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations","Civic League"]
fullentry: FERRISS, Henry T., lawyer; boru, St Louis, Feb. 25, 1882; son of Franklin and Elizabeth H. (Simon) Ferris; graduated Central High School, 1898; A.B., Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y., 1902; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1905; married, Lake Forest, Ill., Nov. 14, 1908, Edith G. Platt; children: Anne Chittenden and Franklin Ferriss, II. Admitted to Missouri bar, June, 1905; assistant circuit attorney, St Louis, 1905-07; since in general practice; member of Ferriss & Ferriss, 1907 and 1908, since of Ferriss, Zumbalen & Ferriss. Republican. Member St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations, Civic League. Clubs: City, Public Question; Recreations: tennis, golf, literature. Office: 820 Rialto Bldg. Residence: 5943 Cates Ave.

clubs: ["Missouri Athletic","Liederkranz","Western Rowing","Cedar Crest","Sunset Hill","Aero","many smaller organizations"]
memberships: ["St Louis Manufacturers' and Exporters' Association","Concordia Turn Verein"]
fullentry: FEUERBACHER, Frank W., maltster; born St Louis, July 30, 1850; son of Max J. and Catherine (Sedler) Feuerbacher; educated Christian Brothers College, St Louis, and Rollers' Commercial College; married, St Louis, Feb. 19, 1884, Carrie Krauss; twelve children, eight of whom are now living: Marie, Elizabeth, Oliver, Fredrick, Edward, Veronica, Caroline and Bonifacius. Served apprenticeship as brewer and maltster at Cincinnati, Milwaukee and several other cities; returned to St Louis, 1880, and started a malt house, 1880; has ever since been closely identified with the business, which is conducted under title of Frank W. Feuerbacher & Co., of which he is proprietor; founded the Carondelet Ice Mfg. and Fuel Co., 1903, and has since served as president; also president Southern Commercial and Savings Bank, Carondelet Milling Co., Western Foundry and Sash Weight Co., Krauss Improvement and Investment Co., Syndicate Construction Co., and Oriental Hotel Co., of Dallas, Tex.; vice president St Louis Catering Co., and director in about ten other corporations. Republican. Member St Louis Manufacturers' and Exporters' Association, Concordia Turn Verein. Member Masonic Order. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Liederkranz, Western Rowing (for forty-two years), Cedar Crest, Sunset Hill Country, Aero, and many smaller organizations. Office: 2705 S. Broadway. Residence: 3635 Flora Boul.

company: Jesse French Piano and Organ Co.
fullentry: FIELD, Oscar Addison, president Jesse French Piano and Organ Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 13, 1887; son of Oscar Addison and Maria (Lumsden) Field; educated in public and high schools, St Louis; married, Grace, Miss., Nov. 11, 1908, Emma Atkinson Dulaney; one child: Lorraine Dulaney, born Mar. 12, 1910. Began active career, Feb. 4, 1904, in piano business with which his father was also identiffed for many years; was elected secretary of the Jesse French Piano and Organ Co., January, 1908, and has served as president of the company since October, 1910. Republican. Presbyterian. Now first vice president National Association of Piano Merchants of America; member board of directors Associated Retailers of St Louis. Recreation: fishing. Office: 1114 Olive St. Residence: 5629 Cabanne Ave.

FIGUEIREDO, Alfonso de, railway official; born. Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, .Tune 8, 1851; son of Joachim Procopio and Maria Thereza do Fiqueiredo; early education by tutors at home, in private school and in Imperial College of Dom Pedro II, in Brazil, then at Beaumont Lodge, Windsor, England, and Tooting Collegiate School, Tooting. Surrey, England; married, St Louis Co., Mo., May 16, 1888, Charlotte Dunlap Clarkson. Came to St Louis in 1871, in the employ of East St Louis Transfer Co., four years; with the Hibernia Bank two years; returned to East St Louis Transfer Co. as chief clerk; 1882, became secretary Madison County Ferrv Co., and freight agent Illinois & St Louis R. R.; in 1885 with St Louis Transfer Railway Co. and Wiggins Ferry Co.; in 1887 became vice president and manager of St Louis Cable & Western Ry.; receiver of same, 1889-90; organized, in 1891, the St Louis & Suburban R. R.; in 1892 returned to St Louis Transfer Co. as general freight agent, and since April, 1899, assistant manager, auditor and director same. Catholic. Vice consul of Brazil since 1879. Member Knights of Honor, Legion of Honor, Royal Arcanum. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: literature. Office: 400 S. Broadway. Residence: 4118 McPherson Ave.

FILLEY, Chauncey Ives; born Lansing-burg, N. Y., Oct. 17, 1829; son of Augustus and Amelia (Filley) Filley; academic education in State of New York and two years in law school in Saratoga Co., N. Y.; came to St Louis, Sept. 16, 1850; married, Lansingburg, N. Y., June 28, 1855, to Miss Anna E. Adams. Began business career. 1850, as clerk for E. A. and S. R. Filley, china and glassware, and from 1855 to 1858 was partner in same firm; engaged in earthenware business in St Louis, 1858-73. Cast first vote for Whig candidate for mayor of St Louis; during Civil War was ardent Unionist, and in 1863 was nominated for mayor by Republican Emancipation Convention; was elected and served until 1864; became one of the leaders of the Republican party in Missouri; delegate-at-large, 1864, to the convention that renominated Lincoln for president; elector on Grant presidential ticket, 1868, and thereafter delegate to every National Republican Convention up to and including 1896; member Missouri State Central Republican Committee, and its chairman in 1876, and again in 1880-98; chief reorganizer of the Republican party in Missouri, 1872; representative of Missouri in National Republican Committee, 1876-92; postmaster of St Louis, 1873-78. Office and Residence: 4100 Westminster PI.

company: Mound City Oil and Supply Co.
fullentry: FILLEY, Frank Blair, president Mound City Oil and Supply Co.; born St Louis, July 31, 1848; son of Giles F. and Maria (Farrington) Filley; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Sept. 14, 1870, Martha Georgine Frederick (died Mar. 17, 1910); children: Giles Robert (deceased), Frank Herbert. Began business career with the Excelsior Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of stoves, and worked in foundries and shops of the company, 1867-96; was superintendent stove works when company retired from the business; in 1896 joined in organizing and has since been president of the Mound City Oil and Supply Co. Republican. Protestant. Member Royal Arcanum. Office: 204 N. Commercial St. Residence: Buckingham Annex.

FILLEY, John Dwight, banker; born St Louis, Feb. 21, 1853; son of Oliver Dwight and Chloe V. (Brown) Filley; educated in public schools and Washington University; married, St Louis, Feb. 16, 1881, Fannie L. Douglass; children: May (Mrs. Ralph Simpkins), Ellen D. (Mrs. James H. Wear), Frances, John D., Jr. Engaged in the bagging business, 1881, in the Standard Mills Bagging Co.; vice president, 1891-1908, and since 1908 vice chairman board of directors, St Louis Union Trust Co. Republican. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis Country, Bankers', Noonday, St Louis, Racquet, Bellerive Country. Recreation: golf. Office: corner 4th and Locust Sts. Residence: 40 Westmoreland PI.

FTLMER, Walter Lockett, manager Dodge & Olcott Co., essential oils, etc.; born Brooklyn, N. Y., Feb. 15, 1868; son of John and Sarah Alice (Lockett) Filmer; educated in public schools of Brooklyn, N. Y.; married, Madisonville, Ky., April, 1898, Elsie M. Hopewell; children: Walter L., Jr., James C. Began business career July 6, 1885, in New York, as office boy for the firm of Dodge & Olcott, dealers in essential oils, vanilla beans, etc.; came to St Louis for same firm as salesman in 1895, and in October, 1897, was made manager of the St Louis branch, in which position continues for the Dodge & Olcott Co., successors of the original firm. Democrat. Club: Missouri Athletic. Office: 19 S. 3d St. Residence: Webster Groves, Mo.

FILSINGER, Henry Joseph, monument dealer; born St Louis, Dec. 8, 1848; son of Balthasar and Henrietta (Gralin) Filsinger; educated in public and private schools of Belleville, Ill.; married, Belleville, Mar. 3, 1874, Kate Ernst; children: Wanda, Ernst B., Adolph F., Harry J., Irma. Apprenticed to monument trade, Oct. 3, 1863, and continued as employe until Sept. 1, 1872, when with Andrew Fruth established in business under firm name of Filsinger & Fruth, retail dealers in monuments; now Filsinger & Fruth Monument Co., of which is president. Democrat. Member Ethical Society. Mason since 1870; was Master Itasca Lodge No. 420, in 1883-84. Recreation: reading. Office: 1617 Washington Ave. Residence: 3134 Lafayette Ave.

FINIGAN, Harry P., wholesale binder twine, etc.; born in Will Co., Ill., Jan. 31, 1857; son of Harry P. and Margaret (Fennelly) Finigan; educated in public schools of Illinois; married, Denver, Colo., Mar. 27, 1881, Lida H. Brooke; children: William H., Margery E. Began business career as clerk in wholesale store of J. & G. Herget, Pekin, Ill., 1871-73; bookkeeper for T. W. Lowry, flour mill, Lincoln, Neb., 1873-78; studied law in office of Connor & Maule, Fairmont, Neb., and was admitted to bar, 1880, engaged in practice for about a year; traveling salesman for Marsh Harvester Co., 1881-82; local dealer in farming implements, Brookings, S. D., 1883-85; assistant sales manager Northwestern Car Co., 1885-88; traveling auditor Walter A. Wood Mowing and Reaping Machine Co., 1888-93; assistant treasurer Walter A. Wood Harvester Co. at St. Paul, Minn., 1893-97; since 1897 of Mac-gowan & Finigan, wholesale binder twine, rope and cordage, St Louis; also treasurer Macgowan & Finigan Foundry and Machine Co., manufacturers of Newton Pulverizer and Roller Harrows. Club: St Louis Power Boat. Office: 42 Gay Bldg. Residence: 17 X. Taylor Street.

FINK, Frederick Bay, president F. B. Fink Instrument Co.; born Bellaire, O., July 15, 1876; son of John and Elizabeth (Scott) Fink; educated in private schools in Ohio and Chicago, Ill.; married, Marshalltown, Ia., June 5, 1902, Bessie W. Cliver; one daughter: Virginia. Began business career with the Keuffel & Esser Co., Chicago, 1893-1901, then with same firm in Xew York City, 1901-03, and in St Louis, 1903-05; on Apr. 1, 1905, organized the F. B. Fink Instrument Co., dealers in mathematical and surveying instruments, of which is president and treasurer. Republican. Presbyterian. Member A. F. & A. M. Office: 105 N. 8th St. Residence: 5216 Morgan St.

FINLAY, Andrew Mitchell, vice president Waters-Pierce Oil Co.; born Glasgow, Scotland, June 29, 1857; son of John Robert and Elizabeth (Mitchell) Finlay; educated in Washington University; married, Springfield, Mass., May 18, 1883, Stella Norton; children: Andrew Lugar, Belle. Has been actively identified with the Waters-Pierce Oil Co. since June, 1878, first as manager at Marshall, Tex., and in 1881 went for the company to the City of Mexico, returning later in same year to Galveston, Tex., as manager for Southern Texas; transferred to St Louis, 1888, and in 1891 came to St Louis as division superintendent, later becoming vice president and general manager and now vice president of the Waters-Pierce Oil Co. (originally J. R. Finlay & Co., 1858, then merged into W. H. Cobb & Co., then into H. C. Pierce & Co., and finally into Waters-Pierce Oil Co., the present corporation). Member Royal Arcanum. Elder First Presbyterian Church. Clubs: Noonday, St Louis, Normandie Golf (director). Favorite recreations: golf, bowling. Office: National Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 4938 Berlin Ave.

FIORITA, Anthony Rocco, commission merchant; born Indianapolis, Ind., Aug. 22, 1879; son of Sylvester R. and Mary (Loos) Fiorita; educated in public schools of St Louis, St. Mary's College, Kansas, and St Louis University; married, June 8, 1901, Annie De Donato; children: Santo O., Sylvester R., II. After leaving school went to work for V. Scalzo Fruit Co. as clerk; became bookkeeper for four years, the city buyer for the F. H. Krenning & Sons, grocers, etc., for four years; then with Milligan, Fiorita Fruit Co. as secretary and treasurer for nine months; joined his father and brother, 1901, becoming treasurer of S. R. Fiorita & Sons Fruit Co., so remaining until October, 1907, when the company consolidated with Scalzo Fruit Co., of which was treasurer; on death of father, January, 1912, was elected president and treasurer of the Scalzo-Fiorita Fruit Co., large dealers in foreign and tropical fruits. Vice president St Louis Fruit Buyers' Exchange; member 8t. Louis Produce Exchange, Western Fruit Jobbers' Association of America. Member of order of Elks. Recreations: home diversions and motoring. Office: 414-416 Wash St. Residence: 4349 Olive St.

FIORITA, Vincent Rocco, commission merchant; born St Louis, June 29, 1881; son of Sylvester R. and Mary (Loos) Fiorita; educated in public schools of St Louis, St. Vincent and St. Mary's Schools, Kansas, and St Louis University; married, St Louis, April, 1904, Mamie De Donato. After leaving school became connected with wholesale fruit business as shipping clerk for five or six years with the Scalzo Fruit Co., and in 1900 joined his father and brother in organizing the S. R. Fiorita & Sons Fruit Co., wholesale fruits, of which was secretary; in October, 1907, firm consolidated with Scalzo Fruit Co., of which was secretary until May, 1910, when was elected vice president; after death of father, January, 1912, was elected to present position as vice president and general manager of the Scalzo-Fiorita Fruit Co. Member Western Fruit Jobbers' Association (publicity committee). Office: 414-416 Wash St. Residence: 5100 Delmar Boul.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","American Medical Association","American Microscopical Society","American Association for the Advancement of Science","Biological Society of St Louis","American Anthropological Society"]
fullentry: FISCH, Carl, physician; born Rostock, Germany, Aug. 17, 1859; son of Wilhelm and Marie Fisch; educated in gymnasium in Mecklenburg, Germany, universities of Rostock, Wuerzburg and Strassburg (Ph.D.), and at Missouri Medical College, St Louis, M.D., 1895; married, 1896, Sophie Hottenrott; one daughter: Marguerite. Engaged in practice of medicine in St Louis since 1895; specialist in pathology and bacteriology; head of the St Louis Pasteur Institute. Member St Louis Medical Society, American Medical Association, American Microscopical Society, American Association for the Advancement of Science, Biological Society of St Louis, American Anthropological Society. Recreations: botany and natural sciences. Office and Residence: 3863 W. Pine Boul.

clubs: ["St Louis","University","Country","Round Table","Town and Gown","Faculty Club of Washington University"]
memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association","American Medical Association","Verein Deutscher Aerzte","Association of American Physicians","St Louis Academy of Science"]
fullentry: FISCHEL, Washington Emil, physician; born St Louis, May 29, 1850; son of Ephraim and Babette (Taussig) Fischel; educated in St Louis High School, St Louis Medical College, M.D., 1871, universities of Prague, Vienna and Berlin, 1872-74; married, St Louis, 1876, Miss Martha Ellis; children: Edna Fischel Gellhorn, Walter, Ellis, Leopold. Engaged in general practice of medicine in St Louis from 1874. Clinical professor medicine in Washington University Medical College. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association, Verein Deutscher Aerzte, Association of American Physicians, St Louis Academy of Science. Member of the Ethical Society. Clubs: St Louis, University, St Louis Country, Round Table, Town and Gown, Faculty Club of Washington University. Office: 401 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 5284 Westminster PI.

FISCHER, Alexander August, real estate and building; born Washington, Mo., May 14, 1866; son of August and Maria (Heining) Fischer; educated in St Louis public schools; married, Washington, Mo., Feb. 20, 1889, Frances Peterson; one son: Roland C. From age of twelve years to age of twenty-three lived on father's farm in Franklin Co., Ark.; came to St Louis, 1889, and took position with the Tower Grove and Southwestern Building and Loan Association as bookkeeper, continuing for eighteen months; in real estate business in partnership with H. W. Mephan for five years; then dissolved and embarked in real estate and speculative building on own account, from which evolved the A. A. Fischer Architectural and Building Co., incorporated, 1899, of which is president; also president A. A. Fischer Realty Co., Builders' Manufacturing and Supply Co. Republican. Recreations: hunting, fishing, literature, music and travel. Office: 728 Chestnut St. Residence: 5256 Vernon Ave.

FISCHER, Andrew Peter, hardware merchant; born St Louis, Sept. 1, 1859; son of John Jacob and Crecentia (Yost) Fischer; educated in St. Peter and St. Paul schools, to twelve; attended night school three years and also studied mechanical drawing and steam engineering; married, St Louis, Apr. 26, 1883, Lena Dressier; children: Louisa (Mrs. Louis Muschany), John, Carrie, Frederick, Michael. Began active career as apprentice in machine shop; received license as steam engineer at twenty-one and became chief engineer Helmbacher Forge and Rolling Mills, continuing in employ of the company over twenty-four years; was with Green Tree Brewery six months and then with Collier White Lead Co.; secretary Albert & Fischer Hardware and Sheet Metal Co. since 1903. Republican. Catholic. Club: South Side Fishing. Recreation: fishing. Office: 2533 S. Broadway. Residence: 1109 Sidney St.

FISCHER, Casper H., banking; born St. Charles, Mo., July 23, 1847; son of Philip and Maria (Gricbel) Fischer; educated in public schools to fourteen; married at St Louis, 1873, Elizabeth Mayer. Visited Germany for two years attending school there; upon returning to St Louis, 1863, secured position as salesman with William Kayser, dry goods merchant, later serving as bookkeeper for George Simpkins; entered employ of the German Savings Institution, 1867, with which has ever since been identified and now filling offices of teller and assistant cashier; president F. J. Schencher Paper Box Co. Member Bank Clerks' Association. Republican. Lutheran. Member Legion of Honor. Club: Liederkranz. Recreations: traveling, atheltics. Office: 4th and Pine Sts. Residence: 3852 Flora Boulevard.

FISCHER, Frank, treasurer Western Furniture Co.; born, Glane, Osnabruck, Germany, Mar. 14, 1850; son of Frank and Elizabeth (Grave) Fischer; educated in private schools in Germany; married, St Louis, November, 1875, Josephine Steudermann; children: Mary (Mrs. Al. Macklin), Frank, Alvina (Mrs. A. Woerking), Joseph, Edward, Eda (Mrs. Charles Oechsner), Henry (deceased), Agnes, George (deceased), Clara. Learned cabinet-making trade and worked at bench in Germany until eighteen years of age, when came direct to St Louis and worked eleven years for Aude Furniture Co.; in 1883 began business on own account, and assisted in organizing the Western Furniture Co., of which is now treasurer and manager. Member Furniture Board of Trade. Roman Catholic. Recreation: fishing. Office: Blair Ave. and Palm St. Residence: 9049 Alice Ave.

FISCHER, John Caster, president Fischer Flour Co.; born, Highland, Madison Co., Ill., June 17, 1850; son of Anton and Elizabeth (Toggenburger) Fischer; educated in public school and Rohers' College; married, St Louis, Sophie N. Kern; children: Oliver C., Edward Allen, Charles Grover, Mary Annie. Began business career in employ of Meyer & Guye, millers and ffour dealers, as shipping clerk and salesman, continuing for twelve years; vice president of Mauntel, Borgess & Co., 1880-90; in 1890 joined in organization of the Fischer Flour Co., millers and flour merchants, of which has since been president. Democrat. Member Tower Grove Turner 8ociety. Recreations: bowling, fishing and all athletics. Office: 111 Market St. Residence: 3821 Hartford Street.

FISCHER, Oscar Hermann, physician; born St Louis, Sept. 10, 1876; son of Herman and Marie (Arcularius) Fischer; graduated from public school, Elleardville, 1891; graduated Manual Training School, St Louis, 1894; Ph.G., St Louis College of Pharmacy, 1896; M.D., Medical Department of Washington University, 1899; unmarried. Was clerk in drug store, 1894-96; interne City Hospital, 1899-1900; resident physician of O 'Fallon Dispensary of Washington University, 1899-1901; in general practice since 1901. Also clinician in Medical Department Washington University. Member City Hospital Alumni Association. Episcopalian. Club: Normandie Golf. Recreation: golf. Office: 700 Carleton Bldg. Residence: 4562 Cook Ave.

company: Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Milwaukee
office: eighth floor National Bank of Commerce Bldg.
fullentry: FISCHER, William J., general agent Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Milwaukee, Wis.; born Alton, Ill., Oct. 24, 1863; son of Frederick and Amelia (Gottlieb) Fischer; educated in public schools of Alton, Ill.; married, Alton, Ill., Aug. 27, 1889, Mary Elizabeth Reiser; children: Ira W., Ralph W. Began business career, 1885, in general fire and life insurance business at Galesburg, Ill., continuing, 1885-88; general agent New England Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Boston, at Omaha, Neb., 1888-99; from 1899 to May 1, 1905, general agent at Detroit, Mich., and since May 1, 1905, general agent at St Louis for the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Milwaukee. Republican. Baptist. Clubs: Mercantile, City, Normandie Golf. Office: eighth floor National Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 4944 Forest Park Boul.

FISH, Edwin Silas, real estate; born St Louis, Nov. 11, 1857; son of Orlando and Martha J. (Goodrich) Fish; educated St Louis public and high schools; married, St Louis, Jan., 1884, Mamie Kinsella (died February, 1904). Began active career as salesman for St Louis Book and News Co.; subsequently acted as salesman for Pulaski Langalier, real estate agent; now member real estate firm of Woolley & Fish; also treasurer Enid Real Estate Co. Member Real Estate Exchange. Independent Republican. Member Ethical Society, Legion of Honor, Royal League. Recreation: literature. Office: 819 Chestnut St. Residence: 953 Hamilton Ave.

FISHELL, Dan S., theatrical manager; born Louisiana, Mo., June 5, 1876; son of Ferdinand and Elizabeth (Sicher) Fishell; educated in public and high schools of St Louis; unmarried. Was associated with the Bostock Ferari Carnival Co. when that organization was in its prime; was manager of the Ellery Creatore Band, press representative of Barnum & Bailey Shows, and was connected in business with the 8hubert8 for five years; promoter and lessee Princess Theatre since 1905; president Fishell Bros. Amusement Co. Democrat. Jewish religion. Mason; member Royal Arcanum, Woodmen. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, St Louis Advertising Men's League. Recreations: baseball and athletics. Office: Princess Theatre. Residence: 4357A Maryland Ave.

FISHER, Charles Brandon, manufacturer of machinery; born St Louis, Aug. 16, 1855; son of George W. and Edith S. (Wood) Fisher; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, May 14, 1884, Helen G. Bernays; children: George B. and Alice. Began as boy with the Fulton Iron Works, learned the machinist's trade and later was employed in the offices of the same company; in 1885 established in business for self and in 1888 entered into partnership with Thomas D. Davis, forming present firm of Fisher & Davis, manufacturers of machinery. Office: 934-940 N. Main St. Residence: 5559 Bartmer Ave.

memberships: ["American Bar Association","Missouri State and St Louis Bar associations","St Louis School of Fine Arts","Congregational Club","Provident Association","Hospital Association","Ancient Order of United Workmen","Legion of Honor"]
fullentry: FISHER, Daniel Dwlggins, judge; born Mt. Etna, Huntington Co., Ind., Dec. 16, 1836; son of Thomas and Elizabeth (Dwiggins) Fisher; educated in private and local public schools of Huntington Co.; A.B., Wheaton College, Wheaton, Ill., 1863, A.M., 1880; honorary degree of LL.D. from same college, 1885; married, Aurora, Ill., July 3, 1863, Carrie A. McKee; two children: Katherine F. (Mrs. George M. Brown) and Jennie G. (now deceased). Admitted to bar by Supreme Court of Illinois February, 1866; began practice at St. Lonis, Apr. 1, 1866, as member of firm of Fisher & Rowell and so continued for twenty-three years; elected judge Eighth Judicial Circuit of Missouri, and served since January, 1889, with exception of two years, 1896 and 1897. Republican. Congregationalism Member American Bar Association, Missouri State and St Louis Bar associations, St Louis School of Fine Arts, Congregational Club, Provident Association, Hospital Association, Ancient Order of United Workmen, Legion of Honor. Clubs: Mercantile, Amateur Athletic. Chambers; Court House. Residence: 3668 W. Pine Boulevard.

FISHER, George Dunbar, wholesale manufacturing optician; born London, Ontario, Can., Nov. 29, 1870; son of Squire James and Elizabeth (Thorburn) Fisher; educated at University of Hyde Park, Can.; married Jan. 16, 1906, Viola Marie, eldest daughter of Eugene Benoist. After leaving college learned optical trade, and in 1891 came to St Louis and worked at the business until 1895, when joined Ernst Eggert in forming firm of Eggert & Fisher, opticians, manufacturing, wholesale and retail; head of George D. Fisher & Co. since Feb. 1, 1911. Presbyterian. Clubs: Mercantile, Normandie Golf, Bellerive Country. Recreations: hunting and golfing. Offices: 405 N. 8th 8t. and 510 N. Grand Ave. Residence: 377 N. Taylor Ave.

memberships: ["American Society of Civil Engineers","Engineers' Club of St"]
fullentry: FISHER, Samuel Brownlee, chief engineer Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry.; son of Rev. Jacob P. and Jane Thompson (Brownlee) Fisher; educated in common school, Washington Co., Pa., Washington and Jefferson College, Pennsylvania, B.8., 1868, M.S., 1871; married, Pittsburg, Pa., Feb. 8, 1882, Agnes Crooks; children: Brownlee, Anna Palmer. With Rogers Locomotive Works, Paterson, N. J., 1869-72; in service of the engineering department of the Pennsylvania Lines, Northwest System, between Pittsburg, Chicago and the lakes in all grades of service from chain-man to assistant engineer, 1873-85; chief engineer Milwaukee & Northern R. R., 1885-90, Minneapolis, St. Paul & Sault Ste. Marie Ry., 1890-92, Everett & Monte Cristo Ry., Everett, Wash., 1892-94; since 1895, chief engineer Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry. Also consulting engineer Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry. of Texas. Member American Society of Civil Engineers, Engineers' Club of St. Loius. Republican. Presbyterian. Club: St Louis Railway. Recreation: cycling. Office: 407 Wain-wright Bldg. Residence: 4606 Maryland Ave.

company: C. F. Blanke Tea and Coffee Co.
fullentry: FISHER, William, first vice president C. F. Blanke Tea and Coffee Co.; born St Louis, May 17, 1865; son of John H. and Fannie (Nicolet) Fisher; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, Sept. 5, 1888, Mattie E. Brunner; one daughter: Aurelia Mattie. Began business career as messenger boy for the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad, then was office boy for Krafft-Holmes Grocery Co., advanced to street salesman and then entered brokerage business with D.#F. Leavitt & Co., became a partner two years later and so remained until Jan. 1, 1895, when was employed by C. F. Blanke Tea and Coffee Co.; two years later made buyer of coffee department; later was placed in charge of tea department and still has charge of the two departments, in connection with the office of first vice president. Republican. Episcopalian. Clubs: Union, Million Population, The Traffic of St Louis. Recreation: outdoor sports. Office: 7th St. and Clark Ave. Residence: 1355A Clara Ave.

FITZGERALD, John, superintendent of terminals, Louisville & Nashville R. R.; born Memphis, Tenn., Sept. 26, 1867; son of Michael and Mary (Egan) Fitzgerald; educated in schools of Memphis, Tenn.; unmarried. Began railway service, 1882, becoming, for eighteen months, messenger in superintendent's office of the Louisville & Nashville R. R. at Mem- Shis, Tenn.; then in local freight office at lemphis and chief clerk division freight office at Memphis until 1887; traveling freight agent, with headquarters at Memphis, Tenn., until February, 1892; gegeral agent at Chicago, Ill., until Oct. 10, 1898; division freight agent at Memphis until May, 1900; superintendent at terminals, since 1900, in charge of traffic and transportation at St Louis, entire service having been with the Louisville & Nashville R. R. Clubs: Mercantile, Noonday, Glen Echo, Missouri Athletic, The Traffic of St Louis and St Louis Railway Club. Recreation: baseball. Office: 312 N. 8th St. Residence: 4108 Westminster PI.

memberships: ["American Society of Civil Engineers","American Society of Mechanical Engineers","Engineers' Club of St Louis","Loyal Legion"]
fullentry: FLAD, Edward, civil engineer; born Arcadia, Mo., Nov. 23, 1860; son Henry and Caroline (Reichard) Flad; educated at public and high schools, St Louis, and Washington University, graduating C.Ek. 1881; married, 8t. Louis, February, 1890, Emilie E. Speck; one daughter: Virginia Speck Flad.
