After graduation in 1881 held various positions, including that of assayer for the Mary Murphy Mining Co., Colorado; draughtsman for the Mississippi River Commission at St Louis, and experiments on preservation of gum timber; draughtsman and mechanical engineer for St Louis Water Works, 1883-88; designed, 1888, temporary pumping plant of 20,000,000 gallons capacity for St Louis, of original design, the pumps being placed on cradles (design later copied by several other cities); made experiments on settling and filtration of Ohio River water at Cincinnati; in partnership with Prof. .T. B. Johnson under firm name of Johnson & Flad, consulting engineers, 1889-92, designed water works and sewerage systems for several smaller cities; in general practice as consulting engineer, 1892-99; water commissioner for city of 8t. Louis, 1899-1903; designed and built first floating dredge for cleaning settling basins; made plans for complete filter plant for city of St Louis; since 1903 in general practice as consulting engineer. Republican. Member American Society of Civil Engineers, American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Engineers' Club of St Louis, Loyal Legion. Clubs: Bellerive Country, Noonday. Recreations: reading and golf. Office: 1200-1204 Fullerton Bldg. Residence: 5575 Waterman Ave.

FLAMMGER, Frederick, president of the Flammger & Grahl Blank Book Co.; born in northern part of Germany, Aug. 1, 1843; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, November, 1868, Mary A. Pariso; children: Arthur B., Fred W., Laura J., Ella A. Came to St Louis from Germany in 1855; learned bookbinding trade in St Louis houses; served in Civil War in First Missouri Regiment under Col. (afterwards Gen.) Frank P. Blair, in Missouri, and later in the Army of the Cumberland, for three years and four months. After the war worked at his trade for seventeen years; then was with Frey & Flammger, 1882-85. In 1885 engaged in business for self, and in 1890 the business was incorporated as Flammger & Grahl Blank Book Co., of which is president. Ex-Senior ViceCommander Blair Post No. 1, G. A. R., Dept, of Missouri. Office: 316-318 N. 3d St. Residence: 3511 Sidney St.

company: Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co.
fullentry: FLEBBE, Herman, president Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co.; born Larstedt, Germany, Apr. 7, 1850; son of Frederick and Wil-helmina (Hartman) Flebbe; educated in public schools in Germany; married, St Louis, 1880, Miss A. Celler; five sons: William, Albert, Hugo, Otto, Hermann. Came to St Louis from Germany in 1871; began active career as clerk for hardware house, 1871-1876; worked for flour merchant, 1876-79; started business, 1879, as Flebbe & Co., jobbers in flour, sugar, etc., and incorporated the business, 1884, as the Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co., of which has since been president. Member Merchants' Exchange. Recreation: travel. Office: 109-113 S. 11th St. Residence: 1916 Lami St.

FLEISHEL, J. Travis, lumber; born Tyler, Tex., Nov. 30, 1884; son of Marc L. and Florence (Smith) Fleishel; educated in Tyler public schools, graduating from high school, 1902; unmarried. Began lumber career with Colonial Lumber & Timber Co., engaged at mills, Shamrock, La., until 1906; then to general offices, St Louis; secretary and treasurer of the company since 1909. Democrat. Baptist. Recreation: tennis. Office: 619 Third National Bank Building. Residence: 8 Beverly PI.

residence: 44Lancashire Garden," Kent Rd., St Louis County.
fullentry: FLESH, Edward Matthew, president of C. H. Albers Commission Co.; born St Louis, Aug. 15, 1869; son of Matthew M. and Susan Elizabeth (Carter) Flesh; educated in public schools and Smith Academy, St Louis; married, 8t. Louis, Oct. 1, 1890, Hetta May Albers. Began business career as a painter with Flesh & Mook Painting Co- 1883-85; entered employ Collier White Lead Co., 1885; manager Collier 8hot Tower Co., 1886-95; moved to Chicago as manager linseed oil department National Linseed Oil Co., November, 1895; moved back to St Louis, Dec., 1898; Jan., 1899, became vice president C. H. Albers Commission Co., pres. 1912; vice president Advance and Venice Elevator and Warehouse Co., Belt Elevator, Terminal Elevator, of East St Louis. Member Merchants9 Exchange. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, Missouri Athletic, Mercantile, Noonday, Automobile (secretary and treasurer), Aero. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: Fierce Bldg. Residence: 44Lancashire Garden," Kent Rd., St Louis County.

memberships: ["St Louis Dental Society","St Louis Society of Dental Science (president","1905-06)","Washington University Association; secretary Odontological Dental Society","1865-72"]
fullentry: FLICKINGER, Adam, dentist; born St Louis, May 10, 1847; son of Jacques Balthazar and Katherine (Furman) Flickinger; educated at Old Madison (public) School; Central High School, 1861; Rohrer's Commercial College, 1864-65; Homoeopathic College of Missouri, 1867; M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1869; D. D.S., St Louis Dental College, 1869; D.D.S., Pennsylvania College of Dental Surgery, 1873; post-graduate course, Heidelberg, Germany, 1873; married, St Louis, Sept. 8, 1881, Ida Grace Helier; one daughter, Alice, who graduated at Mary Institute, St Louis, and Bryn Mawr College, Pennsylvania, degrees of A.B. and A.M. Assistant to Dr. Alexander Dienst, St Louis, 1863-73, and in partnership with him, 1873-77; since practiced alone. Visiting dentist, City Hospital, 1874; professor mechanical dentistry, St Louis Dental College, 187375; member clinical staff, Dental Department, Washington University, since 1904. Republican; judge of elections, 1875. Presbyterian. Member St Louis Dental Society, St Louis Society of Dental Science (president, 1905-06), Washington University Association; secretary Odontological Dental Society, 1865-72. Member Business Men's League of Webster Groves. Clubs: Contemporary, Algonquin Golf. Recreations: horticulture and botanical subjects. Office: 1113 Fine St. Residence: 227 Orchard Ave., Webster Park.

FLORY, Joseph, clerk of St Louis Court of Appeals; born on farm near Logansport, Ind., June 19, 1856; son of Nathan and Elizabeth (Cuppy) Flory; educated common schools, Logansport, married, June 30, 1876, Emma Johnson, Lafayette, Ind.; children: Harry J., Frank F., Nellie B. Removed to Missouri; engaged in railroad business; elected state railroad commissioner of Missouri, 1894, for six years; Republican nominee for governor of Missouri, 1900; secretary Louisiana Purchase Exposition Commission, 1900-04. Engaged in construction of the Trinity & Brazos Valley R. R., 1905-06; trainmaster same road, 1907; with Mexican National Railway, 1908; with law department Missouri Pacific Railway, 1909; private secretary Postmaster Akins until Jan. 1, 1910; since clerk St Louis Court of Appeals. Member Order Railway Conductors, St Louis. Mason, Knight Templar. Recreations: reading and travel (by water preferred). Office: Pierce Building. Residence: 3833 Botanical Ave.

FLOWER, Walter L., steam specialties; born Caroline Co., Md., May 28, 1861; son of Nathan and Rebecca (Wheeler) Flower; educated in public schools; married at Cape May, N. J., Nov. 28, 1887, Belle M. Knott; children: Walter, Harold and Wilbur. Came to St Louis with Leonard & Ellis, oils, Apr. 1, 1884, and remained with the firm as salesman until March, 1898, when established for self under firm name of Walter L. Flower Co., steam specialties. Mason. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Oasis, City. Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: 312-314 S. 8th St. Residence: 5111 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["American Association of Railway Surgeons","Tri-State Medical Association","St Louis District Medical Association","Frisco System Medical Association","Rock Island System Medical Association; fellow Royal Microscopical Society","London"]
fullentry: FLOYD, Frank Monroe, surgeon, physician; born Columbia, Tenn., Jan. 20, 1866; son of B. B. and Sarah C. (Hilton) Floyd; educated in various public and private schools; graduated from Centralia (Ill.) High School, 1885; M.D., Medical Department of St Louis University, 1897; married, St Louis, 1911, Miss Myrtle Dougherty. Engaged in general practice of medicine and surgery since 1894. Consulting surgeon 44 Frisco" System, and division surgeon Rock Island System. Member American Association of Railway Surgeons, Tri-State Medical Association, St Louis District Medical Association, Frisco System Medical Association, Rock Island System Medical Association; fellow Royal Microscopical Society, London. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreation: literature. Office and Residence: 4400 Forest Park Boul.

FLYNN, James Crawford, contractor; born County Cavan, Ireland, Apr. 12, 1840; son of Owen and Martha (Crawford) Flynn; educated in public schools of native land; married, Southington, Conn., Mar. 4, 1864, Louise M. Matthews; children: Annice (now Mrs. Charles Hutton, of Oswego, Kas.), Cecily (now Mrs. E. Knapp), Mattie and Ben, both deceased. Came to America, 1857; served apprenticeship at carpenter's trade in Connecticut; located in St Louis, 1866; has engaged in contracting business on own account since 1871. Republican. Episcopalian. Odd Fellow. Office: 4371 Easton Ave. Residence: 4334 Garfield Ave.

FOLEY, Jeremiah T., clergyman; born, St. Charles, Mo., Apr. 3, 1860; son of Timothy and Elizabeth (O'Keeffe) Foley; graduated Christian Brothers College, St Louis, 1878; studied theology in Sulpician Seminary, Baltimore, Md. Ordained priest of Roman Catholic Church by the late Archbishop Ryan, at St. John's Church, St Louis, Mar. 7, 1883; began pastoral ministrations as assistant in St. Patrick's Church, was transferred to Church of the Holy Angels, where he ministered for nine years; then served as assistant pastor of Sacred Heart Church and later of 8t. Kevin's Church; appointed pastor of St. Cronan's Church, Jan. 24, 1898, then in a thinly settled portion of the city, and now including over 700 families in the parish. Residence: 1203 S. Boyle Ave.

FOLLENIUS, Reinhold H., granite and marble works; born in Warren Co., Mo., May 15, 1839; son of Paul and Maria (Muench) Fol-lenius; educated in district schools of Warren Co., Mo.; married, Milwaukee, Wis., 1864, Lena Westernhagen; one daughter: Mrfc. W. II. Fuchs. Learned granite and marble work trade in St Louis, beginning at age of sixteen, and afterwards worked at his trade in various places through the Mississippi Valley; since 1865 in business for self, conducting granite and marble works in St Louis and confining attention to cemetery work. Member A. F. & A. M. Recreation: reading. Office: 508-510 Chouteau Ave. Residence: 3202 Lafayette Ave.

FOLSOM, Samuel Pearl, lumber; born St. Paul, Minn., Apr. 25, 1865; son of Samuel P. and Mary D. (Gale) Folsom; educated in pub lie schools of St. Paul, Minn.; married, Tiffin, O., Xovember, 1892, Anna M. Rogers. Began business career as chief clerk in the office of the city engineer of St. Paul, Minn., for four years; then engaged as contractor for street pavements in St. Paul and throughout United States for five years. From 1887, actively and continuously engaged in the lumber business at St. Paul, Minu., and Kansas City, Mo., and in Arkansas until established in same line in May, 1905, in St Louis; makes railroad ties a specialty. Democrat. Episcopalian. Recreations: fishing and baseball. Office: 1316 Wright Bldg. Residence: 4511 Washington Boul.

company: Adjustment Bureau of St Louis Credit Men's Association
fullentry: FOOTE, Arthur Hoyt, manager Adjustment Bureau of St Louis Credit Men's Association; born Milwaukee, Wis., July 28, 1858; son of Samuel E. and Elizabeth Lee (Bailey) Foote; educated in public schools of Erie, Pa., 186873, including three years iu high school; married, North East (Erie Co.), Pa., Xov. 7, 1882, Gertrude E. McGill; children: Eleanor Bailey, Lucy Dodds, Horace Stanwood. In employ of Marine National Bank, Erie, Pa., 1873-78; purchasing agent and accountant Missouri Iron Co., Sligo Furnace Co., St Louis, Salem & Little Rock R. R., 1878-83; auditor and general freight and passenger agent Eureka Springs Railway Co., Eureka Springs, Ark., 1883-89; manager Crescent Hotel and secretary Eureka Improvement Co., Eureka Springs, 1889-91; secretary St Louis Traffic Commission, 1892-93; cashier Mansur & Tebbetts Implement Co., 1893-1902; since connected with St Louis Credit Men's Association. Republican. Member Church of the Messiah (Unitarian). Member Civic League; director Xational Association of Credit Men. Office: Security Bldg. Residence: 3739 Windsor PL

FORBES, Alexander Elias, merchant in teas and coffees; born Ayr, Canada, Jan. 11, 1843; son of James H. and Elizabeth (Eastway) Forbes; educated in public school and Jones Commercial College; married, Burlington, Ia., Oct. 18, 1889, Emma J. Johnson; one daughter: Helen M. In 1857 entered the wholesale tea and coffee business established by father in 1853, in which has ever since continued, now being president of the James II. Forbes Tea and Coffee Co. Republican. Presbyterian. Office: 112 Locust St. Residence: 4319 Delmar Avenue.

FORBES, Robert Magnus, teas and coffees; born Alton, Ill., June 20, 1861; son of James H. and Elizabeth (Ryrie) Forbes; graduated from Alton (Ill.) High School, and spent one year at Shurtleff College, Upper Alton, Ill.; married, Alton, Ill., Oct. 14, 1891, Mary P. Lewis; children: Harriet L., Janies H., Charles P. Since July, 1878, associated with father in tea and coffee business in St Louis, now being vice president of James H. Forbes Tea and Coffee Co. Member Business Men's League. Republican. Baptist. Mason (32°), Knight Templar. Office: 908-916 Clark St. Residence: Alton, Ill.

FORCE, Houston Thomas, wholesale hat merchant; born Charleston, S. C., Jan. 7, 1854; son of Benjamin Ward and Julia A. (Harper) Force; educated in public school, Charleston, S. C., private school in Georgia, Bryant & Stratton Business College, Newark, N. J.; married, Memphis, Tenn., Sept. 13, 1876, Anna Lumpkin (died 1901); 2d, Oct. 1, 1903, Margaret Tichenor, of Jefferson City, Mo.; children: Anna Lumpkin (Mrs. S. T. G. Smith), John L., Delphine, Hamlin D. When a lad of fifteen to seventeen was bookkeeper for manufacturing silverware house in New York; lived at Memphis, Tenn., from December, 1872, to January, 1877; came to St Louis, January, 1877, and entered employ of Watkins & Gilliland, wholesale hat dealers; in 1880 became director in Scott-Jones Hat Co., which changed to Scott-Force Hat Co., of which was president, and which later became Scott, Force & Goodbar Hat Co., in 1898; company changed to Boogher, Force & Goodbar Hat Co., of which was president for first year and has since been first vice president. Democrat. Presbyterian. Recreation: hunting. Office: 1606 Washington Ave. Residence: 4343 Morgan St.

memberships: ["Board of Education of St Louis","and served as chairman finance committee six years"]
fullentry: FORD, James Leven, wholesale grocery broker; born Fredericksburg, Va., July 1, 1849; son of James W. and C. Ellen (Taylor) Ford; graduated (second in class) from Virginia Military Institute, 1869; married, Danville, Ky., June 13, 1877, Lida M. Bowman; children: Mrs. James A. Draper (Wilmington, Del.), James L., Jr. Assistant professor mathematics, Virginia Military Institute, 1869-72; principal and professor mathematics at Danville (Ky.) Military Academy, 1872-80; commandant cadets and professor mathematics Agricultural College of Georgia, 1880-81; because of ill health changed occupation in 1881, coming to St Louis and establishing as wholesale grocery broker and commission merchant; since Nov. 1, 1885, of firm of Ford & Doan, St Louis and Kansas City, selling groceries to grocery jobbers of the Mississippi Valley. Democrat. Member Board of Education of St Louis, and served as chairman finance committee six years. Senior warden St. Peter's Episcopal Church. Clubs: Round Table, St Louis. Recreation: literature. Office: 312-314 N. 2d St. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

FORD, William Schofield, president W. S. Ford & Co.; born Bloomington, Ill., Apr. 9, 1873; son of Edwin D. and Ellen (8chofield) Ford; educated in high school of Sedalia, Mo.; unmarried. Entered Meier China and Glass Co. (established 1857) as bill clerk, 1894, and served as salesman, buyer, etc., before being elected, 1904, as vice president of the company, wholesale and retail dealers; in 1907 organized the firm of W. S. Ford & Co., dealers in hotel supplies, of which is president. Republican. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Triple A (director), Country, City, Century Boat, Universal Exposition. Office: 411 N. 3d St. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

residence: St. Lonis Co., near Jefferson Barracks.
fullentry: FORDER, Samuel W., gas and electric engineer; born in St Louis Co., Mo., Nov. 1, 1880; son of Samuel W. and Anna V. (Conn) Forder; educated in grammar schools of St Louis, Manual Training School, graduating, 1897, and Washington University, B.S., 1902; unmarried. After graduation was instructor in Washington University, 1902-03; superintendent of the Laclede Gas Light Co., 190309; manager Northern Indiana Gas and Electric Co., Michigan City, Ind., 1909-11; since engaged as consulting engineer. Member of American Gas Light Association. Episcopalian. Member Sigma Alpha Epsilon. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Residence: St. Lonis Co., near Jefferson Barracks.

FORDYCE, Samuel Wesley, capitalist; born in Guernsey Co., O., Feb. 7, 1840; son of John and Mary A. Fordyce; educated in public schools in Ohio, Madison College, Union-town, Pa., and North Illinois University, Henry Ill.; married, Huntsville, Ala., 1866, Susan E. Chadwick; children: John R. (president Thomas-Fordyce Manufacturing Co., Little Rock, Ark.), William C. (vice president Commonwealth Trust Co.), Jane (wife of David 8. Stanley, lieutenant colonel U. S. A., assistant quartermaster general), Samuel W., Jr. (lawyer). In 1860 became station agent on the Central Ohio Ry.; when war broke out in 1861, enlisted in Co. B, First Ohio Cavalry Volunteers, and served through the war; when left the service was captain of cavalry and inspector general of cavalry of the Army of the Cumberland. At close of war located in Huntsville, Ala., and established the banking house of Fordyce & Rison; became active in politics, and in 1874 served as member of the Democratic State Central Committee of Alabama; removed to Arkansas, 1876, and became largely interested in enterprises of that state; was elected vice president and treasurer, 1881 of Texas & St Louis R. R., of which was appointed receiver, 1885, and within a year relieved it of its financial obligation, and when road was reorganized as the St Louis, Arkansas & Texas Ry. Co., was made its president; again appointed receiver, 1889, and in 1891 road was reorganized as the St Louis Southwestern Ry., of which was president, 1891-99; vice president Apalachicola & Northern R. R., of Florida; director respectively of St Louis Union Trust Co., Kansas City Southern Ry. Co., Illinois, Iowa & Minnesota Ry. Co., St Louis, El Reno & Western Ry., Pierce-Fordyce Oil Association, of Texas; chairman board of directors Little Rock, Hot Springs & Western Ry.; president Hot Springs Street Ry. Co., Electric Ry. Co., Hot Springs Water Co., Electric Lighting Co., Hot Springs Gas Co., of Hot Springs, Ark.; president Houston Oil Co., of Texas; vice president Jefferson Hotel Co., St Louis, Eastman and Arlington hotel companies, Hot Springs, and other corporations. Democrat; delegate to Arkansas Democratic Gubernatorial Convention, 1880, Arkansas Judicial Convention, 1884; member Democratic National Committee from Arkansas, 1884-88; delegate to Democratic National conventions, 1884, 1892. Member Ohio 8ociety of New York, Loyal Legion, Ransom Post, G. A. R. Clubs: Noonday, Bellerive. Recreation: horseback riding. Cflice: 415 Locust St. Residence: 21 Washington Terrace.

FORDYCE, Samuel Wesley, Jr., lawyer; born Hot Springs, Ark., Aug. 11, 1877; son of Samuel Wesley and Susan E. (Chadick) Fordyce; educated Smith Academy, class of 1894; Harvard University, A.B., 1898; Washington University, Law Department, LL.B., 1901; married, 8t. Louis, Dec. 18, 1900, Harriet Frost. Admitted to bar in 1901; was partner with Charles M. Polk, under firm name of Fordyce & Polk, 1904-06; since Jan. 1, 1908, member firm of Fordyce, Holliday & White; President Pierce-Fordyce Oil Association, vice president and general counsel Tennessee Central R. R.; director Commonwealth Trust Co., Provident Chemical Works, Atlas Portland Cement Co., Mamolith Carbon Paint Co., National Light and Power Co., etc. Member 8t. Louis Bar Association, Law Library Association. Democrat. Clubs: Noonday, Racquet, St Louis Country, Cuivre, The Island. Recreation: shooting. Office: 506 Olive St. Residence: Kinloch, St Louis Co., Mo.

FORDYCE, William C., banker; born Huntsville, Ala., Nov. 28, 1871; son of Samuel W. and Susan Elizabeth (Chadick) Fordyce; removed with parents to Arkansas in youth and later to St Louis; educated under private tutelage and in Harvard University, graduating with degree of A.B., 1895; married, St Louis, June 16, 1902, Christine Orrick; three children: William C., Allen Orrick and Christine. Has been actively identified with promotion of many interests, including railroads (steam and electric), manufacturing and banking enterprises, gas and water works and other industries; vice president Commonwealth Trust Co. since 1905; president Hot Springs Gas Co., of Hot Springs, Ark.; vice president Scott City & Northern Ry. Co., of Kansas; vice president Hot Springs 8t. Ry. Co., Hot Springs Water and Electric Co., Planters Hotel Co. of St Louis, Jefferson Hotel Co. of St Louis, etc. Independent in politics. Clubs: University, Racquet, St Louis Country, Noonday. Office: Commonwealth Trust Bldg. Residence: 19 Washington Terrace.

FORLINE, Charles M., manager Keasby & Mattison Co., asbestos materials; born Mat-toon, HI., Jan. 7, 1860; son of John A. anti Elizabeth Corbin Forline; graduated from Ottawa (Kansas) High School, 1870; married, Downs, Osborn Co., Kan., Feb. 16, 1886, Verna Markert; one son: Carl Melville. Was in wholesale drug business on own account for years in Downs, Kan., and afterwards in same business, and mining in Colorado, at Colorado Springs and Manitou, Colo.; later in wholesale drug business in Chicago; left there to become general western manager for Keasby & Mattison Co. Democrat. Mason; member Odd Fellows. Knights of Pythias. Office: 215217 Chestnut St. Residence: 3865 Juniata St.

FORMAN, Hamilton Atchison, banker, retired; born on farm near Nashville, Ill., Feb. 15, 1853; son of William B. and Mary Caroline (Forsyth) Forman; educated in public schools, Washington 8eminary, Richview, Ill., and Jones Commercial College, St Louis, graduating from latter, 1870; married, Nashville, Ill., Apr. 26, 1909, Cora J. Kilber. Began banking as clerk in Tamaroa, Ill., and was afterwards clerk in Washington County Bank, Nashville, Ill.; in December, 1877, with others, organized Du Quoin Bank, Du Quoin, Ill., serving as its cashier until appointed national bank examiner, 1886; served until June, 1890, when was elected vice president of Second National Bank of Cincinnati; resigned to become cashier of the Continental National Bank of St Louis, June, 1892; then reappointed national bank examiner, which position held until Feb. 15, 1901, when was elected president of the Fourth National Bank of St Louis; continued in this office until December, 1906, when the bank was merged with the National Bank of Commerce. Organized the Central National Bank, of which was president from Dec. 6, 1906, to Mar. 7, 1909, when disposed of interests and retired. Was Democrat until 1894, since Republican. Was member of council of Du Quoin, Ill., and was also clerk and treasurer of same city. President City Council of St Louis, 1905-09. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner; member I. O. O. F. Favorite recreation: motoring. Residence: Hotel Beers.

FOSTER, Robert Magruder, lawyer; born Putnam Co., Ga., May 13, 1852; son of Sterling Johnson (M.D.) and-Virginia C. (Heard) Foster; educated private schools; East Alabama Male College, 1867-69; Davidson College, North Carolina, graduating degree of A.B., 1870, A.M., 1875; studied law under Judge N. B. Fagin and Gen. H. C. Thompkins, Union Springs, Ala.; matriculated in St Louis Law School and was graduated with degree of LL.B., 1875; married, Keokuk, Ia., Oct. J9, 1881, Lizzie L. Carpenter; three children: Sterling C., Robert M., Virginia Lee. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1875, and since in practice in St Louis; member Missouri House of Representatives, 1879-81; judge of St Louis Circuit Court and Juvenile Division of Circuit Court, 1902 to Jan. 1, 1909. Member American Bar Association, Missouri State Bar Association. President Central Arkansas & Eastern R. R. Co., Helena Water Co., Haywood (Ark.) Farm Co., Prairie Townsite Co. Democrat. Presbyterian. Mason. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic, Amateur Athletic, Normandie Park Golf. Recreations: golf, hunting and fishing. Office: 1401, 506 Olive St. Residence: 4315 Delmar Boul.

FOUKE, Philip Bond, wholesale raw furs; born New Orleans, La., July 20, 1872; son of Philip Bond and Sue Brent (Leonard) Fouke:. educated in public schools of St Louis and Emanuel Seminary, Dallas, Tex.; married, 1906, Miss Mabel Virginia Riddle. Began business career in 1889 as office boy with Funsten Bros. & Co., Inc.; steadily advanced and acquired large interest in business, becoming manager, and in 1897 was elected vice president and director of the company, which is engaged at wholesale in furs, and especially prominent as receivers and sellers of furs; acquired controlling interest in business and elected president of company, 1907. Director Mechanics-American National Bank. Republican. Congregationalist. Scottish Rite Mason (32°). Clubs: St Louis, Glen Echo Country, Racquet, Noonday, Automobile, Missouri Athletic. Recreations: golf, automobiling and hunting. Office: corner 2d and Elm Sts. Residence: 306 N. Newstead Ave.

FOWKE, Gerard, archeologist; born Mays-ville, Ky., June 25, 1855; son of John D. and Sibella (Mitchell) Smith; present name adopted; unmarried. Was engaged in explorations and surveys of aboriginal remains in eastern United States from Atlantic to Mississippi, Canada to Gulf of Mexico, in connection with Bureau of American Ethnology. 1885-88, 1891-93; also under other auspices at various times; excavations among Norse remains near Boston, 1894 and 1896; explorations on Vancouver Island, B. C., and lower Amoor River in Siberia, for American Museum Natural History, New York, 1898; examinations at Kimmswick, Mo., and Lansing, Kan., of geological deposits containing prehistoric human remains, of aboriginal flint quarries, and of caves for early human remains, in Kentucky, Indiana, Hlinois, Missouri, Tennessee and Alabama, 1902-04; geological and archaeological investigations in Missouri, 1905- 08; investigated glacial deposits and traced pre-glacial channels, in Ohio Valley, during past twenty years; with Missouri Historical Society, St Louis, since April, 1911; making investigations at Quirigua, Guatemala, 1912. Author: Archaeological History of Ohio, 1902; also monographs and reports for Bureau of American Ethnology, especially in twelfth and thirteenth annals, and numerous papers in scientific and historical journals. Address: Missouri Historical Society.

FOX, Charles J., lawyer; born St Louis, Mar. 18, 1874; son of Robert and Nellie (Mc-Guigan) Fox; A.B., Christian Brothers College, St Louis, 1892; LL.B., Law Department, Washington University, 1895; unmarried. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1895, and has engaged in practice at St Louis since Jan. 1, 1899. Democrat. Catholic. Member American Bar Association, St Louis Bar Association. Member Knights of the Maccabees. Club: Missouri Athletic. Office: Times Bldg. Residence: 5129 Kensington Ave.

FOX, Philip Peter, vice president Kaysing Iron and Foundry Co.; born St Louis, May 23, 1888; son of Philip J. and Margaret (Hacker) Fox; educated in St. Francis De Sales (parochial) School, to 1902; St. Peter and Paul's High School, 1902-04; then entered Perkins & Herpel's Business College (changed to New St Louis Business College), from which graduated, Sept. 17, 1904; married, St Louis, Feb. 22, 1911, Mary Baier; one child: Roger Philip. Began business career with Evert P. Maule, contractor and builder, as bookkeeper and stenographer, Sept. 27, 1904, and continued until March, 1908; engaged with Powitzky & Collins Carriage Woodwork Co. as assistant bookkeeper and stenographer, March, 1908-09; then to January, 1910, as bookkeeper Kaysing Iron and Foundry Co., of which now vice president. Republican. Catholic. Recreations: fishing and bowling. Office: 2523 Montgomery St. Residence: 3414A Grace Avenue.

birthcity: Philadelphia; son of George and Rosa (McGovern) Fox. Learned sculpture in Paris and Rome; later engaged in marble work in principal cities of United States; located in St Louis
fullentry: FOX, William C., marble and tile business; born Philadelphia; son of George and Rosa (McGovern) Fox. Learned sculpture in Paris and Rome; later engaged in marble work in principal cities of United States; located in St Louis, 1902, and since manager and treasurer St Louis Marble and Tile Co. Office: 711 S. 12th St. Residence: 2612 S. Compton Ave.

FRALEY, Moses, general insurance; born Frederick, Md., Nov. 24, 1843; son Mannus and Babette (Jandorf) Fraley; educated public schools; married, St Louis, 1865, Mis9 Rosa Harsh; children: Ray (Mrs. Peter Zucker, of New York), Sadie (Mrs. C. A. Stix). Began business career as proprietor of a general merchandise store at Parkersburg, W. Va., coming, to St Louis, 1863, and continuing in same business until 1868; in banking and brokerage business under firm name of Donaldson & Fraley and New York firm of Fraley & Good-hardt, who were members of the New York Stock Exchange; in 1883 engaged in grain commission business in firm of Fraley-Carter Commission Co., with offices at St Louis, Chicago and New York; since 1893 in general insurance business under style of the Insurance Agency Co., of which is vice president. Member Civic League, Business Men's League. Was member Upper House of Municipal Assembly of St Louis under the new scheme and charter for four years (one of two members of that body now living). Jewish religion; president Temple Israel; president Confederated Jewish Educational and Charitable Union. Mason (Royal Arch). Clubs: Columbian (ex-president), City. Recreations: music and philanthropic and educational work. Office: 112 N. 4th St. Residence: 26 Portland Place.

FRANCIS, Albert J., president Francis Construction Co.; born at Alexandria, Ky., Jan. 4, 1871; son of Charles and Sarah (Ware) Francis; educated in public schools; married, Covington, Ky., 1894, Nettie Bressman; one son: Bert. Learned carpenter's trade under father, who was a contractor and builder; engaged as contractor in Covington, and later was manager of erection of additions to soldiers' homes at Danville, Ill., and Dayton, O.; located in St Louis, 1901, as contractor and builder; director Maryville Hotel Co. Democrat. Baptist. Mason; member Knights of Pythias. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic, Oasis. Recreations: fishing and automobiling. Office: 812 Chestnut St. Residence: 5810 Julian Ave.

company: St Louis branch The Manhattan Rubber Manufacturing Co.
fullentry: FRANCIS, Arthur Garesche, manager St Louis branch The Manhattan Rubber Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 27, 1865; son of Charles W. and Eulalie (Maguire) Francis; educated public schools and Washington University; married, St Louis, Oct. 31, 1893, Maude Pease; one daughter: Louise. Entered employ of St Louis branch of the Revere Rubber Co., 1892, continuing for two years; with the New York Belting and Packing Co., 1894-1903, filling position of manager of St Louis branch of the company during the last seven years of that period; manager St Louis branch of the Manhattan Rubber Manufacturing Co. since July, 1903. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreation: baseball. Office: 115 N. 2d St. Residence: 4921 Washington Boul. •

FRANCIS, David Rowland; born Richmond, Ky., Oct. 1, 1850; son of John B. and Eliza C. Francis; graduated, Washington University, St Louis, A.B., 1870; LL.D. conferred by same, 1905; also LL.D., University of Missouri, 1892, Shurtleff College, Alton, Ill., 1903, St Louis University, 1904; married, 8t. Louis, 1876, Jane Perry; children: J. D. Perry, David R., Jr., Talton T., Charles B., Thomas, Sidney R. Resident of St Louis since 1866; entered employ of Shryock & Rowland, 1870; founded, 1877, firm of I>. R. Francis, which in 1884 became D. R. Francis & Brother, later D. R. Francis & Bro. Commission Co., grain merchants, of which is president; founded, 1898, the financial house of Francis, Bro. & Co., of which is president. Also vice president Mer-chants-Laclede National Bank; chairman board of directors Missouri & North Arkansas R. R.; director Mississippi Valley Trust Co.; president board of curators University of Missouri. Was president Louisiana Purchase Exposition Co.; decorated by rulers of principal countries of Europe and Asia; president National Drainage Congress. Democrat; mayor of St Louis, 1885-89; governor of Missouri, 1889-93; Secretary of the Interior, 189697. President Merchants' Exchange of St Louis, 1884. Presbyterian. President Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association. Member National Geographic Society. Clubs: St. Louis, University, Country, Log Cabin, Bellerive, Round Table, Commercial, Noonday, Mercantile, Kinloch (St Louis), Metropolitan (Washington, D. C.), Metropolitan (New York). Office: 214 N. 4th St. Residence: 4421 Maryland Ave.

FRANCIS, David Rowland, Jr., broker; born, St Louis, May 31, 1879; son of David R. and Jane (Perry) Francis; educated at Smith Academy, St Louis; St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H.; B.A., Yale University, 1900; married, Danvers, Mass., June 12, 1901, Sarah C. Coulthurst; one daughter: Alice Peppered Francis. Became a member, June 1, 1901, of the firm of Francis, Bro. & Co., bonds, stocks, cotton, grain, etc.; director Madison County Ferry Co., United Railways Co. Democrat. Presbyterian. Clubs: St Louis, St Louis Country, Racquet, The Island. Office: 214 N. 4th St. Residence: 4421 Maryland Avenue.

FRANCIS, J. D. Perry, broker; born Normandy, St Louis Co., Mo., Oct. 31, 1876; son of David R. and Jane (Perry) Francis; educated in private schools and Yale University, graduating, A.B., 1897; married, St Louis, January, 1900, Emelie De Mun Smith. After graduation entered, 1898, the present bond and stock brokerage firm of Francis, Bro. & Co. Also director of the Madison County Ferry Co., Alton, Granite & St Louis Co., Mortgage Trust Co., Mortgage Guarantee Co., Scruggs-Vandervoort-Bamev Dry Goods Co. Member St Louis Stock Exchange. Democrat. ClubB: St Louis, Racquet, Cuivre, St Louis Country, Noonday. Office: 214 N. 4th St. Residence: 4510 Maryland Ave.

memberships: ["of the St Louis Merchants' Exchange","New York","Chicago and St Louis stock exchanges","New York Coffee Exchange","New York Cotton Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade"]
fullentry: FRANCIS, Thomas H., broker and commission merchant; born Richmond, Madison Co., Ky., July 17, 1855; son of J. B. and Eliza C. (Rowland) Francis; educated in public schools of Richmond and Lexington, Ky.; unmarried. Engaged in farming in Kentucky until twenty-five years of age; came to St Louis, 1880, and entered firm of D. R. Francis as clerk; later became member of firm of D. R. Francis & Bro. Commission Co., and in 1905, of Francis, Bro. & Co., bonds, stocks, cotton, grain and investment securities. Member of the St Louis Merchants' Exchange, New York, Chicago and St Louis stock exchanges, New York Coffee Exchange, New York Cotton Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade. Was member board of directors Merchants' Exchange, 1903 and 1904. Democrat. Presbyterian. Clubs: St Louis, City, Racquet, Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 214 N. 4th St. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

memberships: ["St Louis Real Estate Exchange","of which was formerly vice president"]
fullentry: FRANCISCUS, James Madison, real estate; born St Louis, Mar. 15, 1866; son of James M. and Jane Huffaker (Wade) Franciscus: educated in public schools of St Louis, and Washington University; married, St Louis, June 12, 1890, Katherine G. Lindsay; children: James Lindsay, Jane, Marian, James M., Jr., John D. Began business career as clerk with Simmons Hardware Co., 1885-87, then with auditing department of the Wabash R. R., and afterwards as bookkeeper in Third National Bank, until 1889; in real estate firm of Moffett & Franciscus, 1889-1902; bought partner's interest, and business was conducted as J. M. Franciscus & Co., real estate and financial agents, in which Charles C. Kunz was a partner; firm name was changed in July, 1909, to Franciscus & Kunz, which still continues; vice-president Title Guaranty Trust Co., the American Trust Co. Was special commissioner in partition of The Lindell Estate and gave personal bond of one million dollars; also special commissioner of the D. A. January Estate and gave personal bond of over one-half million dollars. Member St Louis Real Estate Exchange, of which was formerly vice president. Democrat; city treasurer of St Louis, elected 1901 and reelected 1905, continuiug until 1909. Formerly commissioner of Mullanphy Emigrant Relief Fund; vice president St Louis Skin and Cancer Hospital and one of its charter members. Member Business Men's League. Roman Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, Racquet, St Louis Country. Favorite recreations: automobiling, farming. Office: 702 Chestnut St. Residence: 10 Lenox Place.

memberships: ["and president Mullanphy Emigrant Relief Fund","three years; was member City Council","being elected with D"]
fullentry: FRANK, August, vice president and treasurer National Publishing Co.; born Pirmaseus, Germany, Jan. 7, 1847; son of Abraham and Branette (Weil) Frank; reared at Peoria, Ill.; educated in public schools, Peoria, Ill.; married, New York City, May 19, 1872; children: Alfred, Grace F. (Mrs. Chas. L. Green hall). Began business career in retail dry goods business; then for twenty years in wholesale dry goods business, under style of A. Frank & Sons; then changed to retail dry goods store under style of Frank Brothers; removed to Chicago, where continued same business, from which retired, 1899. Took management of St Louis Star and continued until 1905, when daily was consolidated with St Louis Chronicle, the semi-weekly remaining property of 8tar Publishing Co., now the National Publishing Co.; vice president and geueral manager St Louis Star; treasurer the World Color Printing Co., Reliance Engraving Co.; president Frank Real Estate and Investment Co. Democrat. Member and president Mullanphy Emigrant Relief Fund, three years; was member City Council, being elected with D. R. Francis when he was elected mayor. Jewish religion. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country, Sunset Hill Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 716-718 Lucas Ave. Residence: Washington Hotel.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Carondelet Business Men's Association"]
fullentry: FRANK, Harry August, lawyer; born St Louis, Jan. 1, 1886; son of August and Anna Columbia (Sears) Frank; educated St Louis public schools, graduating from Central High School, June, 1905; then entered St Louis Law School (Washington University), from which was graduated with degree of LL.B., June, 1908; married, St Louis, June 6, 1912, Nellie Mabelle Schonfield. Took bar examination at end of second year in law school, 1907, and was admitted to practice in courts of Missouri; in law office of Bishop & Cobbs, 1907-08; has practiced alone since June, 1908. Republican. Presbyterian; secretary board of trustees Carondelet Presbyterian Church. Member St Louis Bar Association, Carondelet Business Men's Association. Member Cache Lodge No. 416, A. F. & A. M., Southern Council, Royal Arcanum, Delta Chi college legal fraternity. Clubs: City, Million Population, Century Boat. Recreation: tennis. Office: Suite 1111-1115, Third National Bank Bldg. Residence: 736A Dover PI.

FRANK, Nathan, lawyer; born Peoria, Ill., Feb. 23, 1852; son of Abraham and Branette (Weil) Frank; educated in St Louis High School, Washington University and Harvard Law School, LL.B., 1872; unmarried. Admitted to bar at St Louis in 1874 and ever since engaged in practice in this city, making a specialty of corporation law. Republican; member of Congress from St Louis in Fiftieth and Fifty-first Congresses, 1887-91; during first McKinley campaign, 1896, was chairman of the Republican State Executive Committee. Member Executive Committee of Louisiana Purchase Exposition, 1904. Clubs: University, Columbian, Westwood, Aero. Office: 1025 Century Bldg. Residence: 4404 W. Pine Boul.

FRANKLIN, Harry, vice president Phoenix Furniture Co.; born, St Louis, Aug. 10, 1867; son of Andrew and Kate Franklin; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, Jacksonville, Ill., 1895, Johanna Weil. Began business career in 1880, and was clerk in various mercantile houses until 1890; since identified continuously with the retail furniture trade, and since its incorporation in 1899 has been vice president of the Phoenix Furniture Co. Jewish religion. Office: 1101-1103 Olive St. Residence: 3300 Shenandoah Ave.

company: Bankers Trust Co. of St Louis
office: Suite 622, National Bank of Commerce Bldg.
memberships: ["board of trustees William Jewell College; member Phi Gamma Delta college fraternity"]
fullentry: FRANKLIN, John Eddy, president Bankers Trust Co. of St Louis; born on farm in Holt Co., Mo., July 31, 1863; son of Shadrach and Imogene (Eddy) Franklin; educated William Jewell College, Liberty, Mo., receiving degree of A.B., 1884, A.M., 1899, and honorary degree of LL.D., 1911; married, Liberty, Mo., Aug. 4, 1886, Emma Timms; four children: Imogene, Alice, Gilbert and Shadrach. Has engaged in banking continuously since twenty-two years of age; president of Bankers Trust Co. of St Louis since 1906. President Mississippi Valley R. R., San Antonio, Uvalde & Gulf R. R. Owns a 5,000-acre farm in Pemisco Co., Mo. (said to be the largest farm in Missouri under one fence). Independent in politics. Baptist. Member board of trustees William Jewell College; member Phi Gamma Delta college fraternity. Club: Mercantile. Recreations: farming, study of sociality. Office: Suite 622, National Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: Colorado Springs, Colo.

FRANTZ, William Henry, builder; born Cincinnati, July 2, 1853; son of Peter and Rosina (Wey) Frantz; educated in public schools, Woodward High School and Nelson's Commercial College, all of Cincinnati; married, St Louis, Sept. 17, 1877, Minnie Deerr; four children: Lorena W., W. Albert, Lewis M. and Rosina M. Came to St Louis at age of seventeen and learned stair building trade with brother and later with Thorn & Fullerton; attended drawing school by night; formed partnership with Allen Dorsey, as Franz & Dorsey, but firm was dissolved, 1877; continued as a stair builder fifteen years longer; began building modern homes in West End, 1892, and has since continued in same line. Republican. Presbyterian. Recreation: traveling. Home: 5222 Raymond Ave.

FRAUENTHAL, Barney Weil, general ticket agent Union Station, St Louis; boru, White Haven, Pa., Feb. 27, 1869; son of Abraham and Jeannette (Weil) Frauenthal; edueated in public schools of Pennsylvania and Central State Normal School of Lock Haven, Pa.; married, Ironton, Iron Co., Mo., May 22, 1895, Louise D. 8chwab; four children: Jeannette, aged 15, Edward, 13, Lucile, 11, and Bernice, 6. Entered service of old Union Depot Co., St Louis, May, 1883; served in telegraph an l ticket departments, until September, 1893; with Wabash Western Line, various stations, until September, 1894; in charge bureau of information at Union Station, September, 1894-January, 1904; general ticket agent Union Station since Jan. 25, 1904; also appointed, Apr. 10, 1912, general passenger and ticket agent Terminal Railroad Association of St Louis, St Louis Merchants' Bridge Terminal Railroad Co. and Wiggins Ferry Co. President Seeing St Louis Automobile Co., Barney's Information Guide Co.; director Union Station Bank; chairman board Terminal Savings Fund; treasurer Mt. Olive Building and Loan Association. Republican; candidate on Republican state ticket for railroad and warehouse commissioner, 1900 (defeated by majority of 41,000 votes); vice president Mullanphy Board and City of St Louis trustee of Fund, 1908; first president Shaw's Garden District Improvement Association, 1909; member Hospital Board, City of St Louis, since July, 1912. Division Commander Missouri Sons of Veterans, 1891, 1892. Member Pride of the West Lodge, A. F. & A. M. Clubs: St Louis Railway (secretary), Irish-American Athletic. Author: Barney's Information Guide to the City of St Louis, 1902. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: Union Station. Residence: 4240 Russell Avenue.

memberships: ["American and Missouri State Medical associations","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: FRAZER, Hal Scott, physician; born Washington, Mo., Sept. 13, 1877; son of Charles R. and Isabella M. (Young) Frazer; educated in public and high schools; matriculated in St Louis College of Physicians and Surgeons, graduating with degree of M.D., 1898; married, St Louis, June 11, 1912, Lila Simpson. In U. S. Marine hospital and public health service, 1898-1900; professor anatomy St Louis College of Physicians and Surgeons, 1900-09, now professor laboratory physiology in same institution; was assistant surgeon Missouri Pacific Railway Hospital, 1905 and 1906. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member American and Missouri State Medical associations, St Louis Medical Society. Mason; member Royal Arcanum, Phi Chi. Recreations: chess, tennis, water sports. Office and Residence: 1111 Chouteau Ave.

FREASIER, Joseph Lafayette, secretary and general manager Modern Wagon and Carriage Co.; born Charlotte, N. C., Apr. 26, 1861; son of John L. and Marguerithe E. (Jamison) Freasier; educated in public schools of Illinois, 1867-79, taking courses in chemistry, geometry, philosophy and physiology (no certificates of graduation issued at that time); married, St Louis, Oct. 27, 1883, Jennie A. Ford; two daughters: Jessie M. (Mrs. Dr. E. R. Van Booven) and Jennie M. Began active career in employ of the James A. Wright Carriage Co., continuing 1880-81; then became connected with the John Deere Plow Co., and was with that concern until 1897; disposed of his interest in the plow company, 1898, and incorporated the Modern Wagon and Carriage Co., a close corporation, the stock being owned by himself, wife and daughter, and has since been secretary and general manager of this organization. Democrat. Presbyterian. Office: 1948-2002 Papin St. Residence: 5064 Washington Ave.

FRECH, Albert, vice president Eisenstadt Manufacturing Co.; born Lebanon, Ill., Aug. 31, 1869; son of Samuel and Elizabeth (Zer-weck) Freeh; educated in public and high schools; married, Elizabeth Nelsch, June, 1894 (died, Apr. 18, 1897); one child: Elenore Mary Nelsch; married, 2d, June 1, 1905, Alvena Gerne. Began active career in employ of the Eisenstadt Manufacturing Co., manufacturing jewelers, and advanced through various departments until 1904, when was elected vice president, a position he now fills. Independent Democrat. Presbyterian. Member Masonic Order. Recreations: automobiling and baseball. Office: 1205 Olive St. Residence: 3529 Halliday Ave.

residence: 6192 Kingsbury Boul. Summer Residence: Three Lakes, Wis.
memberships: ["St Louis Merchants Exchange; ex-president Real Estate Exchange; director and ex-president National Association of Real Estate Exchanges; member Business Men's League"]
fullentry: FREDERICK, August Henry, real estate and financial agent; born St Louis, June 22, 1858; son of Henry George and Elizabeth (Lipphart) Frederick; educated in 8t. Louis public school and St Louis High School; married, St Louis, Dec. 15, 1881, Nannie L., daughter of Harvey L. Fowler, of Binghamton, N. Y.; children: Laura M. (now Mrs. H. F. Hunter, of Milwaukee), William H., Maude L. (deceased). Began business life with Buxton & Skinner Stationery Co., as clerk, later becoming successively bookkeeper, secretary and treasurer of that company, until 1888; since in real estate and financial agency business without partner. Also president and treasurer of the Jesse Morris Realty and Investment Co. and Circuit Realty and Investment Co. Member St Louis Merchants Exchange; ex-president Real Estate Exchange; director and ex-president National Association of Real Estate Exchanges; member Business Men's League. Director of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition Co., from its organization. Elected, 1893, reelected 1897, and served eight years as president of the Board of Assessors. Republican; member Republican City Committee; often delegate to city, state and national conventions. Clubs: Mercantile, City, Missouri Athletic, Three Lakes Fishing and Hunting (Three Lakes, Wis.). Recreations: fishing, hunting and rowing. Office: 111 N. 7th St. Residence: 6192 Kingsbury Boul. Summer Residence: Three Lakes, Wis.

FREES, Henry J., general insurance; born London, England, Dec. 14, 1857; son of Jacob and Rachel (Dann) Frees; came to United States in 1865; educated in London, New York and Montreal, and at McGill University, Montreal, in class of 1881; married, Dallas, Tex., 1888, Ernestine Remhardt; children: Madeline, Katharine, Florence. After leaving college went to Dallas, Tex., where was engaged in music business until 1893; came to St Louis and continued in same line until 1895; since general agent and broker in insurance. Club: Columbia. Office: 308 Security Bldg. Residence: 4250 Lindell Boul.

FREI, Emil, stained and art glass; born Bavaria, Germany, July 17, 1869; son of Michael and Anna (Spiegel) Frei; educated in.public schools and college, also school of art at Munich; came to America, 1894; married, New York City, May, 1895, Emma Miller; children: Emil, Adolph, Emma. Spent several years in San Francisco; located in St Louis, 1897, and engaged as painter and glass artist with A. H. Wallis until 1900; then entered business on own account as manufacturer of stained and art glass, in which has since continued; won grand prize at Louisiana Purchase Exposition for window for Holy Family Church, Watertown, N. Y. Catholic. Club: Liederkranz. Office and Residence: 3934 S. Grand Ave.

FRENCH, Hugh Murray, president Graham Paper Co.; born San Jos6, Calv Aug. 7, 1854; son of Parker Hardin and Lucretia Clay (Edwards) French; educated in St Louis public schools; married, June 11, 1902, Susan Lewis; children: Dudley, Charles Sale. Entered wholesale paper business in 1875 with the firm of Snider & Holmes, continuing until firm retired from business, 1887; with Graham Paper Co., 1888-1900, when left that company to inaugurate and manage the General Paper Co. of Chicago, created for the handling of the products of nearly all paper mills in Wisconsin and Minnesota. Resigned in 1901 on account of ill-health, returning to Graham Paper Co., Dec. 15, 1901, as vice president, until death of B. B. Graham in December, 1904, when became president. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Club: Bellerive Country. Recreation: fishing. Office: 1018 Spruce St. Residence: 4327 Washington Boul.

FRENCH, Jesse, piano manufacturer; born Devonshire, England, July 23, 1846; son of Jacob and Mary Ann French; educated in public schools of Nashville, Tenn., and commercial college, Peoria, Ill.; married, Nashville, Jan. 2, 1872, Callie Lumsden; children: Horace Edgar, Jesse, Jr. Began business career in office of secretary of state, Nashville, then became assistant secretary of state of Tennessee, continuing for seven years; commenced mercantile pursuits as a dealer in sheet music at Nashville, 1872; in 1875 became partner in firm of Dorman, French & Smith, bought out Mr. Smith's interest, firm becoming Dorman & French, and later bought interest of Mr. Dorman, and continued under own name. In 1885 incorporated business as Jesse French Piano and Organ Co., Nashville, Tenn., of which was president until sold out interest, in 1902. Began business in St Louis, 1887, as Field-French Piano Co., which was later absorbed by the Jesse French Piano and Organ Co. About 1900 the Krell-French Piano Co. was organized, of which was vice president until August, 1905, when elected president; now president Jesse French & Sons Piano Co., of New Castle, Ind. Director Liberty Mills (Nashville, Tenn.). Republican. Baptist. Recreation: traveling. Office: 1426 Central National Bank Bldg. Residence: 4133 Morgan St.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: FRENCH, Pinckney, surgeon; born in Audrain Co., Mo., May 10, 1852; son of Isaac C. and Melinda Mourning (Mansfield) French; educated in public schools, Mexico (Mo.) Seminary and Mianii Medical College, graduating, M.D., 1873; married, Mexico, Mo., Feb. 5, 1874, Lucy P. Quisenberry. Engaged in practice as surgeon in Mexico and St Louis; vice president Vandeventer Bank; director of Lincoln Trust Co., Neighborhood Heat and Light Co. Founder and financial secretary Barnes University; founder and trustee Centenary Hospital. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Methodist. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: literature. Office: Chemical Bldg. Residence: 6925 Delmar Boulevard.

memberships: ["American Institute of Chemical Engineers","Society of Chemical Industry of Great Britain","American Chemical Society","Deutsche Bunsengesellschaft","Academy of Science of St Louis","St Louis Chet deal Society","Chemists' Club (New York)"]
fullentry: FRERICHS, Frederick William, manufacturing chemist; born Etzel, Ostfriesland, Germany, Mar. 23, 1849; son of Frederick and Magdalene (Frisius) Frerichs; educated in gymnasium, Oldenburg, Germany, and University of Gottingen, Ph.D., 1874; married, Oct. 20, 1886, Amelia Zeller; children: Frederick W., Jr., Hildegarde Christine. Served as lieutenant of the Reserves in the Second Hessian Infantry Regiment No. 82, Germany, until 1882. Engaged as manufacturing chemist since 1880, and since 1886 managing director of the Herf & Frerichs Chemical Co., also vice president. Member American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Society of Chemical Industry of Great Britain, American Chemical Society, Deutsche Bunsengesellschaft, Academy of Science of St Louis, St Louis Chet deal Society, Chemists' Club (New York). Evangelical Lutheran. Club: St Louis. Recreation: industrial research. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 4320 Washington Boul.

memberships: ["Temple Shaare Emeth (member board of directors)","Jewish Charity and Educational Society"]
fullentry: FREUND, Fred Siegfried, treasurer American Bakery Co.; born St Louis, Nov. 7, 1857; son of Moritz and Yetta (Steiner) Freund; educated in St Louis public schools to 1873; married, Williamsport, Pa., Nov. 21, 1888, Fanny Wurzel; three children: Arthur J., Bertha C., Michael W. Began business career with A. Frank & Sons, wholesale dry goods, 1875-83; joined the L. Freund & Bros. Bakery and formed the Freund Bros. Bread Co., which on Mar. 1, 1907, was merged with the American Bakery Co., of which has since been treasurer and member board of directors. President Freund Bros. Real Estate Co. Republican. Member Temple Shaare Emeth (member board of directors), Jewish Charity and Educational Society. Mason (Cosmos Lodge, Scottish Rite Consistory, Moolah Temple Mystic Shrine); also B. P. O. Elks. Clubs: Mercantile, Columbian, St Louis Riding (treasurer). ^Recreation: horseback riding. Office: 901-911 Liggett Bldg. Residence: 4554 Berlin Ave.

FREUND, Harry, department store; born, St Louis, Oct. 10, 1874; son of Siegmund E. and Emma (Pfeiffer) Freund; graduated from public school, l5o9; one year in high school; unmarried. Employed by father, beginning March, 1891, and upon father's death, December, 1898, became general manager of the store; bought the business with brother and mother from estate, April, 1899, and incorporated it as S. E. Freund's Sons Shoe and Clothing Co., conducting a department store business, and has been president from incorporation in 1904. Also president Favorite Amusement Co. Republican. Jewish religion. Mason. Office: 1560 S. Broadway. Residence: 1622 Mississippi Ave.

memberships: ["B'nai B'rith; vice president B'nai El Congregation"]
fullentry: FREUND, Simon, baker, retired; born Pil-sen, Austria, Apr. 30, 1847; son of Moritz and Yetta (Steiner) Freund; came to America with parents, 1849; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, Feb. 25, 1872, Pauline Schwartz; ten children: Mrs. Martha Mange, Samuel, Louis S., Albert B., Charles J., Mrs. Jennie Gutfreund, Mrs. Augusta Litt-man, Walter L., Eleanor, Florence. Became identified with bakery establishment in youth which was founded by his father, and after death of latter, 1872, assumed control; one of incorporators of the Freund Bros. Bread Co., which was sold out to the American Bakery Co., 1907, when he retired; vice president Freund Bros. Real Estate Co.; director American Bakery Co. Republican. Jewish religion. Member B'nai B'rith; vice president B'nai El Congregation. Mason. Office: 913 Soulard St. Residence: 3001 Longfellow Ave.

FRICK, Frank J., real estate; born Utica, N. Y., June 11, 1865; son of Joseph F. and Susan P. (Matt) Frick; educated in public school and Eastman Business College, Poughkeepsie, N. Y.; married, Kirkwood, Mo., Nov. 6, 1901, Cornelia A. Luebbering; one son: Edward Louis. Came to St Louis, 1888, and since treasurer and secretary of the F. H. & C. B. Gerhart Real Estate Co. Also secretary and treasurer Frick Realty Co.; secretary Gerhart Realty Co., secretary Flandrin Realty Co. Member of the Real Estate Exchange. Member Knights of Columbus, Royal Arcanum. Office: Wainwright Bldg. Residence: Webster Groves, Mo.

FRICKE, Frederick Henry, president Fricke-Hahn Drug Co.; born 8t. Louis, Apr. 4, 1873; son of Henry and Christine (Eicker-mann) Fricke; educated in St. John's (parochial) School, Webster (public) School, St Louis College of Pharmacy, graduating with degree of Ph.G., March, 1892; married, Alhambra, Ill., Sept. 25, 1895, Lena Willig; one daughter: Ethel. Began active career as clerk in drug store, St Louis, 1887; started a retail drug store at 19th and Madison Sts., 1893; assisted in organizing the Fricke-Hahn Drug Co., 1902, of which has since been president and treasurer. Democrat; chairman 4 4 Major-f or-Governor'' organization of St Louis, 1912. Protestant. Member American and Missouri State Pharmaceutical associations. Mason; member Keystone Lodge, A. F. & A. M.; Beliefontaine Chapter, Royal Arch Masons; St Louis Commandery, Knights Templar; A. & A. Scottish Rite; Moolah Temple, A. A. O. N. M. S. Club: City. Recreations: motor touring, bowling and fishing. Office: 1637 N. 19th St. Residence: 3218 Hebert St.

FRIEDMAN, Abraham, shoe manufacturer; born in Bavaria, Germany, Dec. 25, 1862; son of Joseph and Johanna (Hamburg) Friedman; educated in public schools of Germany; married, St Louis, 1898, Cora Stix; children: William Stix, Agnes Dinah. Began business career in 1880 as clerk in the wholesale house of Friedman Bros., boots and shoes, Boston, remaining in the store until 1884; traveling salesman for same firm until 1888, and assistant general manager of Memphis, Tenn., branch, 1888-91; located in St Louis, becoming a member of the firm of Friedman Bros. & Schafer, boots and shoes, and in 1898, on organization of the Friedman Bros. Shoe Co., was elected secretary and treasurer of the company; in 1906 name was changed to Fried-man-Shelby Shoe Co., of which is president. Member Business Men's League. Republican. Jewish religion. Clubs: Glen Echo, Columbian. Recreation: golf. Office: 1621 Washington Ave. Residence: 4904 Berlin Ave.

FRIEDMAN, Henry Arthur, cloak manufacturer; born Detroit, Mich., Feb. 27, 1874; son of Nathan and Regina Friedman; graduated from University of Michigan, Ph.B., 1893; studied at Harvard Law School; unmarried. Admitted to the bar in 1894. After leaving college became associated in business with rather and brother, Robert V., under present style of N. Friedman & Sons, manufacturers of ladies' wearing apparel, established in 1875. Member Business Men's League. Member B'nai B'rith. Jewish religion. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country, Ann Arbor Club. Recreation: golf. Office: 1233 Washington Ave. Residence: 39 Kingsbury PL

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Association","City Hospital Alumni Association"]
fullentry: FRIEDMAN, Jacob, physician; born St Louis, Apr. 16, 1856; son of Moses and Helena (Meyer) Friedman; graduated from St Louis High School, 1873; graduated in chemistry, Washington University, 1876; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1878; post-graduate studies, University of Vienna, Austria; married, St Louis, 1888, Fannie Stern; two children: Maurice L. and Cecelia. In practice in St Louis since 1878; professor of therapeutics, Medical Department of St Louis University; member staff of Jewish Hospital. Republican. Jewish religion. Member St Louis Medical Association, City Hospital Alumni Association. Mason. Club: Columbian. Recreation: baseball. Office: Carleton Bldg. Residence: 4653 Berlin Ave.

FRIEDMAN, Nathan, cloak manufacturer; born in Hungary, 1844; educated in schools in Austria; married, Budapest, Hungary, Miss Regina Rosenberg; children: Henry A., Robert V. Came to United States in 1870 and located in Michigan; established in the retail dry goods business in 1875, and in 1894 came to St Louis, admitting his two sons, under present style of N. Friedman & Son9, manufacturers of ladies' cloaks. Jewish religion. Director Jewish Hospital. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country. Member Temple Israel, B'nai B'rith. Office: 1233 Washington Ave. Residence: 39 Kingsbury PI.

FRIEDMAN, Robert V., cloak manufacturer; born, Elkhart, Ind., Sept. 9, 1875; son of Nathan and Regina Friedman; graduated from University of Michigan, Ph.B., 1894; married, Chicago, Dec. 27, 1910, Florentine Foreman. Since leaving college has been associated with father, Nathan Friedman, and brother, Henry A. Friedman, in present firm of X. Friedman & Sons, manufacturers of cloaks. Jewish religion. Member B 'nai B 'rith, Business Men's League. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country, Ann Arbor. Recreation: golf. Office: 1233 Washington Ave. Residence: 5561 Waterman Ave.

FRIELING, Christ, president Frieling Hardware Co.; born in province of Hanover, Germany, Nov. 18, 1859; son of Henry and Anna (Viehe) Von Frieling; public school education; married, St Louis, May 18, 1884, Clara Mary Ziegler; three children: Clara, Anna, Frederick. Learned carpenter's trade in old country; came to America, May 16, 1881, and worked as journeyman in St Louis for five years; engaged in business for self, 1886; in hardware business with son since March, 1912. Republican. Member Evangelical Lutheran Church. Member North St Louis Business Men's Association, City Association. Office: 3511 Kossuth Ave. Residence: 3240 N. 20th St.

FRIELINGSDORF, Hugo August, vice president Banner Iron Works; born St Louis, Apr. 25, 1871; son of Julius and Kate (Schroeder) Frielingsdorf; educated in public schools and polytechnic school, graduating from latter, 1886 ; married, St Louis, Sept. 26, 1894, Ethel C. Bruce; two children: John, William Koken. Began as office boy in employ of Scherpe & Koken, the title of the house being changed successively to the Scherpe & Koken Architectural Iron Co., and the Koken Iron Works; vice president Banner Iron Works since 1901. Republican. Mason; member Royal Arcanum. Club: Century Boat. Recreations: fishing, bowling, rowing. Office: 4560 Shaw Ave. Residence: 4260 Flora Boulevard.

FRIER, Thomas John, purchasing and supply agent Wabash R. R.; born Keokuk, Ia., Feb. 12, 1866; son of John and Mary (Roach) Frier; educated in public and parochial schools, Keokuk, to 1883; married, Keokuk, Ia., Oct. 5, 1892, Anna Neyens; three children: John, Thomas, Elizabeth. Began railroad career May 1, 1883, and continued with Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railway Co. until 1909; successively, clerk in master mechanic's office, Keokuk, 1883-89; storekeeper, St. Joseph, Mo., June 1899-1901; supply agent of Missouri lines, at Hannibal, 1902-August, 1904; assistant supply agent, Chicago office, until 1907; general storekeeper entire Burlington System, 1907-09; since with Wabash R. R. as purchasing and supply agent, St Louis. Democrat. Catholic. Recreation: walking. Office: Title Guarantee Bldg. Residence: 5833 Julian Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni"]
fullentry: FRIES, William August, physician; boru, Mascoutah, HI., Jan. 12, 1861; son of John and Catherine (Oberling) Fries; attended Jefferson (public) School near Fayetteville, Ill., 1866-75, Franklin (public) School, Belleville, Ill., 1876-77; Medical Department of Washington University, M.D., 1883; married, St Louis, Oct. 3, 1888, Katie Dehner; children: Armand, William, Jr. Assistant physician City Hospital, 1883-84; since 1884 engaged in practice in St Louis. President and treasurer South Broadway Pharmacy since 1892. Member American Medical Association, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni. Republican. Protestant. Office: 1544 8. Broadway. Residence: 3209 Shenandoah Ave.

company: George J. Fritz Foundry and Machine Co.
fullentry: FRITZ, Emile Henry, secretary and treasurer George J. Fritz Foundry and Machine Co.; born St Louis, July 21, 1875; son of George John and Minnie (Weisel) Fritz; educated in public school; Educational Institute; Smith Academy; Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, St Louis, June 9, 1909, Josephine Lang; one son: James Laug. In 1892 engaged m service of Union Casualty and Insurance Co., as assistant bookkeeper until Feb. 17, 1898, when became secretary and treasurer of George J. Fritz Foundry and Machine Co., manufacturers of engines, boilers, laundry machinery and general machine-shop work. Independent in politics. Protestant. Member Liederkranz. Odd Fellow. Favorite recreation: bowling. Office: 2008-2028 S. 3rd St. Residence: 3422 Magnolia Ave.

office: 705 Olive St. Residences: 6327 Westminster PI. and 722 Hamilton Ave.
memberships: ["Missouri State Bar Association","Law Library Association","Civic League"]
fullentry: FRUMBERG, Abram M, lawyer; born To-wanda, Bradford Co., Pa., Mar. 30, 1875; educated Susquehanna Collegiate Institute; A.B., Lehigh University, 1892; student Columbia Law School, one year; LL.B., New York Law School, 1895; married Lillian Nebenzahl, of New York City, Apr. 6, 1896. In offices of Judge George M. Van Hoesen, New York City, until 1898; since in practice in St Louis. An authority in law of the theater; has been actively identified with congressional contest cases, naturalization fraud cases, etc. Served as special judge Court of Criminal Correction, 1906 and 1907. Member Missouri State Bar Association, Law Library Association, Civic League. Democrat. Member Temple Israel. Member Pennsylvania Society. Club: Columbian. Recreations: fishing, hunting, golfing. Office: 705 Olive St. Residences: 6327 Westminster PI. and 722 Hamilton Ave.

FRUTH, Andrew, monuments; born in Rhenish Palatinate (Rheinpfalz), Germany, Sept. 23, 1849; son of Jacob and Christina (Muhler) Fruth; graduate of public schools and business college of Speyer-on-Rhine, Bavaria, Germany; married, Belleville, Ill., Oct. 21, 1873, Caroline, daughter of William Brandenburger, children: Dr. Otto J., Herman A., Hilda. When fourteen years of age began business life as clerk in law and real estate office of Counselor George P. Suess, Speyer, Germany, remaining with him until 1868, when came to United States; became clerk in mercantile business, Belleville, Ill., advanced to manager of George A. Bradford's store until 1872, when resigned to join Henry J. Filsinger in present firm of Filsinger & Fruth, manufacturers and dealers in marble and granite monuments, St Louis. Republican. Evangelical Protestant. Member Liederkranz. Mason. Recreation: music. Office: 1617 Washington Ave. Residence: 3066 Hawthorne Boul.

memberships: ["National Dental Association","Missouri State Dental Association (former president)","St Louis Society of Dental Science (ex-president)","St Louis Dental Society (vice president)"]
fullentry: FRUTH, Otto J., dentist; born St Louis, July 7, 1874; son of Andrew and Caroline (Brandenburger) Fruth; educated in public schools to 1889; then three years in St Louis Manual Training School, graduating, 1892; entered Scientific Department of Washington University, two years' term, ending 1904; then entered Dental and Medical Department, graduating in dentistry, D.M.D., 1897, and in medicine, M.D., 1898; married, St Louis, Feb. 12, 1910, Helen M. Gempp; one child: Helen Marie. Practiced dentistry since 1898; professor of porcelain dental art Barnes Dental College, and treasurer same college. Member National Dental Association, Missouri State Dental Association (former president), St Louis Society of Dental Science (ex-president), St Louis Dental Society (vice president). Republican. Member Compton Hill Council, Royal Arcannm. Clubs: Union, Liederkranz. Recreations: travel and art. Office and Residence: 3060 Hawthorne Boul.

FRY, Francis Rhodes, physician; born Cincinnati, O., Oct. 1, 1853; son of Rev. Benjamin St. James and Eliza M. (Baldwin) Fry; educated in public schools; Smith Academy; A.B., Ohio Wesleyan University, 1877, A.M.; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1879; married, Keokuk, Ia., Mar. 15, 1900, Emily Net-tleton H&mill; children: Edwin St. James, Elizabeth Valle. After graduation in medicine was interne of City Hospital one year; in general practice of medicine in St Louis since 1881; professor of nervous diseases in Medical Department of Washington University. Member medical staff St. Luke's Hospital and Martha Parsons Hospital. Member American Neurological Association, American Medico-Psychological Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Clubs: University, Bellerive. Recreations: golf, motoring. Office: 505 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 4609 McPherson Ave.

company: Charles F. Luehrmann Hardwood Lumber Co.
fullentry: FRY, Thomas W., secretary Charles F. Luehrmann Hardwood Lumber Co.; born Minneapolis, Minn., July 29, 1868; son of Thomas W. and Jessie Comigys (Snyder) Fry; educated in public schools of Cairo, HI., and Louisville, Ky.; married, St Louis, June 29, 1898, Jessie Calvert Willcox (died, Mar. 12, 1912); children: Jessamine W., Thomas W. and Marie Louise (all deceased), William Willcox, Isabel Marie, Fanita Marie. Began business career as office boy with J. J. Sylvester, coal merchant, 1884-86; with Consolidated Coal Co., then with Tennessee River Packet Co., as clerk; entered lumber business Sept. 1, 1889, with Russell-Massengale Commission Co., remaining two years; employed by the Charles F. Luehrmann Hardwood Lumber Co., of which became stockholder in 1897, and secretary and director since 1900; director Indiana & Arkansas Lumber and Manufacturing Co., Marianna, Ark.; treasurer Wayne Manufacturing Co., St Louis; director of L'Augnelle Railroad Co. Republican. Episcopalian. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreation: billiards. Office: 148 Carroll St. Residence: 5452 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["Civic League","St Louis Society of Social Hygiene","St Louis and Missouri State Social Service Conference; member committee of nine to organize Central Council of civic organizations of St Louis; appointed by Mayor F"]
fullentry: FUCHS, Walter H., physician and surgeon; born St Louis, Sept. 21, 1869; son of Carl E. and Agnes L. (Guether) Fuchs; educated in public schools of St Louis; Toensfeld's Educational Institute; Manual Training School, Washington University; Washington University, 1888-89; M.D., Beaumont Hospital Medical College, 1891; married, St Louis, May 10, 1898, Paula Fallenius; two children: Ralph Fallen, Lola. In practice in St Louis since 1891; junior surgeon Missouri-Pacific Railway Hospital, April-October, 1890; junior interne St Louis City Hospital, April, 1891-April, 1892; assistant surgeon St. Mary's Infirmary, April, 1892-November, 1893; first assistant surgeon and gynecologist, Woman's Hospital, 1894-99; editor publications of St Louis Medical Society, 1893-96. Republican. Member Civic League, St Louis Society of Social Hygiene, St Louis and Missouri State Social Service Conference; member committee of nine to organize Central Council of civic organizations of St Louis; appointed by Mayor F. Ill Kreismann as member St Louis Board of Health, June, 1911. Unitarian; member board of trustees of Compton Hill Congregational Church; member board of councilors Drury Academy, Springfield, Mo. Member American Medical Association, etc. Clubs: City, Public Question. Recreations: sociology, music, tennis. Office and Residence: 3202 Lafayette Ave.

FULLER, Aaron, vice president Stix, Baer & Fuller Dry Goods Co.; born in Baden, Germany, Mar. 22, 1858; son of Leopold and Caroline Fuller; educated in public schools in Germany; married, Chicago, Ill., Sept. 6, 1885, Freda Baer; children: Leo, Corinne. Came to United States in 1873 and was located in Chicago until 1880, when went to Fort Smith, Ark.; clerked in dry goods stores in Chicago and Fort Smith; started on own account in 1880, with Julius A. and Sigmund Baer, as Baer Bros. & Fuller, proprietors of the 4‘Boston Store," Fort Smith, Ark.; became member of Stix, Baer & Fuller Co., proprietors of the 44Grand Leader," St Louis, 1892, and removed permanently in 1894 from Fort Smith to St Louis. President Boston Store, Fort Smith, Ark. Member Business Men's League. Republican. Jewish religion. Mason (32°). Clubs: Columbian, Mercantile, Glen Echo Country, Westwood Country. Recreation: golf. Office: Cor. Broadway and Washington Ave. Residence: 32 Washington Terrace.

memberships: ["(and ex-president) Missouri State Dental Association","St Louis Dental Society","Society of Dental Science","St Louis (honorary)","American Dental Association","National Dental Association","Hlinois State Dental Society","Iowa State Dental Association"]
fullentry: FULLER, Albert Homer, dentist, retired; born in Berkshire Co., Mass., Oct. 14, 1841; son of Albert and Julia (Judd) Fuller; attended Castleton (Vt.) Seminary, 1853, Troy Conference Academy, Poultney, Vt., 1854, Academy North Granville, N. Y., 1855, and grammar and high schools at Warsaw, Ill., until 1860; graduated from St Louis Medical College, M.D., 1872, and from the Missouri Dental College, D.D.S., in same year. Served in 118th Illinois Infantry Volunteers from August, 1862, until October, 1865. Engaged in practice of dentistry in St Louis from 1872 until retired from active practice, 1906. Was professor of operative dentistry in Missouri Dental College (now Dental Department of Washington University) and dean of same, for two years previous to resignation, until resigned in 1901; for several years emeritus professor of operative dentistry. Member (and ex-president) Missouri State Dental Association, St Louis Dental Society, Society of Dental Science, St Louis (honorary), American Dental Association, National Dental Association, Hlinois State Dental Society, Iowa State Dental Association. Member Missouri Historical Society. Residence: 4004 Delmar Boulevard.

FULLERTON, Baxter P., clergyman; born Pleasant Hope, Mo., Mar. 20, 1851; son of Andrew W. and Harriet A. (Landreth) Fullerton; educated McGee College, Missouri, 187174; Drury College, Missouri, 1874-76, A.M.; B.D., Cumberland University, Tennessee, 1879; (D.D., Drury, 1887; LL.D., Central University of Kentucky, 1908); married, Kirksville, Mo., Dec. 14, 1881, Callie L. Mitchell; two children: Hugh M., probation officer of Juvenile Court of St Louis, and Lucile. Ordained Cumberland Presbyterian ministry, 1876; pastor Kansas City, Mo., 1879-91, Lucas Avenue Church, St Louis, 1891-1906; field secretary Board of Home Missions for District of the South and Southwest since 1906. President Cumberland Presbyterian Board of Mission?, 1894-1906; editor Missionary Record, 18991907; moderator Presbyterian General Assembly, 1908; president of board of Presbyterian Theological Seminary of the South, Cincinnati; trustee Linwood College, St. Charles, Mo. Was member Board of Freeholders, 1885, that made present charter of Kansas City. Mason; member Royal Arcanum. Recreation: athletics. Office: Odd Fellows Bldg. Residence: 6128 Kingsbury Boul.

memberships: ["Civic League","St Louis Symphony Society","Sigma Chi fraternity"]
fullentry: FULLERTON, Hugh Mitchell, chief probation officer Juvenile Court; born Kansas City, Mo., May 11, 1885; son of Baxter P. and Callie (Mitchell) Fullerton; educated in St Louis public schools, graduated from Central High School, 1904; then entered Washington University, graduating, A.B., 1908; married, Chicago, May 8, 1912, Miss Mariquita Simpson. Continuously with Juvenile Court since graduation; deputy probation officer, 1908-10, chief probation officer since October, 1910. Presbyterian. Member Civic League, St Louis Symphony Society, Sigma Chi fraternity. Club: City. Recreations: outdoor diversions, music. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg. Residence: 6036 Washington Ave.

FULLERTON, Samuel Holmes, president Chicago Lumber and Coal Co.; born Belfast, Ireland, Apr. 22, 1852; son of Samuel and Anna (Holmes) Fullerton; educated in public schools in Ireland; married, Tecumseh, Neb., Jan. 17, 1877, Lucy Cook; children: Robert W., Ruby L. (Mrs. W. G. Horton, New York), Samuel Baker. Came to United States in 1871 and began with Robert Marshall, lumber dealer and contractor, Pittsburgh, Pa. In same line at Tecumseh, Neb., two years; then went to Kansas, where remained until 1896, when came to St Louis after a successful business career of twenty years in lumber business at Atchison, Kan.; now president and general manager Chicago Lumber and Coal Co., established 1866, and incorporated, 1895, with paid-up capital of $6,500,000, company owning and operating mills in Arkansas, Mississippi, Louisiana, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Idaho and Washington. Also president Gulf Lumber Co., Bradley Lumber Co., William Farrell Co., British-American Mills and Lumber Co., Brown Lumber Co., Chicago Lumber and Coal Co. (of Texas), Fullerton & Stewart Lumber Co., Powell Hardwood Lumber Co., Chicago Gulf Export Lumber Co. President Fullerton-Moses Tie Co., Schultz Lumber Co., Silver Lake Manufacturing Co., Gulf & Sabine Railroad Co., Warren, Jonnsville, Sabine R. R., Little Rock, Sheridan & Sabine River Ry. Vice president Wells Lumber Co., Colonial Lumber and Timber Co., Tioga & Southern Railway Co. Director Third National Bank of St Louis. Member Business Men's League. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Glen Echo Country, Commercial, Maine Hunting and Fishing. Office: 506 Olive St. Residence: 4569 W. Pine St.

FULTON, Albert, physician and surgeon; born Bloomington, Ill., Nov. 4, 1857; son of David R. and Dorothy (Ogden) Fulton; educated in public schools in Illinois; Add Ran College, Hood Co., Tex.; St Louis College of Physicians and Surgeons, M.D., 1883; married, St Louis, 1895, Laura Ford Elms; one daughter: Dorothy O. Since graduation in 1883 continuously engaged in practice of medicine in St Louis; professor of mental and nervous diseases in College of Physicians and Surgeons.
