READ, Benjamin Stalker, general manager Bell Telephone Co. of Missouri; born Carthage, Tenn., Jan. 21, 1876; son of Thomas Benton and Alice Treadway (Johnson) Read; educated in public schools; married, Carthage, Apr. 20, 1899, Sallye Berry Stevens; two sons: Charles Joseph and Ben S., Jr. Entered service of Cumberland Telegraph and Telephone Co., as toll station attendant and messenger boy, October, 1889; afterwards made manager at Carthage and still later was in general offices at Nashville, Tenn., manager at Owensboro, Ky., New Orleans, La., and division superintendent for Southern Mississippi and state of Louisiana; was elected general manager Missouri Bell Telephone Co., Mar. 1, 1912, and has since occupied that position. Member Business Men's League. Trustee Christian High School, New Orleans. Democrat. Member Christian (Disciples) Church. Royal Arch Mason; member Knights of Pythias, W. O. vV., also Jovian. Clubs: Mercantile, City, Million Population. Recreations: outdoor sports. Office: 611 Locust St.

READ, Edward Mason, pianos and organs; born in Chittenden Co., Vt., July 25, 1846; son of Hon. David and Emily (Marsh) Read; educated in public schools, and musical education received in East, studying organ and composition with S. B. Whitney of Boston; married, Plattsburgh, N. Y., April 24, 1873, Elizabeth S. Platt; children: Grace Van Wyck (wife of Rev. H. I). Hannum, Superior, Wis.), Marie Platt (Mrs. H. S. Gardner), Edward Mason, Jr., Sarah Ferris (Mrs. John Bryant Reinhart). Went to Chicago from Burlington, Vt., and after service in company's Chicago branch, came to St Louis in 1879 as manager of the St Louis house of The Estey Co., Estey pianos and organs, and has so continued ever since. Church organist and composer of music for pipe organ and piano. Republican. Presbyterian. Office: 1116 Olive St. Residence: 5649 Cates Ave.

REARDON, James A., wholesale glue, etc.; born Quincy, Ill., July 17, 1860; son of Michael J. and Amelia (Burns) Reardon; educated in public schools until fifteen; married, St Louis, June 6, 1883, Margaret Kilcullen; children: Robert E., James Ambrose, Jr., Joseph Vincent, Marguerite, Genevieve, Catherine. Began business career as porter in wholesale glue house in St Louis, 1878, in which became shipping clerk, 1879-81; salesman, 1881-84; manager, 1884-91; since 1891, president of Reardon Manufacturing Co., manufacturers and wholesale jobbers of glue, curled hair, cold water paint, sand-paper, etc. Ex-president Latin-American Club; ex-president St Louis Furniture Board of Trade; organized and brought over Irish exhibit to World's Fair. Democrat. Roman Catholic. Club: Papyrus (vice president). Collector rare books, first editions, etc. Office: 1531-1533 North Broadway. Residence: 519 N. Newstea-d Avenue.

REASOR, William Edward, manager Draughon's Business College; born Edna, Kan., Aug. 22, 1879; son of William and Mil-icent (Hammer) Reasor; B.S., Ohio Valley College, Sturgis, Ky., 1898; married, Louisville, Ky., Apr. 13,1904, Ethel Hulda Renz; two children: Gertrude Renz, Charles Hayden. In grocery business, Sturgis, Ky., 1897; with various business colleges until 1902; principal, bookkeeping department Draughon's College, St Louis, 1902-03; bookkeeper Donovan Commission Co., 1904-05, Celia Commission Co., 1906; president Reasor-Rappel Mercantile Co. (three stores), 1907-09; in real estate business with C. E. Hayden, 1909-10; manager Draughon's Practical Business College, since 1910; also in real estate business (subdivision, Maple Place, No. 3). Democrat. Baptist. Member Bridgeton Lodge No. 80, A. F. & A. M. Club: Masonic. Recreation: landscaping and gardening. Office: 611 N. Broadway. Residence: Thomas Sta., Wellston.

REBER, Charles S., lawyer; born St Louis, Aug. 18, 1870; son of Samuel aud Margaret M. (Reese) Reber; educated public schools; Smith Academy, 1887; A.B., Washington University, 1891; St Louis Law School; unmarried. Admitted to bar, 1893, and since in general practice; is associated in practice with Isaac H. Lionberger. Served two months in Signal Corps, Spanish-American War. Republican. Episcopalian. Member St Louis Bar Association. Clubs: Algonquin, Bellerive, Triple A. Recreation: outdoor athletic sports. Office: Rialto Bldg. Residence: 3630 Delmar Boul.

memberships: ["American Society of Civil Engineers","American Institute of Electrical Engineers","St Louis Engineers' Club","St Louis Academy of Science"]
fullentry: REBER, Henry Linton, vice president and general manager Kinloch Telephone System; born St Louis, Aug. 18, 1870; son of Samuel and Margaret M. (Reese) Reber; educated in public schools, Smith Academy, class of 1888, and Washington University, C.E., 1893; unmarried. Began business career as draughtsman in water department of City of St Louis, 1893, and in same year with chief engineer's office, Union Pacific System, as assistant engineer; from 1896 to 1897 identified with enterprises of Charles H. Ledlie, consulting engineer; then with St Louis Electric Construction Co. as engineer, 1897-98; secretary and chief engineer Kinloch Telephone Co., 1899-1901; secretary and general manager same company, 1901-09; vice president and general manager Kinloch Telephone System since 1909. In United States military service, as captain Third H. S. Volunteer Engineers in Spanish-American War, 1898-99; captain Company 15, posse comitatus, during 1900. Member American Society of Civil Engineers, American Institute of Electrical Engineers, St Louis Engineers' Club, St Louis Academy of Science. St Louis Merchants' Exchange, Business Men's League, Military Order of Foreign Wars. Independent Republican. Episcopalian. Clubs: University, Mercantile, City, Algonquin, Bellerive, Aero Club of America. Favorite recreation: outdoor sports. Office: Kinloch Bldg. Residence: 3630 Delmar Boul.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Law Library Association","Delta Psi Fraternity"]
fullentry: RECTOR, James Alcorn, lawyer; born Hot Springs, Ark., June 22, 1884; son of Elias William and Rosebud (Alcorn) Rector; educated, public schools of Hot Springs; Speers Lankford Military Academy, Searcy, Ark.; Lawrenceville School, Lawrenceville, N. J., graduating 1906; Law Department, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va., graduating with degree of LL.B., 1909; unmarried. Admitted to bar, 1909, and began practice at Hot Springs, Ark.; located in St Louis, 1910; practiced as member firm of Taliaferro, Rector & Taliaferro until Oct. 1, 1911, since alone; secretary and treasurer Logan Ventilating Window Co. Democrat. Methodist. Member St Louis Bar Association, Law Library Association, Delta Psi Fraternity. Lecturer on *4 Sales,'' in City College of Law and Finance. Member Masonic Order, Elks. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreation: athletics. Member American Olympic Team, London, 1908; coholder of world's record for 100 yards dash in 9 3-5 seconds. Office: Third National Bank Bldg. Residence: 4324 Maryland Ave.

memberships: ["Premier Lodge Knights of Pythias","United Commercial Travelers"]
fullentry: REDDING, Charles Justus, president Redding Feather Manufacturing Co.; born Bryan, O., Apr. 28, 1875; son of David and Jenette (Simonds) Redding; removed to Kansas City, Mo., at age of eight years and attended public schools there; came to St Louis, 1896, and took commercial course in the old Southwestern Business College; married, Anna Scheidig, of St Louis, May, 1897; one daughter, Estelle. Began manufacturing millinery feathers, 1899 (the first enterprise of the kind west of New York); incorporated the business as the Redding Feather Manufacturing Co., June, 1911. Independent in politics. Unitarian. Member Premier Lodge Knights of Pythias, United Commercial Travelers. Recreation: baseball. Office: 19th and Locusts Sts. Residence: 4609 Page Boul.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","St Louis Verein Deutscher Aerzte","Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni","American Association of Gynecologists and Obstetricians","Missouri State Medical Association","American Medical Association","8t"]
fullentry: REDER, Francis, surgeon; born New Athens, Ill., Jan. 9, 1864; son of Franz (M.D.) and Theresa (Dietz) Reder; educated in public school, New Athens; private school, Belleville, Ill.; Washington University, St Louis; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1884; in European universities, 1888-91; married, Quincy, Ill., June 23, 1897, Ella Castle; children: Eloise, Dorothea, Francis. House surgeon, City Hospital, 1884-85, and Female Hospital, 188586, St Louis; German Hospital, New York, 1886-88; since 1891 engaged in surgical practice in St Louis; chief of clinic diseases of rectum, in Medical Department, Washington University, 1899-1911; consulting surgeon of Wabash and Burlington railroads; visiting surgeon, City Hospital; surgeon, Missouri Baptist Sanitarium. Member St Louis Medical Society, St Louis Verein Deutscher Aerzte, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni, American Association of Gynecologists and Obstetricians, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association, 8t. Louis Surgical Club, Association of Military Surgeons, Southern Surgical and Gynecological Society; first lieutenant Medical Reserve Corps, H. S. A. Republican. Mason. Club: Army and Navy (Washington, D. C.). Recreations: art, music and sports of the field. Office: King's Highway and Delmar Boul. Residence: 4629 Cook Ave.

REEDY, William Marion, editor and proprietor The Mirror; born St Louis, Dec. 11, 1862; son of Patrick and Ann (Marion) Reedy; educated in public schools, Christian Brothers Academy and St Louis University, receiving degree of Master of Accounts from latter, 1880; married. Began business career as reporter on the Missouri Republican, now the Republic, and for many years special writer on the Globe-Democrat and other papers. Since 1893 editor, and since October, 1896, editor and proprietor St Louis Mirror. Independent, with Democratic leanings. Roman Catholic. Office: Syndicate Trust Bldg. Residence: Clonmel Farm, Webster Groves, Missouri.

BEHEIS, John Alois, president St Louis Lumber Co.; born in St Louis County, Mo., Feb. 8, 1867; son of Jacob and Susan (Ziegler) Reheis; educated at St. Vincent Schools, St Louis; married, St Louis, 1892, Emma Dreher; one daughter, Marie. Began business career in 1880 with George A. Rubelmann Hardware Co., continuing as clerk for two and a half years, then for two and a half years with H. A. Hyatt, photographic supplies; then entered employ of John J. Ganahl Lumber Co., as assistant bookkeeper, and continued fifteen years, the last ten years as vicepresident; then organized Reheis-Rolfes Lumber Co. in 1900, and in 1903 consolidated it with the Eau Claire-St Louis Lumber Co., wholesale and retail lumber, of which was vice president until 1905, when, upon death of Mr. Marbes, succeeded him as president of the company. Sold his interests in the company, 1906, and organized the Wilson, Reheis & Rolfes Lumber Co., of which was president until August, 1908, when this company consolidated with a number of other lumber companies as the St Louis Lumber Co., of which is president. Also director Broadway Investment Co. Member Business Men's League. Roman Catholic. Clubs: Lumbermen's, Sunset Hill Country, Arcadia Country. Favorite recreation: fishing. Office: 2509 S. Broadway. Residence: 3449 Pestalozzi St.

REHFELD, Gustave, chemist; born Berlin, Germany, Oct. 31, 1858; son of Charles R. and Henrietta (Langdon) Rehfeld; educated in high school (Das Graue Kloster), Berlin; graduated from University of Berlin, 1878 (D. Phil.); post-graduate work at University of Jena, Germany, and Ecole Chimique, Paris, France; circled globe in interest of archaeological studies, coming to United States in 1883; married, Waco, Tex., Feb. 1, 1890, Miss B. Bassist; children: Herbert Clarence, Hertha Belle, Walter Leon, Norma Beatrice. Located at Galveston, Austin and Waco, Tex., in pharmaceutical lines, 1883-97; traveled in South America, Central America and Mexico, 1897-1900; founded the Heptol Split Manufactory, Waco, Tex., 1900; removed plant and business to St Louis, 1903, where it was conducted as The Morrison Heptol Co., manufacturers of laxative waters, of which was secretary and treasurer; now chemist and superintendent of laboratory of Meyer Bros. Drug Co. Democrat. Mason. Office: 4th and Elm Sts. Residence: 4145 Laclede Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State","Tri-State and American Medical associations"]
fullentry: REHFELDT, Charles Sixtus, physician and surgeon; born, St Louis, Sept. 1, 1873; son of Charles and Constance Victoria Emma (Kaminsky) Rehfeldt; educated in public schools of St Louis and by private instruction; registered as pharmacist, State of Missouri, by examination, January, 1891; graduated from Missouri Medical College, 1896; unmarried. Engaged as pharmacist in St Louis, 1891-96; acting assistant surgeon, U. S. Marine Hospital and Public Health Service, Evansville, Ind., 1896-98; since in general private practice in St Louis; professor phvsical diagnosis American Medical College. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State, Tri-State and American Medical associations. Republican. Presbyterian. Recreation: traveling. Office and Residence: 2302 S. Jefferson Ave.

REHME, Henry R., banker; born St Louis, May 8, 1861; son of Gerhard and Louise (Holt-mann) Rehme; educated in St. Anthony's (parochial) School till was twelve years of age, and at Christian Brothers College until 1877; married, St Louis, Oct. 23, 1888, Catherine Lager; children: Martha, Joseph, Harry, Albert, Gregory. Began business career as clerk in retail grocery store in 1877, and after five years entered employ, 1882, of Continental National Bank, serving in various capacities until 1895, when opened real estate office, handling real estate and loans until 1899, when entered employ of St Louis Trust Co.; resigned, 1902, to become cashier of the Wellston Bank, Wellston, Mo.; resigned, July, 1905, to accept position as cashier in City National Bank of St Louis, remaining until 1910, when the bank merged with Central National Bank; organized the City Trust Co., of which was president until he sold interests and retired in October, 1911; since July 1, 1912, secretary and treasurer Farmers and Merchants Trust Co. Democrat. Catholic; member of several Catholic societies, and of Tower Grove Turn Verein. Recreations: driving and bowling. Office: Cor. Grand and Gravois Aves. Residence: 4127 Nebraska Ave.

REICHARDT, Oscar George, merchandise broker; born Mascoutah, Ill., Nov. 19, 1880; son of George and Louise (Storck) Reichardt; educated in public schools of St Louis and St Louis Mercantile College, graduating November, 1895; married, Feb. 14, 1911, Helen Morton Young. Began business life as salesman for Albach-Flach Commission Co., Nov. 9, 1896, until Mar. 23, 1903; on Apr. 1, 1903, joined in organization of the Rosen-Reichardt Brokerage Co., of which is vice president, the company doing a wholesale grocery brokerage and importing business. Republican. Protestant. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Union, Sunset Hill Country, Midland Valley Country, Liederkranz. Office: 800-804 Spruce St. Residence: Royal Astor Apts.

memberships: ["of Travelers' Protective Association","Catholic Knights of America"]
fullentry: REICHMANN, John, president Feuerborn Toy and Mercantile Co.; born, Trenton, Ill., Mar. 7, 1859; son of Joseph and Barbara (Reinbold) Reichmann; educated in public schools of Trenton, Ill.; married, St Louis, Sept. 25, 1883, Frances Bulla; children: Ella Louisa (Mrs. Frank P. Drees), Frances Sophia, John, Florence Bertha, Genevieve. Began business career as a delivery boy with Francis B. Meissner, book-seller, of St Louis; in 1878 became a clerk in the store of the H. P. Fabricius Toy Co., and afterwards was traveling salesman with the same company until 1894, when engaged in similar capacity with the Feuerborn Toy and Notion Co.; in 1904 joined in the organization of the Feuerborn Toy Co., incorporated, Jan. 1, 1905, title changed,1911, to Feuerborn Toy and Mercantile Co., of which he is president. Roman Catholic. Democrat. Member of Travelers' Protective Association, Catholic Knights of America. Favorite recreation: bowling. Office: 919 N. Broadway. Residence: 3215A Oregon Ave.

REID, Erastus F., president Seminole Chemical Co.; born Randolph Co., Ill., Mar. 22, 1854; son of Jerome J. and Margaret Ann (Ryan) Reid; educated in common schools; married,. Rockwood, Ill., 1888, Alice L. Walters (died 1902); one son, Earl E.; married, 2d, St Louis, 1906, Rebecca Besser. Learned blacksmith's trade and later employed as stationary engineer, St Louis; became member George W. Reid Oil Co., 1902; president Seminole Chemical Company since 1911. Republican. Presbyterian. Residence: 4856 Easton Avenue.

REID, George W., lubricating oils and greases; born Rockwood, Ill., Feb. 13, 1856; son of Joseph and Margaret A. (Ryan) Reid; educated in public schools of Rockwood; married, St Louis, 1884, Addie I. Luttrell; children: George L. (deceased), Ewing, Roger Edward, Ruth Ann. Came from Rockwood to St Louis, 1875; began business career with M. C. Bingnall & Co., plumbers' supplies, and afterwards N. O. Nelson Manufacturing Co., 187582; in 1882 began business of handling and compounding lubricating oils and greases, and incorporated the business in 1886 as Geo. W. Reid Oil Co., of which is president. Also, in 1903, with brother, J. Edward Reid, established firm of Reid Bros., agents for threshing machinery. Democrat. Favorite recreation: hunting. Office: 410 N. Main St. Residence: 4762 Cote Brilliante Ave.

REID, William Joseph, president T. J. Reid Shoe Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 22, 1863; son of M. W. and Laura (Hanly) Reid; educated in public schools of St Louis and at St Louis University, married, San Francisco, April, 1893, Jane Hughes; children: Rienzi, Roland, Marian, Genevieve, Thomas J., Lucille. After leaving school became salesman, and ten years later went to San Francisco and conducted a store, 1892-95; sold out and engaged as salesman for Baughman Shoe Co., and Mauzy & Reid Shoe Co., both wholesale, until June, 1904, when came to St Louis to visit the World's Fair; returned to California in Julvf but came back to St Louis to stay, November, 1904, becoming vice president of the T. .1. Reid Shoe Co., retailers, established 1.863, incorporated 1892; on death of brother, Thomas J. Reid, October, 1911, was elected president of the company. Member Retail Merchants' Association. Democrat. Catholic. Member Independent Order of Foresters, Knights of Columbus. Recreations: ffshing and driving. Office: 709-711 Washington Ave. Residence: Ferguson, Mo.

REIFSNIDER, Calvin Kryder, president Midland Publishing Co.; born Greentown, O.. Mar. 21, 1847; son of Joseph Graeff and Annie (Kryder) Reifsnider; educated, district schools and Mt. Union College, 1865-66; married, St Louis, Dec. 10, 1884, Anna C. Porter Ellis; children: Mrs. R. L. Scott, of St Louis. Mrs. G. A. Jewell, of Cincinnati, Mrs. F. W. Stanton, of Findlay, and two sons deceased. Served in Company B, 162d Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry, Civil War; taught school, and was connected with Aultman-Miller Reaper Works, Akron, O.; began newspaper work on Cleveland Daily Herald, 1870; came to St Louis, 1876; bought the Journal of Com merce, 1878, changed it to “The Age of Steel," and sold it out, 1883; founder, 1883, and since president Midland Publishing Co. Published the St Louis Miller, and the Indus trial Gazette, afterwards merged into 14 Farm Machinery"; publisher of Implement Blue Book, also of books written by wife: Unforgiven; How She Earned It, or $25,000 in Eleven Years; Saved by a Dream; Between Two Worlds; True Memory; Gilgal-Stones that Pave the Way. One of the founders of St Louis Trade Press Association and of Federation of Trade Press Associations. Independent Republican. Swedenborgian. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner; member Ran som Post, G. A. R. (commander, 1909 and 1910.) Recreation: principally automobiling. Office: 804% Pine St. Residence: 5249 Lindell Boulevard.

memberships: ["North St Louis Turn Verein","Knights of Pythias"]
fullentry: REINERT, Otto, president Gold Spring Distilling Co.; born Hanover, Germany, June 21. 1855; son of William and Augusta (Voss) Reinert; educated in gymnasium in Germany: married, St Louis, 1881, Ida Fette; children: Richard, Carl, Otto, Eraa (Mrs. Julius I. Leber). Resident of St Louis since 1873; began business career as salesman for E. R. Rice Mercantile Co., cigars, etc., then salesman for Becker, Niemann & Co., soap manufacturers, and as salesman for the G. Riesmeyer Distilling Co.; organized, 1881, the Gold Spring Distilling Co., of which is now president. Independent in politics. Catholic. Member North St Louis Turn Verein, Knights of Pythias. Club: Liederkranz. Office: 1106-1108 N. Broadway. Residence: 2928 Sullivan St.

REINHARD, Edwin F., president Shepard Baking Powder Co.; born Union, Mo., Aug. 10, 1869; son of Frederick W. and Pauline (Dress) Reinhard; educated public schools, Union, Mo.; Northern Indiana Normal Institute, Valparaiso, Ind., graduating 1890; State University, Columbia, Mo.; unmarried. Began active career as salesman for James W. Scudder & Co., 1890, continuing for five years; with Pennsylvania Salt Manufacturing Co., 1896-97; salesman Shepard Baking Powder Co., manufacturers of baking powder, 1897-1907, and president of same since 1907. Republican. Baptist. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 311 N. Main St. Residence: Union, Mo.

mnames: H.t chief weigher St Louis Post Office; born St Louis
office: born St Louis, Nov. 4, 1864; son of August and Katherine (Windhorst) Reinhardt; educated in St Louis public schools to 1881; married, St Louis, June 24, 1891, Minnie Deterding; two children: Nelson A. and Luella. After leaving school served three years in picture frame gilding trade with Pettis & Leathe, until 1883; then entered Government service in general post office and advanced through various branches; was supervisor Fair Grounds Station of post office during World's Fair, 1903-04; appointed to present position July, 1908. Financially interested in Reinhardt Improved Burial Vault. Republican. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Recreation: fishing. Office: St Louis Post Office.
fullentry: REINHARDT, John H.t chief weigher St Louis Post Office; born St Louis, Nov. 4, 1864; son of August and Katherine (Windhorst) Reinhardt; educated in St Louis public schools to 1881; married, St Louis, June 24, 1891, Minnie Deterding; two children: Nelson A. and Luella. After leaving school served three years in picture frame gilding trade with Pettis & Leathe, until 1883; then entered Government service in general post office and advanced through various branches; was supervisor Fair Grounds Station of post office during World's Fair, 1903-04; appointed to present position July, 1908. Financially interested in Reinhardt Improved Burial Vault. Republican. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Recreation: fishing. Office: St Louis Post Office. Residence: 2922 Greer Ave.

REINHARDT, John Washington, president John W. Reinhardt Stair Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 18, 1862; son of Jacob and Margarett (Mueller) Reinhardt; educated in Shepard and Lyon (public) schools; High Polytechnic, 7th and Chestnut Sts.; married, St Louis, September, 1895, Eleanor Bomberg; four children: Adah May, Lois Estelle, William Harvey, Edua Salinda. Began learning trade as stair builder, 1877; entered business for self, 1888, as the John W. Reinhardt Stair Co., of which has been president since incorporation, 1904. Republican. Congregationalist. Member City Industrial Association. Mason (Blue Lodge, Chapter, Commandery and Shrine). Club: American Wheel. Office: 25 S. 15th St. Residence: 5188 Vernon Ave.

REINHART, Emil Trodler, wholesale grocer; born Boonville, Mo., Dec. 20, 1862; son of Karl and Fredericka (Trodler) Reinhardt; graduated from Boonville (Mo.) public schools; married, Houston, Tex., June 6, 1899, Ida Bibb Johnson; children: Vivienne, Philip W. At age of seventeen entered employ of Hayward & Co., wholesale grocers, Hannibal, Mo., as traveling salesman, and a year later connected self in same capacity with Krafft, Holmes & Co., wholesale grocers, St Louis; later was house buyer and manager or James W. Scudder & Co., continuing until Feb. 1, 1902, when established the Reinhart Grocer Co., of which has since been president. Republican. Recreations: outdoor sports. Office: 501 5. 3d St. Residence: Ferguson, Mo.

REINHOLDT, Julius W., banker; boru, St Louis, Jan. 30, 1869; son of William and Marie (Sinner) Reinholdt; educated public and private schools; married, St Louis, Feb. 6, 1890, Frieda Barthel; three children: Julius W., Roland R., Charles A. Began as messenger National Bank of Commerce, 1887, and assistant cashier, 1898-1912; since vice president International Bank of St Louis. Republican. Presbyterian. Mason. Clubs: Liederkranz, St Louis, Union, Masonic, Bankers'. Recreations: fishing, billiards. Office: 222 N. 4th St. Residence: 3658 Cleveland Ave.

REIS, Charles Edwin, president Carondelet Planing Mill; born Shakopee, Minn., Apr. 19, 1868; son of Valentine and Josephine (Ap-feld) Reis; educated in parochial schools of Belleville, Ill., and Belleville public and high schools; married, St Louis, June 25, 1901, Sarah Mullen; two children: Charles E., Jr., and M. J. Alice S. Came to St Louis Aug. 3, 1891, and began in planing mill business, continuing until plant was destroyed by fire, July 8, 1905; built a new factory and engaged in local and shipping business, being president and treasurer of the company, manufacturers of sash, doors, blinds, etc. Democrat. Roman Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus. Recreations: ffshing and traveling. Office: 5826 S. Broadway. Residence: 5812 Michigan Ave.

REIS, Frederic Ernest, dry goods commission; born Brooklyn, N. Y., Dec. 10, 1859; son of Adolph and Rosalie Ada (Lowerre) Reis; educated in Brooklyn public schools and Shortledge's Academy, Kennett Square, Pa., graduating June, 1874; married, St Louis, Dec. 14, 1881, Ida Boyden; children: Gordon L., Frederic E., Jr., Arthur B. Began business career as assistant bookkeeper, Ingersoll Paint Co., New York, 1874; stock clerk, Lowenstein Bros., Memphis, Tenn., 1875; stock clerk, Rice, Stix & Co., Memphis, Tenn.; came to St Louis with them, 1879, and became buyer for same firm, 1883-99; vice president Dwyer Bros. Mercantile Co., 1899-1901; with Ferguson-McKin-ney Dry Goods Co., 1901-08; since treasurer Wagner & Reis Commission Co. Republican. Unitarian. Member Legion of Honor, Royal Arcanum. Recreations: whist, motoring. Office: 619 N. 8th St. Residence: 5144 Von Ver-sen Ave.

REIS, Henry F., lumber; born Shakopee, Minn., Feb. 21, 1800; son of Valentine and Josephine (Apfeld) Reis; educated in public schools of Minnesota; married, Belleville, Ill., 1889, Millie Ganahl; children: Valentine F., Edith P., Walter Charles (deceased), Oliver Vincent, Irwin Paul, Viola E., Jerome Henry. Regan business life as an associate of his father in the contracting and building business in Belleville, Ill., for ten years; came to St Louis, 1889, and engaged in the lumber business under firm name H. F. Reis & Co., in 1900; president the John J. Ganahl Lumber Co., 1903-08; since president II. F. Reis Lumber and Material Co. Also secretary Carondelet Planing Mill Co. Office: 5318 Virginia Ave. Residence: 6622 Michigan St.

memberships: ["St Louis Music Dealers' Association","Knights of Columbus"]
fullentry: REIS, Valentine Anthony, pianos and musical gcods; born St Louis, Sept. 20, 1874; son of Bartholomew and Bernerdine (Stein-weh) Reis; educated in public schools and business college; married, St Louis, Nov. 23, 1905, Emma Rcbou. Established a book and news depot at eighteen, of which was proprietor from 1893 to 1912; began as dealer in musical instruments, 1898, incorporated, 1907, as Val. Reis Piano Co., of which is president. Catholic. Member St Louis Music Dealers' Association, Knights of Columbus. Clubs: Catholic, Carondelet Motor Boat. Recreations: motoring and motor boating. Office: 1005 Olive St. Residence: 6037 Waterman Ave.

BEITH, Edward Benjamin, treasurer Adam Roth Grocery Co.; born St Louis, Dec. 17, 1857; son of Henry T. and Catherine (Arnold) Reith; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, 1878, Clara Zimmer; children: Chester Frazer, Ethel Louise, Edna Elizabeth (Mrs. P. H. Mead, Jr.). Began business career as collector with the Iron Mountain Bank for one year, then bookkeeper for International Bank one year; since 1879 with Adam Roth (established 1848) and his successor, Adam Roth Grocery Co., wholesale grocers, as, successively, bookkeeper, cashier, credit man, and, finally, since 1900, treasurer of the company. Republican in national politics. Member Legion of Honor, Royal Arcanum. Office: Cupples Block (433 S. 7th St.). Residence: 535 Linden Ave., Clayton, Mo.

KELLER, August H., cashier Bremen Bank; born St Louis, Mo., Feb. 25, 1867; son of August F. and Anna M. (Appel) Reller; educated in private school, public school and Jones Commercial College (graduated); married, St Louis, Aug. 22, 1895, Flora Gast; children: Oliver, Etta, Virginia. Began business career as a clerk in a retail grocery store; in 1884 became clerk in the Bremen Bank, now cashier. Republican. Lutheran. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Glen Echo Country, Franklin. Recreation: golf. Office: 3600 N. Broadway. Residence: 24 Gast PI.

REMBOLD, Henry, president H. Rembold Optical Co.; born Cologne, Germany, Dec. 12, 1808; son of Peter and Margaret (Westes) Rembold; came to United States, 1872; educated in public schools of Chillicothe, Mo.; married, St Louis, Oct. 20,1897, Fannie Gram-lich; children: Arthur, Gertrude, Margaret, Mamie, Elsa. Removed to St Louis, 1880; began business career with Blattner & Adams, opticians, 1882-88; then with A. S. Aloe, optician, one year; after that with Erker Bros. Optical Co., until 1902, when started for self, organizing H. Rembold Optical Co., of which is president. Catholic. Member Royal Arcanum, Tower Grove Heights Improvement Association. Favorite recreation: photo outings. Office: 512 Fine St. Residence: 3655 Connecticut St.

REMMERS, Theodore William, manufacturer; born St Louis, June 30, 1863; son of Henry B. and Martha Elizabeth (Yesberg) Remmers; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, May 27, 1891, Emma Prietzel; children: Florence Dorothea, Hilda Anna. Served apprenticeship at Felber Machine Works, St Louis; member Remmers & Whittaker, pattern makers, Kansas City, Mo., 1886-87; went east, 1887, and returned to St Louis, 1890, establishing, Feb. 1, 1890, the Remmers Pattern Co., of which was president until March, 1909; now president of the Dia-graph Co. (established Aug. 20, 1902), manufacturers of stencil cutting machines. Director Broadway Savings Trust Co. Republican. Protestant. Mason (32°). Recreation: fishing. Office: 2121 N. 9th St. Residence: 3513 Pestalozzi St.

RENABD, Louis, retired merchant; born Berlin, Germany, Oct. 1, 1854; son of Charles and Helene (Rosenstock) Renard; educated in private gymnasium at Berlin, Germany; married, St Louis, Feb. 6, 1905, Sallie Singer; children (by first wife): Helen (Mrs. Ill R. Putzel, of Denver, Colo.), Blanche, Wallace. Began business career as cash boy for two years; then, Apr. 4, 1867, entered employ of Trorlicht & Duncker, carpetings and curtain goods, as office assistant, and remained with same house in various capacities, becoming secretary of the Trorlicht, Duncker & Renard Carpet Co.; sold interests and retired, September, 1907; vice president Union Station Bank since February, 1909. Republican. Hebrew. Club: Columbian. Office: 12th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: 4463 Westminster PL

RENTH, Henry, treasurer Funsten Bros. Co., furs; born St Louis, Oct. 15, 1857; son of William and Catherine (Von Olt) Renth; educated in Eyser's Institute, St Louis public school, and St. Joseph's (parish) School; unmarried. Began business career at the age of thirteen as cash boy with Wm. Barr Dry Goods Co., then as general office man, continuing until 1883; became cashier for Funsten & Co., continuing until 1893, when the Funsten Bros. & Co., Inc., was organized and incorporated, of which is treasurer. Member Business Men's League. Independent in politics. Catholic. Member Goethe Gesellschaft, Weim-er, Germany. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Automobile. Recreations: reading and automobiling. Office: 2d and Elm Sts. Residence: 1813 Cora Ave.

RETON, Arthur Edwin, manager American Type Founders Co.; born Milwaukee, Wis., Jan. 28, 1869; son of John T. and Mary E. (Adams) Reton; graduated from public schools of Kansas City, Mo.; married, Washington, D. C., May 7, 1900, Frances M. Dewey. Began business career in the Kansas City Type Foundry, of which father was proprietor; started a printers' supply house in Kansas City, which was consolidated with the American Type Founders Co. in 1894; manager Kansas City branch of that company, 1894-97; since 1897 manager St Louis branch same company. Mason (32°). Republican. Member B. P. O. Elks. Office: 9th and Walnut Sts. Residence: Washington Hotel.

REUTER, Philip George, secretary and treasurer Reuter-Jones Manufacturing Co., special machinery and mill supplies; born Xashville, Ill., Jan. 21, 1876; educated in public schools and business college; married, Chamois, Mo., June 7, 1905, Margaret Crut-singer. Began business career as clerk Huege-ley Milling Co., Nashville, Ill., 1896; entered service of Government, 1898, and accompanied Commission to Five Civilized Tribes of Indian Territory; then for two years secretary and treasurer Canadian Trust Co., Muskogee, Okla.; assisted, 1905, in organizing the Reuter-.Tones Manufacturing Co., St Louis, of which has since been secretary and treasurer. Member National Metal Trades Association. Republican. Protestant. Office: 1607 S. 3d St. Residence: 2616 Louisiana Ave.

REX, William S., f president St Louis Bank Fixture Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 5, 1866; son of John and Mary E. (Hooper) Rex; graduated from St Louis University in class of 1880; unmarried. Began business career in 1880 with firm of Bearman, Heidelberg & Co., wholesale clothing, Xew York, 1880-84; came to St Louis in 1884, and was with Mack & Co., wholesale clothing, until 1886, when became connected with the St Louis Bank Fixture Co., with which has ever since been identified; in 1904, upon its incorporation, was elected to present position as president of the company. Democrat; member Democratic City Central Committee. Catholic. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 811 Walnut St. Residence: 317 Union Ave.

REXFORD, Ley Peterson, manufacturer; born Somerville, Mass., Jan. 1, 1876; son of Richard W. and Grace (Peterson) Rexford; educated in public schools of Philadelphia; married, St Louis, Oct. 12, 1905, Lucy Livingston Whitelaw; two children: Louise Augustine, Oscar Whitelaw. After leaving school served for several years in the Third National Bank; was secretary and treasurer of the American Roll Paper Co., 1906-07; president American Paper Cutter Manufacturing Co., 1907-10; president American Paper Products Co. since 1910. Republican. Presbyterian. Office: 2d St. and Bremen Ave. Residence: 3829 Westminster PI.

memberships: ["American Bar Association","Missouri and St Louis Bar associations","Law Library Association"]
fullentry: REYNOLDS, George Delachaumette, lawyer; born Gettysburg, Pa., Dec. 16, 1841; son of Rev. William M. (I).D.) and Anna (Swan) Reynolds; educated in public schools, Gettysburg and Allentown, Pa., and Springfield, Ill.; graduated from Illinois State University (then at Springfield, 111), A.B., 1861, A.M., 1866; enlisted as private in Second Illinois Light Artillery, 1861; mustered out in 1866 as lieutenant colonel, U. S. Volunteers; married, Louisiana, Mo., Oct. 10, 1876, Julia, eldest daughter of Augustus S. and Maria Vogdes; children; George V., James W* (died Sept. 19, 1911), Julia. Admitted to bar at Hannibal, Mo., October, 1867; settled at Potosi, Washington Co., Mo., 1867; circuit attorney, old Fifteenth Circuit, 1868-71; removed to St Louis, 1871; went to Colorado, 1874; settled at Boulder, Colo., and practiced there until 1877, when returned to St Louis; engaged in active practice until elected judge of the St Louis Court of Appeals in 1908, for a term of twelve years, which position he now holds, being presiding judge of the court. One of attorneys of Insurance Department of Missouri, 1877-81, and compiled, with W. S. Relfe and 8. M. Gilbert, the Revision of the Insurance Laws of Missouri, 1879; admitted to bar, Supreme Court, United States, 1881; H. S. attorney for Eastern District of Missouri, 1889-93. Member American Bar Association, Missouri and St Louis Bar associations, Law Library Association. Member G. A. R. (past commander Gen. Lyon Post, No. 2); companion Military Order Loyal Legion of the United States (past commander Missouri Commandery); member Tuscan Lodge, A. F. & A. M. In 1896 organized the Pennsylvania Society of St Louis and was its first president. Protestant Episcopalian. Club: Mercantile. Favorite recreations: fishing and sailing. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 4239 Lindell Boul.

REYNOLDS, Matthew Givens, lawyer; born Bowling Green, Mo., Nov. 19, 1854; son of Dr. Stephen J. and Sophronia (Givens) Reynolds; graduated IT. S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, Md., 1874; resigned from navy, 1877; studied law under Robinson & Smith, Bowling Green, and at St Louis Law School; admitted to bar, 1878; married, Louisiana, Mo., 1880, Mamie Fagg; eight children: Stephen Clark, Florence (wife of Guy Gruner, lieutenant U. S. A.), Alice (Mrs. Fred W. Mysenberg of New York), Mary, Matthew G., Jr., Robert Parker, Lucy Winn and John. Practiced at Bowling Green and Louisiana, Mo., and since 1886 at St Louis. Elected judge Circuit Court of St Louis, 1904; served four and one-half years, and resigned to reenter practice of law; member of firm of Reynolds & Harlan since 1909. Elected member Missouri House of Representatives from Pike Co., 1880; delegate Republican Xational Convention, 18H4; U. S. attorney Court of Private Laud Claims, 1891-1904. Mason, Knight Templar. Clubs: Mercantile, Racquet, City. Recreation: fishing. Office: 1105, 705 Olive St. Residence: St. Regis Apts.

RHODES, Mosheim, English Lutheran clergyman; born, Williamsburg, Pa., April 14, 1837; son of Peter and Catharine Rhodes; educated West Sunbury; graduated in theology, Susquehanna University, Selinsgrove, Pa., 1.861; (D.D. Wittenberg College, Springfield, O., 1878); entered ministry, 1861; married, May 4, 1861. Pastor Sunbury, Pa., 186165, Lebanon, Pa., 1865-69, St. Mark's Lutheran, St Louis, since 1871. President General Synod, Evangelical Lutheran Church, 1885-86; president Lutheran Board of Education; trustee United Societies of Christian Endeavor. Author: Life Thoughts for Young Men; Life Thoughts for Young Women; Vital Questions Pertaining to Christian Belief; also Expository Lectures on Epistle to the Philip-pians, etc. Address: 4414 Washington Ave.

RICE, Arthur Joseph, dry goods merchant; born Xew York City, Nov. 2, 1870; son of Henry and Rachel (Herman) Rice; was graduated from Columbia Grammar School, New York, 1888; matriculated at Columbia University and was graduated as chemist, degree of Ph.G., 1891; unmarried. Began active career in employ of Parke, Davis & Co., Detroit, as chemist, 1892, continuing, 1893, and until fall of 1894; identified with the Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co. since October, 1894, and member board of directors since 1908. Democrat. Jewish religion. Member Masonic Order, B. P. O. Elks. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood, City, Mercantile Libraray. Favorite recreations: golf, motoring and baseball. Office: 1000 Washington Ave. Residence: West End Hotel.

office: Suite 1508, Xew Bank of Commerce Bldg.
memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Academy of Science","Washington University Alumni Association","St Louis Law School Alumni"]
fullentry: RICE, Charles M., lawyer; born St Louis, Apr. 8, 1882; son of Jonathan and Aurelia (Stix) Rice; educated in St Louis public schools to 1898; Smith Academy, 1898-1900; then entered Washington University and graduated, A.B., 1904; graduated from St Louis Law School, LL.B., 1907; married, St Louis, Sept. 23, 1908, May Goldman; two children: Erna Sarah, Jay D. Goldman. Admitted to bar, 1906, and engaged in general practice with law firm of Lyon & Swarts; in partnership with Joseph W. Lewis as Lewis & Rice since March, 1909. Director School of Social Economy; secretary Jewish Hospital; treasurer St Louis Branch Boy Scouts of America; trustee Kingsbury Terrace and Kingsbury Place. Member St Louis Bar Association, Academy of Science, Washington University Alumni Association, St Louis Law School Alumni. Republican. Jewish religion. Clubs: City, Columbian, Westwood Country. Recreations: golf and fishing. Office: Suite 1508, Xew Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 51 Kingsbury Terrace.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association","American Medical Association"]
fullentry: RICE, Dell Frank, phy sician and surgeon; born Paw Paw, Mich., July 24, 1863; son of Xorman and Clarinda L. (Stone) Rice; educated in public schools of Paw Paw; Ph.C., College of Pharmacy, University of Michigan, 1885; M.D., Louisville Hospital College of Medicine, Louisville, Ky., 1892; married, St Louis, 1897, Ida Freudenstein; children: Lucille, Josephine, Norman, Ida Dell. Engaged in business as druggist at Louisville, Ky., 1885-93; came to St Louis in 1893, and since in general practice as physician and surgeon. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association. Mason. Office: Delmar Bldg. Residence: 5145 Cabanne Ave.

company: F. R. Rice Mercantile Cigar Co.
fullentry: RICE, Frank R., president F. R. Rice Mercantile Cigar Co.; born Mackinac Island, Mich., Jan. 20, 1843; son of Justin and Mary (Throop) Rice; educated in public schools, Detroit; married, Boston, Mar. 17, 1883, Emma F. Lock; two children: Kathleen (Mrs. 8. B. Sheldon) and Justin R. Began business career as a member firm of Rice & Byers, dealers in cigars and tobacco, St Louis, 1871; firm name changed to F. R. Rice & Co., 1879; in 1892 the business was incorporated as the F. R. Rice Mercantile Cigar Co., of which has since been president; director Mechanics-American National Bank. Republican. Enlisted as private in First Michigan Infantry, Apr. 18, 1861; served as private and commissioned officer, until wounded, and lost a leg at battle of Fredericksburg, Va., Dec. 13, 1862; was transferred to Veteran Reserve Corps, H. S. A., June 27, 1863, and remained in that corps until close of the war; was then commissioned as second lieutenant, Forty-fourth U. S. Infantry, and remained with the regiment until retired as captain, Jan. 15, 1871. Member Loyal Legion, Ransom Post, G. A. R. Club: Mercantile. Office: 305 X. 4th St. Residence: 3660 Lindell Ave.

memberships: ["New York Chamber of Commerce","Metropolitan Museum of Art"]
fullentry: RICE, Henry, merchant; born Bamberg, Bavaria, Germany, June 28, 1835; son of Seligman and Henrietta (Newman) Rice; educated in Polytechnic School and Realschule, Bamberg; came to United States in 1850; married, New York, Aug. 12, 1863, Rachel Herman; children: Samuel H. (deceased), Sol. J. (deceased), Arthur J., Jerome H., Fred D., Hilda (now Mrs. Horace S. Gumbel), Edna (now Mrs. L. B. Tim), Florence (now Mrs. Milton C. Blum). Was in New York City, 1850-53; in clothing business as Henry Rice & Co., Jacksonville, Ill., 1853-61; military storekeeper, U. 8. Army, 1861-62; established in dry goods business, Memphis, Tenn., in summer of 1862, in firm of Rice, Stix & Co., remaining there until 1879, when business was removed to St Louis, where it was later incorporated as Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co., of which was president, now chairman advisory board. Has lived in Netv York since 1866, and represents the firm in the East. Trustee for many years of Baron Hirsch Fund, which disburses about $300,000 yearly to Russian immigrants, and identified with many philanthropic and charitable organizations. Member New York Chamber of Commerce, Metropolitan Museum of Art. Republican; was one of Committee of Seventy that helped elect Colonel Strong as Mayor of New York in 1894; has served as commissioner of Board of Education, New York. Address: 377 Broadway, New York.

RICHARDS, Darius P., wholesale sterling silver, etc.; born Columbia, Mo., Aug. 30, 1876; son of Darius P. and Sophia P. Richards; educated in public and high schools of Columbia, Mo., and State University of Missouri; married at Kansas City, Mo., 1904, to Miss Gertrude Lucille Campbell; children: Ralph C., Darius P, Jr. Began business career as buyer for retail jewelry store of father, D. P. Richards, June, 1895, and served until his death, in March, 1897; in June, 1897, opened store under firm name of Richards & Hen-ninger, of which was president until sold, January, 1900, to Claud M. Wheeler, firm becoming Henninger & Wheeler; traveling salesman with A. J. Jordan Cutlery Co., September, 1900, to January, 1904, then manager of retail and city wholesale departments, same company, until Apr. 14, 1906; joined in organizing, Apr. 15, 1906, the Maschmeyer, Richards Silver Co., of which is secretary and treasurer. Clubs: Mercantile, Million Population, Sunset Hill. Office: 203 Carleton Bldg. Residence: 6157 Berlin Ave.

RICHARDSON, Ernest Herbert, men's furnishings; born in Forest of Dean, England, February, 1869; son of Thomas J. and Mary (Jones) Richardson; educated in private school in England and at Coronal Institute, San Marcos, Tex.; married, November, 1908, Xella, daughter of Dr. Frank Tracy. Went to Texas in boyhood, and after leaving school was in retail millinery business with his mother for six years in Texas; came to St Louis in 1891, entered service of T. B. Boyd & Co., importers, retailers and manufacturers of men's furnishings; in 1899 became junior partner of the firm; in 1904 the business of T. B. Boyd & Co. was incorporated under the title of T. B. Boyd Furnishing Goods Co., of which has since been vice president. Member Associated Retailers. Club: Mercantile. Office: Olive and 6th Sts.

company: Russell A. Richardson Real Estate Co.
fullentry: RICHARDSON, Russell A., president Russell A. Richardson Real Estate Co.; born Quincy, Ill., June 2, 1866; son of Charles R. and Meriba (Avise) Richardson; educated in Quincy public schools to 1882; married, St Louis, Oct. 3, 1894, Lucy E. I. Methudy; two children: Charles E., Russell K. After leaving school engaged with father in merchandising and cotton planting, Louisiana, until 1892; then removed to St Louis, and since engaged in real estate business; owner of several subdivisions. Member St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Protestant. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner; member B. P. O. Elks. Clubs: Liederkranz, Missouri Athletic. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 204, 706 Chestnut St. Residence: 1746 Waverly PI.

RICHARDSON, William Haerston, lumber; born Aberdeen, Miss., Sept. 1, 1858; son of Jack P. and Mary Louise (Meek) Richardson; educated in St Louis public schools. Started business career in 1885 as clerk for his father, under firm name of J. P. Richardson Lumber Co.; became member of firm of J. P. & W. Ill Richardson, 1898; on Aug. 1, 1904, was elected vice president Massengale Lumber Co., hardwood lumber; on death of his father, Apr. 30, 1910, he succeeded firm of J. P. & W. H. Richardson, and since operates in own name; also representative of Deco-Veneer Co., of Indianapolis. Republican. Mason; member Royal Arcanum, Order of Hoo Hoo. Office: 737 Century Building.

memberships: ["Merchants' Exchange (second vice president","1904-05","vice president","1905-06","president","1906-07); past first","second and third vice presidents St Louis Manufacturers' Association; member and past fourth vice president Business Men's League; member International Apple Shippers' Association","Xational League of Commission Merchants","Western Fruit Jobbers' Association"]
fullentry: RICHMOND, Manley Glencoe, wholesale fruits and produce; born Detroit, Mich., Mar. 12, 1857; son of Emerson and Mary (Cassidy) Richmond; educated in common schools of Oxford, Mich., and University of Michigan; married, St Louis, Aug. 22, 1888, Gillian Eudore Irish; children: Gillian I., Gladys L., Glendo-lyn M. After leaving university taught school in Oakland Co., Mich., for two years and was elected superintendent of schools of Oxford Township; then was bookkeeper to a produce firm in Detroit, two years; came to St Louis, in fall of 1881, and embarked in produce business as Richmond & Andrews, for one year, then for self, two years; since 1884 member firm of 8baw & Richmond; incorporated, 1890, as Shaw & Richmond Produce Co., of which is president. Member Merchants' Exchange (second vice president, 1904-05, vice president, 1905-06, president, 1906-07); past first, second and third vice presidents St Louis Manufacturers' Association; member and past fourth vice president Business Men's League; member International Apple Shippers' Association, Xational League of Commission Merchants, Western Fruit Jobbers' Association. Democrat. Mason, Knight Templar (Ivanhoe Commandery), Shriner. Office: 829 N. 3d St. Residence: 5666 Cabanne Ave.

RICKETTS, Alfred, president Alfred Ricketts Realty Co.; born London, Eng., Feb., 12, 1865; son of Charles and Martha (Levi) Ricketts; public school education; married, St Louis, Jan. 15, 1891, Clara Gerhard; two children: Charles E. and Virginia M. Came to America, 1886; assistant manager Browning, King & Co., clothiers, St Louis, 1886-1902; now president Alfred Ricketts Realty Co., Missouri Oolitic Stone Co.; secretary and treasurer Rio Grande Timber and Development Co., Active Investment Co., Walloon Investment Co. Member St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Democrat; judge of election, Sixth Precinct, Twenty-eighth Ward, ten years. Baptist; clerk, Third Baptist Church (membership 2,300) since 1905, also deacon. Member Modern Woodmen of America, National Union. Club: Apollo. Recreation, music. Office: 816 Olive St. Residence: 5632 Von Ver-sen Ave.

RIDDLE, Frank Coston, manufacturer of burial caskets; born Allegheny City, Pa., May 24, 1852; son of John Weaver and Eliza (Adams) Riddle; educated in public and private schools of Allegheny City, Pa.; married, Allegheny City, Mar. 7, 1878, Ada Lucene Layton (died May 14, 1879); married, 2d, St Louis, Feb. 28, 1883, Georgella Meredith. Began business career, 1868, in employ of Hamilton, Lemmon, Arnold & Co., manufacturers of coffins and caskets, Allegheny City; in 1870 was employed by Allegheny Savings Bank as teller; returned to employ of Hamilton, Lemmon, Arnold & Co. in 1874, as traveling salesman; located in New York, 1876, as manager of their business in New York and New England; came to St Louis, 1879, and engaged in same business on own account; formed copartnership with Robert M. Riddle, 1882, and continued under name of F. C. Riddle & Bro., until 1890, when business was incorporated as F. C. Riddle & Bro. Casket Co., manufacturers of burial caskets and jobbers of undertakers* supplies, of which is president. Director Jefferson Bank. Republican. Methodist. Mason, Knight Templar; member Royal Arcanum, Legion of Honor. Recreations: automobiling and golf. Office: 1400-1412 Hogan St. Residence: 4507 McPherson Ave.

residence: 5207 Lindell Boul. Summer Residence: Charlevoix, Mich.
memberships: ["board of trustees of First Presbyterian Church"]
fullentry: RIDDLE, George Treadway, president Franklin Bank; born St Louis, Feb. 22, 1847; son of Alexander and Mary E. (Treadway) Riddle; educated in grammar and high schools in St Louis; married, St Louis, Apr. 5, 1877, Fredericka Mohrenstecher; children: Gertrude F. (Mrs. Eben T. Bradbury), Edna M. (Mrs. Arthur B. Birge), Clara M. (Mrs. Edward A. Morse, Jr.), Georgia E. Began business career, 1863, as clerk in provost-marshal general's office in St Louis, remaining until end of war; clerk and bookkeeper with James and William Patrick, lumber merchants, 1865-70; secretary, 1870-78, of Mississippi Planing Mill Co., which was succeeded, 1878, by the Riddle-Rehbein Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of mill-work, packing boxes and interior finish for residences, of which is president and treasurer, active management of company being in the hands of his son-in-law, Eben T. Bradbury; president of Franklin Bank since Mar. 1, 1911. In 1902 formed the George T. Riddle Real Estate Co., for the purpose of holding the real estate acquired -during his business career, and is its president and treasurer; also president of Carthage Marble and White Lime Co. Republican. Presbyterian. Member board of trustees of First Presbyterian Church. Club: Bankers'. Office: Franklin Bank, 4th and Morgan Sts. Residence: 5207 Lindell Boul. Summer Residence: Charlevoix, Mich.

EIDGELY, Henderson, capitalist; born Springfield, Ill., Dec. 10, 1853; son of Nicholas H. and Jane Maria (Huntington) Ridgely; educated in Springfield public schools; married, Jan. 25, 1889, Emily S. Parker. Entered father's banking institution, Springfield, 1869; later came to St Louis and since engaged principally in real estate investments. Director Ridgely National Bank, Springfield, Ill.; large owner of St Louis and other property. Extensive traveler both in America and Europe. Member Provident Association. Clubs: Apollo and Amphion (associate member). Recreations: fishing, hunting, billiards. Residence: 5738 Von Versen Ave.

RIEFLING, Frank Joseph, lumber manufacturer; born St Louis, Nov. 18, 1877; son of John George and Anna Magdalen (Hennerich) Riefling; began attending school at Burford-ville, Mo.; moved to St Louis with parents and was student public and parochial schools and St Louis University; took course in bookkeeping and shorthand, Southwestern Business College; married, St Louis, Oct. 3, 1900, Kitty Buchanan; one son, Richard George, born Feb. 23, 1903. After experience in various lines of business became stenographer for A. P. Bollinger Co., at St Louis, February, 1896, and was connected with H. Lee Servoss in a similar capacity, 1897; was identified with the Missouri Lumber & Land Exchange, Kansas City, Mo., as stenographer and bookkeeper; went to company's mills at Grandin, Mo., to learn lumber trade, 1898; returned to St Louis, 1899, and worked for Chicago Coal and Lumber Co., until Mar. 1, 1901; then entered employ of George W. Miles Timber and Lumber Co., as stenographer and bookkeeper, advancing to secretary and general manager, which offices he now holds; also vice president Columbia Cooperage Co., Broadway Vehicle Co. Independent in politics. Catholic. Member Hoo-Hoo, Tower Grove Turn Verein. Recreations: fishing, hunting, motoring, amateur photography. Office: Wright Bldg. Residence: 3310 Magnolia Ave.

RIEFLING, John George, retired; born. Muelhausen, Germany, April 3, 1853; son or Henry and Christiana (Meinhardt) Riefling; went to St. Vincent School, St Louis, one year and five months; married, St Louis, July 13, 1875, Anna M. Hennerich; children now living: Frank Joseph, George Barnard, Harry Paul. Worked as stove moulder until 1881; in grocery and general merchandise business until 1885; in grocery and liquor business until 1901; then established Columbia Cooperage Co., of which was president until 1900, retired. Was one of founders of American Brewing Co., 1891. Democrat; postmaster at Burford-ville, Mo., 1883-85. Catholic. Recreations: literature and music. Residence: 2700 Russell Avenue.

RIGG, William Johnson, manager St Louis branch, Underwood Typewriter Co.; born Stratford, Ont., Can., June 4, 1868; son of William Johnson and Arabella (Harvey) Rigg; educated in public school of Stratford, until 1882; married, Newark, N. J., Sept. 28, 1902, Ella Ulrick; one son, Irving. After leaving school was dry goods clerk at Hamilton, Ont., until 1888; then was clerk with L. A. Smith Dry Goods Co., Detroit, for one and one-half years, then with Adam, Meldrum & Anderson, dry goods, Buffalo, N. Y., with American Writing Machine Co., in New York City, as salesman, the Hammond Typewriter Co., Chicago, the Remington Typewriter Co., St Louis, Jan. 2, 1896; then with the Underwood Typewriter Co., as salesman in Buffalo, N. Y., 1902, and in 1903 returned to St Louis and has since been manager of the company's house here. Democrat. Mason (32°). Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreations: hunting, fishing and athletic sports. Office: 115 N. 8th St. Residence: 4338 Laclede Ave.

RILEY, William Francis, contractor of municipal work; born St Louis, Dec. 28, 1863; son of William and Ann (Martin) Riley; edc ucated in public and parochial schools, 8t. Louis, to 1877; married, St Louis, Jan. 6,1886, Katherine Nolan; eight children: William A., Frank A., Loretto, Cecilia, Irene, John, Albert, Katherine. Began business career at St Louis, 1892, and continuously engaged in contract work until 1890; since president of The William F. Riley Construction Co., contractors for public works. Democrat. Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus, Royal Arcanum. Recreation: theatre. Office: 522-523 Victoria Bldg. Residence: 3640 Cook Ave.

RINAMAN, Ryon Lewis, banker; born in Muskingum Co., O., Feb. 28, 1866; son of Napoleon and Elizabeth Mary (Sibley) Rina-man; public school education; married, New Orleans, November, 1894, Nannie Reed; one daughter, Elizabeth G. Began as clerk in railroad office, continuing about two years; then in employ of wholesale grocery house at Springfield, Mo.; visited Pacific coast and Alaska, 1885-86; in various business enterprises, 1886-89; engaged in insurance business at Birmingham, Ala., and New Orleans, 188997; manager American Surety Co. of New York, at 8t. Louis, 1897-1901; secretary and treasurer Illinois State Trust Co., East St Louis, until 1908; secretary Illinois Bankers' Association, at Chicago, 1908-09; since vice president Title Guarantee Trust Co. and American Trust Co. Mason. Clubs: City, Bellerive (St Louis), Union League (Chicago). Recreations: motoring and golf. Office: 706 Chestnut St. Residence: 6182 Washington Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: RING, Frank, physician and surgeon; born St Louis, June 11, 1855; son of Edward W. and Mary (Roche) Ring; graduated from St Louis University, 1871, St Louis College of Physicians and Surgeons, 1892; married, 8t. Louis, 1887, Nellie Prendergast. Began business career as manufacturer of oils and refined lard in association with father from 1871 until death of father in 1877, then continued business alone until 1885, as Edward Ring & Sons; withdrew in 1885, and later began study of medicine; since graduation, in 1892, engaged in general practice as physician and surgeon. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Catholic. Recreation: travel. Office: 619 Chemical Bldg. Residence: 0218 Wagner Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange since its organization"]
fullentry: RING, John, exporter of provisions; born in County Cork, Ireland, June 12, 1841; son of Edward and Mary (Roche) Ring; educated in private schools in Ireland, and later attended St Louis University and Christian Brothers College, taking a course in chemistry; married, St Louis, Sept. 8, 1868, Katie M. O'Neil, daughter of the late Joseph O'Neil, president m of Citizens' Bank; children: Vincent P. (deceased), Catherine O'Neil (deceased), Ethel (deceased), John, Jr., Joseph, Genevieve, Mary (Mrs. Dr. Louis R. Padberg). Began business career in the pork packing establishment of father in 1855, and later became a partner in the business under firm name of Edward Ring & Sons, in which continued for years; more recently engaged on own account as shipper and exporter of lard, tallow, grease, etc. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange since its organization. Formerly engaged as inventor of double acting ammonia compressors, now used by manufacturers of ice machines in United States; now interested in an apparatus of his own invention for the purification and refrigeration of air in subways. Member Academy of Science of Philadelphia, Alumni Association of St Louis University. Roman Catholic. Office: 508 Chamber of Commerce. Residence: 3924 Westminster PI.

RIPPEY, John Denise, lawyer; born Lawson, Ray Co., Mo., May 2, 1876; son of Joseph T- and Talitha (Gordon) Rippey; attended public schools till 1891; A.B., Lawson College, 1895; A.B., LL.B., University of Missouri, 1899 (while there was member of Sigma Chi, Phi Delta Phi, and Theta Nu Epsilon fraternities); married Gertrude Christophel, Nov. 7, 1911. After graduation in law was admitted to bar, 1899, and has since engaged in practice in St Louis as Rippey & Kings-land. Member St Louis Bar Association. Office: 112 N. 4th St. Residence: 5906 Plymouth Ave.

memberships: ["board of directors Western Commercial Travelers' Association"]
fullentry: RITCHEY, Alexander Catlette, vice president Ferguson-McKinney Dry Goods Co.; born Pleasant Gap, Bates Co., Mo., Mar. 6, 1846; son of Leander Horace and Maria Duncan (Stark) Ritchey; lost father at age of seven years and family moved to Allen Co., Ky.; mainly self-educated, but possessed advantages of limited attendance at country schools of Ky.; married, Auburn, Logan Co., Ky., Feb. 24, 1869, Mary Elizabeth Catherine Veirs; children: John E. (now director Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co.), Mrs. A. W. Payne, Blanche (deceased), and Catherine V. Began working on farm at age of eleven, continuing until eighteen; clerk J. S. Procter & Co., general merchandise, Franklin, Ky., for one year; then moved to Auburn, Ky., for same firm; next went to Louisville, Ky., and attended commercial school for a short time; entered employ of R. H. Edelen & Co., jobbers of hats, Aug. 13, 1867, and went on road as salesman, traveling in Kentucky for ten years and in Texas for three years; with McCord-Boomer & Co., in same line of business, for sixteen months; was with the Gauss-Hunicke Hat Co. of St Louis from Jan., 1882, until became identified with the Gauss-Shelton Hat Co., remaining with latter concern until Jan., 1900; then assisted in organizing the Ferguson-McKinney Dry Goods Co., of which was one of the incorporators and is now vice president. Member board of directors Western Commercial Travelers' Association. Democrat. Baptist; treasurer Third Baptist Church Endowment Fund, and also of Missouri Baptist Sanitarium Endowment Fund. Member Tuscan Lodge No. 300, A. F. & A. M. Club: Mercantile. Recreations: chess and baseball. Office: Ferguson-McKinney Dry Goods Co. Residence: 6124 Kingsbury Boul.

RITTER, Edward P. V., real estate and financial agent; born Chester, Ill., Sept. 27, 1858; son of Valentine and Josephine Hortense (Paschali) Ritter; educated in St Louis public schools, Washington University and Bryant & Stratton Business College, St Louis; married, St Louis, June 25, 1884, Fannie Belle, daughter of Congressman W. U. Stone; children: Paschal Stone, Wesley Har-court. Began business life as clerk with the 4‘Famous" Shoe and Clothing Co., of which afterwards became successively cashier, bookkeeper, secretary, vice president and president. In 1892 engaged in the real estate business with Charles C. Nicholls; assisted in organizing the Nicholls-Ritter Realty and Financial Co., of which was vice president until the business was taken over by the Nicholls-Ritter-Goodnow Realty Co., and is vice president of latter corporation; also vice president St Louis, Lakewood & Grant Park Ry.; president Merchants' and Manufacturers' Exchange, a corporation of New York City, and president of the Floral Garden Development Co. of New York. Republican. Methodist. Mason (32°), Knight Templar. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: motoring. Residences: Jefferson Hotel, St Louis, and also New York City. Office: 718 Chestnut St.

RITTER, Otto Ludwig Reinhard, superintendent Hyde Park Brewery; born Wiesbaden, Germany, April 11, 1853; son of Hein-nck and Amalie (Ebenhach) Ritter; educated in elementary schools, Bavaria and Wurzburg; entered polytechnic school and continued studies until 1873; acquired knowledge of brewing business by service in breweries in Germany; married, Germany, 1880, Charlotte Boeder; two children: August, Emma. After leaving school engaged with Riedinger & Son Machine Factory, Augsburg, Bavaria, and continued until 1876; with Augsburg Machine Co., Bavaria, 1877-9; came to America, 1880; began business career, St Louis, 1880, and since continuously connected with Hyde Park Brewery. Mason. Office: 2110 Salisbury St. Residence: 3500 University St.

RIVET, Antoine Rush, financial and commercial editor of Globe-Democrat; born St Louis, Aug. 29, 1851; son of John and 'Gertrude (Koch) Rivet; educated in public schools and afterwards by private instructors* married, St Louis, 1883, to Miss Marie C. L'Ange; two sons: Ignatius L., Francis X. Began in newspaper work, 1874, and has been assigned to all departments and branches; has worked on all papers in the city; for several years engaged m the electrical business; took private instruction for three years in electricity. Since 1892, financial and commercial editor of Globe-Democrat. Associate member American Institute of Electrical Engineers. Catholic. Member St Louis League of Electrical Interests. Office: The Globe-Democrat. Residence: 7511 Pennsylvania Ave.

memberships: ["American Institute of Architects and St Louis Chapter same","Business Men's League"]
fullentry: ROACH, Harry F., architect; born, St Louis, May 7, 1871; son of H. E. and Sarah (Haley) Roach; educated in public schools and manual training school, St Louis, and at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston; married, St Louis, Mar. 8, 1893, Mary E. Gallup; children: M. Constance, John G. (deceased), Mildred E. (deceased), Harry F., Jr., Alden G., Dorothy E. Began practice as architect in spring of 1891; member firm of H. E. Roach & Son, 1891-1900, since alone. Member American Institute of Architects and St Louis Chapter same, Business Men's League. Baptist. Club: City. Recreations: study of railroad mechanical devices and music. Office: Syndicate Trust Bldg. Residence: 3812 Flora Boul.

memberships: ["St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations"]
fullentry: ROBBINS, Alexander Henry, Jr., lawyer and law publisher; born St Louis, June .21, 1875; son of Alexander H. and Annie (Robinson) Robbins; graduated from Divoll Grammar School, 1890, Central High School, 1894, Washington University and St Louis Law 8chool, LL.B., 1898; married, St Louis, Feb. 20, 1903, Katherine Gundelfinger; one daughter, Mary Robbins. In 1898 entered on practice of law in association with Judge J. G. Woerner; collaborated with Judge Woerner in publication of his work on the American Law of Administration, 1899; editor of the Central Law Journal since 1901, and since 1905 secretary Central Law Journal Co. Wrote and published, 1903, text-book on “American Advocacy," now leading text-book on advocacy and legal ethics. Professor of the Law of Domestic Relations at the St Louis University Institute of Law. Democrat. Southern Methodist. Member St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations. Office: 420 Market St. Residence: 4465 Greer Ave.

company: St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co.
office: Cor. Wabash Track and Newstead Ave.
memberships: ["Latin-American Club (president","1898-99 and 1901-02); was also president Farm Implement and Vehicle Board of Trade","1897"]
fullentry: ROBBINS, Edward Combs, president St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co.; born, Hawes-ville, Hancock Co., Ky., Dec. 5, 1841; son of Samuel and Mary Augusta (Longest) Robbins; came to St Louis in childhood; educated in Wyman's, Avery's and Martin's schools and graduated from St Louis High School, 1859; attended Dr. Wines' School, 1859-60, and Amherst College, Mass., September, 1860, to May, 1861; served in Confederate Army, 1861-65; married, St Louis, Dec. 5, 1872, Eleanor Woodruff Kingsland; one son, Leroy Kingsland Robbins. Returned to St Louis in 1867; was engaged with the American Powder Co., 1867-68; went into iron firm of Graff, Bennett & Co., 1868, and remained until its dissolution in 1888; meanwhile engaged, in 1879, in manufacture of well drilling machinery and tools, in which has ever since continued. Is president of the St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co. Member Latin-American Club (president, 1898-99 and 1901-02); was also president Farm Implement and Vehicle Board of Trade, 1897. Democrat. Presbyterian/ Club: St Louis. Recreation: reading. Office: Cor. Wabash Track and Newstead Ave. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

company: St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co.
office: S. Newstead Ave. and Wabash R. R. Tracks.
memberships: ["Society of Colonial Wars","Sons of Revolution","Society of Foreign Wars","United Spanish War Veterans"]
fullentry: ROBBINS, Leroy Kingsland, vice president St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 10, 1873; son of Edward C. and Eleanor W. (Kingsland) Robbins; graduated from the St Louis Manual Training School, and from Washington University, B.S., in mechanical engineering, 1895; married, Greenfield, Ohio, Dec. 10, 1895, Adelia B. Southward; one son, Leroy S. Robbins. After graduation, in 1895, took present position as vice president of the St Louis Well Machine & Tool Co., manufacturers of well-drilling machinery for sinking water, oil and gas wells, and mineral prospecting machinery. President of the Implement and Vehicle Board of Trade for 1905. Presbyterian. Commissioned first lieutenant, Company D, Mar. 16, 1894, and captain Company C, Feb. 3, 1897, in First Regiment Infantry, National Guard of Missouri; commissioned and served as captain Company C, First Regiment Missouri Volunteer Infantry, during Spanish-American War, May 4 to Oct. 31, 1898; commissioned captain Company A, First Infantry National Guard of Missouri, Apr. 10, 1907, and as such served in April, 1911, as one of Missouri's representatives with the regular army concentrated in Texas during the Mexican Revolution; commissioned major, Third Battalion, First Regiment Infantry, July 6, 1911. Member Society of Colonial Wars, Sons of Revolution, Society of Foreign Wars, United Spanish War Veterans. Clubs: University, Missouri Athletic. Recreation: military affairs. Office: S. Newstead Ave. and Wabash R. R. Tracks. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

ROBBINS, Nelson Chapman, president A. Robbins Varnish Co.; born St Louis, May 8, 1852; son of Alexander and Eliza A. (Chapman) Robbins; educated in St Louis public schools and Griswold College, Davenport, Ia; unmarried. Began business career handling goods on commission and traveled for ten years (half the time); with firm of A. Robbins & Co., varnish manufacturers, from 1871 to 1885, when business was incorporated under present style of A. Robbins Varnish Co., of which became president in 1902. Member Paint, Oil and Drug Club. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreation: Fishing. Office: 15311539 N. 8th St. Residence: 2956 Dickson St.

memberships: ["St Louis and American Bar associations","St Louis Law Library Association","Civic League"]
fullentry: ROBERT, Douglas W., lawyer; born Little Rock, Ark., Sept. 20, 1806; son of Rev. P. G. (D.D.) and Elizabeth (Scott) Robert; educated at Smith Academy, St Louis; LL.B., St Louis Law School (Washington University), 1898; married, St Louis, Apr. 19, 1900, Eliza Clendenin; children: Elizabeth Clendenin, Isabelle Douglas. Engaged in general practice in St Louis from graduation in 1898; since 1906, member of law firm Robert & Robert. Member St Louis and American Bar associations, St Louis Law Library Association, Civic League. Democrat. Episcopalian. Mason. Member of Royal Arcanum. Club: Racquet. Office: 414 Rialto Bldg. Residence: 4950 Forest Park Boulevard.

residence: Page Boul. and Partridge Ave., St Louis Co.
fullentry: ROBERTS, John Calvin, manufacturer of boots and shoes; born. Ready ville, Tenn., Dec. 17, 1853; son of James Madison and Louisa (Conley) Roberts; graduated from Woodbury (Tennessee) College, 1872, and from T. A. Leddin's Commercial College, Memphis, Tenn., 1874; married, Minneapolis, Minn., Aug. 5, 1889, Anna C. Kiser; children: Elzey Mea-cham, John Calvin, Jr. Clerked in country store for one year, then was two years in retail hardware store at Murfreesboro, Tenn.; went to commercial college; worked as bill clerk for M. L. Meacham & Co., wholesale grocers, Memphis, one year, and after that returned to Murfreesboro, Tenn., and engaged one year in retail grocery business; then went on road selling shoes for Bramlet & Moore, Boston, Mass.; came to St Louis, 1880, and was associated with Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co. until 1897; vice president Roberts, Johnson & Rand Shoe Co. until 1911, since vice president International Shoe Co. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Glen Echo, Noonday. Recreations: golf, motoring. Office: 15th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: Page Boul. and Partridge Ave., St Louis Co.

ROBERTSON, John C., lawyer; born Tyrone, Blair Co., Pa., Jan. 18, 1872; son of Alexander and Mary A. (Pittman) Robertson; educated public and high schools, St Louis; LL. B., St Louis Law School, 1894; married, St Louis, Sept. 25, 1899, Adelia Black; children: Esther M. and Florence I). Admitted to bar, 1894, and since in practice in St Louis. Justice of the peace Seventh District, 1900-06. Republican. Member St Louis Bar Association. Royal Arch Mason. Club: City. Office: 715 Times Bldg. Residence: 2924 Barrett St.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Surgical Club","Washington University Alumni Association"]
fullentry: ROBERTSON, William Murray, physician; born Fayette, Ala., Oct. 3, 1866; son of John C. and Mary (Alley) Robertson; educated in public schools, Bellevue High School, Virginia; A.B., Washington and Lee University, Virginia, 1885; M.D., Medical Department, University of Virginia, 1889; unmarried. Interne New York City Hospital for two years after graduation; came to St Louis, 1894, and has since been engaged in practice in this city. Associate surgeon, Jewish Hospital; genitourinary surgeon to City Hospital; instructor in genito-urinary surgery in Medical Department of Washington University. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Surgical Club, Washington University Alumni Association. Clnb: University. Office: 602 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: Colonial Bldg.

ROBERTSON, William Pitman, president Dixie Printing Co.; born, Tyrone, Fa., Mar. 18, 1868; son of Alexander and Mary A. (Pitman) Robertson; educated, public schools, Tyrone, and Independence, Kan., and Clay School, St Louis; married, St Louis, R. May Kay; one son, Earle. Began learning printer's trade at Independence, Kan., 1880; came to St Louis and opened an office at Ninth and Pine Sts., 1886, selling out next year; was proprietor and editor Brighton News, Brighton, Ill., 1889-90; sold out and returned to 8t. Louis; associated with others in Robertson Printing Co., 1891, but disposed of interest, 1904, since identified with the Dixie Printing Co., of which is president; also director Dixie Realty Syndicate. Member Business Men's League. Was treasurer and chairman Publicity and Advertising Committee of Constitutional Amendment Association No. 10, in campaign of 1910; director Citizens' Industrial Association; member executive committee St Louis Sunday School Association. Presbyterian. Recreations: motoring and tennis. Office: 1627 Washington Ave. Residence: 3625 Finney Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association","American Medical Association"]
fullentry: ROBINSON, Anslem Clark, physician; born St. Charles, Mo., Nov. 13, 1851; son of Rev. John W. and Dorcas (Griffith) Robinson; attended Gimble German School, five years, Washington University (academic and collegiate courses); M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1874; married, St Louis, Dec. 2, 1875, Maria Duffer; children: Mrs. Hattie R. Leggat, Mrs. Ella R. Scarritt. Engaged in general practice of medicine in St Louis since 1874. Was for ten years city physician of St Louis, and afterwards served for four years member of the St Louis Board of Health; for twenty-five years chief surgeon Police Department, St Louis; served for one year as major surgeon, First Regiment, National Guard of Missouri. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association. Democrat. Member St. John's Methodist Church. Recreation: athletic sports. Office: 428 Delmar Bldg. Residence: 5083 Westminster PL

ROBINSON, Anthony Saugrain, president Thomas Law Book Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 12, 1855; son of Anthony Saugrain and Elizabeth May (Alton) Robinson; educated in Christian Brothers College, St Louis; married, Bunker Hill, Ill., Dec. 10, 1884, Eugenia W. Dorsey; two children: Edward Hamilton and May Eugenia. Began active career as clerk in a mercantile house, continuing, 1871-73; engaged in farming, 1874-76, and again as clerk, 1877-84; became identified with the Thomas Law Book Co., 1885; served as secretary until 1908, since president. Democrat. Catholic. Was Supreme Regent Royal Arcanum, 1903 and 1904, now Supreme Treasurer; member Royal League, Legion of Honor. Recreations: music, fishing. Office: 14 S. Broadway. Residence: 5529 Von Versen Ave.

residence: 11 Princeton Ave., University Heights, St Louis.
fullentry: ROBINSON, Earle Temple, president Robinson Fire Apparatus Manufacturing Co.; born Nevada, Mo., Aug. 14, 1880; son of William R. and Ella (Berry) Robinson; educated in public schools to 1893; Smith Academy scientific class, 1900; took course in engineering under Professor Maloney, English engineer, 1903; unmarried. Began business career with father, lumber dealer, 1900; elected treasurer Stemple Fire Extinguisher Manufacturing Co., Sept. 1, 1900; was general manager and gradually purchased capital stock Stemple company, also bought plant and good will P. J. Cooney Manufacturing Co., July, 1906; consolidated two companies under name of Robinson Fire Apparatus Manufacturing Co., incorporated, 1904; since president and general manager same. Member North St Louis Business Men's Association. Served four years as member First Regiment, National Guard of Missouri. Democrat. Member Christian Church. Club: Mercantile. Recreations: experimental work and automobiling. Office: 42504208 North 20th St. Residence: 11 Princeton Ave., University Heights, St Louis.

ROBINSON, Eben Clay, lumber merchant; born Marysville, O., Oct. 1. 1847; son of William Morrison and Hannah Hooper (Crawford) Robinson; educated in common and high schools of Marysville; married, Thayer, Kan., Nov. 24, 1872, Katherine Elizabeth Stall; five children: Calvin L. (secretary Chicago Lumber and Coal Co.), Arthur D. (master mechanic, Sioux City, Ia.), Cora B., Lena M. (Mrs. W. B. Christian), Frederick M. Entered lumber business at Thayer, Kan., 1874, continuing there until 1880; in business at Ottawa, Kan., 1880-90, as partner S. A. Brown Lumber Co. (line yards); located at St Louis, 1890, and was in lumber business on own account, 1890-1900; president E. C. Robinson Lumber Co. (line yards), since 1900; member Business Men's League, and made trip to Panama, February, 1912. Was connected with retail grocery business at Thayer, Kan., 1870-80. Democrat. Protestant. Mason (32°). Clubs: Masonic, Lumbermen's (treasurer), Normandie Golf, Oasis Hunting and Fishing. Recreation: traveling. Office: 1311 Wright Bldg. Residence: 6231 Waterman Ave.
