ROBINSON, Frederic Morrison, vice president E. C. Robinson Lumber Co.; born Ottawa, Kan., Oct. 15, 1882; son of Eben C. and Katherine E. (Stall) Robinson; educated in public schools, graduated from Central High School, 1902; then entered Washington University, graduated with degree of B.S., 1906; married, St Louis, Apr. 9, 1910, Lonore Bond Clabaugh; one cnild, William M. Since graduation engaged with father, doing business as E. C. Robinson Lumber Co.; vice president same since 1910. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity. Recreation: baseball. Office: 1311 Wright Bldg. Residence: Ferguson, Mo.

ROBINSON, George Rowan, retired; born in St Louis Co., Mo., Sept. 14, 1866; son of George R. and Anne Randolph Page (Andrews) Robinson; educated in public schools; married, Old Orchard, Mo., Nov. 25, 1902, Elsie H. Hewlett. Was employed in auditor's office Missouri Pacific Ry., November, 1880, to June, 1884; Antlers Hotel, Colorado Springs, Colo., June to October, 1884; Clark & Stuy-vesant Grocery Co., St Louis, November, 1884, to May, 1880; Meyer's Feed Mill, St Louis, May, 1886, to May, 1888. Vice president Andrews & Robinson Forage Co., May, 1888, to October, 1893; established Ralston Purina Co., October, 1893, manufacturers of cereals. Democrat. Episcopalian. Residence: Kirkwood, Missouri.

ROBINSON, Henry Kellogg, machinery; born Amherst, Mass., Aug. 18, 1878; son of William and Jane B. (Ingram) Robinson; educated in public schools of Worcester, Mass., and at Amherst College, graduating in class of 1900; married, New York City, Oct. 3, 1901, Lucy May Johnson; one son, Hobert. On leaving college became cashier in office of the Munson Steamship Line, in New York City; came to St Louis, 1901; with Johnson Machinery Co., 1901-04; president Johnson-Rob-inson Machinery Co., 1904-09; now local manager Lambert Hoisting Engine Co. Member Alpha Delta Phi fraternity. Office: 717 N. 2d St. Residence: 771 Belt Ave.

birthcity: New York City. June 10. 1853; son of Henry Barclay and Caroline (Betts) Robinson; educated Charles Morris' School
fullentry: ROBINSON, Jchn Beverley, professor architecture. Washington University; born New York City. June 10. 1853; son of Henry Barclay and Caroline (Betts) Robinson; educated Charles Morris' School, New York City, 186567; George C. Anthon's School, 1867 69; Columbia University, 1869-72; married, New York, July 1, 1885, Elizabeth Devereux Urn-sted; two sons, Beverley and Devereux and one daughter, Elizabeth Devereux Marriott. In independent business as architect, firm of Thayer & Robinson, New York City, 1882-97; deputy superintendent school buildings, Board of Education, New York City, 1897-1910; professor architecture, Washington University, since 1910. Fellow American Institute of Architects and member of St Louis Chapter same; member Alumni Association Columbia College. Clubs: Artists' Guild (St Louis), Columbia University (New York City). Author: Principles of Architectural Composition, 1899; Architectural Composition, 1908. Address: Washington University. Residence: 3739 Windsor PI.

birthcity: New York City. June 10. 1853; son of Henry Barclay and Caroline (Betts) Robinson; educated Charles Morris' School
fullentry: ROBINSON, Paul Gervais, physician; sco Vol. 1906.

ROBINSON, Samuel Roland Hiland, railroad contractor; born in County#of Gray, Ontario, Can., Nov. 22, 1860; son of Thomas Argo and Sarah (Scott) Robinson (both from the north of Ireland); educated in common schools of Ontario; married, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Can., Mar. 4, 1884, Mary Elizabeth McPhee; children: Thomas Argo, Leone, Charles Roland, Gordon Walter. Began, 1872, as water boy on Hamilton Northwestern It. R., Canada; later held various positions on railroads and in lumber camps in Michigan; in 1882 began as railroad contractor; superintendent and manager of Minnesota & Arizona Construction Co., constructing railroads and canal in Arizona; in 1898-1900 superintendent of construction Vera Cruz, al Pacifico R. R. in Mexico; engaged in construction of Arizona & Southwestern R. R. in Arizona and Mexico, 1900-02; in partnership with MacArthur Bros, in construction of Frisco R. R. between St Louis and Crystal City; also in construction of Little Kanawha R. R., a branch of the Wabash, in Ohio; in 1904 laid 127 miles of track for the Canada Northern R. R. in Canada. Has been member of firms of Robinson & Jeffrey* constructing Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul R. R., Robinson & Maney and Robinson & Chaney; builder of Missouri River Northwestern R. R. in South Dakota. Now member of S. R. II. Robinson & Son Contracting Co. Republican. Congregationalist. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Office: Chemical Bldg. Residence: 4339 Morgan St.

residence: Arcadia, Mo.; also St. Regis Apts., 8t. Louis.
fullentry: ROBLEE, Joseph Henry, vice president The Brown Shoe Co.; born Granville, N. Y., Apr. 8, 1859; son of Mahalon and Rhoda (Dillingham) Roblee; educated in public schools of Granville, Friends' Seminary, Easton, N. Y., Granville Military Academy; married, Granville, Sept. 23, 1885, Florence Allen; children: Robert A., Louise. Came to St Louis, 1879; entered employ of Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co. as clerk, July 5, 1879, and later was traveling salesman for same firm; in November, 1887, became connected with the Brown Shoe Co., shoe manufacturers, of which was treasurer until 1893, since which time has been vice president. Member business Men's League, Civic League. Independent in politics. Baptist. Clubs: Glen Echo Country, St Louis, Mercantile, Arcadia Country. Recreations: farming and horsebock riding. Office: The Brown Shoe Co. Residence: Arcadia, Mo.; also St. Regis Apts., 8t. Louis.

residence: St. Charles, Mo. Country Home: Augusta, Mo.
fullentry: ROBYN, Ernst, wholesale grocer and banker; born St Louis, June 2, 1850; son of Prof. Henry and Alwina (Angelrodt) Robyn; educated public schools; Christian Brothers College; Wirtz German and French Institute; Lincoln-Jefferson Law College (correspondence course); married, St Louis, Dec. 5, 1872, Elizabeth. Schoenthaler; six children: Ernest, Ella, Philip, Evelyn, Oscar, Emma. Began in grocery business, St Louis, Mar. 21, 1865, and has ever since been connected with that branch; president Knippenberg Grocer Co. since 1910; also actively identified with banking, and president Central Bank of St. Charles, Mo. Member Simpson Battery, O. M. M.; honorary member Post No. 576, G. A. R., Department of Missouri. Republican. Presbyterian. Recreation: vacations on farm. Office: 206-210 S. 7th St. Residence: St. Charles, Mo. Country Home: Augusta, Mo.

ROBYN, Paul, fire underwriter; born St, Louis, Dec. 10, 1853; son of Professor William and Clemence (Miltenberger) Robyn; educated in Christian Brothers Academy, 1863; Washington (public) School, 1864; Wyman Institute, 1866; Washington University, 1869; married, St Louis, Apr. 23, 1890, Louise Dyer; children: Pauline, Lucille, Virginia, Odille, Paul, Jr. Began in insurance business in 1871 in St Louis and has continued ever since; became member of the insurance firm of Roes-lein & Robyn, 1880, and since 1904 vice president of The Insurance Agency Co., this agency handling over one million dollars in insurance premiums annually. Besides fire insurance writes accident, employers' liability, tornado, automobile, marine, burglary, plate glass and bonding insurance. Trustee Guardian Angels' Home. Democrat. Roman Catholic. Club: St Louis. Recreation: music. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 3716 Pine St.

ROCKEL, Charles Elliott, leaf tobacco merchant; born St. Paul, Minn., Mar. 19, 1862; son of Gustavus and Johanna (Heller) Rockel; educated in public schools, St Louis; unmarried. Since 1879 has been connected with wholesale leaf tobacco; embarked in business on own account, 1897, as senior partner of Rockel, Woeldike & Co.; retired from that firm in January, 1903, and on Feb. 1, 1903, started present firm of Rockel Leaf Tobacco Co., wholesale dealers, of which is president. Republican. Evangelical Lutheran. Mason (32°). Office: 15 S. Second St. Residence: 4937 Laclede Ave.

memberships: ["Missouri State Dental Society","St Louis Dental Society","Washington University Alumni Association"]
fullentry: RODDY, Willard A., dentist; born Boone Co., Mo., Aug. 25, 1865; son of Robert A. and Sarah Roddy; educated in public schools and Missouri Dental College, graduating 1888; married, Boonville, Mo., Sept. 20, 1893, Emma Gibson. In practice in St Louis since 18.88. Member Missouri State Dental Society, St Louis Dental Society, Washington University Alumni Association. Democrat. Presbyterian. Office: Frisco Bldg.

RODES, Boyle Owsley, general insurance; born Danville, Ky., Mar. 25, 1882; son of Charles II. and Mary (Davis) Bodes; A.B., Central University of Kentucky, 1901; unmarried. Engaged in development work in southern part of Mexico, 1902-04; came to St Louis, 1904, and since connected with W. H. Markham & Co., insurance, now junior partner of the firm; vice president T. L. Horn Trunk Co. Presbyterian. Secretary Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association. Clubs: St Louis Country, Racquet, University. Recreations: golf and riding. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 4155 Lindell Boul.

RODES, Joseph H., lawyer; born Ralls Co., Mo., Mar. 24, 1854; son of Dr. Tyree Rodes (of Virginia) and Eliza (Tipton) Rodes, daughter of Gen. Jacob Tipton, of Tennessee; educated public schools; Van Rensselaer Academy, Ralls Co.; Central College, Fayette, Mo., graduating with degree of Ph.B., 1877; taught schools and studied law in office of Judge Theodore Brace, of Paris, Mo.; matriculated in Law Department, University of Missouri, graduating, degree of LL.B., 1881; married Leona Williams, of Mexico, Mo., Dec. 31, 1891; two children: Beulah H., W. Clifton. Practiced in Paris, Mo., 1882-91; formed partnership with Judge A. H. Waller, 1886, as Waller & Rodes, Moberly, Mo., and Rodes & Waller, Paris; dissolved partnership, 1881, and practiced in Sedalia, 1891-1910; removed to St Louis, 1910, and retired from active practice, devoting attention to personal affairs. President and general manager Worrell Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of chemicals and disinfectants; president of trustees, Florida Fruit Lands Co., of Kansas City, Mo., holding in trust 180,000 acres of land. Prosecuting attorney Monroe Co., 1882-86 inclusive; was first state game and fish warden of Missouri under the Walmsly law and secured about 300 convictions in two years. Member Missouri State Bar Association. Democrat. Protestant. Member St Louis Business Men's Association. Mason (Blue Lodge, Chapter, Commandery, Shrine); member Elks, Knights of Pythias. Recreations: hunting, fishing, golf. Office: 918 Wainwright Bldg. Residence: 5448 Forest Park Boul.

memberships: ["of St Louis Bar Association and Law Library Association"]
fullentry: RODGERS, Hickman Price, lawyer; born St Louis. Feb. 5, 1859; son of James A. and Hannah E. (Stith) Rodgers; educated in public schools of St Louis; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1880; married, St Louis, Sept. 25, 1884, Margaret McChesney; children: Sterling, Milton, Atwell. Admitted to St Louis bar, June 14, 1880; enrolled in United States Supreme Court, Apr. 13, 1903. Since admission has been engaged in general practice of law and is an authority on special tax questions; appointed judge of Court of General Sessions, 1907; nominee for judge of Probate Court, 1910. Member of St Louis Bar Association and Law Library Association. Democrat. Mason, Knight Templar; member Legion of Honor. Office: 415 Pine St. Residence: 4718 Cote Brilliante Ave.

RODGERS, William Langdon, secretary-treasurer Fernholtz Brick Machinery Co.; born, Alton, HI., July 8, 1873; son of Gol. Andrew F. and Jennie (De La Plaine) Rodgers; educated in public schools; A.B., Shurtleff College, Upper Alton, Ill., 1892; LL.B., St Louis. Law School, 1898; unmarried. Practiced law in St Louis, 1899-1902, as member of law firm of Foster & Rodgers. Since 1899 has been secretary and treasurer, and since 1902 has devoted entire attention to business as general manager of the Fernholtz Brick Machinery Co. Democrat. Recreations: fishing and baseball. Office: 1421 S. Boyle St. Residence: 4326 W. Pine St.

BOEDER, Philip, bookseller; born Offen-thal, Hesse-Darmstadt, Germany, Jan. 7, 1846; son of John and Marie Roeder; came to St Louis in 1855; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, 1870, Amanda C. Sonnewald (now deceased); children: Oliver L., Charles W., Philip, Jr., Emma (Mrs. Oscar O. Durham), Amanda (Mrs. Louis F. Aber). Began business career in early part of 1862 as errand boy with W. H. Gray, for whom later became clerk, and finally, in fall of 1879, started in business on own account as bookseller, stationer and newsdealer, in which has continued ever since; head of Philip Roeder Book and Stationery Co. Republican. Office: 703 Locust St. Residence: 1709 Carr St.

company: Roehrig & Jacoby Wall Paper and Carpet Co.
fullentry: ROEHRIG, Philip, president Roehrig & Jacoby Wall Paper and Carpet Co.; born Bavaria, Germany, June 7, 1850; son of August and Elizabeth (Schramm) Roehrig; educated in grammar schools of Germany; married Friedericka W. Jacoby, of Bremen, Germany, Sept. 10, 1878; five children: Herman, Perla (Mrs. E. C. Alexander), Edward P., Augustave, Elsie. Arrived in America Oct. 3, 1866; became connected with wall paper business at 1308 Franklin Ave., St Louis, 1874; president and treasurer Roehrig & Jacoby Wall Paper and Carpet Co. since 1893. Republican. Lutheran. Mason; member Legion of Honor, Knights of Honor, Harugari; honorary member West St Louis Turn Verein. Office: 1223 Olive St. Residence: 1837 Lafayette Ave.

ROESCH, Anton, carpets, wall paper, etc.; born St Louis, Dec. 7, 1862; son of Michael and Elizabeth Roesch; educated in Pestalozzi and Carroll public schools; married, St Louis, Aug. 19, 1886, Caroline Vollmar; children: Ernestine (Mrs. Arthur Ruemler), Anton, Ella, Adolf, Oscar, Walter. Began business career in 1883, lime whiting and paper hanging; began in wall paper business aud carpets, 1887; incorporated business, 1896, as the Roesch Carpet and Wall Paper Co., and in 1909 changed name to Roesch Furniture, Carpet and Wall Paper Co., of which is president and treasurer. Republican. Evangelical. Member Young Men's Christian Association, Civic League. Office: 1541-1543 8. Broadway. Residence: 2744 Cherokee St.

ROGERS, Charles Loomis, president 81igo Furnace Co.; born Greene, Chenango Co., N. Y., Oct. 25, 1858; son of Rev. Ferdinand and Sylvia Jeannette (Loomis) Rogers; educated at Lehigh University, South Bethlehem, Pa., graduating with degree of M.E., 1883; married, Bethlehem, Pa., Dec. 9, 1885, Fanny Alder Webb. Began as draughtsman for New York Central & Hudson River R. R. Co., 1883, continuing for five years; general manager Milton Car Works, Milton, Pa., 1888-99; district manager American Car and Foundry Co., Milton, 1899-1905; president Sligo Furnace Co. since 1905; also president Sligo & Eastern R. R. Co. Has resided in St Louis since 1907. Member Civic League. Independent in politics. Episcopalian. Mason; member Chi Phi college fraternity. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Bellerive (St Louis), Engineers' (Xew York). Recreations: motoring, golf. Office: 915 Olive St. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

memberships: ["of Bar Association of St Louis","Law Library Association of St Louis"]
fullentry: ROGERS, Stephen Cook, lawyer; born Chicago, Ill., Sept. 9, 1872; son of Randolph R. and Cynthia (Scott) Rogers; educated in public schools at Jefferson City and Centretown (Cole Co.), Mo., 1878-89. Worked on farm at Centretown until eighteen years of age; then carried newspapers and clerked in stationery and music store at Jefferson City for three years; worked in shoe factory six years, studying law at night; admitted to bar at Jefferson City, Nov. 26, 1896; located in St Louis and started to practice law, Jan. 14, 1897; general practice. Member of Bar Association of St Louis, Law Library Association of St Louis. Democrat. Episcopalian by birth and training —not attached. Mason; member Knights of Pythias. Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: Suite 710-712 Carleton Bldg. Residence: 4437 Delmar Boul.

ROGERS, William Bolla, president Rogers-Schinitt Wire and Iron Co.; born Nashville, Ill., Sept. 27, 1872; son of John F. and Elizabeth E. (Ferguson) Rogers; educated in public schools, graduating from high school, 1892; married, Ashley, Ill., Apr. 29, 1896, Harriet E. Meffert; two sons: Harold Lucian, Donald Porter. Began active career with the Excelsior Wire and Iron Co., 213 Market St., St Louis, 1893; was a member of the Lasar-Let-zig Manufacturing Co., incorporated 1896; was with the Cleveland Rolling MiH Co., Cleveland, O., from 1899 until the company sold out to the American Steel and Wire Co.t and with Ludlow-8aylor Wire Co. until 1903; then returned to the Lasar-Letzig Manufacturing Co.; assisted, in 1909, in organizing the Rogers-Schmitt Wire & Iron Co., manufacturers of ornamental bronze aud iron work, of which has since been president. Democrat. Presbyterian. Mason; member Corner Stone Lodge No. 323, A. F. & A. M.; Beliefontaine Chapter, Xo. 55, R. A. M.; Ivanhoe Commandery, No. 8, Knights Templar; Rose Hill Lodge, Xo. 120, O. E. S. Club: Masonic. Recreation: reading. Office: 1714-1716 X. Broadway. Residence: 6321 Isabella Ave.

ROHAN, James Michael, vice president of Title Guaranty Trust Co., and of American Trust Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 18, 1867; son of Michael and Mary (McGovern) Rohan; A.B., Christian Brothers College, 1883; married, St Louis, Apr. 22, 1896, Mae Wathen; children: Eugene, Virgil, Philip, Francis M.. James A., Joseph E. Engaged in business of examination of titles to real estate, 1883-99; assistant manager title department of 8t. Louis Trust Co. and its successor, the Title Guaranty Trust Co., of which was elected secretary and treasurer in 1902, and vice president in 1910; vice president American Trust Co.; vice president St Louis Fire Works Co.; secretary Mound City Building and Loan Association and several savings and building associations. Democrat. Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus. Club: Mercantile. Office: 710 Chestnut St. Residence: 5039 Raymond Ave.

company: John Rohan & Son Boiler Works Co.
fullentry: ROHAN, John Ambrose, vice president John Rohan & Son Boiler Works Co.; born St Louis, Jan. 1, 1874; son of John and Christina (Lortz) Rohan; educated in public and private schools to 1881; St. Alphonsus (parochial) School, 1881-83; then Christian Brothers Coll ^ge, graduating with degree of B.S., 1893; married, St Louis, Apr. 26, 1899, Mary Elizabeth Hatton; one child, John A., Jr. Engaged in the boiler manufacturing business. 1893; elected vice president of company, 1894; superintendent of works since 1905. Trained vocal and instrumental musician, St Louis product; baritone voice, and expert sight-reader of music. Member Apollo (musical) Club, Temple Israel Choir, Temple Male Quartette. Democrat. Catholic. Member B. P. O. Elks, Benton Council, Royal Arcanum. Club: St Louis Millers'. Recreation: basebalL Office: 1915 North 9th St. Residence: 5912 Cates Avenue.

BOHAN, Philip Alphonse, boiler manufacturer; born St Louis, July 15, 1877; son of John and Christina (Lortz) Rohan; educated at Christian Brothers College; married, St Louis, June 25, 1910, Stella Price Holliway. Began business career as assistant in the office of John Rohan & son Boiler Works Co., as a mechanical draughtsman, and later did the estimating work for the company; on death of father, 1905, succeeded to the presidency of the company; in 1908 resigned as president and became treasurer and general manager. Also director Broadway Savings Trust Co. Recreation: music. Office: 1915 X. 9th St. Residence: Hotel Berlin.

ROHDE, Henry, vice president J. B. Sickles Saddlery Co.; born St Louis, Mo., Feb. 1, 1846; son of J. B. and Wilhelmina (Droeger) Rohde; educated in private school, 1852-54, public school, 1854-59, Jones Commercial College (nights), 1862; married, St Louis, Apr. 25, 1877, Minnie, daughter of late Henry Meier, president of Franklin Bank; children: Cora, Ella, Edwin. In employ of Warne, Chee-ver & Co., hardware and house furnishing goods, 1860-63; then with Hayden & Wilson, wholesale saddlery hardware, later incorporated as the P. Hayden Saddlery Co., as salesman until 1805; traveling salesman for same company, 18(55-81, buyer until May 1, 1902, when bought an interest in the J. B. Sickles Saddlery Co., of which is first vice president. Member German Evangelical Church. Served in 1864 in the Seventh Regiment of State Militia. Odd Fellow; member Legion of Honor. Club: Gilead Fishing and Hunting. Favorite recreation: fishing. Office: 2100-2104 Washington Ave. Residence: 5105 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: ROHLFING, Charles G., physician; born St Louis, Dec. 24, 1843; son of William L. and Elizabeth (Richman) Rohlfing; educated in Lutheran parochial schools, public schools and Central High School, St Louis; Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia; M.D., Humboldt Medical College, St Louis, 1867; married, St Louis, 1870, Mathilda Pulse; eleven children, four of whom are living: Florence Mathilda, Charles E., Olive Stella and Dr. Walter A In practice at St Louis since 1867. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Independent Republican. Lutheran. Office: 1827 Cass Ave. Residence: 3803 Russell Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association"]
fullentry: ROHLFING, Leuis Christian, physician; born in Franklin Co., Mo., Mar. 5, 1866; son of Louis C. H. and Mary (Wollblock) Rohlfing; educated in grammar schools in Franklin Co., 1872-81, and St Louis, 1881-82; St Louis Manual Training School, graduating 1885; M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1887; married, St Louis, Nov. 14, 1889, Louise C. Luecke; one daughter, Ethel L. Continuously engaged in general practice of medicine since graduation, first four years in Kansas, coming to St Louis, 1892. Director North St Louis Trust and Savings Bank. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association. Republican. Methodist. Office and Residence: 3521 Dodier St.

memberships: ["American Society Civil Engineers","Society of Engineers of Germany","American Railway Engineers and Maintenance of Way Association","Engineers' Club of St Louis","fraternity of German Students of A"]
fullentry: ROHWER, Henry, civil engineer; born on estate near Rendsburg, Holstein, Germany, Oct. 17, 1847; son of Henry and Magarete (Rohwer) Rohwer; educated in public schools, Province of Holstein, Polytechnic Institute (private), Hamburg; graduate Royal Polytechnic High School, Hanover, 1869; came to United States in 1869; married, Fremont, Neb., Oct. 8, 1873, Anna Sievers; children: Oscar H. D., Henry G. A., Walter Chesbrough (deceased), A. Louise, Enne (deceased). From 1869 to 1874 was topographer, chief draftsman, engineer in charge of construction and chief engineer Burlington & Missouri River R. R., in Nebraska, and for one year (1872) also resident engineer at Omaha of the Omaha & South Western Ry.; city engineer of Omaha, Neb., 1876-81, establishing street grades, starting with paving of same and planning and supervising sewers and water works; division engineer locating and constructing Oregon Short Line (then branch of Union Pacific Ry.), engineer in charge of tunnel and later resident engineer and engineer of maintenance of way, same line, 1881-85; engineer in charge location and construction Omaha Belt Railway and Missouri Pacific extension to Omaha and Lincoln, Neb., 1885-87; assistant engineer in charge of maintenance of way, Mo. Pacific Ry., Sedalia, Mo., 1887-1901; chief engineer Missouri Pacific Ry. System, Mar. 1, 1901, to Jan. 1, 1905; consulting engineer, same system, until June, 1906, since in private practice. Member American Society Civil Engineers, Society of Engineers of Germany, American Railway Engineers and Maintenance of Way Association, Engineers' Club of St Louis, fraternity of German Students of A. H. A. H. Republican. Evangelical Lutheran. Office: 609 Fullerton Bldg. Residence: 564(5 Cates Ave.

ROLF, Henry William, wholesale wall paper; born St Louis, Mo., Sept. 29, 1863; son of John C. and Mary (Manther) Rolf; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Oct. 12, 1887, Rosa Buckha; children: Edna (Mrs. Tryce Pickens), John, Hyacinth, Henry W., Jr. Began business career as shipping clerk for F. W. Rosenthal in wall paper business, continuing ten years; then served in same capacity with Newcomb Bros. Wall Paper Co., for five years; was for seven years with the National Wall Paper Co., and stockholder in the G. H. Oliver Wall Paper Co. until 1901, when joined in organization of the G. W. Miller Wall Paper Co., wholesale dealers in wall paper, of which is vice president. Republican. Member Royal Arcanum. Recreation: fishing. Office: 1504 Pine St. Residence: 2325 Oriole Ave.

ROMER, Wilhelm J., merchant tailor; born Lima, Allen Co., O., Xov. 8, 1868; son of Joseph and Wilhelmina (Laba) Homer; educated at St. Xavier's College, Cincinnati; married, Lima, O., Oct. 11, 1897, Winnifred Sullivan; children: Rosamond Josephine, William Sullivan. Learned the merchant tailoring business, in which has been actively engaged on his own account since 1889; in April, 1900, joined Howard F. Kohler in establishing the present firm of Kohler & Romer. Member Permanent Exposition. Catholic. Club: St Louis Riding. Kecreation: horseback riding. Office: 304 Carleton Bldg., 6th and Olive Sts. Residence: 4848 Fountain Park.

ROOS, Solomon, manager The American Metal Co., Limited; born Frankfort a/M., Germany, Apr. 22, 1876; son of Jacob and Johanna (Mayer) Roos; gymnasium education in Germany; married, St Louis, Jan. 16, 1906, Selma Kalter; children: Margaret, John. Engaged in trade in metals since 1892, beginning at Frankfort-on-the-Main, and continuing in same line in Xew York, 1894-95; since 1895 connected with the American Metal Co. of New lork, Limited, of which became resident manager at St Louis, January, 1905. President Lanvon-Starr Smelting Co., St. Paul Mining Co.; vice president Bartlesville Zinc Co. Member Merchants' Exchange. Mason. Club: Columbian. Ofhce: 506 Olive St. Residence: 4467 McPherson Ave.

RORICK, David, insurance; born near Columbus, Franklin Co., O.; son of Cornelius Hoyt and Julia Fowler (Kimball) Rorick; educated in district and high schools, Franklin Co., O.; married, Wyandotte, Kan., Sept. 27, 1869, Lucy A. Meriwether; one son, David, Jr. Began business career as clerk in hotel, Newcastle, Iud., 1858; learned marble cutting trade and followed it until enlisting, in 1862, as private, Co. G, Thirty-first Iowa Infantry; promoted to first lieutenant on battlefield at Vicksburg, Miss., and thereafter served on staff of Gen. W. T. Sherman; took part in battles of Chickasaw Bluffs, Arkansas Post, siege of Vicksburg, Lookout Mountain, Dallas, Ken-esaw Mountain, around Atlanta, Jonesboro, March to the Sea, and Columbia, 8. C., where was taken prisoner, exchanged and returned to the command at Raleigh, N. C.; joined in march through Virginia to Washington, D. C., where armies were reviewed by Grant and Sherman and mustered out in 1865. Resumed marble business and studied law; removed to Jefferson Co., Kan., and began practice of law in firm of McArthur & Rorick, 1867; elected to lower house of Kansas legislature, 1869-70, and was one of three members who voted against ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States; became connected with American Central Insurance Co., Xovember, 1869, and has served consecutively as special agent, general agent on Pacific Coast, 1877-78, general adjuster, second vice president, 1894, and as vice president since 1903. Democrat. Member Military Order of Loyal Legion. Mason (32°), Knight Templar. Odd Fellow. Member Ransom Post, G. A. R. Club: Missouri Athletic. Office: 816 Olive St.

ROSEBROUGH, Charles A.; born Galena, Ill.,Sept. 10,1853; son of Richard Love andLu-cretia (Hunt) Rosebrough; came to St Louis. 1858; educated in St Louis public schools and high school; married, St Louis, Feb. 23, 1885, Ida V. Hagaman; children: Charles A., Hester, Richard L., Sidney H. Since leaving school entire business career has been spent in monument manufacturing work; now president and treasurer the Rosebrough Monument Co. Mason (32°), Knight Templar. Office: Olive and 20th Sts. Residence: 4549 Cook Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society","American Medical Assn"]
fullentry: ROSEBROUGH, Frank Henry, physician; born St Louis, June 17, 1878; son of James William and Margaret (Robinson) Bose-brough; educated at St Louis public schools; Manual Training School; studied medicine two years in Marion-Sims College; advanced work in science, Summer School, New York University, 1901; assistant in science, Westminster College, Fulton, Mo., 1901-02; A.B., Westminster College, 1902; M.D., Medical Department, St Louis University, 1904; post-graduate courses in New York, 1905, London and Vienna, 1908, Vienna, 1909, Berlin and Vienna, 1910, Paris, 1912; unmarried. Associated in practice (diseases of eye and ear) with Dr. J. G. Ehrhardt since 1904; member visiting staff of St Louis City Hospital (diseases of the eye), 1910. Presbyterian. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society, American Medical Assn., of Vienna, Beta Theta Pi. Member Occidental Lodge, No. 163, A. F. & A M.; St Louis Chapter, No. 8, R. A. M. Clubs: City, Triple A Golf. Recreations: automobiling and golf. Office: 928 N. Grand Ave. Residence: 3802 Windsor PI.

memberships: ["Xational Canned Goods and Dried Fruit Brokers' Association"]
fullentry: ROSEN, Louis, president Rosen-Reichardt Brokerage Co.; born Bayou Sara, La., Apr. 10, 1876; son of Louis and Dora (Miller) Rosen; educated in public schools to 1888; then entered Tulane High School, Xew Orleans, graduating, 1892; married, Chicago, Apr. 27, 1898, Hattie Benjamin; two children: Louis, Jr., Earl. Began business career as member firm of Louis Rosen & Co., 1895, and continued until 1902; then organized Rosen-Reichardt Brokerage Co., importers and commission merchants, canned goods, dried fruits, etc. Also director International Bank; president National Preserve Co. Member Xational Canned Goods and Dried Fruit Brokers' Association. Republican. Jewish religion. Mason (32°), Shriner. Club: Western Country (treasurer and director). Recreation: golf. Office: 800 Spruce St. Residence: 5218 Raymond St.

ROSENHEIM, Robert Faist, millinery merchant; born St Louis, July 12, 1861; son of Morris and Matilda (Ottenheimer) Rosenheim; educated in the public schools of St Louis, and for six years in Frankfort-on-the-Main and Stuttgart, Germany, until 1877; married, St Louis, Feb. 14, 1898, Lottie Dorothy Ware. Returned to St Louis from Germany in summer of 1877, and engaged in 1879 with his father's business, Rosenheim, Levis & Co., wholesale millinery, serving fourteen years, from boy to partner, 1879-93; engaged in various enterprises 1893-96, and finally, with father and brother, opened again in 1896; sold out in 1899, and then established the R. F. Rosenheim Toggery Co.; since 1907 in retail millinery business. Republican. Recreation: traveling abroad. Office: 3826 Olive St. Residence: 3867 Washington Boul.

ROSENTHAL, George Daniel, manager General Electric Co.; born Krementschug, Russia, Jan. 6, 1869; son of Herman and Anna Rosenthal; educated in University of Poltawa, Russia, 1879-81; came to United States in 1882; attended high school of Mitchell, S. D., 1883-86; married, St Louis, Apr. 27, 1896, Josephine Murphy; children: George D., Jr., Nor-myan, Leonore Katherine, Helen Dorothy, Josephine. Employed with the General Electric Co. since 1887; in factory at Harrison, N. J., 1887-90, Chicago office, 1890-92, since 1892 manager of St Louis branch. Also vice president P. C. Murphy Trunk Co. Republican. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Clubs: Mercantile, City, Liederkranz, Engineers'. Favorite Recreations: books, golf, fishing and hunting. Office: 815-816 Wainwright Bldg. Residence: 4304 Washington Boul.

ROSENTHAL, Isaac Bernhardt, president Rosenthal-Sloan Millinery Co.; born Villmar, Germany, Jan. 6, 1849; son of Bernhardt and Shanett (Ackerman) Rosenthal; educated in public schools; married, Scranton, Pa., Aug. 3, 1870, Carrie Lipschutz; one daughter living, Ray (now Mrs. Walter Wise). Came to America, 1862; clerk in retail dry goods store, San Francisco, several years, and engaged in business on own account six years; removed to New York, 1867, and was member firm of D. Hauser & Co., wholesale dry goods; in business, Scranton, Pa., eight years; sold out, and located in St Louis; established wholesale millinery business, 1876, as I. B. Rosenthal & Co., later I. B. Rosenthal Millinery Co., and since 1900, Rosenthal-Sloan Millinery Co., of which is president. Republican. Jewish religion. Mason. Clubs: Mercantile, Columbian. Recreation: motoring. Office: 1700 Washington Ave.

office: Title Guarantee Trust Bldg., 726 Chestnut St.
fullentry: ROSENTRETER, Adolph, rabbi; born Gol-lantsch, Germany, Dec. 27, 1858; son of Meyer and Frommet Rosentreter; graduated from gymnasium at Berlin, 1878, and from University of Berlin, 1880; married, 1st, St Louis, Aug. 15, 1886, Fanny Schwabe (died Feb. 7, 1902); children: Emmy, Frieda, Meyer; married, 2d, St Louis, Nov. 27, 1904, Eva Gotts-chalk. Rabbi of congregation at Meseritz, Germany, 1877-84; came direct to St Louis, 1884, and from Jan. 10, 1885, to 1911, was rabbi of B 'nai Amvona Congregation, but the position not affording sufficient monetary return, secured employment with Washington National Bank, continuing with its successor, the American Trust Co. Now rabbi of Beth David Congregation. Republican. Member B'nai B'rith, Free Sons of Israel, I. O. B. A., O. B. A., Progressive Order of the West, Modern Woodmen of America, Yeomen Brotherhood; ex-president Beth Moshah Sekenim (Home for the Aged). Office: Title Guarantee Trust Bldg., 726 Chestnut St. Residence: 4311 W. Belle Pl.

ROSSKOPF, Henry A., lawyer; born St Louis, Dec. 31, 1877; son of John and Susan (Hiestand) Rosskopf; educated, Lyon (public) School until fifteen; Bryant & Stratton Business College; LL.B., Benton College of Law, 1901; married, St Louis, June 5, 1905, Mrs. Augusta Rogers; three children: Eugenia C., Henry A. and Susan Lea. In employ of St Louis Woodenware Works, 1892-1900; admitted to bar 1901; associated with Charles F. Krone in practice, 1901-05; appointed assistant circuit attorney, 1905, and re-appointed, 1909. Republican. Member German Evangelical Church. Member Bar Association of St Louis. President Tower Grove Heights Improvement Association. Mason; member Sons of Veterans, Tower Grove Turn Verein. Recreation: baseball. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg. Residence: 3504 Hartford St.

ROTH, Frederick, Sr., wholesale coffee merchant; born in Bavaria, Germany, Sept. 14, 1856; son of John and Franziska (Matt) Roth; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Dec. 25, 1876, Amelia Yeckel; children: Mrs. Lulu Roth Henckler, Frederick, dr., Oliver H. Began business career as a grocery clerk, 1872-75; entered retail grocery business in 1875 and continued until 1885; began in wholesale coffee business in 1885, as city salesman, and continued as such until 1898, when with associates organized the Roth-Homeyer Coffee Co., importers and jobbers of coffees, of which has since been president. Also vice president of St Louis Boat and Engine Co. Republican. Recreations: fishing and bowling. Office: 601 N. Main St. Residence: 2950 Milton Ave.

memberships: ["executive committee of Business Men's League; treasurer and one of the three originators of the Children's Industrial Farm Association","which provides a two weeks' outing","on the Association farm","for 900 children selected from the poorest tenement districts","during the summer months"]
fullentry: ROTH, George Adam, president of the Adam Roth Grocery Co.; born, St Louis, Aug. 22, 1855; son of Adam aud Margaret (Arnold) Roth; educated in public and private schools, also in Bryant & Stratton Business College; married Mary Tillery, of Columbia, Mo., Oct. 20, 1886; children: Thomas A., Margaret Frances. After leaving school, 1874, entered the retail grocery house of his father, Adam Roth, this business having been established by his father at Broadway and Spruce Sts., 1.848, and changed to a wholesale basis in 1876. Began at the bottom and served in every department, and, upon incorporation of the business in 1885 as the Adam Roth Grocery Co., became vice president of the company, continuing until death of his father, June 2*0, 1900, when he became president; also vice president of the Payne-Roth Grocery Co. of Columbia, Mo.; director Litchfield (Ill.) Grocer Co., and American Coffee Co. Member executive committee of Business Men's League; treasurer and one of the three originators of the Children's Industrial Farm Association, which provides a two weeks' outing, on the Association farm, for 900 children selected from the poorest tenement districts, during the summer months. Member of the Grand Avenue Presbyterian Church; member Royal Arcanum; Chancellor of Bonaparte Council and member of the Supreme Council of the Legion of Honor. Club: City. Office: Cupples Block, 7th and Poplar Sts. Residence: 5145 Von Versen Ave.

ROTH, John Jacob, architect; born St Louis, Jan. 17, 1884; son of Henry and Dora Elizabeth (Schrecke) Roth; educated in public and high schools; St Louis School of Fine Arts; studied architecture at Washington University, completing the course in 1906; married, May 29, 1912, Flora M. Breyman. Began practice in St Louis, 1902; spent two years traveling in Japan and China, studying the architecture of those countries; in civil service under War Department of United States in Manila as assistant to consulting architect, 1908-09; building commissioner of University City, 1912; member firm of Roth & Study. President St Louis Architectural Club; member Beta Theta Pi. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Union, Liederkranz. Recreations: horseback riding, music and art. Office: Suite 1108 Liggett Bldg. Residence: 27 Amherst Ave., LTniversity Citv.

ROTH, Will Keber, real estate; born St Louis, July 7, 1865; son of Adam and Margaret (Arnold) Roth; educated in German schools, 1872, public school, 1880, Manual Training School, 1880-83, in first graduating class; married, St Louis, Jan. 22, 1896, Anna H. Haeussler; children: Albert William, Anna Eleanor. During summers, 1880-83, was employed with John Kimpel, wagonmaker and blacksmith shop, and with Turner & Co., millwrights; drove wagon and assisted in shop with B. Roth Tool Co., then as timekeeper, draftsman, wood-inlayer, and assistant to superintendent, Pullman Car Shop. In 1885 became connected as errand boy, and subsequently was office boy, street buyer, auditor, buyer, and was vice president Adam Roth Grocery Co; in 1909 became associated with sales department of Papin & Tontrup, real estate loans and leases. Republican. Active member Compton Hill Congregational Church. Recreations: traveling and outdoor sports. Office: 626 Chestnut St. Residence: 2909 Aeco-mac St. (Compton Heights.)

ROTHENSTEINER, John E., clergyman; born St Louis, Jan. 7, 1860; son of John and Magdalene Rothensteiner; educated SS. Peter and Paul's (parochial) School; Christian Brothers College; went to Milwaukee, Wis., 1875, and spent nine years as student at St Francis Seminary. Ordained priesthood Roman Catholic Church, at St Louis, by Archbishop Ryan, 1884; acting pastor parish of Portage de Sioux; then assigned to Jackson, Mo., where continued for two years; subsequently in charge of Reviere aux Vases, Ste. Genevieve Co., Mo.; pastor St. Michael's Church, Fredericktown, Mo., for twenty years, 1887-1907; pastor Holy Ghost parish, St Louis, since 1907. Under his administration of the Church of the Holy Ghost, a new church building has been erected at an expenditure of about $90,000, also the new parsonage, $13,000. Director parochial school of Holy Ghost parish; secretary Board of Synodal Examiners of archdiocese of St Louis. Democrat. Trustee State Historical Society, Columbia, Mo. Spent four months traveling in Europe, 1898. Author: The Catholic Church and Civil Liberty, 1892; Hoffnung und Erinnerung, (Hope and Memory), 1903; Indianer Sommer (Indian Summer), 1905; Heliotrope (a book of verse), 1908; Am Sonniger Hang (On the Sunny Slope), 1909; Columbus the Christ Bearer, 1911; Sonnets and Songs, 1911; also translations from the German. Residence: 1911 N. Taylor St.

ROTHGIESSER, Louis, men's furnishings: born Borek, Germany, Apr. 9, 1872; son of Michael and Charlotte (Kory) Rothgiesser; resident of St Louis since 1885; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St. Lonis, Feb. 9, 1897, Fannie Epstein; one daughter, Alice. On leaving school became connected with the gentlemen's furnishing and tailoring business with S. Rothgiesser & Bro., becoming a member of the firm in 1890, and in 1903 the style of the firm was changed to Rothgiesser Bros., as at present. Also vice president Colonial Laundry Co. and Colonial Tower Service Co. Member South Broadway Merchants' Association. Republican. Mason. Office: 101-103 N. Broadway. Residence: 4546 Laclede Ave.

ROTHGIESSER, Simon, men's furnishings: born in Germany, Mar. 22, 1860; son of Miehael and Charlotte (Kory) Rothgiesser; educated in St Louis public schools; unmarried. Resident of St Louis since 1876; connected with Kory & Sons, manufacturers of clothing, for seven years; established in business in men's furnishings, 1883; joined by brother, Louis, as S. Rothgiesser & Bro., and in 1903 the firm became Rothgiesser Bros.; director Washington National Bank. Republican. Member Young Men's Hebrew Association. Office: 101-103 N. Broadway.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association (secretary","1912)","Blackstone Society (president","1912)","Mississippi Society of St Louis (ex-president)","Delta Psi","Phi Delta Phi law fraternity"]
fullentry: ROUDEBUSH, Alfred Holt, lawyer; born New Orleans, Apr. 12, 1873; son of Rev. George Shot well (D.D.) and Margaret Hughes (Moore) Roudebush; A.B., University of Mississippi, 1894; LL.B., Washington University, 1900; married, St Louis, Nov. 30, 1907, Susan D'Arcy; one son, George Shotwell, Jr., born Feb. 18, 1909. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1901, and has practiced in St Louis since February, 1901; assistant city counselor, 1907-10; associate city counselor, 1910-11; was instructor in Smith Academy, 1896-1900. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member St Louis Bar Association (secretary, 1912), Blackstone Society (president, 1912), Mississippi Society of St Louis (ex-president), Delta Psi, Phi Delta Phi law fraternity. Recreation: walking. Office: 720 Rialto Bldg. Residence: 5616 Cates Ave.

ROWE, Thomas J., lawyer; born St Louis, June 26, 1851; son of David and Margaret (Fitzgerald) Rowe; A.B., Christian Brothers Academy, St Louis, 1868; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1872; married Elizabeth A. O'Neill of Griggsville, Ill., Aug. 7, 1879; nine children, six of whom are living: Thomas J., Jr., Henry, Robert, Nathaniel David, Mrs. Adele Rowe Oyler, and Vivian. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1872, and since engaged in practice in St Louis. Democrat. Catholic. Office: Suite 220 Wainwright Bldg. Residence: 3736 Delmar Boul.

ROWE, William, retired; born Bristol, England, Jan. 13, 1830; son of Thomas and Mary (Du Fay) Rowe; educated in public schools; married, 2d, Portsmouth, Eng., 1865, Harriet Young; children (by first wife): Mamie, William, Emma; children by 2d marriage: Nellie, Alice, Ada, Effie. Came to America in 1845 and to St Louis in 1849; engaged as mate and captain on steamboats plying the Mississippi River and all its tributaries, until 1865, and during the Civil War was captain of hospital boat on Mississippi for U. S. Government; in 1865 established in business as dealer in tents, awnings, and all kinds of duck goods, and later added rubber clothing and footwear, incorporating the business in 1894 as the Mound City Duck and Rubber Co., of which was president until 1909, when retired. Residence: 1525 N. Market St.

memberships: ["Merchants' Exchange of St Louis","Life Underwriters' Association","Kentucky Society"]
fullentry: ROWLAND, Edmund Shackelford, life insurance; born Richmond, Ky., Jan. 17, 1860; son of Sidney V. (one of the pioneers of Kentucky) and Susan (Shackelford) Rowland (descendant of the De Irvine family of Kentucky, which came to Virginia in the early days of the Revolution; William and Christopher Irvine and the latter's son Christopher were pioneers of Kentucky and actively instrumental in the development of the state); educated in schools at Danville, Ky.; married at Danville, 1882, to Miss Patti Belle Bryant. Traveled in California for two years for the Mayfield Woolen Mills Clothing Co.; connected with concessions during World's Fair period; resident manager for about one year for the North American Accident Insurance Co., of Chicago; city manager Prudential Insurance Co., 1905-07; since member of firm of Rowland & Wilson, general managers state of Missouri for Prudential Insurance Co. of America. Member Merchants' Exchange of St Louis, Life Underwriters' Association, Kentucky Society. Presbyterian. Clubs: St Louis, Missouri Athletic. Recreation: fishing. Office: 512 Chemical Bldg. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

ROWLAND, Joseph Henry, contractor granitoid paving; born Hamilton Co., Tex., Feb. 12, 1855; son of Joseph and Sallie Ann (Ferguson) Rowland; educated in district schools of Frsnklin Co., Mo.; married, St Louis, Nov. 6, 1893, Mary E. Hartmann; six children: Hazel, Joseph Edgar, Jessie Mabel, George, Alice and William. Engaged in farming in Franklin Co. until 1888 and then became connected with blacksmithing; conducted a flour mill in Gasconade Co., Mo., 1889-93; located in St Louis, 1893, and has since been identified with contracting business; founder and head of Joseph H. Rowland Granitoid Construction Co. Democrat. Universalist. Member Royal Arcanum. Office: 610 Chestnut St. Residence: De Soto, Mo.

RUBELMANN, George Alwin, president George A. Rubelmann Hardware Co.; born St Louis, Apr. 7, 1869; son of George A. and Sara (Guthrie) Rubelmann; educated in St Louis public schools, LaGrange (Mo.) Baptist College, and Foster's Academy, St Louis; married, Louisiana, Mo., June 6, 1895, Mattie Harvey. On leaving school in 1885, entered the house of George A. Rubelmann Hardware Co. (established 1860, incorporated 1881), and after serving in various capacities became vice president of the company. For one year, because of impaired health, traveled extensively in the United States. Republican. Baptist. Member Knights of Pythias. Office: 905907 N. Sixth St. Residence: 6131 Westminster Place.

RUBELMANN, George Ferdinand, president Rubelmann-Lucas Hardware Co.; born St Louis, May 2(5, 1869; son of John G. and Bertha (Umrath) Rubelmann; educated in public and private schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, 1896, Anna Wiegand; one daughter, Alice D. Began business career as assistant to father, John G. Rubelmann, in hardware store (established 1860), the firm then being Rubelmann & Co., and incorporated July, 1885, as the Rubelmann-Lucas Hardware Co., of which later became a director and since 1898 has been president of the company. Member Civic League. Member Evangelical Church. Office: 1939 N. Broadway. Residence: 6309 McPherson Ave.

RUBINSTEIN, Tobias I*, shirt manufacturer; born Kovno, Russia, 1866; son of Nathan I. and Sarah R. (Taubman) Rubinstein; educated in Russia; came to United States, July, 1881; married, St Louis, September, 1890, Lillie Weiss; children: Wilton, Adeline. Started in shirt business in 1887; incorporated, 1893, as the New Era Manufacturing Co. Hebrew religion. Office: 903 Lucas Ave. Residence: 4382 Pine St.

RUCKER, William Henry, 2d vice president Boogher, Force & Goodbar Hat Co.; born Cole Camp, Benton Co., Mo., Sept. 25, 1857; son of Henry Anthony and America Fry (Ferguson) Rucker; educated in public schools of Pilot Grove, Mo.; married, Columbia, Mo., Oct. 25, 1882, Fannie Hickman Lukens; one daughter, Lucile. Began active career as clerk in general store at Pilot Grove for H. W. Harris, 1875; entered business on own account in same town as Lukens & Rucker, 1883; sold out to Gehlken & Maddex in 1889; became connected with the Scott & Jones Hat Co., of St Louis, Jan. 1, 1888, and continued with its successor, the Boogher, Force & Goodbar Hat Co. to present time, director and 2d vice president since 1906. Democrat. Baptist. Member William D. Muir Lodge, No. 277, A. F. & A. M.; St Louis Chapter, No. 8, R. A. M.; Missouri Consistory, No. 1; Moolah Temple, A. A. O. N. M. S. Recreation: breeding standard bred horses. Office: 1608 Washington Ave. Residence: Columbia, Mo.

RUECKING, Herman, president Ruecking Construction Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 6, 1858; son of Henry and Louise (Zu Broxton) Ruecking; educated in public schools, St Louis, to 1873; married, St Louis, Oct. 21, 1881, Emma Rapp (died, 1903); married, 2d, St Louis, June, 1904, Clara Schubert; three children: Herman, Emma, Frederick. After leaving school, engaged with father in contracting business, and continued until 1886; then engaged in business for self, first building sewers for city. Purchased quarry, 1888, and conducted same alone until incorporated as Ruecking Construction Co., 1904; since conducting general construction and quarry business. Interested in municipal government; served as Ninth Ward delegate on City Central Committee. Republican. Protestant. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Liederkranz. Recreation: athletic sports. Office: 4030 Marine Ave. Residence: 4850 S. Broadway.

RUECKOLDT, George, manufacturer of fixtures; born Waldkappel, Germany, Jan. 14, 1852; son of George and Elizabeth (Burg-hardt) Rueckoldt; educated in public schools in Germany; married, Bremen, Germany, Oct. 17, 1875, Anna Werner; children: Bertha (Mrs. Adolph Miller), Emma (Mrs. Gustava Schmitt), Charles, George (deceased). Learned cabinet-maker's trade in Germany, beginning 1866, and served several years there as superintendent before coming direct from Germany to St Louis, 1881; employed twenty months in B. Tholes Artistic Cabinet Works, then started in business with William Staudte, as manufacturers of interior wood work, under firm name of Staudte & Rueckoldt, until 1893. when business was incorporated as the Staudte & Rueckoldt Manufacturing Co., of which has since been president. Independent in politics. Member German Evangelical Church. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Member St Louis Social Society, German-American Alliance. Club: Liederkranz. Favorite recreation: athletic exercises. Office: 112 Soulard St. Residence: 3549 Holliday Ave.

RUEHMKORF, Henry J., secretary and treasurer Feuerborn Toy Co.; born Red Bud, Ill., Nov. 6, 1859; educated in public schools; married, 1888, Anna Bahrenburg. Began business career with general merchandise firm iu home town, and continued to 1888; then came to St Louis and engaged with Hennen & Co., dealers in notions, as salesman, and became a partner, 1905; business changed hands and was incorporated as Feuerborn Toy Co., of which has since been secretary and treasurer. Republican. Methodist. Member Royal Arcanum. Office: 919 N. Broadway.

RUEMMELI, Albert, manufacturer; born in City of Mexico, Jan. 24, 1853; son of Henry and Elizabeth (Hoffmann) Ruemmeli; educated in Germany; married at Zurich, 1881, Louisa Knoblauch; children: Marie, Clara, Ella, Louise, Alice. Learned trade of machinist in Switzerland and Germany; came to America in 1881, and worked in New York City, 18818.3, and in St Louis, 1883-96; in 1896 joined in organization of the Ruemmeli-Dawley Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of icemaking and refrigerating machinery, of which has since been president. Member Liederkranz. Office: 3900 Chouteau Ave. Residence: 2102 Lafayette Ave.

RUHE, Henry F. W., general manager American Bakery Co.; born Germany, May 12, 1847; son of Henry and Maria (Borg-manu) Ruhe; educated in public and parochial schools, to 1857; then came to America, and continued studies at Indianapolis, until 1860; took course in Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, Buffalo, N. Y., Dec. 17, 1868. Mary Werner; seven children: Mary (Mrs. William May), Henry W., Carrie (Mrs. Frederick E. C. Kuhlmann), Bertha (Mrs. Julius Horstman), Louisa, George and Gertrude. Served as apprentice, and journeyman carpenter, to 1872; began as salesman with Welle-Boettler Bakery Co., 1872, became partner, 1884, and continued until 1897, when company merged into the American Bakery Co. and he became director and general manager same. President Ruhe-Boettler Realty Co.; vice president Theo. R. Appel Realty Co.; director North-Western Bank. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Liederkranz. Recreations: motoring, traveling. Office: 901-7 Liggett Bldg. Residence: 2129 St Louis Ave.

RUHL, Joseph Anthony, clothing manufacturer; born Columbus, O., Oct. 31, 1855; son of Anton and Caroline (Engler) Ruhl; reared on farm; educated in schools of Columbus; married, Columbus, Nov. 25, 1880, Catherine G. Zimmer; children: John A., Charles J., Lucille, Agnes, Catherine, Marie, Marguerite. In 1875 took position as stock clerk in wholesale elothing store at Columbus; moved to Omaha, Xeb., 1887, and started firm of Gilmore & Ruhl, which moved to St Louis, April, 1897; after death of Mr. Gilmore, organized the J. A. Ruhl Clothing Co., wholesale clothing manufacturers, of which is president. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Catholic. Office: 1231 Washington Ave. Residence: 4459 Lindell Ave.

memberships: ["Business Men's League","Lake-to-the-Gulf Deep Waterway Association","Missouri Manufacturers' Association","Universal Exposition Co"]
fullentry: RULE, Adrian Ogle, real estate; born in Pike Co., Mo., Nov. 12, 1860; son of John Thomas and Eliza Ann (Ogle) Rule; educated in Louisiana (Mo.) High School, and in law school of Washington University, 1885; married, St Louis, Nov. 27, 1895, Julia Cave; five children: Adrian O., Jr., Francis Daniel, John Cave, Rhodes Elmore, Mary Julia. Began business career as printer's boy in office of Champ Clark, when latter edited paper at Louisiana, Mo., for three years; came to St Louis, 1881; librarian St Louis Law Library for four years; studied law, was admitted to bar, 1885, and engaged in practice until September, 1889; since in business as real estate and financial agent; vice president Kilgen-Rule Real Estate Co. Member Business Men's League, Lake-to-the-Gulf Deep Waterway Association, Missouri Manufacturers' Association, Universal Exposition Co., St Louis Real Estate Exchange (ex-president). Democrat. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Noonday, Maine Hunting and Fishing. Office: 713 Chestnut St. Residence: 3832 Lindell Boul.

RULE, Virgil, lawyer; born Louisiana, Pike Co., Mo., Mar. 31, 1864; son of John T. and Eliza Ann (Ogle) Rule; educated in public schools, Louisiana, graduating from high school, 1880; LL.B., St Louis Law School (Washington University), 1887; married, St Louis, Feb. 16, 1898, Estelle, daughter of John D. Johnson; children: Amy Johnson, John Thomas, Jane, Helen, Virgil, Jr. Printer's 4‘devil," Louisiana Journal, 1880; employed with division engineer Chicago & Alton R. R., at Louisiana, 1881; clerk Exchange Bank, Louisiana, and Farmers' Bank, Bowling Green, Mo., 1881-83; assistant librarian and librarian, Law Library Association of St Louis, 188390; studied law while in library, 1884-87; in office of Charles P. and John D. Johnson, 189094; in practice of law in St Louis since 1891. Judge of Circuit Court, 1908. Democrat. Member American and St Louis Bar associations. Clubs: St Louis, Bellerive Country. Office: 1016, 506 Olive St. Residence: 3731 Westminster PL

company: James W. Byrnes Belting and Hose Co.
fullentry: RUMSEY, Edwin, vice-president James W. Byrnes Belting and Hose Co.; born East Bridgewater, Mass., March 10, 1851; son of Alfred S. and Marcia A. (Hatch) Rumsey; educated in public and private schools and high school, Bridgewater, Mass.; married, Mid-dleboro, Mass., May 6, 1872, G. Matilda Briggs. Came to St Louis from Xew York in 1880, and started as salesman .for the L. M. Rumsey Manufacturing Co.; in 1890 engaged with the Revere Rubber Co., and in 1896 the James W. Byrnes Belting and Hose Co. was incorporated. In 1910 firm name was changed to Byrnes Belting Co., of which has since been vice president and sales manager, company being manufacturers of belting and wholesale* dealers in all kinds of hose and packings, and now located in own new building, occupying 40,000 square feet of floor space. Also general manager St Louis Fire Hose and Equipment Co. Republican in national, liberal in local politics. Non-sectarian. Office: 2107-11 Locust St. Residence: 5045 Raymond Ave.

office: 810 N. 2d St.; branch office: Mexico City, Mexico.
memberships: ["Military and Naval Order Spanish-Ainerican War","Order of Foreign Wars"]
fullentry: RUMSEY, Horace Southard, vice president and general manager of the L. M. Rumsey Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, March 30, 1877; son of Lewis Miller and Emma (Gaty) Rumsey; educated in public schools, Smith Academy, St Louis Manual Training School, class of 1895, and Washington University; married, St Louis, Nov. 19, 1902, Louise Chappell; one daughter, Louise G. C. On leaving school entered the shops of the L. M. Rumsey Manufacturing Co., and after learning the business of manufacturing steam fittings and plumbing supplies took charge of the machine shop; served as volunteer in Spanish-American War, 1898; was traveling salesman, covering United States, Canada and Mexico, 18981900, for the L. M. Rumsey Manufactkring Co.; became cashier in 1900, and in 1902 was made general manager of the company, now also vice president. President Security Building Co.; director Good Hope Mining Co. Served ten years in 1st Regiment National Guard of Missouri as 2d lieutenant of Company L, 1st lieutenant of Company H, and captain of Company A. Member Military and Naval Order Spanish-Ainerican War, Order of Foreign Wars. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: Noonday, Mercantile, Missouri Athletic, Glen Echo. Recreations: golf, motoring and fishing. Office: 810 N. 2d St.; branch office: Mexico City, Mexico. Residence: 5265 Westminster Place.

RUMSEY, Lewis Miller, Jr., president L. M. Rumsey Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, Jan. 24, 1870; son of Lewis Miller and Emma (Gaty) Rumsey; educated in public schools of St Louis, Washington University, and Smith Academy, class of 1893; married, St Louis, Apr. 2, 1902, Florence Newton; children: Lewis Miller, H., and Margaret. On leaving school became associated with the L. M. Rum-sey Manufacturing Co., manufacturers and jobbers of steam fittings, etc., established by father in 1805; advanced from office boy through various departments; had charge of factory and later of the office, then vice president until 1905, since president of the company. Also director St Louis Union Trust Co. and State National Bank of St Louis; secretary Granite Bi-Metallic Consolidated Mining Co. Served eight years in First Regiment, Missouri National Guard, and for six months in First Missouri Volunteer Infantry in Spanish-American War. Member Military Order of Foreign Wars. Clubs: Noonday, Glen Echo, Missouri Athletic, Racquet. Recreations: hunting and golf. Office: 810 N. 2nd St. Residence: 4378 Westminster PL

RUNYAN, Van Leer, dental supplies; born Nashville, Tenn., Dec. 17, 1846; son of Benjamin M. and Mary E. (Dunkin) Runyan; educated in St Louis public schools and Washington University until 1803; married, Prairie du Rocher, Dec. 19, 1868, Euphrasie Clarke; children: Benjamin M., Clement D., Van L., Jr., Eloise M. (Mrs. Lucien M. Harris), Robert A., Caroline P. (Mrs. Wm. Simpson), Sidney L. Has been resident of St Louis from childhood, and was engaged in various mercantile and financial pursuits until 1893; assistant cashier of the Continental National Bank, 1893-96, and of the Fourth National Bank, 1896-1905; cashier, 1905-06, assistant cashier, 1906-11, National Bank of Commerce; since vice president O'Brien-Worthen Co., dental supplies. Office: 906 Olive St. Residence: 5808 Westminster PI.

RUPRECHT, William, president W. & F. Ruprecht Construction Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 14, 1869; son of Joseph and Barbara (Kunkel) Ruprecht; educated iu public schools to thirteen; married, St Louis, 1888, Louisa Emmeneger; three children: William, Edward, Frank. Learned trade of stationary engineer; later engaged in hauling business, and organized firm of W. & F. Ruprecht, general contractors, now W. & F. Ruprecht Construction Co.; secretary and treasurer Banner Bottling Co., Banner Sash and Door Co.; member Rup-recht-Voirol Hollow Concrete Block Construction Co.; director Southern Commercial Savings Bank. Catholic. Member Woodmen of America. Office: 8011 S. Broadway. Residence: 8300 8. Broadway.

RUSSELL, Charles Silas, manufacturer and miner; born St Louis Co., Mar. 7, 1833; son of James and Lucy (Bent) Russell; educated in St Louis Co. and at Yale College; married, St Louis, 1818, Mary E. Mead (who died, 1897); 2d, St Louis, 1906, Florence Davis; children (all by first marriage): Sue M. (Mrs. Thomas G. Portis), Silas Bent, Charles M., and three sons who are deceased—Edward Mead, Guy R. and Wolfert Ecker. Began active career in connection with affairs relating to the family estate, and for several years was associated with his mother in management of the Oak Hill Farm and coal mines owned by the estate, adjoining the tract of land now known as Tower Grove Park, in St Louis; assisted in organizing the Russell Coal Co., of which was general manager; president for many years of the Parker-Russell Mining & Manufacturing Co., now chairman of board; president Russell Real Estate & Investment Co. Democrat. Episcopalian. Recreation: literature. Office: 501 Liggett Bldg. Residence: 5973 Cates Ave.

RUSSELL, Ernest John, architect; born London, England, March 5, 1870; son of John Stokes and Mary J. (Mayhew) Russell; came to United States in childhood; educated in public schools in Colorado; married, Springfield, O., 1896, Elizabeth Dunlap; two children: Mary D., Elizabeth B. Began study of architecture in 1887, and has been continuously identified with the profession ever since; member of firm of Mauran, Russell & Garden, 1900-09, Mauran & Russell, 1909-11, Mauran, Russell & Crowell since 1911. Past chairman Public Baths Commission; past president Architects' League of America; fellow American Institute of Architects; member American Society for Testing Materials, St Louis Architectural Club, Missouri Historical Society. Member House of Delegates, St Louis, 1909-1911. Baptist. Clubs: University, St Louis, Racquet, Noonday, City, Automobile, Aero, Glen Echo, Bellerive. Recreation: automobiling. Office: 1620 Chemical Bldg. Residence: 3835 Westminster PL

RUSSELL, Francis Wayland, clergyman; born Fairport, N. Y., Sept. 21, 1865; son of Byron P. and Betsy (Pitman) Russell; B.Sc., University of Nebraska, 1890; graduated McCormick Theological Seminary, 1894; (D.D., Coe College, 1903); married Lucile Cross, of Fairbury, Neb., Oct. 5, 1897. Ordained Presbyterian ministry, 1894; pastor, Fairbury, 1894-7, Marshalltown, Ia., 1897-1903, Boulder, Colo., 1903-04, West Presbyterian Church, St Louis, since 1904. Chairman foreign missions work, Presbyterian Church, for Missouri. Member Loyal Legion, Sigma Chi. Club: Mercantile. Address: 5848 Maple avenue.

RUSSELL, S. Bent, civil engineer; born in St Louis County (now St Louis), Aug. 21, 1860; son of Charles S. and Mary Elizabeth (Mead) Russell; educated at St. Paul's College, Palmyra, Mo., Shenandoah Valley Academy, Winchester, Va., Smith Academy and Washington University, St Louis, graduating as engineer of mines, 1881; married, 1886, Anne Clendenin; three children: Austin C., Isabel K., Wolfert E. Began professional work, 1881, as instrument man on railroad and river improvement work; entered St Louis Water Department as assistant engineer, 1882, and most of practice after that until 1902 was in engineering positions in that department; since 1902 in private practice as consulting civil engineer. In 1908 was chief engineer Louisville water works; became secretary and treasurer of The Parker-Russell Mining and Manufacturing Co., January, 1911; also interested in Russell Real Estate and Investment Co. Past president St Louis Engineers' Club; member American Society of Civil Engineers, Civic League. Originator of several improvements in machinery for testing materials. Author of numerous professional monographs and contributions. Clubs: City, Bellerive Country. Recreation: Golf. Office: 501-508 Liggett Bldg. Residence: 4950 Washington Ave.

RUSSELL, Thomas A., lawyer; born Cabell Co., Va. (now W. Va.), Aug. 24, 1834; son of John and Rebecca (Buffington) Russell; was a student of Marshall Academy, Cabell Co., 1846-47; came to Missouri, 1847; entered University of Missouri, 1847, but gave up studies to cross plains to California, 1849; returned to Missouri, 1854, and again entered University of Missouri, graduating 1857; studied law under brother, Col. F. T. Russell, and was admitted to bar at Kansas City, Mo., 1858; married, Columbia, Mo., Feb. 16, 1858, Miss M. L. Lenoir; two children: Minnie L. (now wife of J. D. Thomas) and Frances L. (wife of Dr. Thomas E. Ferguson). Began practice in Kansas City, 1857, associating with Thomas F. Bell; removed to St Louis, 1864, and practiced until 1907, except during years 1895, '9(i and '97, when he served as judge of Circuit Court. Interested in Lenox Hall, a young ladies' school, conducted by his daughter, Mrs. Thomas, at University City. Has served as member and vice president of Board of Education, St Louis. Democrat. Member Christian (Disciples) Church. Odd Fellow. Office: Laclede Bldg. Residence: 4041 Cook Ave.

RUST. Martin A., real estate; born St Louis, July 25, 1864; son of Bernhard and Helena (Menne) Rust; educated St. Anthony's (parochial) School; St Louis University; Bry- 5i: ant & Stratton Business College; married, St Louis, May 8, 1889, Clara B. Lodenkamper; seven children: Martin L., Walter J., Adele C., Larelda B., Marcella C., Othmar J., Ermin G. Began active career as clerk for Wulfing Dieckriede & Co., wholesale grocers, 1878; became clerk for J. F. Imbs Milling Co., 1880, advancing as bookkeeper, cashier and treasurer until 1903; then was appointed deputy recorder of deeds, which position he held for three years; resigned Apr. 30, 1906, and on May 1, started real estate firm of Korte-Rust Realty Co., with which has since been identified. Member Real Estate Exchange. Democrat. Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus, St. Vincent's Orphan Society, St Anthony's and St. Cecelia's Benevolent Societies, etc. Recreation: reading. Oflice: 816 Chestnut St. Residence: 4119 Oregon Ave.

RUTLEDGE, Charles Waite, lawyer; born Hillsboro, Ill., Mar. 16, 1871; son of Thomas Jefferson and Sylvia (Bennett) Rutledge; educated public schools; Hillsboro Academy; Washington University; married, Springfield, Ill., July 5, 1895, Florence N. Morse. In real estate business, 1891-96; admitted to Missouri bar, 1896, and since in practice at St Louis. Alternate delegate to Republican National Convention, Chicago, 1908; candidate for Republican nomination for circuit judge, 1908 and 1910. Protestant. Member St Louis Bar association, Civic League. Mason; member Knights of Pythias. Club: Rotary. Recreation: literature. Office: 924 Wainwright Bldg. Residence: 3658 Flad Ave.

RUTLEDGE, James Edmund, president Rutledge & Taylor Coal Co., selling agents for the Xew Staunton Coal Co., Security Coal and Mining Co. and Groom Coal Co.; born Bloomington, Ill., Oct. 30, 1861; son of Washington Delany and Lucy (Askins) Rutledge; educated in public schools of St Louis; children: Hattie Frances (Mrs. R L. Murphy, of East St Louis), Walter Edmund. Resident of St Louis since 1871, coming from Springfield, Ill.; began business career as cash boy at William Barr Dry Goods Co., and later in various other occupations, finally entering the coal business as salesman for the Consolidated Coal Co., in 1888; began business on own account in 1894. Organized the Rutledge & Taylor Coal Co., shippers of bituminous coal, of which is president and treasurer; this company has branch offices at Chicago and Davenport, Iowa, and salesmen of the company cover all territory reached by Illinois coal fields; the company handles 1,500,000 tons of coal yearly. Also president and treasurer Security Coal and Mining Co.; president New Staunton Coal Co., and Standard Briquette Fuel Co., of Kansas City. Member Business Men's League. Mason. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic. Favorite recreations: fishing and music. Office: 820 Security Bldg. Residence: 5950 Von Versen Ave.

RUTLEDGE, Oscar Pinckney, insurance; born in Titus County, Tex., Mar. 3, 1859; son of James and Martha (Sparks) Rutledge; educated in public schools of Texas; married, Columbia, Tenn., Dec. 5, 1882, Anna Wilson. Began in drug business at Columbia, continuing for thirteen years as clerk or proprietor; then sold out and bought interest in Columbia (Tenn.) Herald, of which was business manager; sold out and entered general insurance as agent for various companies in fire and casualty insurance; special agent in Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee, 1901-2; resident manager, liability and boiler department, U. 8. Casualty Co. of New York, at St Louis, covering Missouri and southern Illinois, 1902-08; with J. E. Lawton & Son, as manager of liability department, 1908-Nov. 30, 1911; since Dec. 1, 1911, manager of the casualty department of the Fidelity & Deposit Company of Baltimore, Md., covering eastern and southwestern Missouri and southern Illinois. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member Tuscan Lodge Xo. 360, A. F. and A. M., Royal Arcanum, Legion of Honor. Club: City. Favorite recreations: fishing, hunting, boating. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 1041 Goodfellow Ave.

RUTLEDGE, Robert, real estate agent; born, Gold Hill, El Dorado County, California, Mar. 4, 1857; son of Edward and Elizabeth (Wrav) Rutledge; educated in public schools in California; married, Allegheny, Pa., Nov. 17, 1881, Elizabeth McLelland Cowden; children: Robert C., Edward A., Elizabeth W., Helen W. (Mrs. Robert S. Montgomery), Thomas Granville. Came to St Louis with parents in 1873; began as office boy iu 1874; three years later became bookkeeper, and in 1880 member of firm of S. D. Porter & Co.; in December, IS,84, title of firm was changed to Rutledge & Kilpatrick, and later became the Rutledge & Kilpatrick Realty Co., of which is president. Member Real Estate Exchange. Democrat. Member United Presbyterian Church. Clubs: Mercantile, St Louis. Recreation: reading. Office: 717 Chestnut St. Residence: 4414 Morgan St.

partyqual: / ic nominee for circuit judge in 1910
memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Missouri Historical Society; president Washington University Association","1911-12"]
fullentry: RUTLEDGE, Thomas George, lawyer; born, Gold Hill, El Dorado County, California, July 26, 1871; son of Edward and Elizabeth (Wrav) Rutledge; came to St Louis with parents, 1873; educated in St Louis public schools; A.B., Washington University, 1892, LL.B., 1894; unmarried. Admitted to bar in 1894, and has since been continuously engaged in general practice in St Louis; now member of firm of Johnson, Rutledge, Marlatt & Lashly. Democratic nominee for circuit judge in 1910. United Presbyterian. Member St Louis Bar Association, Missouri Historical Society; president Washington University Association, 1911-12. Clubs: University, Bellerive, City. Office: 506 Olive St. Residence: 4951 Washington Ave.

RUTLEDGE, William Askins, real estate; born Mechaniesburg, Ill., Mar. 12, 1855; son of Washington Delany and Lucy (Askins) Rutledge; educated in public schools of Springfield, HI.; also course in business college; married, St Louis, Feb. 17, 1903, Mrs. Fannie L. Poole; one stepson, Clemens Arthur Poole. Began business career, 1870, in employ of wholesale, law book firm, and later with wholesale drug houses; dealer in real estate since 1873; in business alone, 1877-1882; partner with William M. Horton, 1882-95, then alone until 1897; since president of William A. Rutledge Realty Co. Republican. Methodist; was for several years secretary and treasurer St Louis City Church Extension and Missionary Society of M. E. Church. Life member Y. M. C. A. Mason. Recreations: fishing, boating. Residence: 5246 Minerva Ave.

RYAN, Michael S., C.M., D.D., president Kenrick Seminary; born 8t. Louis, Dec. 22, 1875; son of John and Ellen (Ready) Ryan; educated St. Mary's Seminary, Perryville, Mo.; University of Minerva, Rome, Italy; degrees of Ph.D. and D.D. from Roman University. Ordained to priesthood Roman Catholic Church by Cardinal Cassetta, Rome, Italy, 1898; president Kenrick Seminary since Sept. 1, 1906; also professor moral and pastoral theology. Residence: Kenrick Seminary.

memberships: ["of Public Library Board; member St Louis","Missouri State and American Bar associations","Civic League"]
fullentry: RYAN, O'Neill, lawyer, jurist; born St Louis, Jan. 5, 1860; son of Richard and Margaret (O'Neill) Ryan; educated at Benton (public) School until 1873; then at Polytechnic Building Xight School for two years; studied law in office of Given Campbell; married, St Louis, 1897, to Mary Carmen Rash-coe; children: John O'Neill, Francis Campbell, Mary Carmen, Mary Kathleen Margaret. Admitted to bar in June, 1880; partner in law practice with Given Campbell, 1883-99; judge of Circuit Court of City of St Louis, 1900-06; resumed practice and since 1911 member firm of Ryan & Thompson. Member of Public Library Board; member St Louis, Missouri State and American Bar associations, Civic League. Was Supreme Chancellor of Legion of Honor of Missouri, 1890. Catholic. Club: Noonday. Office: 506 Olive St. Residence: 29 Windemere PI.

SACHS, Guy Solomon, merchant; boru, St Louis, May 5, 1879; son of Solomon and Minnie (Epstein) Sachs; educated in St Louis public schools, graduating from Central High School, 1896; married, St Louis, Jan. 11, 1911, Marie Heibel. Began business as traveling salesman for Hurst & Zucker Neckwear Co.; organized, 1905, the Superior Manufacturing Co., of which is president. Republican. Jewish religion. Club: Columbian. Recreation: motoring. Office: 801 Washington Ave. Residence: 6160 Washington Ave.

occupation: concert pianist and teacher of piano
memberships: ["National Music Teachers' Association","Missouri State Music Teachers' Association (ex-president)"]
fullentry: SACKS, Nathan, concert pianist and teacher of piano; born St Louis, June 4, 1870; son of Simon and Rachel (Ryback) Sacks; graduated St Louis High School, 1886; studied music with Alberto Jonas, Ann Arbor, Mich., 189798; then went to Vienna, Austria, and spent -V2 years under Prof. Theodore Leschetizky; studied composition with R. Fuchs, Vienna, and Max Bruch and J. Wolff, Berlin, spending three years in Europe; married, St. James, Mo., July 11, 1912, Mrs. Maude A. Rawlings, daughter of Captain and Mrs. W. F. Henry. Began teaching music in St Louis and East St Louis, 1888; upon returning from abroad, 1902, was appointed music director of Baylor Female College, Belton, Tex.; returned to St Louis, 1903, and founded Sacks School of Music, of which has since been director. Republican. Jewish religion. Member National Music Teachers' Association, Missouri State Music Teachers' Association (ex-president). Prominently identified with musical affairs and has given one to three annual piano recitals in St Louis for past seven or eight years. Club: Papyrus. Author (piano compositions): Cradle Song; Minuet; Themb and Variations; also a number of unpublished compositions for piano. Address: 619 N. Kingshighway.

SACKS, William, lawyer; born St Louis, Mar. 18, 1874; son of Simon and Rachel (Ryback) Sacks; educated in public schools, St Louis High School, and Benton Law College; married, Apr. 7, 1905, Miss Lynna Heard. Entered postal service as clerk in 1891; became chief clerk, foreman, assistant superintendent and finally superintendent of city delivery; held latter office for five years, until January, 1905 (chairman of board civil service examiners, 1898-1903), when resigned, on admission to bar, to take up general practice of law, in which is now engaged. Director Wellston Trust Co., president Lynna Realty and Investment Company. Republican. Jewish religion. President Young Men's Hebrew Association, 1903-4. Member Masonic fraternity, B'nai B'rith. Office: 706 Carleton Bldg. Residence: 6152 Berlin Ave.

memberships: ["of St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations","Missouri Historical Society"]
fullentry: SAGER, Arthur Noble, lawyer; born Kenosha, Wis., Dec. 2, 1871; son of George H. ami Margaret (Long) Sager; educated in Kenosha High School; LL.B., Law Department of De Pauw University, Greencastle, Ind., 1893; married, Feb. 14, 1894, Lizzie Scott; one son, George H., Jr.; married, 2d, Jan. 3, 1901, Louisville, Ky., Matilda F. C. Cowling; one (laughter, Margaret Churchill. Admitted to bar in Arkansas, 1893; came to St Louis, 1896, and has since engaged in general practice. Circuit attorney of St Louis, 1904-08, then resumed private practice. Member of St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations, Missouri Historical Society. Republican. Methodist. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile. Favorite recreations: literature and music. Office: New Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 4916 McPherson Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society; president Gregory Medical Society"]
fullentry: SAHLENDER, Otto L., physician and surgeon; born Belleville, Ill., March 17, 1870; son of Gottfried and Julia Luetta Sahlender; educated in public schools of Belleville, and Medical Department of Washington University, graduating M.D., 1896; unmarried. Has been in St Louis since 1893; began in commercial pursuits, then took up study of medicine; engaged in practice as physician and surgeon since 1896; was physician in charge of obstetrical out-clinic of Washington University for one year; on hospital staff 4th Illinois Infantry, 1893-96. Member St Louis Medical Society; president Gregory Medical Society. Office and Residence: 321 N. Grand Ave.

birthcity: Ireland; son of Henry Lucas and Harriet Charlotte (Sterne) St. George; educated under private tuition; married
fullentry: ST._GEORGE, William Sterne, railway official; born in Ireland; son of Henry Lucas and Harriet Charlotte (Sterne) St. George; educated under private tuition; married, Grace Kinnear Reeves, of New York City, Apr. 23, 1899; two daughters: Marjory, Katherine. Contracting freight agent Port Royal & Augusta Railway, at Augusta, Ga., 1876-81; secretary and treasurer Augusta & Port Royal Compress Co., 1881-2; freight agent, Savannah, Florida & Western Railway at Savannah, Ga., Jan. 1-Oot. 15, 1882; general southern agent at Atlanta, Ga., 1882-3, general agent at Louisville, Ky., 1883-4, general eastern agent at Xew York, 1884-94, Cincinnati, New Orleans & Texas Pacific Railway; general eastern agent at Xew York, 1894-1905, and general passenger and ticket agent at St Louis, since Oct. 15, 1905, Missouri, Kansas & Texas Railway. Clubs: Mercantile, The Traffic of St Louis. Recreation: boating. Office: Wainwright Bldg. Residence: Cambridge Apts.
