SALE, Lee, lawyer; born Louisville, Ky., March 8, 1861; son of Isaac and Henrietta (Dinkelspiel) Sale; educated in public and high schools, Louisville;; A.B., Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, 1881; teacher at Boys' High School, Louisville, Ky., 1881-83; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1885; married, St Louis, April 27, 1903, Hilda Levy. Admitted to bar at St Louis, June, 1885, and since engaged in general law practice; member of firm of Sale & Sale. Lecturer St Louis Law School, 1892- 07. Democrat; member Board of Commissioners on Charitable Institutions of St Louis, appointed 1904. Member of St Louis Bar Association. Member of .Jewish Congregation Shaare Emeth. Was active in the organization of the Jewish Hospital of St Louis, and was secretary and director during the first three years of its existence. Favorite recreation: fishing. Office: 1514-1518 New Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 5200 McPherson Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations"]
fullentry: SALE, Moses Nathaniel, lawyer; born Louisville, Ky., Oct. 17, 1857; son of Isaac and Henrietta (Dinkebpiel) Sale; educated in Louisville public schools; B.A., University of Louisville, 1877; attended Louisville Law School while in office of James Speed, ex-atty.-general of the United States, and read law for two years in his office until September, 1881; married, St Louis, April 5, 1887, Florence D. Rider; children: Rietta, Erna (deceased), Frances. Admitted to bar, 1879; came to St Louis, September, 1881, aud engaged in practice, first alone, then as senior member of Sale and Sale, 1884-1903. Judge of Circuit Court of the City of St Louis, first by appointment of Governor Dockery, in November, 1903, to fill the unexpired term of Franklin Ferriss, resigned, and elected November, 1904, for term of six years; since December, 1910, member firm Sale & Sale. Member St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations. Democrat. Jewish religion. Member of Selden Society of London. Club: Noonday. Office: 415 Pine St. Residence: 5632 Cabanne Ave.

SALE, Samuel, rabbi; born Louisville, Oct. 29, 1854; son of Isaac and Henrietta (Dinkel-spiel) Sale; graduated public schools and at University of Louisville, 1872; studied at University of Berlin and at Rabinnical Seminary of Berlin, 1873-8; University of Berlin, 1878; rabinnical diploma; married, Baltimore, Jan. 12, 1881, Rachel Goldenberg; children: Llewellyn, Ashley, Irma, Gretchen, Frank, Ruth and Blanche. Rabbi of Har Sinai Congregation, Baltimore, 1878-83, Congregation Anshe Maarab, Chicago, 1883-7; Congregation Shaare Emeth (“Gates of Truth"), St Louis, since 1887. Has officiated as chaplain at all national political conventions held in St Louis during residence there. Member B 'nai B 'rith. Mason (32°). Recreation: study of classical and Oriental languages. Address: 4621 Westminster PL

SALISBURY, Charles Edwin; born Utica, N. Y., March 31, 1862; son of John and Mary Salisbury; educated in public schools; married, Arkansas City, Kan., 1887, Rose Wagner; children: Fay W., Earl E. Began business career as clerk in retail store of W. Lippett, Hamilton, N. Y., 1879-80; then with A. Allen, retail boots and shoes, 1880-80; then in retail boot and shoe business at Arkansas City, Kan., 1886-98; came to St Louis, 1898, and became connected with O. J. Lewis Mercantile Co., wholesale auctioneers and commission merchants, of which was treasurer from 1900 to 1907, later vice president. Recreation: traveling. Office: 616 N. Eighth St. Residence: 5142 Cabanne Ave.

SALOMON, Fred Zadek; born Greeley, Colo., October 11, 1872; son of Adolph Z. and Matilda (Joel) Salomon; educated, Denver High School; unmarried. Was associated with father in department store business in Denver until 1901; came to St Louis, 1901, as superintendent Famous Shoe & Clothing Co. (now Famous Barr Co.), and still continues as superintendent; also president Associated Retailers' Suburban Delivery Co. Jewrish religion. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country. Recreations: motoring and swimming. Office: 519 Washington Ave. Residence: 4950 McPherson Ave.

SALTER, John Cleveland, physician; born. Waverly, Ill., Aug. 7, 1873; son of John Cleveland and Margaret (McKee) Salter; graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., 1893; A.B., Yale University, 1897; M.D., Johns Hopkins University, 1901; post-graduate work, Berlin, 1901; unmarried. House physician, St. Luke's Hospital, New York, 1902-03; resident physician New York Lying-in Hosp., 1903-04; instructor Washington University, St Louis, since 1904; member visiting staff St Louis City Hospital, St Louis Skin and Cancer Hospital. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: University, City. Recreation; automobiling. Office: Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 4398B Olive St.

office: S. E. cor. 11th and Carr Sts.
fullentry: SANBORN, Charles W., vice president Standard Heel and Counter Co.; born Moul-tonborough, N. H., Dec. 7, 1863; son of Charles S. and Nancy L. (Eaton) Sanborn; educated in public schools in New Hampshire; married, Lynn, Mass., May 1, 1886, Emma D. Webster; seven children. Was connected with shoe manufacturing^ interests at Lynn, Mass., 1880-93; removed tof St Louis in 1893, and became connected with the Standard Heel and Counter Co., manufacturers of heels, counters, of which is vice president. Office: S. E. cor. 11th and Carr Sts. Residence: 4642 N. Market Street.

SANDERS, Barney Henry, iron and brass foundry; born St Louis, June 18, 1865; son of Henry and Louisa (Haase) Sanders; educated in private and public schools and business college; unmarried. Learned pattern making and machinist trade and worked as journeyman in various foundries; bought stock in Pleuger & Henger Manufacturing Co., and was secretary and general manager of the company from 1893 to 1908; firm name then changed to American Foundry and Manufacturing Co., of which is president and general manager. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic, Engineers'. Recreation: traveling. Office: 11th and Hebert Sts. Residence: 1114 Mallinckrodt St.

SANDERS, Lon, president Sanders Engraving Co.; born Corinth, Miss., Sept. 30, 1886; son of Dr. Marion M. and Cinnie C. (Bruton) Sanders; educated in public schools; married, Corinth, Apr. 25, 1891, Ida L. Sharp; children: Anita L., Gladys. Entered career of engraver at Chicago in 1886; came to St Louis in 1887, and organized the Sanders Engraving Co., manufacturing electrotypers and engravers, operating extensive plants at St Louis, Memphis, Tenn., and Chattanooga, Tenn.; is president of company and owner of 90 per cent of its stock. Also director Grand Avenue Rank; vice president National Thermo Co.; treasurer Chamberlain Park Association; secretary Clemens Place Protective Association. Is president Missouri Democratic' League and was the moving spirit in pushing the campaign of Joseph W. Folk for President. Was mentioned as a Democratic candidate for mayor in spring election, 1909, but declined to run. Was a nominee upon the Democratic ticket for City Council in April, 1911. Southern Methodist. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic. Office: 221-223 Olive St. Residence: 5431 Bartmer Ave.

SANDS, George Lincoln, railway official; born Brunswick, Me., Apr. 18, 1845; son of Jacob Waterhouse and Mary Jane (Dunlap) Sands; educated in public schools of Brunswick, Me.; entered merchant marine at age of sixteen, serving before the mast until September, 1863; entered United States Navy as acting master's mate, September, 1863; promoted to acting ensign, January, 1865; honorably discharged, August, 1865; married, Houston, Tex., 1874, Theresa A. Doebbler. Began railway service as brakeman, Chicago & Northwestern Ry., in 1865, and has since been in railroad work as, consecutively, brakeman, conductor, road master, train master, resident engineer, division superintendent, general manager, vice president; vice president and general manager St Louis, Kansas City & Colorado R. R., 1890-1902; was also vice president and general manager Wiggins Ferry Co.; since August, 1902, vice president of the St Louis & North Arkansas R. R. Co. Also president New Staunton Coal Oo. Unitarian. Member St Louis Railway Club. Office: 818 Security Bldg. ___

office: Roe Bldg., Broadway and Pine St.
fullentry: SANDS, James Thomas, manager and\ trustee Roe Estate; born St Louis, Feb. 22, j 1844; son of Samuel Gilbert and Ann Marie (Wright) Sands; educated in public and private schools and by private tutors at Marysville, Cal.; bachelor. Began business career as bookkeeper in mercantile firm at Marysville, Cal.; returned to St Louis, 1867; bookkeeper and cashier U. S. Internal Revenuue office, 1867-69; represented John J. Roe & Co. in packing business at St. Joseph, Mo., 186970; partner in firm of John J. Roe & Co., 1870-71; since 1872 manager Roe Estate, and for years was a director in many corporations; built Roe Building, 1884. Member Merchants' Exchange. Read law, 1872-74, has had probate practice. Member of Old Home Circle and Assembly clubs; one of organizers of McCullough Dramatic Club. Deeply interested in Americana and genealogy for past twenty-five years and has in preparation work on family history from data gathered in Europe and America. Member Society of Colonial Wars, Sons of the Revolution, Military Order Foreign Wars, New England Society, Society of War of 1812, Order of Founders and Patriots, Legion of Honor. Clubs: University, Country, Aero (St Louis), The Strollers (New York). Favorite recreations: dramatics and genealogical research. Office: Roe Bldg., Broadway and Pine St. Residence: Buckingham Club.

SARTELLE, John Coburn, railway official; born Ft. Craig, N. M., Oct. 30, 1869; son of William Judson and Sophia (Fletcher) Sar-telle; educated in grammar school, and one year in high school, Peoria, Ill.; married. Phoenix, Ariz., Oct. 28, 1890, Helen Mary Robinson, of Lexington, Ill.; one daughter. Laura Louise (Mrs. S. V. Brooks, of Atlanta, Ga.). Stenographer with Santa Fe Ry., Topeka, Kan., 1892-95, and has continued with same railway as follows: private secretary to assistant freight traffic manager, Chicago, 1895-97; contracting freight agent, Chicago. 1897-1904; southern freight and passenger agent, Atlanta, Ga., 1904-09; general agent, New Orleans, 1909-10; general agent freight department Santa Fe System, St Louis, since June 1, 1910. Republican. Presbyterian. Member Business Men's League. Mason. Club: Traffic of St Louis. Recreations: golf and fishing. Office: 209 N. 7th St. Residence: 5968 Clemens Ave.

office: Humboldt Bldg., Grand and Washington Aves.
memberships: ["American Laryngologie-al","Rhinological and Otological Society","St Louis Academy of Science","American Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society","City Hospital Alumni Society","American Academy of Oto-Laryngology","Verein Deutscher Aerzte"]
fullentry: SAUER, William Emil, physician; born. Evansville, Ill., Apr. 17, 1875; son of Nicholas and Elizabeth (Gerlach) Sauer; educated in public schools of Evansville, Ill., Sparta (Ill.) High School, Shurtleff College, Alton, Ill.; M.I)., Medical Department of Washington University, 1896; post-graduate work in universities of Heidelberg and Berlin, Germany, and Vienna, Austria; married, Sparta, Ill., 1901, Irene Borders. Engaged in medical practice since Apr. 25, 1896; practice now limited to diseases of the ear, nose and throat; instructor in clinical laryngology, Washington University. Member American Laryngologie-al, Rhinological and Otological Society, St Louis Academy of Science, American Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society, City Hospital Alumni Society, American Academy of Oto-Laryngology, Verein Deutscher Aerzte. Verein Alter Deutscher Studeuten. Presbyterian. Clubs: University, Bellerive, Algonquin Country. Office: Humboldt Bldg., Grand and Washington Aves. Residence: 4965 Maryland Ave.

SAUERBRUNN, George, president Sauer-hrunn Construction Co.; born in Germany, Apr. 14, 1857; son of Valentine and Christian (Luekbaun) Sauerbrunn; came with parents to America, 1861; educated in St Louis public schools; married, St Louis, June 25, 1882, Kmma Lohide; five children: Charlotte, Ethel, Alma, George C., Roy. After leaving school engaged with James Bright, contractor, and continued until 1884; began brick construction business for self, 1884, gradually becoming general contractor; present company was incorporated, 1897. Republican. Lutheran. Member Knights of Pythias. Recreation: fishing. Office: 111 X. 7th St. Residence: 5328 Von Verse n Ave.

memberships: ["American Pediatric Society","American Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: SAUNDERS, Edward Watts, physician; born in Campbell Co., Va., Oct. 15, 1854; son of Robert C. and Caryetta (Davis) Saunders; educated in private schools; M.D., University of Virginia, 1875; post-graduate work in Royal University of Vienna; unmarried. Came to St Louis in 1878, and has since been continuously engaged in practice of his profession; professor emeritus of pediatrics and clinical obstetrics in Medical Department of Washington University; member medical staff of Bethesda Hospital and of the Missouri Baptist Sanitarium. President of the Bethesda Association. Member American Pediatric Society, American Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Presbyterian. Club: Arcadia Country. Recreation: automobiling. Office: 4500 Olive St. Residence: 1541 S. Grand Ave.

SAUNDERS, Ripley Dunlap, journalist; born Ripley, Miss., Dec. 17, 1850; son of Dr. Pascal Washington and Catherine (Kennelly) Saunders; educated private select schools at Marianna, Ark., Memphis, Tenn., and Pass C hristian, Miss.; married, St Louis, Aug. 3, 1903, Mrs. Mary E. (Schinkel) Spearing. Bookkeeper, 1874-89; connected with St Louis Republic, 1889-90, St Louis Post-Dispatch, 1890-92; correspondent Post-Dispatch in Xew York, 1892-93; Sunday editor, 1893-90; editorial writer St Louis Republic, 1890-1902, except during Spanish War; with Washington Times, October, 1902-January, 1903, then with St Louis Republic until August, 1903; since special writer and now dramatic critic of the St Louis Post-Dispatch. Was lieutenant in Light Battery A, First Missouri Artillery, but resigned; reenlisted in same at beginning of war with Spain, and served as gunner-corporal in invasion of Porto Rico by Gen. Xel-son A. Miles, 1898. Presbyterian. Democrat. Author: John Kenadie, 1902; Colonel Todhun-ter of Missouri, 1911. Office: Post-Dispatch. Residence: 3910 Westminster FI.

memberships: ["Reformed Episcopal Church; president Spruce Street Mission"]
fullentry: SAUNDERS, Virginius Otey, real estate; born in Cooper Co., Mo., May 18, 1847; son of Dr. Samuel H. and Sarah Ann (Otey) Saunders; educated in public schools in Otterville, Mo.; married, 1873, Ada Alexander, of Cooper Co. (died Sept. 22, 1911); children: Vir-ginius O., Jr., Paul, Mrs. Lola Rayburn. Came to St Louis, 1865; in employ of wholesale dry goods house of Wear & Hickman, 1868-78; then with Crow, Hargadine & Co., wholesale dry goods, and afterwards became interested in Ely, Walker & Co., and remained in that firm seven years; member firm of Janis, Saunders & Co.; sold out interest there in December, 1893, going into Wear & Boogher Dry Goods Co. as secretary, but two years later retired from dry goods business; manager Interstate Merchants' Association, 1903-11; now in real estate business. Mayor of Webster Groves, Mo., 1911-12. Member Reformed Episcopal Church; president Spruce Street Mission. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: mission work. Office: 1002 Century Bldg. Residence: 5012 Cabanne Ave.

SAUNDERS, William Flewellyn, secretary and general manager Business Men's League; born Wetumpka, Ala., Mar. 19, 1860; son of Robert Milton and Mary Jane (Toomer) Saunders; educated in public schools, Berlin, Germany, Furman University, Greenville, S. C., and Randolph-Macon College, Ashland, Va.; married, St Louis, Christmas Day, 1891, Lilian L. Stone; one boy, William F., Jr., and one girl, Nancy Lewis. Left college before completing course and worked on newspapers for thirteen years; edited the Times in Ouray, Colo., and established a daily in Santa Fe, N. M.; correspondent Xew York Herald and Chicago Times; with expedition that rescued Meeker women from hostile Utes after White River massacre in 1875; afterwards reporter for St Louis newspapers until 1893, when he became secretary to Mayor Cyrus P. Wal-bridge; election commissioner, 1895-98; assistant postmaster of St Louis, 1898-1901; since Jan. 1, 1901, secretary and general manager of the Business Men's League. Clubs: Mercantile, City, Artists' Guild. Office: 510 Locust St. Residence: 5562 Clemens Ave.

office: New National Bank of Commerce Bldg.
fullentry: SAWTELLE, Harry Gregg, insurance; born Wheeling, W. Va., Dec. 2, 1866; son of George Franklin and Priscilla (Morgan) Sawtelle; educated in Danville (Iowa) High School; married, Junction City, Kan., Nov. 9, 1898, Daisy Henderson McClure; one daughter, Gertrude Louise. Clerk in a Kansas country grocery, 1885-86; employed as collector and salesman for The Rockwell Merchandise and Grain Co., Junction City, Kan., Jan. 1886, to March, 1898; engaged in retail book and stationery business at Junction City, 1898-1900; sold out, and became house salesman for John L. Boland Book and Stationery Co., St Louis, 190001; since Jan. 1, 1901 /engaged in fire and casualty insurance business. Republican. Kpiscopalian. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Masonic. Office: New National Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 955 Maple PI.

SAWYER, Frank Orville, manufacturer; boru, Exeter, N. H., Dec. 22, 1835; son of Almon and Charlotte Neil (Libbey) Sawyer; educated in public schools to 1847; A.B., Woodward College, Cincinnati; married, Bunker Hill, Ill., May 16, 1872, Ellen S. Knowl-ton; three cliildren: Frank Knowlton, Edith (deceased), Mary Knowlton (Mrs. C. J. Nie-haus). Began business career as wholesale paper dealer, St Louis, 1859, and continuously engaged in paper business until 1905. President American Insulating Co. since 1905. Served three months in Union army during Civil War, with active service in early battles in Missouri, under Capt. George Rowley. Republican. Member Church of the Messiah. Mason (32°), Shriner. Office: 705 Olive St. Residence: 4246 Lindell Boul.

SAWYER, Isaac Howe, financial agent; born Boxford, Mass., Apr. 3, 1858; son of Thomas and Sophia Bridgeman (Howe) Sawyer; educated in public schools of Boxford and in Putnam High School, Newburyport, Mass.; married, Wollaston, Mass., Jan. 15, 1896, Bertha Colby; children: John Colby, Aaron Everett. With firm of Hyde, Peabody & Co., Boston, 1876-80; connected with wholesale shoe house of Smith, Simmons & Peabody, Toledo, O., as manager of store, 1880-84; department manager American Rubber Co., of Boston, 1884-90; became connected with The Brown Shoe Co., 1890; second vice president of the company, 1910-12; since representing Max Oscher & Co., financial agents, New York. President Missouri Manufacturers' and Exporters' Association; ex-president St Louis Advertising Men's League; member Business Men's League, Civic League. Methodist. Mason, Knight Templar. Clubs: Mercantile, City. Recreations: motoring, horseback riding. Office: 404 Carleton Bldg. Residence: 4342 Washington Ave.

SCANLAN, Philip Christy; born St Louis, Xov. 2, 1870; son of James J. and Mary Fe-licite (Christy) Scanlan; educated St Louis University; Holy Cross College., Massachusetts; Stonyhurst College, England. Widower. With Wiggins Ferry Co., 1892-1902, retiring as secretary and treasurer. Appointed by Mayor Rolla Wells, park commissioner, April, 1907, and served until June 1, 1911. Democrat. Catholic. Member Business Men's League. Clubs: University, St Louis, Noonday, Racquet and Country. Recreation: traveling. Office. Security Bldg. Residence: 4450 Lindell Boul.

SCARRITT, Charles Hale, vice president and general manager Scarritt-Comstock Furniture Co.; born St Louis, Mar. 1, 1855; son of Russell and Charlotte (Gilette) Scarritt; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Oct. 3, 1900, Ella G. Robinson; one daughter, Violet G. After leaving school entered house of Scarritt Furniture Co. (founded 1837 by father, Russell Scarritt, as Scarritt & Mason, later becoming Scarritt, Curtis & Mason and then Scarritt Furniture Co.). After clerkship of few years became member of firm, and later he and brother, S. G., became the principals; style changed, 1897, to Scarritt-Comstock Furniture Co., of which is vice president and general manager (brother, S. G., retired from presidency and from active business because of failure of health). Also president Western Furniture Co. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member Tuscan Lodge, A. F. & A. M. Clubs: St Louis, Missouri Athletic, Glen Echo Country, St Louis Railway. Recreations: fishing and golf. Office: Broadway and Locust St. Residence: 5807 Clemens Ave.

SCHABERG, John Fred, president J. F. Schaberg Hardware Co.; born Germany, May 10, 1843; son of John Henry and Elizabeth C. (Greive) Schaberg; was brought to America, 1844; educated in public schools of St. Charles Co., Mo., and at Eden College, St. Charles Co.; married, Cappeln, Mo., Jan. 31, 1867, Louisa C. Brueggemann; six children: Lydia J., Hanna L., J. Fred, Jr., Irwin W., Mrs. E. Ill Brewer, Mrs. John Hecker. Reared on farm until seventeen; came to St Louis at age of eighteen and worked in a grocery store for five years; started in grocery business on own account, 1866; formed partnership with brother, under title of H. & J. F. Schaberg, continuing, 186884, when sold out to brother; in hardware business, 1884-1910; then incorporated as J. F. Schaberg Hardware Co., of which is president. Served in Home Guards during the Civil War. Republican. Baptist. Office: 2505-2507 S. Jefferson Ave. Residence: 4030 Hartford Street.

residence: I^iracres Stock Farm, St Louis Co.
fullentry: SCHADE, Wilfred, Custom House broker; born St Louis, Mar. 5, 1869; son of George J. and Magaret (Steininger) Schade; educated in St Louis public schools and graduated from Manual Training School, 1887; married, St Louis, Nov. 9, 1899, Harriet Collins Gleason; one son, Carlisle Schade. Clerk Custom House broker's office (Charles II. Wyman & Co.).* August, 1887, to Jan. 1, 1892; started business of Wilfred Schade & Co., Jan. 1, 1892; appointed foreign freight agents of the Chesapeake & Ohio R. R., Jan. 1, 1894, also foreign freight agents of its fast freight lines, The Kanawha Despatch, The Blue Ridge Despatch. Republican. Congregationalist. Clubs: City, Traffic of St Louis, Automobile, Contemporary. Recreation: stockraising. Office: 814 Century Bldg. Residence: I^iracres Stock Farm, St Louis Co.

SCHAEFFER, Jacob, soap and candle manufacturer; born, St Louis, Apr. 12, 1849; son .V>4 of Nicholas and Anne Marie (Ley) Schaeffer; educated in St Louis Univeisity, then went abroad and studied in France and Germany; married, St Louis, April 25, 1883, Mary C. Murray; one daughter, Marie B. Since 1870 engaged in present business as manufacturer of mining, coach and star candles, laundry soaps, grades of lard oil, etc., first with father, Nicholas Schaeffer, until 1879; since with his successor, the Schaeffer Bros. & Powell Manufacturing Co., of which is now president. Member Civic League. Club: Automobile. Recreation: motoring. Office: Barton and Kos-cuisko Sts. Residence: 4430 Forest Park Boul.

office: De Kalb St. and Geyer Ave.
clubs: ["Western Rowing","Cruisiug and Anedo Hunting and Fishing"]
fullentry: ECHAELICH, August J., vice president St Louis Architectural Iron Co.; born St Louis, Apr. 8, 1866; son of August and Christina (Kaffai) Schaelich; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, June, *.890, Anna Kemper; children: Laura, Alma. Lived on farm in Jefferson Co., Mo., from age of eleven to twenty; came to St Louis, 1886, and entered employ of the Christopher & Simpson Architectural Iron Co., remaining until 1900, then withdrew and joined in organizing the St Louis Architectural Iron Co., of which is vice president. Member Royal Arcanum, Tower Grove Turn Verein. Clubs: Western Rowing, St Louis Cruisiug and Anedo Hunting and Fishing. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: De Kalb St. and Geyer Ave. Residence: 3638 Juniata St.

SCHAFF, Charles Ellsworth, railway official; born in Licking Co., O., Feb. 4, 1856; son of Isaac Milton and Angeline (Cleves) Schaff; self-educated; married at Columbus, O., Dec. 31, 1878, Leila White; two sons: Howard E. and Frederick A. Began railway career as water boy for a section gang on the Pennsylvania lines at 50 cents a day, and became freight brakeman at $45 a month; then successively freight fireman, driver of switch engine, freight conductor, yardmaster, trainmaster, superintendent and general superintendent; assistant to president, 1893-94, assistant general manager, 1894-95; general manager, 1895-1906, vice president, New York Central Lines west of Buffalo, viz., Lake Shore & Michigan Southern Ry., Michigan Central R. R., Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati & St Louis Ry., Chicago, Indiana & Southern R. R., Lake Erie & Western R. R., Peoria & Eastern Ry., Cincinnati Northern R. R., Indiana Harbor Belt R. R., 1906-Apr. 10, 1912; since president Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry. Member Business Men's League. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday. Office: Wainwright Bldg. Residence: 4415 W. Pine Boul.

SCHALL, Edward Garrett, examiner of land titles; born East St Louis, Ill., June 17, 1870; son of Henry and Luisa (Witte) Schall; educated in public schools; married, Sept. 30, 1891, Cora M. Meyer; children: Cora Edna, Ewart G. (deceased), Edward G., Jr., Charles Henry, Margaret Witte, Louise Marietta, Hil-degard Helen. Engaged in constant practice in St Louis as examiner of land titles since Dec. 19, 1889. Member Civic League, National Geographic Society. Independent in politics. Presbyterian. Favorite recreations: floriculture and photography. Office: 1021 Chestnut St. Residence: Webster Groves, Mo.

SCHARFF, Adolph, wholesale liquors; born Essingen, Germany, Jan. 25, 1843; son of Aaron and Lena (Rose) Scharff; educated in public schools in Essingen; married, Montgomery, Ala., May 7, 1874, Jeanette Myer; children: Dr. Eugene A., Ophelia (Mrs. Jack Elson), Clarence, Myrtle. Came to United States, 1864; was a short time in Cairo, Ill., and from there went to Vicksburg, Miss., and became clerk in dry goods house of brothers. Scharff Bros.; in 1870, with brother, Lazarus, opened up wholesale liquor business at Vicksburg, continuing until 1876, when removed stock to St Louis, where firm continued business as L. & A. Scharff until 1906; then incorporated as L. & A. Scharff Distilling Co., of which is secretary and treasurer. Republican. Jewish religion. Club: Columbian. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Offiee: 1427 Lucas Ave. Residence: 4967 W. Pine Boul.

SCHARFF, Edward E., wholesale grocer: born Vicksburg, Miss.; son of Nicholas and Carrie (Bemheimer) Scharff; educated in public schools, St Louis, and Poughkeepsie (N. Y.) College, class of 1888; unmarried. Began business career as assistant in minor capacities in father'8 wholesale grocery business, and on its incorporation, 1893, as Nicholas Scharff & Sons Grocer Co., was made vice president and treasurer. President Merchants Exchange, 1909; member Business Men's League. Republican. Jewish religion. Clubs: Mercantile, Columbian, Westward Country, Millers', Traffic. Recreations: golf and motoring. Office: 801 Spruce St. Residence: 5225 Lindell Ave.

SCHARFF, Lazarus, distiller and wholesale liquor merchant; born Essingen, Bavaria. June 1, 1846; son of Aaron and Lena (Rose) Scharff; educated in schools in Bavaria; married, Fayette, Miss., June 7, 1876, Clara Eis-man; children: Arthur, Helen (Mrs. Albert Newman, of Joplin, Mo.), Harold, Herbert. Adolph, Milton. Came to United States in 1871, and has since been engaged in wholesale wine and liquor business; was in business at Vicksburg, Miss., 1871-76; since in St Louis; was member of firm of L. & A. Scharff, title changed, 1906, to L. & A. Scharff Distilling Co., Inc., of which is president. Jewish religion; member United Jewish Charities. Club: Columbian. Office: 1427 Lucas Ave. Residence: 4371 Lindell Ave.

SCHARFF, Nicholas, wholesale grocer ; born Landau, Bavaria, Mar. 13, 1836; son of Aaron and Lena (Rose) Scharff; educated in public and private schools; married, Port Gibson, Miss., 1870, Carrie Bernheimer; chihlreff: Kdward, Blanche, Sidney, Maude, Evelyn, Lennie and Aurelia. Began business career in mercantile houses at Vicksburg, Miss.; established the firm of Scharff Bros., wholesale dry goods, boots and shoes, until 1875; established, 1875, the business of Scharff & Bernheimer, wholesale grocers, which continued uutil 1893, when he bought out the interest of his partner and incorporated the Nicholas Scharff & Sons Grocer Co., of which has since been president. Jewish religion; ex-president of Congregation Shaare Emeth; member United Hebrew Charities, Cleveland Orphan Asylum, and other charitable institutions. Club: Columbian. Office: 801-809 Spruce St. Residence: 5225 Lindell Boul.

SCHARLACH, Frederick Richard; born Montgomery Co., Mo., Mar. 26, 1868; son of Rudolph and Helena (Gross) Scharlach; educated in public schools, Mexico, Mo., to 1881; high school, Jefferson City, Mo., to 1888; then entered St Louis College of Pharmacy, graduating, 1890; married, Moberly, Mo., June 6, 1894, Emma Beatty. Began as boy in drug store, 1881, and continued until 1892; with J. S. Merrell Drug Co. (wholesale), as salesman until 1902 and sales manager until 1909; since then representing Auto Sales Gum and Chocolate Co. Director Union Station Bank, .Togood Realty Co. Member Missouri Pharmaceutical Association, Travelers' Protective Association (director). Democrat. Lutheran. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner; member Royal League. Club: Masonic. Recreations: traveling, automobiling. Office: 312 Olive St. Residence: 4963 Fountain Ave.

SCHABLOTT, George John, dry goods; born Landau, Bavaria, July 29, 1853; son of Peter and Lena (Wehl) Scharlott; educated in public schools and under private tutelage; married. St Louis, 1887, Lena Deichler; children: Charles G., Emil S., Frank, Conrad F. and Mamie. Came to America, 1873; engaged as carpenter in St Louis, later in employ of Peters Furniture Manufacturing Co., and St Louis Furniture Co. Entered dry goods business, 1880, in partnership with father-in-law, Charles Deichler, 1882, until death of latter, 1895; then in control for self until June, 1911, when business was incorporated as the George T. Scharlott Mercantile Co., of which is president. Member Xorth St Louis Business Men's Association. Protestant. Member Turn Verein, German Orphans' Home, Altenheim. Recreation: singing. Office aud Residence: 2312 N. Market St.

SCHATTGEN, William, vice president Busy Bee Candy Co.; born Jefferson City, Mo., May 30, 1809; son of Peter and Catherine (Fischer) Sehattgen; educated in public schools in St Louis; married, St Louis. Feb. 24, 1898, Alvin ia Kombrink; children: Grace, William, Jr., Paul, Helen. Resident of St Louis since November, 1876; began business career as a boy in the Krien Chain Factory and continued six years; followed trade of painting until November, 1894, when entered the employ of W. W. Candy Co. as apprentice and learned the candy making trade; eventually became a partner and, on incorporation of the business as the Busy Bee Candy Co., was elected vice president. United Presbyterian. Recreation: church work. Office: 417 N. 7th St. Residence: 4566 Gibson Ave.

SCHATZMAN, Jules Joseph, investment securities; born St Louis, Oct. 18, 1879; son of Jules and Rose (Horan) Schatzman; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, November, 1903, Genevieve Graham; children: Thomas, Mary, Alice. Began business career in 1894, entering Simmons Hardware Co. as clerk and remaining with them until 1899; then was clerk with National Bank of Commerce, 1899-1902, and with Germania Trust Co., 1902-03; member firm of Hermann & Schatzman, investment securities, 1903-08, and in same business alone until 1911; since associated with G. H. Walker & Co., stock and bond brokers. Independent in politics. Catholic. Office: 307 N. 4th St. Residence: 3700 Connecticut Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association","American Medical Association"]
fullentry: SCHAUB, Charles William, physician; born St Louis, Aug. 28, 1867; son of John and Sophia (Jacob) Schaub; educated at St Louis public schools; M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1894; married, St Louis, Jan. 18, 1898, Emma Keifaber; two daughters: Berenice and Virginia. In general practice in St Louis since 1894. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association. Mason (32°); member Missouri Consistory, Shrine. Club: Liederkranz. Recreations: driving, horseback riding. Office and Residence: 2300-2302 Salisbury St.

SCHAUS, Paul, manager Excelsior Brewery; born Ehrenbreitstein, Germany, June 29, 1861; son of Frederick and Sybilla (Allen-dorf) Schaus; educated in schools in Germany; married, St Louis, 1890, Mary Madden; children: Freda May, Catherine Blanche, Sybilla Eunice. Emigrated to United States from Germany, 1881, locating in New York until about 1883, when came to St Louis; was bookkeeper for wholesale druggists; became bookkeeper and cashier, 1889, and in 1900 was made manager of the Hyde Park Brewery Depot; promoted, December, 1907, to manager of the Excelsior Brewery. Member Tower Grove Turn Verein, German-Amencan Alliance. Club: Liederkranz. Favorite recreations: hunting, fishing and music. Office: 17 S. 17th St. Residence: 3840 Hartford St.

SCHELP, George Henry, secretary and treasurer Joseph W. Moon Buggy Co.; born Ballwin, St Louis Co., Mo., Mar. 2, 1859; son of Frederick and Marie (Kleinsorge) Schelp; educated in public schools of Ballwin, Mo.; married, Ballwin, Mo., Mar. 18, 1885, Hannah M. Zeinert; children: Charles Milton, Walter F., Esther A. Member of Schelp Bros., fire insurance agents, Ballwin, Mo., 1877-87; of Fred. Schelp & Sons, Ballwin, manufacturers of wagons, buggies, etc., and dealers in farm implements and machinery, 1880-87 (succeeding F. Schelp, who was in the wagon business there over forty years); then of Schelp Wagon and Carriage Co., St Louis (organized by George H. Schelp and F. Schelp, Jr.), 1887-93, which business was discontinued after a fire; joined J. W. Moon, December, 1893, in organizing Joseph W. Moon Buggy Co., of which is secretary and treasurer; also secretary of the Moon Motor Car Co., which was incorporated Oct. 2, 1907; director Schelp-Burke Tire and Rubber Co. Republican (member St Louis Republican Club). Methodist; president board of trustees Salem M. E. Church, cor. Page Boul. and Pendleton Ave. Recreation: church work. Office: Main and Douglass Sts. Residence: 4148 W. Belle PI.

SCHENK, Nicholas, insurance; born St Louis, July 2, 1871; son of Adolph and Julia (Reider) Schenk; educated private schools and Christian Brothers College, St Louis; married, St Louis, November, 1900, Emma Hagedorn. Began business career as a salesman for safes; in the insurance business with Royal Insurance Co. as broker, 1897-1905; member firm of Campbell, Schenk & Co., general insurance, 1905-08; formed, 1908, present firm of Nicholas Schenk & Co. Inventor of the Schenk Pneumatic Wheel. Catholic. Office: Odd Fellows Bldg. Residence: 1051 Goodfellow Ave.

residence: 7240 Rule Ave., Maplewood, Mo. Summer Home: Spring Lake, Mich.
fullentry: SCHENK, Oscar A., life insurance; born Tell City, Ind., Sept. 10, 1873; son of Christian and Augusta (Steiner) Schenk; educated public schools of Jasper, Ind.; married, St Louis, 1895, Edith Fuller; children: Helen, Dorothy, .John. Began active career as printer, continuing, 1890-1900; assistant general organizer Knights of Pythias insurance department, in Missouri, 1900-05, and general organizer for northern Missouri with headquarters at St. Joseph, 1905-07; appointed agent Bankers Life Insurance Co., 1907; manager St Louis office same, 1909, and general agent for Missouri and Illinois since 1911. Democrat. Member Knights of Pythias. Recreation: fishing. Office: 618-619 Frisco Bldg. Residence: 7240 Rule Ave., Maplewood, Mo. Summer Home: Spring Lake, Mich.

SGHENKEL, Henry, retired; born, Hesse Darmstadt, Germany, Dec. 24, 1837; son of George and Maria (Heil) Schenkel; educated in schools in Germany and Jones Commercial College, St Louis; married, St Louis, 1861. Margareta Kalbfleisch; children: Annie, Mary (widow of Dr. Rudolph Hanser), Ida (Mrs. Powell Doederlein, of Dundee, Ill.), Cornelia (wife of Prof. Otto Boeder, of Springfield. Ill.), Amanda (wife of Rev. E. Bruegman), Henry A. Came from Germany to St Louis in 1854, and began work as a cooper; afterwards was in the grocery business and later was bookkeeper in St. George Flour Mill for seven years; in 1863 became a member of the firm of John G. Haas & Co., manufacturers of laundry soaps, and from incorporation of the business in 1882 as J. G. Haas Soap Co.. wa9 president of the company; retired, 190s. Lutheran. Residence: 1445 John Ave.

SCHERCK, Henry Joseph, B.S.. M.P., physician; born New Orleans, La., Dec. 5, 1867; son of Major Isaac ami Esther (Marks) Scherck; educated in public schools. New Orleans; Academical Department of Tulane University to 1885; M.D., Medical Department, Tulane University, New Orleans, 1889; student University of Heidelberg, Germany, 1900; B.S., St Louis University; married, St Louis, Aug. 30, 1902, Natalie Altheimer; two sons: Irving Gordon and Henry J., Jr. Practiced medicine at New Orleans until 189(5. when came to St Louis and has since een engaged in the practice of genito-urinary surgery here: chief dispensary surgeon of the municipal dispensaries of City of St Louis, 1903-07; visiting genito-urinary surgeon, City Hospital; surgeon in charge of genito-urinary division Jewish Hospital Dispensary; genito-urinary surgeon to Jewish Hospital; clinical instructor of genito-urinary surgery, St Louis University School of Medicine, and genito-urinary surgeon Missouri Pacific R. R. Hospital. Member editorial staff St Louis Medical Review. Member American Urological Association, St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association, Mississippi Valley Medical Society, Charity Hospital Alumni Association. Democrat. Jewish religion. Clubs: City, Columbian. Office: Century Bldg. Residence: 45o7 McPherson Ave.

SCHERMERHORN, Alexander Van Rensselaer, surety bonds and casualty insurance; born Baltimore, May 29, 1880; son of Charles Seymour and Charlesetta (Applegarth) Scher-merhorn; educated public schools of Baltimore; Baltimore City College; A.B.. Johns Hopkins, 1900; LL.B., University of Maryland, 1902; married, Baltimore, Apr. 28, 1904, Edith May Salisbury; three children: Lewis Van R., Edith May, Killian Van R. Practiced law, Baltimore, until August, 1905; assistant superintendent agents U. S. Fidelity ami Guaranty Co. of Baltimore, 1905-08; general agent same company for Oklahoma, headquarters at Muskogee, 1908-11, and manager western department at St Louis since Nov. 1, 1911; member firm of Martin, Schermerhorn & McLean. Republican. Episcopalian. Member Kappa Alpha Fraternity (Southern). Recreation: reading. Office: 705 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 5635 Bartmer Ave.

office: Hall St. and St Louis Ave.
fullentry: SCHEVE, Julius Lincoln, hardwood lumber; born Mascoutah, St. Clair Co., Ill., Apr. 16, 1865; son of Charles and Elizabeth (Dathan) Scheve; educated public schools and University of Illinois; married, Grayville, Ill., Dec. 14, 1897, Metamora Clarke. Began business career in a mill at Grayville, Ill., 1888; entered lumber business at St Louis, with the Bonsack Lumber Co., 1895, and continued for twelve years; member Krebs-Scheve Lumber Co. since 1907. Republican. Member Ethical Society. Mason. Club: Mercantile. Office: Hall St. and St Louis Ave. Residence: 4173 Flad Ave.

SCHEWE, William Henry, real estate; born St Louis, Aug. 24, 1871; son of Fred and Mary (Horstmann) Schewe; educated, Henry Ames (public) School; married, St Louis Co., Mar. 16, 1892, Carrie Althoff (died .July 10, 1909); three children: Mary L., Edna C. and Fred W.; married, 2d, St Louis, June 16, 1910, Julia M. Furstenfeld; one son, Richard Mansfield. Engaged in farming up to 1902; in grocery business, 1902-05; since in general real estate business; also director Baden Bank. Republican. Member United Brethren. Clubs: St Louis, City. Recreation: horseback riding. Office: 8212 X. Broadway. Residence: 1063 Hornsby Ave.

SCHIELE, Edwin, whisky merchant; born St Louis, July 9, 18(52; son of Sigmund and Fanny (Schulman) Schiele; educated in St Louis public schools and Jones Commercial College; married, St Louis, December, 1897, Mynne Kramer; children: Herbert Sigmund, Frances Fanny. Began business career in wholesale notions house; entered liquor business at seventeen, and at twenty went on road as traveling salesman. Began business for self in 1895, at Cincinnati, and in 1899 removed to St Louis and established firm of Edwin Schiele & Co., distillers of whisky. Republican. Jewish religion. Member Ethical Society. Club: Columbian. Office: 204 S. 4th St. Residence: 4558 Washington Ave.

memberships: ["North St Louis Business Men's Association; secretary and treasurer Teutonia Hall Association"]
fullentry: SCHIELE, Jacob W.y general insurance; born Highland, Ill.; son of Jacob .John and Sylvia (Winterroth) Schiele; public school education; married, St Louis, May 16, 1900, Clara Brinckmeyer; four daughters: Grace L., Sylvia D., Alice L., Edna H. Learned barber's trade and followed it from 1889 to 1899; entered insurance business as agent for Jefferson Mutual Fire Insurance Co.; in Xovem-ber, 1908, formed general agency under title of the Schiele-Kleinsehmidt Agency Co., of which is president and of which William A. Kleinschmidt (who had been connected with The Xational Enameling and Stamping Co. for a number of years) is secretary. Republican; served as deputy marshal, 1898-1901;* now candidate for Missouri House of Representatives from Fourth District. Protestant. Member North St Louis Business Men's Association; secretary and treasurer Teutonia Hall Association. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Avalon, of Clement, Mo. (secretary and treasurer). Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 2931 Barrett St.

SCHIELE, Sidney, real estate; born St Louis, Aug. 23, 1873; son of Sigmund and Fanny (Schulman) Schiele; educated in grammar and high schools of St Louis; married. St Louis, Jan. 8, 1906, Belle Idleman. Began business life in wholesale house of Baer, Sea-songood & Co. in 1888. Engaged in real estate business with brother-in-law, Samuel Bowman, until 1895; since in real estate business for self. Secretary to St Louis Real Estate Exchange, 1897-1907. Republican. Clubs: Columbian, Westward Country, Mercantile. Office: 813-815 Chestnut St. Residence: 4718 McPherson Ave.

SCHILLER, Francis Henry, clergyman; born St Louis, June 4, 1880; 9on of Robert and Mary (Mueller) Schiller; educated, St. Vincent's (parochial) School, 1886-94; in business pursuits, 1894-98; student Sacred Heart College, Prairie du Chien, Wis., 189.81901; St. Mary's Institute, Dayton, O., 1901 02; Kenrick Seminary, St Louis, 1902-07, graduating, 1907. Ordained priest Roman Catholic Church by Archbishop Glennon, June 11, 1907; assistant rector Sacred Heart Church 1907-09; assistant rector Cathedral since Aug. 20, 1909. Independent in politics. Residence: 209 Walnut St.

memberships: ["Baden Saengerbund; also Twenty-seventh Ward Republican Club"]
fullentry: SCHILLER, William, photo supplies; born Frankfort-on-the-Main, Nov. 21, 1867; son of William and Louise Schiller; educated in public schools of native city to 1884; came to America, 1885; married, St Louis, Jan. 1, 1887, Pauline Schnelzenbach; four children: Johanna, Louise, Rudolph, Ella. Began business career with M. A. Seed Dry Plate Co., St Louis, 1886, aud continued until 1888; engaged as photographer, 1888-90; since conducted photo supply business, now known as W. Schiller & Co. Member Baden Saengerbund; also Twenty-seventh Ward Republican Club. Club: Dixou Hunting and Fishing. Recreations: hunting, fishing. Office: 6 S. Broadway. Residence: 1701 Cora Ave.

SCHINDLER, Frank, vice president Gravois Planing Mill Co.; born, Silesia, Germany, June 20, 1861; son of Albert and Mary (Pohi) Schindler; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, Nov. 17, 1887, Bertha Lowack; five children: Fred, Edwin, Alfred, Elsa, Frank. Came to America, 1887; learned planing mill business in old country and worked at trade in St Louis until organization, 1903, of the Gravois Planing Mill Co., of which has since been vice president. Republican. Member Tower Grove Turn Verein. Office: 3026 Juniata St. Residence: 3525 Hartford St.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society","Academy of Science (St Louis)","Alumni Association St Louis University"]
fullentry: SCHISLER, Edwin, physician; born St Louis, Mo., Nov. 27, 1874; son of Henry Michael and Caroline (Koenig) Schisler; educated, Educational Institute; St Louis High School; matriculated in Beaumont Hospital Medical College (Medical Department, St Louis University), graduating with degree of M.D., 1890; married, St Louis, Mar. 2, 1898, Lilv G. Young. In practice at St Louis since 1896; medical examiner Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. since 1898; physician in charge of St Louis Altcnheim since 1904; president Fresh Air Mission since 1907; on medical staff Alexian Brothers Hospital since 1910; assistant in medicine, St Louis University, since 1910. Member American Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society, Academy of Science (St Louis), Alumni Association St Louis University. Scottish Rite Mason, Shriner; member Royal Arcanum. Recreations: horseback riding, automobiling. Office and Residence: 2600 S. Grand Ave.

SCHISLER, Henry Michael, retired; born in St Louis Co., Mo., July 4, 1843; son of Michael and Melinda Schisler; educated in country school in St Louis Co. and in St Louis schools; married, St Louis, Mar. 3, 1873, Caroline C. Koenig; children: Dr. E. J., Mrs. E. N. Karcher, Atnanda (Mrs. William Essmueller), Arthur W. Began business career as a clerk in grocery store for a few months, then on Jan. 14, 18(55, entered employ of William Koenig & Co., seeds and agricultural machinery, with whom remained until 1876, then became member of firm of H. Michel & Co., seeds, etc.; entered Plant Seed Co., 1878, and a year later became member of the firm, remaining until 1895, when joined in organizing a seed company of which was vice president, 1895-1909; now spends most of his time with A. W. Schisler Grain Co., 708 N. 4th St. Republican. Served in Company A, First Missouri Regiment, 1863-64. German Protestant. Member board -directors the German Protestant Orphans' Home. Member A. F. & A. M., Travelers' Protective Association. Recreation: traveling. Office: 708-710 N. 4th St. Residence: 3807 Hartford St.

company: Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co.
fullentry: SGHIWITZ, Edward, secretary Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co.; born Goliad, Tex., Nov. 28, 1852; son of Christoff and Katherine (Weiskirch) Schiwitz; educated in public schools, in Germany; married, St Louis, .Tune 17, 1876, Anna Lintz; eight children living: August, Anna (now Mrs. Edward McDonnell), Ida, Clara, Charles, Dolly, Louise, Edna. Learned confectionery business and worked at baker's trade in St Louis; associated with Herman Flebbe, 1878, and opened flour and bakery supply store, later admitting William Pamper in to partnership, as Flebbe-Schiwitz-Pamperin Flour, Grocer and Commission Co.; present name Western Candy and Bakers' Supply Co., of which is secretary. Member St Louis Turn Verein, Carondelet Singing Club. Office: 113 S. 11th St. Residence: 2808 Victor St.

SCHLAFLY, August, banker; born on farm in Switzerland, May 4, 1850; son of John Joseph and Helena (Margis) Schlafly; educated in private and public schools; married, Carlyle, Ill., Nov. 12, 1874, Jane Allen; children: Helen Jane (now Mrs. William C. Connett), Mary Jessie, Louis Allen, John F., Paul A., Janies J. Engaged in mercantile business and private banking at Carlyle, Ill., in. 1871; organized the State Bank in 1894, which was changed in 1900 to First National Bank of Carlyle; also organized the Bank of Breeze, First National Bank of Edwardsville, HI., Citizens' National Bank of Alton, Ill., and Union Trust and Savings Bank of East St Louis, Ill., of which is now president; member of August Schlafly & Sons, commercial paper and bonds; director Mississippi Valley Trust Co.; president St Louis Coliseum since its organization. Member Business Men's League. Director and member advisory board of St Louis University. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Glen Echo Country. Office: 400, 506 Olive St: Residence: 4532 Westminster PI.

SOHLAG, Charles, coffees and teas: born Hessen Cassel, Germany, July 21, 1871; son of Johannes and Elizabeth (Nikal) Schlag; attended grammar schools, Germany; came to United States, September, 1886; student in public schools, St Louis, and Perkins & Her-pel Business College; married, St Louis, Feb. 28, 1895, Barbara Lielich; four children: Frank, Edwin, Viola and Carl. Began in employ of Mrs. Christina Schlag, retail groceries, St Louis, 1886, continuing about four years; with Fred Ringhoff one year; was connected with the Great Eastern Coffee and Tea Co. as city salesman, 1890-97; in coal and teaming business two years, and then sold out to organize the Progressive Coffee and Tea Co., 1900; after two years disposed of interest in the company and organized the Ideal Coffee and Tea Co., which was incorporated April, 1903; has since been president and manager same. Recreation: ffshing. Office: 1244 S. Broadway. Residence: 4548 Magnolia Ave.

SCHLAPP, Carl Henry, president Krenning Grocer Co.; born Ft. Madison, la., July 18, 1867; son of August and Caroline (Knust) Schlapp; educated in public schools and business college; married, Burlington, Ia., Oct. 26, 1905, Frances Neally Higbee; one son, Carl Higbee. Began business career in freight office of the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy R. A k R-, Burlington, Ia., then shipping clerk for Biklen-Winzer Grocer Co., Burlington, Ia., and became consecutively bill clerk, salesman in house, city salesman and secretary; in August, 1902, moved to St Louis, buying out F. H. Krenning & Son, and forming stock company under name of Krenning Grocer Co., of which is president. Also director Biklen-Winzer Grocer Co., of Burlington. Member Business Men's League. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet, Algonquin Golf, Missouri Athletic (St Louis), Burlington Boat, Burlington Golf (Burlington, Ia.). Office: 816-818 N. 3d St. Residence: Algonquin, St Louis Co., Mo.

SCHLECHT, Joseph A., president Mound City Buggy Co., born St Louis, Mar. 28, 1878; son of Charles and Louisa (Braun) Schlecht; educated in public schools of St Louis and Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, St Louis, Aug. 8, 1907, Mamie M. Mueller. Began active career at age of fifteen in employ of Nelson Morris & Co., packers, and advanced through various positions to that of general southern auditor; gave up connection with this company to become identified with the Banner Buggy Co., under Russell E. Gardner; after one year entered buggy business on own account, November, 1900, and was founder and has since been president of the Mound City Buggy Co., dealers in vehicles and automobiles. Catholic. Recreations: fishing, motor touring and theater. Office: Broadway and Cass Ave. Residence: 3666 Wyoming St.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni"]
fullentry: SCHLEIFFARTH, Edgar Louis, manufacturer of surgical supplies; born Cincinnati, Apr. 5, 1859; son of Charles and Matilda (Hofferberth) Schleiffarth; educated in public schools; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1881; married, St Louis, May 5, 1886, Anna R. Wetzel; children: Hilda (Mrs. Otto Wey-mann), Edgar, Armin, Gertrude, Lucille. Began practice of medicine in 1881, first as interne in the City Hospital and then in regular practice, became identified with the business established by his father in 1859, as manufacturer of surgical apparatus, and is now senior member of Chas. Schleiffarth Co. Member St Louis Medical Society, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni. Republican. Member First Regiment, Missouri National Guard. Liberal Unitarian. Mason (33°); member Liederkranz. Office: 8 S. Broadway. Residence: 2804 Eads Ave.

SCHLERETH, John J., clergyman; born St Louis, July 7, 1871; son of Anthony and Anna M. (Voll) Schlereth; educated St. Nicholas and St. Bernard's parochial schools; Christian Brothers College; St. Mary's Seminary, Perry-ville, Mo. Ordained priest Roman Catholic Church by Bishop Montgomery, May 30, 1896; served as missionary in Chicago and New Orleans to 1897; teacher of canon law, church history and liturgy, St. Mary's Seminary, Perry ville, 1895-1901; assistant pastor St. Vincent de Paul Church, St Louis, since 1907. Residence: 1427 S. 9th St.

SCHLOSSTEIN, Adolph George, physician; born St Louis, Oct. 2, 1872; son of Adolph and Caroline (Schaeffer) Schlossstein; educated St Louis public schools; graduated Toens-feldt's Educational Institute, 1889; graduated Smith Academy, 1890; M.D., Washington University Medical School, 1894; married, St Louis, Oct. 29, 1901, Clara Emma Braun; two sons: Frederick Alfred and Adolph George, Jr. In practice at St Louis since Jan. 1, 1895; lecturer and instructor, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Washington University Medical School; lieutenant Medical Reserve Corps, H. S. A. Member Evangelical Church. Member St Louis Medical Society, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni, Verein Deutscher Aerzte of St Louis, Alumni Association Washington University Medical School, Alma Mater of St Louis. Club: Liederkranz. Office and Residence: 3153 Longfellow Boul.

SCHLUETER, Robert E., surgeon; born St Louis, June 9, 1872; son of Ernst and Elisabeth (Pullmann) Schlueter; educated in public schools of St Louis; Toensfeld's Educational Institute, St Louis; Ph.G., St Louis College of Pharmacy, 1891; M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1895; unmarried. Teacher of pharmacy and physiology, Missouri Medical College, until it became connected with Washington University, 1899; instructor in Department of Surgery, Washington University until July, 1911; has since devoted entire time to private practice of surgery. President St Louis College of Pharmacy; member St Louis Medical Society (president, 1911), Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association, etc.; first lieutenant Medical Reserve Corps, U. S. A. Republican. Member Civic League. Recreations: travel and literature, principally medical history. Office: Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 909 Park Ave.

SCHLUETER, William George, secretary Bohn-Lenartz Commission Co.; born St Louis, July 15, 1878; son of William and Louisa (Herr) Schlueter; educated at St. Joseph's School, St Louis, Christian Brothers School and Bryant & Stratton Business College, 1895; married, St Louis, Feb. 22, 1905, Bertha Wille; three children: Marcella, William, Bertha. Entered employ of Hoffman Bros. Produce Co. as entry clerk, 1895; in 1900 became connected with Steffen & Stoltman, commission merchants, who were later succeeded by the Bohn-Stoltman Commission Co., and after the death of Henry Bohn in February, 1905, the present Bohn-Lenartz Commission Co. was organized, of which is secretary and treasurer. Republican. Roman Catholic. Recreation: bowling. Office: 714 N. 4th St. Residence: Shrewsbury Park.

office: Corner of Main and Dorcas Sts.
fullentry: SCHMEDTJE, Johannes, secretary and manager Adolphus Busch Glass Manufacturing Co.; born Holstein, Germany, Oct. 23, 1850; son of S. and Marie (Dieckmann) Schmedtje; educated in gymnasium in Germany; married, St Louis, May 28, 1878, Johauna Busch; children: Adolph, Elsa (deceased), Gussie, Paula, Clara, Lily, Hilda. Emigrated to St Louis, 1870; engaged as clerk in wine house, 1870-75; became identified with Anheuser-Busch Brewing Association as general clerk, 1875, and was in freight department for fifteen years; when glass works were erected, was put in charge of same by Adolphus Busch in 1891; now vice president, secretary and manager, Adolphus Busch Glass Manufacturing Co. Evangelical Lutheran. Independent in politics. Club: Liederkranz. Favorite recreations: music and thespian art. Office: Corner of Main and Dorcas Sts. Residence: 2337 S. 13th St.

SCHMIDT, Anthony John, secretary Brown Bond and Stock Co.; born Glasgow, Mo., Dec. 2, 1882; son of Conrad and Josephine (Rei-deser) Schmidt; educated in parochial schools and academy to 1896; then attended Pritchett College, Glasgow, Mo., until 1898; married, June 8, 1910, Adele Thiebes (died June 11, 1911). Came to St Louis, 1901, and engaged as stenographer with Brown Bond and Stock Co., becoming secretary in 1903. Republican. Catholic. Club: Missouri Athletic. Recreations: tennis and handball. Office: 400 N. 4th St. Residence: 3242 Longfellow Boul.

office: N. W. cor. 7th and Locust Sts.
memberships: ["Compton Hill Council","Royal Arcanum","National Union","Foresters","and Masonic Order"]
fullentry: SCHMIDT, August Richard, president G. R. Schmidt Woolen Co.; born St Louis, Jan. 21, 1877; son of Frank and Minna (Hennecke) Schmidt; educated in public schools, St Louis; married, St Louis, Emma, daughter of George Rueckoldt; one son, George Rueckoldt, born Apr. 15, 1909, and one daughter, Edna Emma, born Jan. 19, 1912. Began active career as errand boy and tailor's apprentice with B. F. Meyers Tailoring Co., 1892; office boy Joseph M. Hayes' Woolen Co., 1893-96; entry clerk Labsap-Crucknell Woolen Co., 1896; continuing until 1901; then became connected with the Greeley Printery as secretary, remaining in that position for seven years; resigned June, 1908, and was president of the Schmidt-Hochberg Woolen Co., importers and jobbers of woolens and tailors' trimmings and supplies, until May 1, 1911, when firm name was changed to G. R. Schmidt Woolen Co., of which is president. Republican. Liberal Protestant in religious views. Member Compton Hill Council, Royal Arcanum, National Union, Foresters, and Masonic Order. Clubs: Western Rowing, Masonic. Office: N. W. cor. 7th and Locust Sts. Residence: 3141 Michigan Ave.

SCHMIDT, John B., president John B. Schmidt Sign Co.; born St Louis, Nov. 3, 1860; son of August and Minna Schmidt; educated in St Louis public schools, Polytechnic School, Washington University; married, Sept. 21, 1887, Emma Schueler. After leaving school moved to Minneapolis, Minn., with parents and engaged in sign painting; returned to St Louis, 1885, and conducted sign painting business as John B. Schmidt & Co.; incorporated under present name, 1900. Director Olive Land and Mining Co. Republican. Presbyterian. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner; member Ancient Order of Druids, Knights of Pythias, Legion of Honor. Clubs: Liederkranz, Sharp Shooters. Office: 1113 Pine St. Residence: 3432 Chippewa St.

SCHMIDT, Louis, candy manufacturer; born Rhine Province, Prussia, Dec. 10, 1848; son of John and Elizabeth (Stamm) Schmidt; graduated from Central Wesleyan College, Warrenton, Mo., 1866; married, St Louis, June 10, 1871, Caroline Blanke; children: Lydia (Mrs. F. A. Kansteiner), Emma (Mrs. Hugo Boellner), Adeline (Mrs. George Gibson), Louis, Jr., William O., Albert F. Came to St Louis 1864; first permanent position was as errand boy for Col. A. A. Schaeffer, and in 1867 became clerk in store of W. Witte. Moro, Ill., but soon returned to St Louis and worked in hardware store of Charles Meyer and later with F. A. Kansteiner; with Metropolitan Bank until 1869, when became connected with Blanke Bros. Candy Co.; now treasurer of Blanke-Wenneker Candy Co.; also vice president Strassberger Conservatory of Music; treasurer Blanke Bros. Realty Co. Was in organized college company of militia during Price'8 raid, in Civil War, but was not enlisted in the army. Mason. Clubs: Liederkranz, Million Population. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 608 Market St. Residence: 3668 Snaw Ave.

SCHMITT, Eugene Emil, secretary and treasurer Rogers-Schmitt Wire and Iron Co.; born St Louis, Nov. 24, 1876; son of Charles and Anna (Mayer) Schmitt; educated at Penrose (public) School to fourteen; spent three and one-half years in Schenk's Drawing Academy, working for tuition; married, St Louis, Apr. 17, 1901, Paula Frances Proske; three children: Irwin E., Anna M., Girard C. Engaged as sketch artist two and one half years; entered employ of the Ludlow-Saylor Wire Co. as draughtsman and estimator, 1896, continuing until 1903; secretary St. Lonis Wire and Iron Co., 1903-09; assisted in organizing the Rogers-Schmitt Wire and Iron Co., 1909, of which is secretary and treasurer. Republican. Presbyterian. Member West Gate Lodge, No. 445, A. F. & A. M.; Beliefontaine Chapter, No. 25, R. A. M.; Ivanhoe Commandery, No. 8, Knights Templar. Club: Masonic. Recreation: fond of athletic sports. Office: Broadway and Mound Sts. Residence: 1815 N, Garrison Ave.

memberships: ["Master Bricklayers' Association","West St Louis Business Men's Association"]
fullentry: SCHMITT, Frederick, building contractor; born Pomeroy, O., Jan. 1, 1870; son of Conrad and Marie (Kuehne) Schmitt; educated in public schools; married, Cincinnati, 1890, Amelia Aschbach; three children: Fred, Raymond Julius, Henrietta. Began to provide for own support at ten and at eighteen commenced learning bricklayer's trade; in contracting business on own account since 1893; president Fred Schmitt & Co. Republican. Member Master Bricklayers' Association, West St Louis Business Men's Association. Recreation: automobiling. Office and Residence: 5912 Von Versen Ave.

memberships: ["South Broadway Merchants9 and Manufacturers' Association","Sons of Veterans","Catholic Knights of America"]
fullentry: SCHMITZ, Herman M., real estate; born Milwaukee, Wis., Nov. 18, 1870; son of Edward and Eva (Firmbach) Schmitz; educated at Toensfeldt's Educational Institute; unmarried. Bill clerk for the Hays Woolen Co., 1885-90; collector for Kroeger & Linde, 189092; salesman in real estate business, 1892-93; since in partnership with Gustave Meisenbach, firm of Meisenbach & Schmitz, real estate and financial agents. Member South Broadway Merchants9 and Manufacturers' Association, Sons of Veterans, Catholic Knights of America. Recreation: fishing. Office: 604 Chestnut St. Residence: 4527 Virginia Ave.

SCHMITZ, Rudolph, president Schmitz & Shroder Clothing Co.; born Mayence, Germany, Mar. 17, 1852; son of Ludwig Albrecht and Augusta (Wolf) Schmitz; educated in realschule in Germany; married, St Louis, Nov. 17, 1875; Helene Lipphardt; children: Rudolph, Jr., Adele, Walter Lipphardt, Edgar F. Came to United States April, 1870; started as clerk at cloth house of Hugh Boyle, St Louis, July, 1870, became buyer, 1875, and continued with successor, J. M. Hayes, until 1880; represented Cincinnati cloth house of Hy. Geiershofer & Co., 1880-84; started Swiss embroidery factory in 1884 and sold out in 1889; in clothing business since 1890; president and treasurer Schmitz & Shroder Clothing Co., president Lipphardt & Klie Clothing Co., of East St. Lonis, Lipphardt & Heymann Clothing Co., of Detroit; director Central National Bank of St Louis. Member Manufacturers' Association. Republican. Member Society for Ethical Culture. Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo Country. Recreations: horseback riding and music. Office: 8th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: 5385 Waterman Ave.

SCHMOLL, John, contractor and banker; born Amsterdam, Holland, Feb. 16, 1870; son of Gerritt M. and Fredrika (Van Der Lann) Schmoll; educated in public schools of St Louis and Academy of Architectural Science, graduating 1894; married, St Louis, June, 1896, Sophia Uthoff; three children: Frederick G., Dewey John, Ethel. Has engaged in brick contracting and construction business since 1894; president Tower Grove Bank; Contracting Supply Co., Consumers' Brick and Quarry Co.; director American Trust Co. Republican; chairman Republican City Central Committee. Member Board of Freeholders, 1911. Presbyterian. President Master Bricklayers' Association; member Tower Grove Heights Improvement Association. Mason, Knight Templar (Ascalon Commandery), Shriner; member National Union. Clubs: Liederkranz, Tower Grove Turn Verein. Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: 816 Olive St. Residence: 3626 Utah PL

SCHNECK, Henry, merchant tailor; born Washington, Mo., Feb. 4, 1861; son of Jacob and Marguerita (Freischlag) Schneck; educated jn public schools, Washington, Mo., until 1877, and Johnson's Commercial College, St Louis, 1884; married, St Louis, Apr. 7, 1885, Emma M. Benda; children: Ruby, Harry Guy. Came to St Louis, 1877, and entered employ of Mills & Averill, clothiers, as clerk, later becoming cashier, then secretary in 1901, vice president in 1903; on Feb. 14, 1905, resigned and with A. C. Mills and J. H. Dunklee, organized firm of Mills, Schneck & Dunklee, merchant tailors. Mr. Dunklee died June 10, 1905, and firm is now under title of Mills-Schneck-Powers Tailoring Co. Republican. Mason (32°), Knight Templar. Office: 705 Washington Ave. Residence: 6046 Berlin Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations"]
fullentry: SCHNEIDERHAHN, Edward Vincent Paul, lawyer; born St Louis, Sept. 23, 1874; son of Maximilian and Frances (Bleckmann) Schneiderhahn; educated in St. Mary 's and St. Vincent's parochial schools; title of A.B., from St Louis University; LL.B., Law Department, Washington University, 1896; unmarried. In practice since 1896. Member St Louis and Missouri State Bar associations. Member City Council, 1908-11 (vice president, 1910-11). Member National German-American Alliance (ex-president Missouri Division), Catholic Union of Missouri (ex-president), St Louis Settlement Association (board of governors), etc. Republican. Recreation: walking. Office: 722 Chestnut St. Residence: 1129 S. 7th St.

SCHOEN, Ernest E., secretary Standard Syrup Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 10, 1876; son of Jacob and Amelv (Eller) Schoen; educated in public schools of Iowa City, Ia., Peoria, Ill., and Leavenworth, Kan.; married at St Louis, 1899, to Miss Grace Ferry. In 1894 organized the Standard Syrup Co., of which is secretary. Has been a member of the First Regiment, National Guard of Missouri, since 1895, and was captain of Company E until 1908; served six months in the volunteer service, during the war with Spain, in the First Missouri Volunteers. Member Spanish War Veterans. Clubs: Officers of National Guard, Missouri Athletic. Recreation: walking. Office: 215 S. 2d St. Residence: 3039 Eads Ave.

SCHOEN, Jacob, syrup refiner; born, Bohemia, Austria, 1845; educated as chemist at University of Prague, Bohemia; married Miss Amely Eller. Came to the United States from Germany in 1866, and was engaged, until 1894, as chemist in the employ of sugar refineries and glucose factories; resided in St Louis, 1874-80; in Buffalo, N. Y., 1880-94; since 1894 president of The Standard Syrup Co. Office: 215 S. 2d St. Residence: 3039 Eads Ave.

SCHOENBERG, Friedrich E., president F. E. Schoenberg Manufacturing Co., window and window wire screens, etc.; born Germany, June, 1846; educated public schools; married, St Louis, 1872, Wilhelmina Witrock; two children: Gustav and Clara (Mrs. William Boefer, Jr.). Learned trade of glazier and cabinet maker; in German Army, 1867-69, advancing to corporal. Came to America, 1870, to St Louis, 1871; in employ Balke-Thonssen & Phierman Co., manufacturers picture and looking glass frames, until 1874; member firm*of Schmidt & Schoenberg, 1874 until death of Mr. Schmidt, 1890; then acquired entire ownership, the business since incorporated as the F. E. Schoenberg Manufacturing Co. Mason and Odd Fellow. Office: 2022 De Kalb St.

company: Schoenlau Steiner Trunk Top and Veneer Co.
fullentry: SCHOENLAU, William, president Schoenlau Steiner Trunk Top and Veneer Co.; born Boesingfeld, Lippe-Detmold, Germany, Nov. 0, 1839; educated in common schools, Germany; came to America, 1857; married, St Louis, May, 1863, Augusta Hains (died 1875); 2d, St/Louis, Jan. 16, 1877, Sophia Beuger; eight children, four living: Augusta (Mrs. Edward Palus), Elizabeth (Mrs. Joseph Hickel, Jr.), Ida W., Anna Marie (Mrs. Otto G. Steiner). Began business career St Louis, 1857, and continued in Central Market until 1861; with brother in grocery business, 1861-62; then conducted same alone; became connected with Kukkuck Two-Ply Trunk Top Co., 1894, which was re-incorporated, 1896, and since president of company. Owner Schoenlau Grove. Member St Louis Turn Verein. Republican. Member Protestant Evangelical Church. Club: Liederkranz. Recreation: traveling. Office: 129 E. Fillmore St. Residence: 1214 S. 18th St.

SCHOENTHALER, J. G. Woerner, secretary Eisenstadt Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, Jan. 5, 1879; son of Fred C. and Dorothea (Thormann) Schoenthaler; educated, Clinton (public) School; Manual Training School; unmarried. Began active career as bookkeeper and assistant cashier of the Scudder Gale Grocer Co., 1894, continuing seven years; became connected with the Eisenstadt Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of jewelry, Sept. 15, 1901, and has been secretary of same since 1903. Democrat. Member Ethical Society, B. P. O. Elks. Recreations: music and field sports. Office: 1205 Olive St. Residence: 4121 Magnolia Ave.

SCHOKMILLER, Charles Henry, type foundry; born St Louis, Aug. 21, 1870; son of Gottlieb and Louise (Herwig) Schokmiller; educated iu St Louis public schools to 1885; married, St Louis, Dec. 6, 1898, Cecelia Butler; one child, Charles F. Served as apprentice with Kingsland & Douglass Manufacturing Co. to 1890; with Joseph Heimbach Machine Co., 1890-91; with Burroughs Adding Machine Co., Central Type Foundry, Inland Type Foundry Co., and Keystone Type Co., to 1904. Engaged in manufacture of type founders' machinery, 1904, consolidated with Western Printers9 Supply Co., of Chicago, 1905, and formed Western Type Foundry Co., of which is vice president and manager. Republican. Protestant. Mason. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Masonic. Recreation: motoring. Office: 108 Pine St. Residence: 3831 Page Boul.

SCHOLLMEYER, Adolph Rudolph, real estate; born St Louis, Jan. 6, 1868; son of Rudolph and Henrietta (Woeltje) Scholl-meyer; educated in public schools; unmarried. Began active career in real estate office, 1889; established business for self, 1890; incorporated, 1905, as A. R. Schollmeyer Real Estate Co., of which has since been president. Also secretary Schiller Investment Co., Dresden Investment Co., Sutter Real Estate Co., Sideyer Real Estate and Investment Co., Wiesekorn Realty and Investment Co., Eiler Real Estate and Investment Co. President St Louis Real Estate Exchange, 1912; member Business Men's League, Civic League. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: Theatre. Office: 705 Chestnut St. Residence: Buckingham Hotel.

SCHOLLMEYER, Gustave Herman, director Hargadine-McKittrick Dry Goods Co.; born St Louis, June 6, 1865; son of Rudolph and Henrietta (Woeltje) Schollmeyer; educated in St Louis public schools; married, St Louis, Nov. 26, 1910, Mary Bird. Began active business career with D. Crawford & Co., 1878, and continued until 1885; then became connected with Hargadine-McKittrick company, as stock clerk, department salesman, traveling salesman, assistant general manager, stockholder and director; has had charge of sales since 1907. Also second vice president Tower Grove Bank (St Louis) and director of Bank of Piedmont, Piedmont, Mo. Owner of 2,000-acre farm in southeastern Missouri. Member Mound Builders, Southeastern Missouri Drummers' Association (president. 1905); national director of Travelers' Protective Association; organized Scully's Army, 1896, an auxiliary to Travelers' Protective Association. Democrat. Episcopalian. Member Tuscan Lodge, A. F. & A. M.; Missouri Chapter Xo. 1, R. A. M.; St. Aldemar Com-manderv, Knights Templar; Moolah Temple, A. A. O. N. M. S.; also B. P. O. Elks (life member). Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo, Oasis Hunting and Fishing, Cascade Fishing. Favorite recreations: golf and fishing. Office: 911 Washington Ave. Residence: 6460 Ellen-wood Ave.

memberships: ["Washington University Association","Alumni of Washington University Medical Department","Verein Deutscher Aertzte","St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Society","American Medical Association (oto-laryngological section)","Mississippi Valley Medical Society","City Hospital Alumni"]
fullentry: SCHOLZ, Roy Philip, physician; specializing in nose, throat and ear; born St Louis, Apr. 21, 1879; son of Philip and F. Belle (Carrington) Scholz; educated at Clay School, Central High School, Educational Institute; M.D., Medical Department, Washington University, 1904; post-graduate study, Imperial and Kingly University, Vienna, Austria, and in Berlin and Freiburg, Germany, and Berne, Switzerland; unmarried. Assistant in St Louis City Hospital, 1904-05; was assistant to Drs. M. Hajek and Hofrat and Prof. Adam Politzer, of University of Vienna, 1905-08; after returning to America became chief of nose, throat and ear department of the Social Service Hospital and Clinic, St Louis, and took up private practice in Metropolitan Building. Oto-laryngologist to Christian Orphans' Home, St Louis Blind Girls' Home, Father Dunn's Xewsboys' Home, Terminal Railroad; member medical staff Tuberculosis Society of St Louis; oto-laryngologist visiting staff of St Louis City Hospital, Female Hospital Sanitarium, Koch Sanitarium and Infectious Hospital, etc. Editor oto-laryngo-logical department St Louis Medical Review. Republican. Member Washington University Association, Alumni of Washington University Medical Department, Verein Deutscher Aertzte, St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Society, American Medical Association (oto-laryngological section), Mississippi Valley Medical Society, City Hospital Alumni. Mason (32°), Shriner. Clubs: City, Alma Mater. Office: Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 1110 Ferry St.

SCHONEBECK, Louis William, fire insurance; born St Louis, Aug. 19, 1865; son of Charles B. and Catharine (Drebes) Schone-beck; educated in O'Fallon School, Henry Ames School aud Bryant & Stratton Commercial College; married, Chicago, Nov. 24, 1903, Catharine Enide. Began business career on the sixteenth anniversary of birth, Aug. 19, 1881, as office boy with the Jefferson Mutual Fire Insurance Co. of St Louis; has remained with the company continuously and since 1901 has been secretary and treasurer. Republican. Protestant. Mason (32°), Shriner. Member Royal Arcanum. Club: Century Boat. Favorite recreations: athletics and fishing. Office: 317 Chestnut St. Residence: 2904 Ac-comae St.

SCHORR, John J., secretary Schorr-Kolkschneider Brewing Co.; born St Louis, Sept. 22, 1876; son of Jacob B. aud Louise (Koechel) Schorr; educated in German and English public and private schools, St Louis, until 1892; then served apprenticeship, and attended Brewers Academy, Chicago, to 1896; married, St Louis, Apr. 25, 1900, Emma Leroi; two children: Alma, Ilda. Began business career with Tennessee Brewing Co., Memphis, 1896, continuing to 1907; engaged with Green Tree Brewery, 1897-98; was assistant superintendent and brewmaster Charles G. Stifel Brewing Co., 1898-1901; since secretary of Schorr-Kolkschneider Brewing Co. Republican. Mason, Knight Templar, Shriner. Office: 2537 Natural Bridge Rd. Residence: 3817 X. 12th Street.

SCHOTTEN, Jerome J., coffees, spices, etc.; born St Louis, Aug. 15, 1882; son of Julius John and Pauline C. (Feldman) Schotten; educated at St Louis University and Smith Academy; unmarried. Began business career working during school vacations in the various departments of William Schotten & Co., roasters of coffees, and manager same since Sept. 1, 1902. Clubs: Racquet, St Louis. Office: 318 S. Broadway. Residence: Racquet Club.

SCHOTTEN, Julius John, coffee merchant; born St Louis, June 9, 1858; son of William and Wilhelmina E. (Verborg) Schotten; educated at St. Mary's (parochial) School and St Louis University; married, St Louis, Nov. 9, 1881, Pauline C. Feldman; children: Jerome J., Zoe Louise. At age of fifteen was bookkeeper at Iron Mountain Bank; two years later, on death of father, became connected with firm of William Schotten & Co., as cashier; became partner in 1880, and since death of brother, 1897, has been sole owner of the business (founded by William Schotten, 1847), firm being importers and wholesale dealers in teas, coffees and spices; also president National Coffee Roasters' Association. Catholic. Member Business Men's League. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet. Recreation: golf. Office: 318 S. Broadway. Residence: near Clayton, Mo.

SCHRAUBSTADTER, Oswald, vice president Inland Type Foundry; born Brookline, Mass., April 23, 1868; son of Carl and Augusta (Stern) Schraubstadter; educated in public and high schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, June 5, 1901, Eleanor B. Heynen; two sons: Carl, Oswald, Jr. Entered employ of Central Type Foundry, St Louis, in 1884, and continued with that company in advancing positions, and when, in 1903, the Inland Type Foundry was incorporated to manufacture type and printers' supplies, was one of the incorporators of the company, of which is now vice president. Clubs: Mercantile, Liederkranz, Xiangua Game and Fish Preserve. Favorite recreations: music and fishing. Office: 204 N. 14th St. Residence: 3134 Longfellow Boulevard.

SCHRAUBSTADTER, William A., president Inland Type Foundry; born Brookline, Mass., Oct. 21,1864; son of Carl and Augusta (Stern) Schraubstadter; educated in public schools of Brookline, Mass., and St Louis; married, St Louis, 1891, Mary Wells McEutire: children: Lucille, Madeline, Edith, Alvina. Came to St Louis, with parents, from Brookline, Mass., 1875. Began business experience with the Central Type Foundry of St Louis, where learned type-founder's trade until 1893; in 1894, with brothers, Oswald and Carl, organized the Inland Type Foundry, of which is president. Clubs: Mercantile, Arcadia Country, Liederkranz, Niangua Game and Fish Preserve. Recreations: outdoor sports, music and art. Office: 204 N. 14th St. Residence: 4425 W. Belle PI.

SCHRENK, Hermann von, botanist; born College Point, L. I., N. Y., Mar. 12, 1873; son of Professor Joseph and Anna (Bandtke) Schrenk; graduated Hoboken Academy, 1888, Oswego Xormal School, 1889, Cornell University, B.S., 1893 (A.M., Harvard, 1894, Ph.D., Washington University, 1897); married, Feb. 22, 1909, Mary Jane Kimball. Assistant in botany, Harvard University, 1893-94; instructor Manual Training School, St Louis, 1895-96; instructor plant diseases Shaw School of Botany, Washington University, 1896-1903; special agent U. S. Department Agriculture, 18981901; pathologist in charge Mississippi Valley Laboratory, Bureau Plant Industry, U. 8. Department of Agriculture, 1901-06; chief division forest products, Bureau of Forestry, 1903-05; in charge investigations on timber diseases and timber preservation; special commissioner U. S. Department Agriculture, 1903. Lecturer on timber diseases and wood preservation, Yale Forest School, 1902-07. Chairman Missouri State Forest Commission. Present occupation: consulting timber engineer at Tower Grove and Flad Aves.; also pathologist Missouri Botanical Garden; lecturer Biltmore Forest School. Member Botanical Society of America, A. A. A.
