S., Deutsche Botanische Gesellschaft, National Geographical Society, American Forestry Association, American Society of Naturalists (treasurer, 1904-08), Society for Promotion of Agricultural Science, American Society for Testing Materials, American Railway Engineers and Maintenance of Way Association, St Louis Academy of Science, Association Internationale des Botanistes; member International Jury, St Louis Exposition. Secretary American Board of Editors Botanisches Centralblatt; specially engaged in investigations on diseases of fruit trees and forest trees and timber preservation. Unitarian. Author: Decay of Timber and Methods for Preventing It; Seasoning of Timber, and papers on kindred subjects. Clubs: University, Round Table, City. Residence: 4139 McPherson Ave.

SCHROEDER, Roland, vice president Philip Gruner Bros. Lumber Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 2, 1867; son of George and Caroline (Gruner) Schroeder; educated St Louis public schools until 1885, then at Franklin Institute to 1888; married, St Louis, Oct. 10, 1892, Emma Simpkins. Began with Philip Gruner Bros. Lumber Co., 1892, serving in various capacities, and became vice president, 1902; also vice president Leisner Realty and Building Co., elected 1908. Republican. Member Ethical (culture) Society. Mason. Club: Midland Valley Country. Recreations: golf, fishing and outdoor sports. Office: 4006 N. Broadway. Residence: 5007 Von Versen Ave.

SCHROETER, Charles F., president Schroe-ter Coal Co.; born St Louis, Jan. 29, 1854; son of Edward Charles and Laura (Neidner) Schroeter; educated in Cross Lutheran (parochial) School, St Louis, to 1867; Concordia College, Ft. Wavne, Ind., 1867-71; took course in Jones Commercial College, St Louis, 1872; married, St Louis, Oct. 2, 1879, Anna Erck; children: Laura (Mrs. Max Karch), Arthur H., Flora and Edwin (deceased). Began business career, Apr. 12, 1886, since continuously identified with coal interests; organized Schroeter Coal Co., 1886; also president North Breese Coal and Mining Co. and Concordia Publishing House; director South Side Bank since 1903. Lutheran. Recreation: bowling. Office: 2300 Miami St. Residence: 2302 Miami Street.

SCHROETER, Oscar J., hardware; born St Louis, July 18, 1869; son of Bruno O. and Christiana Schroeter; educated in public schools. With hardware house of Julius Morisse two years; then entered employ of Simmons Hardware Co., but eighteen months later returned to original position; associated with brother, Charles G., and established Schroeter Bros. Hardware Co., of which is president. Officer 717 Washington Ave.

memberships: ["American and Missouri State Medical associations","St Louis Medical Society","Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni","Alumni Association Medical Department of Washington University"]
fullentry: SCHUCHAT, W. Louis, physician and surgeon; born in Austria, Apr. 2, 1875; son of Moritz and Helene (Wieder) Schuchat; came to St Louis with parents, 1876; attended St Louis public schools, graduating from Madison School, 1889; attended the Polytechnic, Foster Academy, and graduated from Central High School, January, 1893; graduated from Missouri Medical College (now Medical Department of Washington University), M.D., summa cum laudef 1896; unmarried. Appointed, after competitive examination, and served as junior assistant physician, City Hospital, 1896*97; since engaged in general private practice as physician and surgeon. Member American and Missouri State Medical associations, St Louis Medical Society, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni, Alumni Association Medical Department of Washington University. Jewish religion; member Young Men's Hebrew Association. Office: 2200 Chouteau Ave. Residence: 3647 Russell Ave.

SCHUCK, Philip, physician and surgeon; born St Louis, Jan. 20, 1876; son of Philip J. and Mary (Saddel) Schuck; educated in public schools, high school, and the Educational Institute, St Louis; graduated from Marion-Sims College of Medicine, M.D., 1897; married, St Louis, 1904, Elsie Von Tolcacz; one son, Carl Alfred. In general practice as physician and surgeon in St Louis since 1897. Office: 1420 S. Broadway. Residence: 1133 Rutger St.

memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange; president St Louis Hay Receivers' Association"]
fullentry: SCHULTE, John Joseph, hay and grain commission; born St Louis, Sept. 16, 1865; son of George J. and Mary (Brode) Schulte; educated at St. Joseph's School and Greer's Commercial College; married, St Louis, Feb. 16, 1887; children: John J., George P., Isabelle, Edna, Brayman, Marie, Karl, Paul and Dorothy. In grain business since 1879; member firm of George J. Schulte & Co. since 1902. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange; president St Louis Hay Receivers' Association. Democrat. Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus, Catholic Knights of America. Office: 505 Chamber of Commerce. Residence: 3701 Evans Ave.

SCHULTE, William Fredrick, secretary Christian Peper Tobacco Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 23, 1877; son of B. Rudolph and Anna (Tirre) Schulte; educated in St Louis public schools to 1890; married, St Louis, May 13, 1903, May Cavendish; two children: William F., Jr., Bernard Richard. After leaving school held minor positions, and engaged with Simmons Hardware Co., 1894-98; conducted grocery business for self until 1900. Entered Christian Peper Tobacco Co. as clerk, 1901, and has been secretary since 1904. Republican. Member Church of Christ. Member I. O. O. F., Modern Woodmen of America. Club: Western Rowing. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 721 N. Main St. Residence: Woodland, Mo.

SCHULTZ, H. E.f Jr., president Zittlosen Manufacturing Co.; born Jefferson City, Mo., Sept. 16, 1866; son of Herman E. and Caroline (Heintze) Schultz; educated in Bryant & Stratton Business College, St Louis, Smith Academy, and Riverview Military Academy, Poughkeepsie, N. Y.; married, St Louis, 1898, Helen Fischer. Began business career with the Schultz Dry Goods and Carpet Co., of Jefferson City, Mo., 1883-85; removed to St Louis, 1885, and entered employ of Martin Zittlosen, manufacturer of tents, awnings, becoming secretary of Zittlosen Manufacturing • Co. in 1888, president since 1891; also president Schultz Realty and Investment Co.; vice president Tower Grove Bank. Member National Manufacturers' Association. Recreations: motoring and traveling. Office: Park Ave. and Dolman St. Residence: 3640 Hartford St.

memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange","St Louis Grain Club"]
fullentry: SCHULTZ, Henry C., president Schultz & Xiemeier Commission Co.; born St Louis, Dec. 6, 1861; son of Louis and Wilhelmina (Bollmann) Schultz; educated in St Louis public schools, Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, Ft. Madison, Ia., May 12, 1887, Ida S. Schaper; one son living, Arthur W\ Began in grain business as office boy, 1877; associated since Mar. 1, 1897, with C. L. Niemeier and H. H. Beckman as Schultz & Niemeier Commission Co., of which is president. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange, St Louis Grain Club. Republican. Lutheran. Recreation: music. Office: 305-306 Chamber of Commerce. Residence: 2945 Dodier St.

memberships: ["North American Retail Druggists' Association","St Louis Retail Druggists' Association","West End Business Men's League","Royal Arcanum","Alumni of St Louis College of Pharmacy"]
fullentry: SCHULZ, Henry William, druggist; born Waverly, O., Dec. 10, 1874; son of William and Katherine (Spitzhirn) Schulz; educated grammar and high schools; matriculated in St Louis College of Pharmacy,* graduating with degree of Pharm. Grad., Mar. 25, 1891; married, W'ellsville, Mo., Apr. 25, 1894, Charlotte May White; two children: Marguerite and Harold. Began in drug business Mar. 5, 1897, in location where he has since remained, and is proprietor Schulz's Pharmacy. Member North American Retail Druggists' Association, St Louis Retail Druggists' Association, West End Business Men's League, Royal Arcanum, Alumni of St Louis College of Pharmacy. Office: Vandeventer and Laclede Aves. Residence: 3955 W. Pine Boul.

SCHUREMAN, Willis Perry, vice president Bradley Stencil Machine Co.; born St Louis, May 29, 1864; son of John N. and Elizabeth (Saville) Schureman; educated in Stoddard School and High School, St Louis; unmarried. Began business with Park, Brother & Co., Black Diamond Steel Works, 1879, and remained with that company, traveling in western territory until 1887, when resigned and became member of firm of Weyer & Schureman, representing Sanderson Bros. Steel Co. and other manufacturers; in 1892 went to Arizona as secretary of the Chrystoval Construction Co. for the building of irrigation canals; returned to St Louis and connected with irrigation enterprises and New York Life Insurance Co.; in January, 1901, accepted position of general manager of the Bradley Stencil Machine Co., manufacturers of stencil machines, and in 1903 was elected vice president, in which office is still serving, as well as in position of general manager. Member St Louis Sales Managers' Association. Republican. Methodist. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Methodist, Union, Century Boat, St Louis Railway, Monroe Hunting. Recreations: hunting and billiards. Office: 3745 Forest Park Boul. Residence: 5820 Maple Ave.

SCHURK, Henry, proprietor and manager Schurk Iron Works; born Westphalia, Germany, Feb. 17, 1864; son of William and Elizabeth (Sellinghoff) Schurk; educated in parochial schools of Henrichenburg, Westphalia; married Lucy Zimmerman, of Westerholt, Westphalia. May 16, 1889; five children: Henry, Lucy, William, Joseph, Anthony. Arrived in America Apr. 1, 1887; started in general iron working business, 1893, under title of Berendes & Schurk; in 1895 partnership was dissolved and name changed to Schurk Iron Works, of which is proprietor. Democrat. Catholic. Office: 327 S. 14th St. Residence: 3433 Montana St.

SCHUSTER, Nicholas B., carriage manufacturer; born Chicago, March, 1852; son of George and Katherine Schuster; educated in public schools to 1804; married, St Louis, May 31, 1882, Katie Reimert; five children. Began business career with Clokey & Hand, hat store, Chicago, 1864, and continued until 1867; in grocery business, 1867-69; then in father's carriage and wagon factory to 1871. Removed to St Louis and was with Solar Carriage Co. to 1872; with Wesley Fallon Carriage Works until 1883; then established present business. Member Knights of Pythia9, Royal Arcanum. Office: 1625 Wash St. Residence: 4974 Wabada Ave.

SCHUSTER, Siegmund Joseph, president Straus Saddlery Co.; born Germany, Apr. 10, 1861; son of Joseph and Sarah (Floirsheim) Schuster; educated in public schools, Germany, to 1874; came to America, 1884; married, New York City, Dec. 1, 1897, Sarah Frank; two children: Blanche and Lucille. Began business career as salesman Phelan Glassware Co., New York, 1884, and continued until 1885; then with Henry Birn organized firm of Schuster & Birn, glassware and china; purchased partner's interest, 1898, and continued alone until 1901. Disposed of New York business to Kollish & Wallock, and removed to St Louis, 1901; then acquired ownership of Jacob Straus Saddlery Co., now conducted as Straus Saddlery Co. Member Business Men 'b League. Jewish religion. Mason. Club: Columbian. Office: 27th and Locust Sts. Residence: 4435 W. Pine Boul.

SCHUYLER, William, teacher; born St Louis, May 4, 1855; son of Montgomery (D.D.) and Sophia Elizabeth (Norton) Schuyler; B.A., Washington University, 1874, M.A., 1877; studied music and composition with private instructors, drawing and painting, St Louis school of Fine Arts, 1876-80; married, Hidee Remington, of Buffalo, N. Y., Dec. 24, 1881 (died 1897); children: Montgomery, Remington, Norton. Teacher, lecturer and writer, general and pedagogical subjects, since 1877; assistant principal in high schools, St Louis, since 1895. Member N. E. A. (president department secondary education, 1905). Democrat. Episcopalian. Author: An Ambassador of Christ, 1901; Under Pontius Pilate, 1906; The Art of Composition (with Philo M. Buck. Jr.); Mona Lisa (under the nom de plume of Guglielmo Scala), 1911. Editor: Macaulay's Life of Samuel Johnson, 1903. Also musical composer. Residence: 1615 Missouri Ave.

SCHWAB, Leon J., vice president Schwab Clothing Co.; born. West Chester, Pa., July 16, 1863; son of Jacob and Amelia (Friedman) Schwab; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, Oct. 25, 1892, Ray Stix; children: James L., William S., Lee J., Alice Stix. Began business career in clothing house in New York in 1879, and in 1884 became connected with the Schwab Clothing Co. of St Louis, manufacturers of clothing (established 1866, incorporated 1883), which served in various capacities until taking present position as vice president of the company in 1895. Republican. Jewish religion; member board of directors Jewish Home for the Aged and Infirm. Mason (32°). Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo Country, Columbian. Recreation: golf. Office: 1132 Washington Ave. Residence: 5106 Washington Avenue.

SCHWANER, Frederick Charles, manager branch house, engines and boilers; born in Evansville, Ind., Jan. 28, 1867; son of Dietrich and Maria (Heim) Schwaner; educated in public schools of Evansville, Ind.; married, Evansville, Nov. 15, 1892, Lorena C. Emrieh; one son, Emrieh P. At age of fourteen entered employ of William Heilman, of Evansville, and continued in his employ and that of his successor for eighteen years as shipping clerk, office man, traveling salesman, purchasing agent and assistant manager; since Jan. 1, 1900, manager of the St Louis branch house of The Brownell Company, manufacturers of engines and boilers. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic, Algonquin Golf. Office: 401 Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 5189 Cabanne Avenue.

SCHWARTING, Henry, tailor; born in Prussia, July 19, 1846; son of Henry and Anna (Rolfs) Schwarting; educated in schools in Germany and by private instruction at St Louis; married, St Louis, 1876, Johaua Louisa Witthoefft; children: William D., Emil Frederick, Harry, Louisa, Tille (Mrs. J. W. Bissell), Delia A. Learned tailoring trade in Germany and worked at it in city of Bremen and other towns until came to America at age of twenty-two; after a short stay in Baltimore came to St Louis, and worked at trade for Keck & Goemann eleven years; was partner for a short time in firm of Wolfe & Schwarting, and in 1880 in firm of Schwarting & Keck, incorporated January, 1906, as Schwarting & Keck Clothing Co., of which is president. Odd Fellow. Recreations: fishing and bowling. Office: 3601 N. Broadway. Residence: 3520 N. 9th St.

office: S. W. cor. 2d and Walnut Sts.
fullentry: SCHWARTZ, Robert Joseph, president All Paper Box Co.; born, St Louis, Dec. 28, 1872; son of Frederick and Theresa (Springer) Schwartz; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, July 25, 1908, Marie Davis; three children: Earle Alfred, Robert Roy, Georgianna Robertia. Began active career in employ of the Moser Cigar and Paper Box Co. at seventeen, continuing for two and one-half years; was with St Louis Paper Box Co. as salesman for twelve years, 18911903; secretary Progressive Box Co., 1903-05; manager box factory of National Candy Co., 1905-09; organizer and president and treasurer All Paper Box Co. since Aug. 1, 1909; also vice president Another Building Co. Republican. Member St Louis Credit Men's Association. Mason; member Anchor Lodge, No. 443, A. F. & A. M. Clubs: Century Boat, American Wheel, St Louis Cricket. Recreation: baseball. Office: S. W. cor. 2d and Walnut Sts. Residence: Clayton, Mo.

SCHWARTZ, Selig, vice president Cohen-Schwartz Rail and Steel Co., born Kief, Russia, Dec. 28, 1867; son of Julius and Bessie (Goldin) Schwartz; educated in public schools of Prussia; married, Rosa Greenspan, of St Louis, June 6, 1887; six children: Frank, Goldie (Mrs. Dave Berger), Dora, Abe, Sam, Bernard. Came to America, 1885; began active career in employ of Standard Stamping Co.; entered retail scrap iron business, at Broadway and Tyler St., with B. Koplar, 1888; in same business on own account, 1890-1902; then with others organized the Cohen-Schwartz Rail and Steel Co., incorporated, October, 1902, of which is vice president and secretary; also vice president L. J. Cohen & Co. and copartner Western Iron and Rag Co. Republican. Treasurer Jewish Orthodox Old Folks Home. Member B'nai B'rith, I. O. O. F. Office: 3130 Hall St. Residence: 5124 Maple Avenue.

memberships: ["St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State and American Medical associations","Verein Deutschen Aertzte"]
fullentry: SCHWARZ, Henry, physician; born Giessen, Hesse-Darmstadt, Germany, Nov. 14,1855; son of Jacob and Susan Schwarz; attended gymnasium to seventeen; came to America, 1873; graduated St Louis College of Pharmacy, 1876; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1879; post-graduate study University of Giessen, Germany, 1879-80; married, St Louis, Sept. 1, 1886, Johanna Laura Forster; four sons: Marquard J., Otto H., Walter C., Frederick W. Served as assistant, University Female Hospital, Giessen, 1880-81, also at University Female Hospital, Heidelberg, in charge pro ternand as first assistant teacher of midwifery, 1881-83; in practice St Louis since 1883. Appointed clinical lecturer on gynecology, St Louis Medical College, 1886, professor gynecology, 1889; professor obstetrics and gynecology, Washington Medical School, since 1900. Member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State and American Medical associations, Verein Deutschen Aertzte. Office and Residence: 440 N. Newstead Ave.

SCHWEDTMAN, Ferdinand Charles, electrical engineer; born Osnabrueck, Germany, May 13, 1867; son of William and Bertha (Van Derwald) Schwedtman; came to United States, 1881: educated at Hanover, Amsterdam, and at Cooper Institute, New York; married Cora H. Gehner, of St Louis, Jan. 18, 1904. Chief engineer Missouri Electric Light and Power Co., 1889-99; founder and general superintendent, 1891-1904, Wagner Electric Manufacturing Co. Consulting engineer. Inventor of electrical and mechanical machines. President Citizens' Industrial Association of St Louis; vice president National Association of Manufacturers; member American Institute Electrical Engineers; member Employers' Liability and Workmen's Compensation Committee. Clubs: University, Mercantile. Office: 706 Locust St. Residence: Kingsbury Apts.

SCHWENKER, Henry Frank, real estate; born New Haven, Franklin Co., Mo., Sept. 24, 1867; son of Charles and Louise (Klein) Schwenker; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, Dec. 20, 1901, Hattie Schneidt; one son, Henry Frank, Jr. Started in business at age of eighteen and for nine years was in the grocery business; after that for six years in the contracting business until 1900; since engaged in general real estate business in St Louis. Member A. F. & A. M. Office: 1107 Chestnut St. Residence: 3706 S. Broadway.

SCHWERDTMANN, Emil Richard, president Schwerdtmann Toy Co.; born Baltimore, Md., Aug. 11, 1861; son Theodore and Augusta (Seegers) Schwerdtmann; educated in private school, Baltimore; married, Keokuk, Ia., February, 1887, Anna Kast; children: Edmund A., Paula G., Alfred L. Entered in 1877, as a boy of sixteen, in the toy business, established bv father at Baltimore in 1853, remaining there until 1880, when the entire business was removed to St Louis, where a branch house had been conducted from 1874. Father died in 1887 and business was incorporated as Schwerdtmann Toy Co., of which has since been president. Evangelical Lutheran. Member Royal Arcanum, American Wheel Association. Recreation: traveling. Office: 811-813 Washington Ave. Residence: 3508 Crittenden Street.

SCHWERDTMANN, Otto F., secretary and treasurer Schwerdtmann Toy Co.; born Baltimore, Md., Oct. 9, 1863; son of Theodore and Augusta (Seegers) Schwerdtmann; educated in grammar and high schools of Baltimore; married, St Louis, September, 1889, Marie Heinieke; children: four daughters, two sons. Began business career at age of sixteen in office of a wholesale cloth house in St Louis; became assistant bookkeeper, bookkeeper, cashier and finally office manager and credit man. In 1886 entered the business of father (established 1853), who was the pioneer in the United States in the exclusive toy business, the firm becoming Schwerdtmann & Sons; on death of father in July, 1887, business was incorporated under present stylo of Schwerdtmann Toy Co., of which has since been secretary and treasurer. Democrat. Evangelical Lutheran. Club: Liederkranz. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 811 Washington Ave. Residence: 3532 Flora Ct.

SCOTT, Oreon Earle, real estate and insurance; born McClellandtown, Pa., Nov. 11, 1871; son of Clark B. and Catherine C. (Gilmore) Scott; educated in public schools of Fayette Co., Pa.; A.B., Bethany College, West Virginia, 1892; LL.B. and A.M., University of Michigan, 1894; married, Chicago, July 17, 1895, Mabel Crabbe; children: Margaret L., Katharine M., Mary E. Financial agent Bethany College^ 1892; admitted to St Louis bar, Oct. 1, 1894; business manager Christian Courier, Dallas, Tex., 1895; engaged in advertising business as Scott Advertising Co., in Cincinnati, 1895-96; president Standard Adding Machine Co., 1907-08; in real estate and insurance business in St Louis, since April, 1896, firm being Oreon E. & R. G. Scott. Member St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Independent Republican. Member Christian (Disciples) Church; secretary Christian Board of Publication; director National Benevolent Association of the Christian Church; inbmber Business Men's League, Advertising Men's League, Pennsylvania Society, Ohio Society, National Geographic Society, Archaeological Institute of America, Missouri Historical Society. Scottish Rite Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner; member Royal Arcanum, Royal League. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, Mercantile, Normandie Golf, Franklin, City, Masonic. Aero. Automobile. Office: 817 Chestnut St. Residence: 5211 Westminster PL

SCOTT, Pierre Chouteau, manufacturer hickory handles, etc.; born St Louis, Feb. 10, 1875; son cf Thomas J. ami Sarah (Lackland) Scott, educated iu Christian Brothers College and at Missouri Military Academy, Macon, Mo., graduating 1894; married in St. Lonis, Jan. 23, 1900, Adele Keller; one daughter, Marie Louise. Began business career in 1897 as clerk in Boatmen's Bank, St Louis; since Jan. 1, 1901, secretary and treasurer of Keller & Tamm Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of hickory handles, and wagon and buggy wood stock (established 1844). Democrat. Served in Battery A, in Spanish-American War, in Porto Rico. Member Business Men's League. Club: St Louis. Recreation: hunting. Office: Main and Victor Sts. Residence: 4464 W. Pine Boul.

SCOTT, Raymond Gilmore, real estate ami insurance; born McClellandtown, Pa., Dec. 11, 1872; son of Clark B. and Catherine C. (Gilmore) Scott; removed with parents to Bethany, W. Va., 1888; A.B., Bethany (W. Va.) College, 1892; LL.B., Law Department of University of Michigan, 1894; married, Rome, Ga., Oct. 6, 1903, May, daughter of John H. Reynolds, president First National Bank of Rome, who died June 13, 1906; children: Reynolds Gilmore and May. Practiced law for four years in cities of Wheeling and Wellsburg, W. Va., 1894-98; came to St Louis, April, 1899, and engaged in real estate and insurance business with brother, Oreon E. Scott, under present firm name of Oreon E. & R. G. Scott. Member of St Louis Real Estate Exchange. Republican. Was engrossing clerk Senate of West Virginia in session or 1899. Member of Christian (Disciples) Chureh. Member Beta Theta Pi Fraternity, Occidental Lodge, A. F. & A. M., Delmar Council, Royal Arcanum. Office: 817 Chestnut St. Residence: 5004 Delmar Boul.

office: came to United States in 1868; worked at trade until 1881 when began business as Scott & Richarz Pressroom Co., at 316 Chestnut St.; removed to 110 8. 9th St. in 1886, and to 325 N. 3d St., in January, 1901, when firm name was changed to Stewart Scott Pressroom Co., of which he is president; removed in 1905 to own building at 312-314 Chestnut St., when firm name was changed to Stewart Scott Printing Co., now doing all classes of printing. Treasurer St Louis Typo-thetce. Republican. Presbyterian. Mason (Scottish Rite), member Chapter, Commandery and Shrine; also member Woodmen of the World, Caledonia Society. °lub: Mercantile. Office: 312-314 Chestnut S.
fullentry: SCOTT, Stewart, president of Stewart Scott Pressroom Co.; born Edinburgh, Scotland, Feb. 22, 1854; son of James and Marget M. (Brown) Scott; educated in Edinburgh, Scotland; married, St Louis, Jan. 15, 1880, Sarah D. Noel; children: Eleanor W., Marget J., Stewart, Jr., Carrie Noel. Left school at eleven years of age, and went to work in printing office; came to United States in 1868; worked at trade until 1881 when began business as Scott & Richarz Pressroom Co., at 316 Chestnut St.; removed to 110 8. 9th St. in 1886, and to 325 N. 3d St., in January, 1901, when firm name was changed to Stewart Scott Pressroom Co., of which he is president; removed in 1905 to own building at 312-314 Chestnut St., when firm name was changed to Stewart Scott Printing Co., now doing all classes of printing. Treasurer St Louis Typo-thetce. Republican. Presbyterian. Mason (Scottish Rite), member Chapter, Commandery and Shrine; also member Woodmen of the World, Caledonia Society. °lub: Mercantile. Office: 312-314 Chestnut S. Residence: 2319 Albion Place.

SCOTT, William Samuel, coal mine operator; born Fredericksburg, Va., Dec. 13, 1862; son of Hugh and Anne (Clarkson) Scott; educated by private instruction and later attended Fredericksburg Military Academy; married, St Louis, Oct. 12, 1897, Margaret Lytton; children: Marjorie L., Henry C., Samuel L. Began business life as a clerk in grocery store of Brockenbrough & Knox, Fredericksburg, Va., and after that in dry goods store of A. B. Botts & Co., at same place until 1879; in bank of Conway, Gordon & Garnett, 1879-82; came to St Louis, 1882; cashier Union Depot Elevator Co., 1882-85; secretary Lalement Milling Co., Carondelet, and later assistant to secretary Carondelet Gas Light Co., 1885-87; vice president T. & H. Mining Co., 1887-93, and when in 1893 that company was merged into the Missouri & Illinois Coal Co., miners of Turkey Hill and Carterville coal, was made vice president and general manager of latter company; president same since January, 1909. Member Business Men's League, Merchants' Exchange. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, City, The Traffic, St Louis Railway. Recreations: walking and the theatre. Office: 407 N. Broadway, room 805. Residence: Carson Rd., Ferguson, Mo.

SCUDDER, Charles, Jr., secretary Wesco Supply Co.; born Kinloch, St Louis Co., Mo., Aug. 9, 1876; son of Charles and Sarah Virginia (Rogers) Scudder; educated in the public schools to 1890; Washington University, 1890-94; married, St Louis, Apr. 17, 1906, Elizabeth Kilpatrick; one child, Elizabeth Liggett. Engaged as salesman with Wesco Electrical Co., 1894, continuously identified with same, and elected secretary Wesco Supply Co., 1906; also director Liggett Realty Co. Was in Light Battery A, Field Artillery, U. S. Army, during Spanish-American War. Republican. Episcopalian. Member Knights of Pythias. Clubs: St Louis, City, St Louis Country, Aero. Recreations: golf and horseback riding. Office: Clark Ave. and 7th St. Residence: 4622 Maryland Ave.

SCUDDER, Charles White, president Rawlings Manufacturing Co.; born St Louis, July 29, 1864; son of .John Anderson and Mary (White) Scudder; educated in Smith Academy and Wyman Institute (now Western Military Academy), St Louis; married, St Louis, Oct. 12, 1887, Mary Mason; children: Mary, Mason. After leaving school began business career with the Hargadine-McKittrick Dry Goods Co.; after that was for six years secretary of the Clark & Stuvvesant Grocery Co. until 1897, when joined in organization of the Rawlings Sporting Goods Co., of which was president until 1907; then organized the Rawlings Manufacturing Co., of which is president, the firm doing a wholesale business only. Director Union Dairy Co. Member Civic League. Republican. Clubs: Noonday, St Louis, St Louis Country, Bellerive Country, Cuivre. Recreations: hunting, fishing, golfing and all outdoor sports. Office: 2301 Lucas Ave. Residence: 75 Vandeventer Pl.

mnames: ton Rogers; president Samuel Cupples Envelope Co.; born St Louis
fullentry: SCUDDER, Cliff ton Rogers; president Samuel Cupples Envelope Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 21, 1862; son of Charles and Sarah Virginia (Rogers) Scudder; educated in public schools of St Louis and in Washington University; married, St Louis, Feb. 24, 1892, Mary Belle Lowman; children: Samuel Cupples, Cliffton Rogers, Jr. Began business career in 1876 with Guernsey, Jones & Co., furniture dealers, as collector, and remained with that company, becoming treasurer, until resigned, 1887, to become vice president and treasurer of the St Louis Electric Light and Power Co., until 1897; elected, February, 1899, vice president and treasurer of the Samuel Cupples Envelope Co., operating large factories at St Louis, New York and Chicago; now president of the company. Also president of the Wesco Supply Co.; director of the Merchants'-Laclede National Bank. Republican. Methodist. Clubs: St Louis Country, St Louis, Noonday. Favorite recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: 638 S. 6th St. Residence: 4557 W. Pine Boul.

SCUDDER, James White, president The Scudders-Gale Grocer Co.; born St Louis, July 3, 1861; son of John A. and Mary (White) Scudder; educated in public schools and Washington University; married, St Louis, February, 1891, Harriet McKinley; children: John Anderson and James W. Began business career as clerk with Fink & Nasse, wholesale grocers, 1881-82; with Garneau, Scudder & Co., grocers, 1882; later secretary for Krafft-Holmes Grocery Co. until 1890, when established in business for self as James W. Scudder & Co., wholesale grocers, which business was amalgamated with The Scudders-Gale Grocer Co., of which is president. Clubs: Noonday, Bellerive Country, Deer Plain. Recreation: shooting. Office: 7i4 Spruce St. Residence: 3833 Washington Ave.

SCUDDER, John A., capitalist; born Maysville, Ky., June 12, 1830; son of Dr. Charles and Mary H. Scudder; came to St Louis at early age; educated in local schools; married, St Louis, 1852, Mary A. White; children: James W., Charles W., Isabel S. (Mrs. Dr. Wheeler Bond), and Mary S. (Mrs. Otto L. Mersman). Followed steamboating practically all of his active career, becoming steamboat captain; was one of organizers of Memphis & St Louis Packet Co. (Anchor Line) and its president, 1870; in 1879 reorganization taking place, with consolidation of another line, company became known as St Louis and Vicksburg Anchor Line, of which was president and chief executive officer; now retired from act-1 ive business. Director State National Bank, St Louis Union Trust Co. Member Merchants' Exchange of St Louis (president 1877). Clubs: St Louis, St Louis Country. Office: Security Bldg. Residence: 17 Vandeventer PI.

SCULLIN, Harry, president Scullin-Galla-gher Iron and Steel Co.; born Leavenworth, Kan., Oct. 6, 1866; son of John and Hannah (Perry) Scullin; educated St. John's College, Fordham, N. Y.; St Louis University; married, St Louis, Dec. 26, 1888, Julia Frye Woodward; two children: Mary Julia, Eugenia Lenore. Began as clerk in office of Union Depot R. R. Co., St Louis, September, 1885; held various positions, becoming purchasing agent, general manager, then vice president of the company; elected director Grand Avenue R. R. Co., 1890, also vice president, general manager and later president same company; formerly a director Laclede Gas Light Co., St Louis National Bank, Missouri & North Arkansas Ry., St Louis, Kansas City & Colorado Ry., Arkansas & Choctaw Ry., also builder, vice president and general manager East St Louis Ry. Co.; president Scullin-Gallagher Iron and Steel Co. since 1900; director Mercantile Trust Co., Mercantile National Bank. Independent Democrat. Roman Catholic. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet, Bellerive. Recreations: shooting, tennis, motoring, and all outdoor sports. Office: 6700 Manchester Ave. Residence: 5218 S. Broadway.

SCULLIN, John, chairman board Scullin-Gallagher Iron and Steel Co.; born in St. Lawrence Co., N. Y., Aug. 17, 1836; son of Nicholas and Mary (Callahan) Scullin; educated in public schools and at Potsdam (N. Y.) Academy; married, Montreal, Canada, Aug. 18, 1863, Hannah Perry; children: Mae (Madame de Gheest), John Harry, Frederick William (deceased), Robert C. (deceased), Lenore (Mrs. Charles McLure Clark), Charles Luis. Was employed on father's farm in Town of Brasher, St. Lawrence Co., N. Y., until at'age of nineteen entered service of Grand Trunk Ry. in construction work in minor capacity and advancing until placed in charge of the work; in 1863 became contractor at Minneapolis, Minn., for construction of Minneapolis & Cedar Valley R. R. (now part of Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul System); then crossed plains and prospected until 1865, when returned to New York state; bridge contractor in Leavenworth Co., Kan., 1866, contractor for construction Central Branch of Union Pacific R. R., 1867. Built extension of Missouri Valley Ry. to Iowa state line in 1868 and part of road from Leavenworth to Cameron, Mo., now owned by the Rock Island System. In 1869 commenced construction of the Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry. from Emporia, Kan., through to Texas, and the Missouri division through to Moberly, completing the work in 1874. In 1875 became interested in street railways in St Louis. In 1883 was appointed general manager of Western division of Mexican Central, City of Mexico, resigning in 18S5 to return to St Louis. President of the Wiggins Ferry Co., 18$f>-1902; president of the St Louis, Kansas City & Colorado R. R. Co., 1899-1902; president of the St Louis & North Arkansas R. R. Co. in 1899; president of the Arkansas & Choctaw Ry. Co. in 1901-02; chairman of board Scullin-Gallagher Iron and Steel Co.; director St Louis Union Trust Co., St Louis Transfer Co., St Louis & North Arkansas R. K. Co., Denison Light and Power Co. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, Bellerive Country, Racquet, Log Cabin. Recreations: golf ami walking. Office: 818 Security Bldg. Residence: 5218 s. Broadway.

SEAMAN, Julius C., merchant tailor; horn. Cleveland, O., Oct. 17, 1848; son of Simon anil Sophia (Lessing) Seaman; educated in public schools; married, Cleveland, Aug. 16, 1874, Barbara Wyman; children: Sylvia 8. (Mrs. E. J. Marx), Harry Alfred, Walter C. Began business career as salesman for Rosenfeld Bros., 1862-74; salesman for Constam Bros.. 1874- 77; since in business for self: now treasurer Kissack & Seaman Tailoring Co. Republican. Jewish religion. Favorite recreation: baseball. Office: 804^» Pine St. Residence: 5201 Westminster PI.

SEARS, Edmund Hamilton, principal of Mary Institute; born Wayland, Mass., Apr. 20, 1852; son of Rev. Edmund Hamilton (D.D.) and Ellen (Bacon) Sears: graduated from Boston Latin School, 1870; A.B., Harvard College, 1874; A.M., Washington University, 1897; married, June 19, 1895, Helen Clark Swazey. Taught at Hampton Normal and Agricultural School, 1874-75; instructor in Latin and Greek, University of California, 1875- 83; conducted private school for girls, 1885-91; principal of Mary Institute, St Louis, since September, 1891. Member Civic League. Swedenborgian. Clubs: Harvard of St Louis, Round Table, Contemporary (St Louis), Authors' (London, Eng.). Author: Political Growth of the Nineteenth Century, 1900. Recreations: tennis and walking. Office: The Mary Institute. Residence: 4 X. King's Highway.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Thayer Law Club","Phi Delta Phi","Phi Gamma Delta"]
fullentry: SEARS, John Harold, lawyer; born. Knoxville, Ia., May 9, 1881; son of William H. H. and Kate (Milner) Sears; educated, Chicago public schools; Elk Rapids (Mich.) High School; St Louis Central High School, graduating, January, 1901; LL.B., Yale University, 1904; married, St Louis, Feb. 29, 1908. Katherine Conroy (died May, 1908). Admitted to Missouri bar, 1904, and since engaged in general practice in St Louis; counsel for Corporation Trust Co. of New York in state of Missouri; director L. C. Smith & Bros. Typewriter Co. of Missouri, Royal Typewriter Co. of Missouri, Atlas Amusement Co., Bender Fish and Oyster Co. (secretary); statutory agent in Missouri of American Bridge Co. of New York and of New Jersey, American Steel and Wire Co., Sinclair & Valentine, New York, etc. Swedenborgian. Member St Louis Bar Association, Thayer Law Club, Phi Delta Phi, Phi Gamma Delta. Club: City. Recreations: reading, theatre. Office: 922-923 New Bank of Commerce Bldg. Residence: 3723 Windsor PI.

memberships: ["of St Louis Bar Association","Missouri State Bar Association"]
fullentry: SEDDON, James Alexander, lawyer; born Richmond, Va., Mar. 9, 1850; son of James A. and Sarah (Bruce) Seddon; educated in country school near Sabot Hill, Goochland Co., Va., Dinwiddie School, Albemarle Co., Va., and University of Virginia, graduating, M.A., 1870; professor of modern languages, 1870-71, in Norwood College, Nelson Co., Va.; returned to University of Virginia, 1871, and graduated from Law Department, B.L., 1872; married, St Louis, Dec. 4, 1889, Louisa Q. Scott; children: Bruce, Scott; married, 2d, Montrose, St Louis Co., Mo., Nov. 15 ,1899, Anne Carter Wickham; children: James A., Jr., and John W. Admitted to bar at St Louis, February, 1873, and engaged in practice of law. Democrat; served as judge advocate, with rank of major, on staff of Governor Marma-duke; was judge of Circuit Court of City of St Louis, March, 1887, to Jan. 1, 1889; member of City Council, Jan. 1, 1885, to Mar. 1, 1887. President McPheeters Warehouse Co. Member of St Louis Bar Association, Missouri State Bar Association. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, University, Noonday, St Louis Country. Recreations: hunting, dogs and farming. Office: 705 Olive St. Residence: 5341 Waterman Ave.

residence: 4468 Forest Park Boul.; also Troy, Ill.
memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange","Chicago Board of Trade","St Louis Grain Club"]
fullentry: SEELE, Frederick William, grain commission; born St Louis, Oct. 20, 1872; son of Frederick W. and Emma M. (Hohenschild) Seele; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, Troy, Ill., November, 1901, Sarah R. Jarvis. Began business career as an employe of Annan, Berg & Co., grain and flour commission merchants, continuing 1890-98; became office manager P. P. Williams Grain Co., 1898, and was secretary of the company, 190106; then organized Seele Bros. Grain Co., of which is senior partner. President Seele Elevator Co.; director Troy Exchange Bank, Troy, Ill. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange, Chicago Board of Trade, St Louis Grain Club. Presbyterian. Recreations: reading, boating, motoring, fishing and hunting. Office: Chamber of Commerce. Residence: 4468 Forest Park Boul.; also Troy, Ill.

SEELIG, M. G., surgeon; born Helena, Ark,. Feb. 19, 1874; son of Simon and Vera (Cohen) Seelig, graduated St Louis High School, 1892; A.B., Harvard University, 1896; M.D., Medical Department, Columbia University, 1900; married, Cleveland, O., January, 1906, Clover Althea Hartz; three children: Clover, Frank, Vera. Practiced in New York, 1900-03; professor surgery St Louis University since 1910; surgeon to City Hospital; associate surgeon Jewish Hospital. Lieutenant Medical Reserve Corps, U. S. Army. Office: Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 5059A Waterman Ave.

company: Entered railway service as clerk in the auditor's office of the Wisconsin Central R. R.
birthstate: 1868. Entered railway service as clerk in the auditor's office of the Wisconsin Central R. R.
fullentry: SEELIG, William L.; born Aug. 15, 1868. Entered railway service as clerk in the auditor's office of the Wisconsin Central R. R., 1886; successively assistant bookkeeper, 188889, general bookkeeper, 1889-90, and chief clerk, 1890 to Apr. 1, 1891, same road; chief clerk auditor's office Jacksonville Southeastern Line, Apr. 1, 1891, to Oct. 1, 1892; general bookkeeper, Oct. 1, 1892, to Nov. 1, 1893, chief clerk, Nov. 1, 1893, to Mar. 1, 1898, auditor receipts and disbursements, Mar. 1, 1898, to Aug. 1, 1900, assistant general auditor, Aug. 1, 1900, to Nov. 10, 1903, and auditor to July 1, 1912 (resigned), Missouri, Kansas & Texas Ry. Mason (32°), Shriner. Office: 105 N. 7th St. Residence: 5737 Bartmer Ave.

SEEVER, William John, archaeologist; born St Louis, July 20, 1861; son of William and Christiana (Erler) Seever; common school education; by profession illustrator and engraver, but best known by his archseological researches. Conducted archseological explorations in Missouri, Illinois and Arkansas, 188092; collected and exhibited, for the state, the Missouri archaeological exhibit at Chicago Exposition, 1893; recorder and curator Missouri Historical Society, 1893-1900; now engaged in archaeological research in Mississippi Valley, especially the central portion; has large collections. Address: 2929 Abner PI.

SEGUENOT, Louis, consular agent for France and consul for Belgium; born Autun, France, Aug. 25, 1833; son of Claude and Jeanne (Paquelin) Seguenot; educated in France, graduating from College of Autun, with degree of Bachelor of Letters, Aug. 20, 1851; married, France, Dec. 31, 1856, Jennie Regnier (died 1895); two children: Louise Clementine (widow of Robert E. Fisher), Isabelle Clementine (wife of William H. Grimes). Came to America April, 1865; professor of French language, 1866-88. Consular agent for France since September, 1888, and consul for Belgium since 1899. Democrat. Catholic. Officer de 1'Instruction Publique (France). Recreation: reading. Office: DeMenil Bldg., 119 N. 7th St. Residence: 4346 Maryland Ave.

company: Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain Ry. companies
fullentry: SEIBERT, James Monroe, real estate and tax agent Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain Ry. companies; born Perry Co., Mo., Feb. 3, 1847; son of Daniel and Sarah Milissa (McCombs) Seibert; educated in common schools of native county and later at McKendree College, Lebanon, Ill.; married, Perry Co., Dec. 27, 1866, Emma Abigail Wilson; four children: Alpha M. (Mrs. Daniel J. Hancock, Jr.), Daniel F. (deceased), Robert M. (deceased), Alma L. Served as sheriff and collector of Cape Girardeau Co., Mo., four years and as collector for six years; elected state treasurer for term of four years, 1884; elected state auditor, 1888, and reelected, 1892 and 1896; excise commissioner St Louis, four years, 1901-05, during Governor Dockery's administration. Has been connected with the Missouri Pacific Ry. Co. since 1906; in law department, 1906-10; general agent of the passenger department, 1910-Sept. 1, 1911; with tax department, Sept. 1, 1911-January, 1912, when the real estate and tax departments were consolidated and he was appointed real estate and tax agent Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain lines. Democrat. Presbyterian. Mason, Knight Templar; member United Woodmen, B. P. O. Elks. Recreations: reading, also hunting and fishing. Office: 411 Title Guaranty Bldg. Residence: 5163 Vernon Ave.

SEIDEL, Emil Ferdinand, retired; born Schlettau, Saxony, Aug. 6, 1840; son of Francis and Caroline (Guenther) Seidel; educated in schools in Germany; came to United States, Apr. 22, 1857; married, St Louis, Sept. 26, 1894, Helene S. Schwarze; children: Frank H. , Robert H. Worked as cabinet maker in various shops and established in business of manufacturing fine woodwork, May 23, 1870, under the firm name of Seidel & Schoenle; bought out partner'8 interest, Dec. 24, 1885; continued business under his own name until July 28, 1902, when became incorporated under the name of E. F. Seidel Manufacturing Co., of which he was president; retired, Aug. I, 1911. Lutheran. Mason. Member Liederkranz. Recreation: art collecting. Residence: 2922 Henrietta Ave.

memberships: ["Civic League","St Louis Gymnastic Society (ex-president)","St Louis Aitenheim"]
fullentry: SEIDEL, Julius, lumberman; born St Louis, Dec. 31, 1866; son of Ernst Louis and Emilie (Ackermann) Seidel; educated in St Louis public schools, Franklin High School and Bryant & Stratton Business College; married, St Louis, Apr. 20, 1904, Eugenia Anthony; two children: Julius Anthony, Alice Eugenia. Began business career, Feb. 1, 1882, in South Side yard of Eau Claire Lumber Co., and after thorough training in inspection, measuring, etc., entered shipping department, of which was given charge, 1886; in 1889 was made salesman, style of company having changed to Eau Claire-St Louis Lumber Co.; was made director, 1896, and in 1897 elected secretary, with full charge of sales department; resigned, Jan. 1. 1903, to enter business for self, organizing Julius Seidel Lumber Co., of which is president, operating wholesale and retail lumber yard. Also secretary Accomac Realty Co. President Lumber Dealers' Association; director Southwestern Lumbermen's Association, Citizens' Industrial Association. Member Civic League, St Louis Gymnastic Society (ex-president), St Louis Aitenheim. Republican. Protestant. Mason (32°), Knight Templar (Ascalon Commandery), Shriner. Clubs: Mercantile, Rotary, Lumbermen's (president, 1909), Masonic, Liederkranz, Century Boat. Favorite recreations: gymnastics, music, literature. Office: 2000 S. King's Highway. Residence: 6040 W. Cabanne Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Homoeopathic Medical Society","Missouri Institute of Homoeopathy","Medical Research Society","American Homoeopathic O"]
fullentry: SEIDLITZ, George Neuman, oculist and aurist; born near Port Gibson, Miss., Apr. 25, 1861; son of George Neuman and Sarah (Measey) Seidlitz; educated in public schools, Keokuk, Ia., Denmark Academy, Denmark, Ia.; Ph.B., State University of Iowa, 1882, A.M., 1885; M.D., Hahnemann Medical College, Chicago, 1884; married, Iowa City, la., May 23, 1888, Florence M. Hess; one daughter, Margaret C. Engaged in practice since 1884; since 1894 specialist in diseases of eve and ear. Member St Louis Homoeopathic Medical Society, Missouri Institute of Homoeopathy, Medical Research Society, American Homoeopathic O. O. & L. Society. Democrat. Episcopalian. Odd Fellow. Office: 1023 N. Grand Ave. Residence: 5939 Clemens Ave.

SELDEN, O. Guy, president Selden-Breck Construction Co.; born in Paulding Co., O., Feb. 24, 1870; son of A. H. and Caroline (Myers) Selden; educated in public schools of Lexington, Ill., and commercial college at Quincy, Ill.; married, St Louis, 1895, Eleonore Cowan; children: Wentworth, Edward, Marie Quinette. Resident of St Louis since 1889; since 1891 in building and contracting business, manager for James Stewart Co., contractors, and later Southwestern manager for George A. Fuller Co., of Chicago and Xew York; since 1904 president of Selden-Breck Construction Co. Associate member Engineersr Club of St Louis. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Bellerive Country, Century Boat. Recreations: golf and motoring. Office: 1108 Fullerton Bldg. Residence: 5139 Westminster PL

SELIGMAN, Harry; born at Connersville, Ind., Dec. 12, 1868; son of William H. and Lizzie (Wallenstein) Seligman; educated in public schools and graduated from Cincinnati High School, then attended business college; unmarried. Resident of Cincinnati, 1869-99; was traveling salesman, and later partner in wholesale clothing house at Cincinnati; sold out interest, 1892, to embark in present business of H. Seligman & Co., manufacturers and wholesale dealers in ladies' neckwear; removed business from Cincinnati to St Louis, 1899. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country. Favorite recreations: hunting, fishing and golf. Office: 1401-1403 Washington Ave. Residence: Washington Hotel.

SELKIRK, Benjamin Johnstone, auctioneer; born St Louis, Mar. 10, 1863; son of Alexander and Louisa Selkirk; educated at O'Fal- Ion, Webster, Chouteau and Clinton public schools; married, St Louis, Jan. 19, 1892, Mary E. McLaughlin; children: Katheryn, Alexander A., Mary Virginia, Benjamin J., Jr. Began business career as messenger boy with Western Union Telegraph Co., 1878; went into cigar business, 1879, then with W. H. Haggerty in auction jobbing business, and at times for self until 1885; auction pool seller, 1885-89; since 1889 partner in firm of A. A. Selkirk & Co., general auctioneers and storage warehousemen. Partner in Selkirk & Eisner, voting booths; general manager Home Comfort Gas Machine Co. Democrat. Catholic. Member Royal Arcanum and Royal League. Office: 1808 Chouteau Ave. Residence: 5105 Fairmount Ave.

SELLER, J. William, candy manufacturer; born Versailles, Ky., Dec. 10, 1870; son of Thomas and Louella (Story) Seller; educated, Vanderbilt University, 1888-92; married, Versailles, Ky., 1897, Vanda Nelson. Began active career with J. William Seller & Co., dealers in shoes, Versailles, 1894, continuing six years; secretary Van B. Nelson Clothing Co., Louisville, Ky., 1900-04; removed to St Louis and has been secretary and treasurer Modern Candy Manufacturing Co. since 1905; also director Tower Grove Bank. Is the owner of all concessions American and National League Baseball clubs at St Louis. Democrat. Baptist. Member Knights of Pythias, St Louis Turn Verein. Recreations: bowling and fishing. Office: 202 S. Main St. Residence: 3615 Shenandoah Ave.

SELLMEYER, Henry John, produce commission merchant; born Oldenburg, Ind., Dec. 4, 1867; son . of John and Mary (Enneking) Sellmeyer; educated in common school and at St. Xavier's College, Cincinnati, O.; married, St Louis, June 2, 1897, Olivia Tietzel; one son, Edwin Henry. Was employed in a general store in Indiana before coming to St Louis in 1885, to take position with Hackman & Gaupel; in 1892 formed partnership with Louis A. Jasper under firm name of Jasper & Sellmeyer, produce commission merchants. Catholic. Member Knights of Columbus. Member Fruit and Produce Exchange, National League of Commission Merchants of the United States. Office: 835 N. 3d St. Residence: 3717 Pennsylvania Ave.

SELLNER, Albert Christian; born Stuttgart, Germany, Mar. 20, 1840; educated in gymnasium in Germany; married, St Louis, 1863, Annie Steinwender; children: Herbert S., William A., Amanda (Mrs. Edward Beek-man), Julia (Mrs. William A. Gardner), Came to United States from Germany in 1859, and was engaged in leather business at Fort Wayne, Ind., and Quincy, Ill., until 1870; removed to St Louis and with Gustav A. Steinwender engaged in wholesale wire and liquor business as Steinwender & Scllner; continued until 1905, when incorporated business as Steinwender & Sellner Mercantile Co., of which was treasurer and manager; later engaged in selling gas and electric lighting fixtures. Member Merchants' Exchange, B. P. O. Elks. Club: St Louis. Office: 412 N. 8th St. Residence: 4540 Duncan Ave.

memberships: ["Washington Artillery","Xew Orleans","1878-84; member Missouri legislature","190305; member Joint Free Bridge Commission","1905-08; member Citizens' Municipal Bridge Commission and chairman campaign committee same; member City Plan Commission","Civic League","Million Population Club","etc"]
fullentry: SELPH, Colin McRae, lawyer; born Richmond, Va., July 16, 1864; son of Colin McRae (officer in Confederate Army) and Elizabeth (Dimitry) Selph; lineal descendant of Gen. John Smith, of Virginia, Robert Mills, designer of Washington monument, and Alexander Dimitry, founder of the public school system of Louisiana; educated, St. Simeon's School, Lushers' Academy and Tulane University, all of New Orleans; married Nancy Helen Witbeck, of St Louis Co., June, 1900; one son, Colin McRae, 3d. Came to St Louis, 1886, and was employed by Philip Roeder, and established circulating library and first general news stand for national dailies, etc.; with Post-Dispatch, 1889-99; manager Kansas City Times, 1899-1900; published World's Fair Bulletin, official journal of Louisiana Purchase Exposition, 1900-04, and awarded diploma and medal for same. Began practice of law, 1905; secretary and counsel Anthracite Coalette Fuel Co. Notable achievement was settlement of Olive Street Bank failure (as chairman association of depositors), whereby 3,880 depositors received 100 ceuts on the dollar. Member Washington Artillery, Xew Orleans, 1878-84; member Missouri legislature, 190305; member Joint Free Bridge Commission, 1905-08; member Citizens' Municipal Bridge Commission and chairman campaign committee same; member City Plan Commission, Civic League, Million Population Club, etc. Delegate Democratic State Convention, 1904, 1900, 1908, Democratic National Convention, 1908; president St Louis Democratic Club, 1906-10; nominee Democratic party for Congress, Twelfth District, 1906 and 1908, receiving largest vote cast for any Democrat in ten years. Catholic. Member Missouri Bar Association, B. P. O. Elks, Knights of Pythias, Caledonian Society. Recreations: music and outdoor sports. Office: 411 Olive St. Residence: 4250 Lindell Boul.

SEMMELMEYER, John Albert, manager Graton & Knight Manufacturing Co.; born Chicago, June 30, 1878; son of John and Sarah D. (Johnson) Semmelmeyer; graduated from public school, Chicago, Ill., 1892; graduated from Y. M. C. A. Commercial College, May, 1897; married, Kenosha, Wis., Feb. 12, 1898, Ella Louise Taylor; children: Hennie Hatten, John Albert, Jr. Employed by Charles Munson Belting Co., Chicago, Ill., as clerk in office, July, 1897, to February, 1899; cashier in Chicago office of New York Leather Belting Co., February, 1899, to Sept. 27, 1902; since then St Louis manager Graton & Knight Manufacturing Co., leather belting. Republican. Episcopalian. Mason, Knight Templar; member Royal Arcanum. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Masonic. Recreations: reading, billiards and pool. Office: 619 N. 8th St. Residence: 5949 Maple Ave.

residence: Clayton, R. F. D. Xo. 1, St Louis Co.
fullentry: SEMPLE, Frederick Humphrey, stock and bond broker; born St Louis, Dec. 24, 1872; son of Edward H. and Mary (Hart) Semple; educated in St Louis public schools, St Louis Manual Training School and Rugby Academy; married at St Louis, 1905, Isabel J. F. Belcher; one daughter, Anne Thruston Farrar. In the stock and bond business since 1896; since Jan. 1, 1910, member of firm of Fisher, Semple & Co. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Racquet, St Louis Country, Automobile, Aero. Recreations: motoring, golf and farming. Office: Rialto Bldg. Residence: Clayton, R. F. D. Xo. 1, St Louis Co.

SEMPLE, Nathaniel Meacon, physician; born Liberty, Clay Co., Mo., Oct. 22, 1876; son of Robert Baylor and Lucy Anne (Shelton) Semple; A.M., William Jewell College, Liberty, Mo., 1894; M.D., Medical Department, Washington University, 1897; postgraduate work, University of Kiel, Germany, 1900-01; University of Paris, France, 1902; married, St Louis, Nov. 6, 1909, Margery Ferriss; one son, Robert Baylor. Began practice in St Louis, 1897; specializes in treatment of the eye. Member Medical Reserve Corps, U. S. A., American Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society, American Ophthalmological Society, St Louis Ophthalmological Society, Washington University Medical Department, Phi Gamma Delta, Nu Sigma Nu. Democrat. Baptist. Clubs: University, Bellerive Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 505 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: Normandy, Mo.

SENSENBRENNER, John F., president C. E. Hilts Shoe Co.; born Buffalo, N. Y., Apr. 7, 1864; son of Philip and Eva (Geller) Sen-senbrenner; educated at St. Joseph College, Buffalo, N. Y.; married, St Louis, 1884, Lillie Burman; children: Joseph, Rose (Mrs. Arthur Von Reppert), Viola (deceased), Edna. Began business career as shoe salesman at Indianapolis, 1881, and in 1884 came to St Louis; became salesman in 1885 with the C. E. Hilts Shoe Co., and upon incorporation of the business in 1S94 was made manager and secretary; in January, 1910, was elected president. Member Business Men's League, Civic League. Member Royal Arcanum. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Liederkranz. Office: corner 6th and St. Charles Sts. Residence: 3638 Cleveland Ave.

SENSENEY, Edgar Moore, physician; born AVinchester, Va., Dec. 29, 1855; son of Edgar Jacob and Margaret Haney (Moore) Sen-seney; educated at Central College, Fayette, Mo.; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1887; post-gTaduate studies at University of Vienna, Austria; married, St Louis, June, 1890, Mary Thurston Messick; children: Eugene Towner, Barbara Thurston, Margaret Moore, Harriet Gaulbert. Engaged in practice of medicine in St Louis since 1887; appointed lecturer in physiology, 1888, professor of therapeutics, 1890, St Louis Medical College. Member Missouri Stat,e Medical Association, St. Lonis Medical Society, St Louis Academy of Science. Democrat. Methodist. Clubs: Illini Yacht, Automobile Club of St Louis. Recreation: hunting big game in Rocky Mountains. Office: Lister Bldg., 4500 Olive St. Residence: 5738 Clemens Ave.

office: N. W. cor. 3d and Walnut Sts.
fullentry: SENTER, Charles Parsons, president Senter Commission Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 14, 1870; son of William M. and Lucy Jane (Wilkins) Senter; educated at Stoddard (public) School, and Smith Academy, St Louis, class of 1888, and University of Virginia; unmarried. Engaged in banking and real estate business, 1890-93; since connected with the house established by father, 1864, as Senter & Co., cotton factors and commission merchants in grain, furs, wool, hides, etc.; in 1900 the business was incorporated as the Senter Commission Co., of which he is president. Expresident St Louis Cotton Exchange; member Merchants' Exchange, Business Men's League. Ex-president Tennessee Society; extreasurer Democratic State Executive Committee, Young Men's Democratic Club; director St Louis Provident Association. Baptist; president Baptist City Mission Board. Clnbs: St Louis, Glen Echo Country, Automobile, Aero (vice president), Franklin. Office: N. W. cor. 3d and Walnut Sts. Residence: No. 1 Beverly PI.

SESSINGHAUS, Oscar F., lawyer; born St Louis, May 12, 1871; son of Gustavus and Helena B. (Diestriehs) Sessinghaus; educated Webster School (grammar); Smith Academy; University of Michigan, graduating, degree of LL.B., 1893, LL.M., 1894; married, St. Lonis, Apr. 13, 1903, Agnes B. Graff. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1894, and since in practice at St Louis; vice president St Louis and Colorado Development Co. Member Thirty-ninth General Assembly, Missouri; assistant H. 8. district attorney, 1898-99. Republican. Member B. P. O. Elks. Club: St Louis Railway. Office: Central National Bank Bldg. Residence: 4336 Olive St.

SETTLE, John G., general contractor and engineer; born Monroe City, Mo., Oct. 3, 1865; son of John B. and Mildred A. (Banis- 54o ter) Settle; educated in public and high schools of Monroe City, Mo.; private instruction in architecture and in mechanical and civil engineering at Pueblo, Colo.; married, Versailles, Mo., Dec. 24, 1902, Agnes Price; one daughter, Nadine. During his residence in Pueblo, 1886-93, was engaged in architecture, civil and mechanical engineering and general contracting, being connected as partner with firms of Sanders & Settle and W. S. Williams & Co.; built large smelting plants and other buildings at Pueblo and in other Colorado towns. Came to St Louis in 1898 and joined in organizing and incorporating a construction company of which was secretary and engineer in charge of construction, and built the Varied Industries Building at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition. At close of fair withdrew from firm and in March, 1904, effected organization for the general contracting business which he is now conducting under the firm name of J. C. Settle & Co., composed of himself and S. R. Price. Has erected nearly 300 buildings for one corporation in St Louis; has built several U. S. Government post-office buildings and custom houses and army posts in Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas; has erected in St Louis and other cities and towns some of the finest church buildings; rebuilt Union M. E. Church at Garrison Ave. and Locust St., etc. Was one of the organizers and for years a director Missouri State Life Insurance Co. In December, 1905, was one of the organizers and incorporators of the Jefferson-Gravois Trust Co. of St Louis. Democrat. Methodist. Mason, Odd Fellow. Club: Masonic. Favorite recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 810 Olive St. Residence: 3909 Cleveland Ave.

SEUEL, Edmund, publisher; born Vincennes, Tnd., Apr. 21, 1865; son of Rev. Peter and Emilie (Konrad) Seuel; educated in Concordia College, Fort Wayne, Ind., to 1883; then continued studies to Concordia Seminary, St Louis, until 1886; married, Indianapolis, Dec. 27. 1888, Emma Ostermeyer; three children: Waldo, Hulda, Ralph. Became president and professor Walther College, St Louis, 1888, and continued until 1907; since engaged in publishing business as general manager Concordia Publishing House. Republican. Lutheran. Club: Ben Franklin. Recreation: music. Office: 3558 S. Jefferson Ave. Residence: 1730 Missouri Ave.

SEVERSON, Cooper Stuart, printing and stationery; born Memphis, Tenn., Mar. 21, 1872; son of Charles S. and Georgia (Cooper) Severson; educated in public schools of Memphis; married Jennie Messiek, of Louisville, Ky., November, 1898; two daughters: Eliza Thruston, Martha Morris. Came to St Louis, 1882; entered employ of the Pacific Express Co. at fourteen and remained eight years, serving in various capacities; with the Spalding Stationery Co. three years, until 1897, since which time has been engaged in the printing and stationery business for himself. Member Business Men's League. Democrat.^Member M. E. Church, South; treasurer Cabanne Church. Mason (Lodge and Chapter); Past Master and now Treasurer Rosehill Lodge; member Royal Arcanum, Modern Woodmen, Knights of Pythias, Maccabees. Clubs: Automobile, St Louis Stationers' (treasurer). Recreation: motoring. Store: 111-113 N. 8th St. Residence: 5561 Von Versen Ave.

office: New Bank of Commerce Bldg., 415 Pine St.
memberships: ["National Confectioners' Association of the United States (secretary","1891-1909","president","1909-11)","Civic League","American Automobile Association; member and director Citizens' Industrial Association"]
fullentry: SEWARD, Francis Dwight, treasurer National Candy Co.; born Rosamond, Ill., Nov. 17, 1859; son of Maurice Dwight and Mary (Marvin) Seward; graduated from Normal High School, Normal, Ill., 1870; attended Illinois Wesleyan University, Bloomington, Ill., 1876-77; married, St Louis, Feb. 5, 1902, Marian Day; one son, Francis Dwight, Jr. Began business career in Bloomington Stove Co. (of which father was one of the incorporators), representing father's estate, Jan. 1, 1879, after his death; came to St Louis, Jan. 1, 1882, as partner in firm of Dodge & Seward, manufacturing confectioners, incorporated as Dodge & Seward Confectionery Co., June 13, 1889 (of which was president), and changed to F. D. Seward Confectionery Co., Mar. 18, 1892, of which remained president until consolidated into the National Candy Co., of which is treasurer, director and member of executive committee. Treasurer and director Clinton Sugar Refining Co., Clinton, la.; director Riverside Land Co., Continental Land Co.; member advisory board Fidelity Deposit Co. of Maryland. Member National Confectioners' Association of the United States (secretary, 1891-1909, president, 1909-11), Civic League, American Automobile Association; member and director Citizens' Industrial Association. Republican. Congregationalist. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, St Louis Country, Contemporary, Automobile. Recreations: automobiling anti fishing. Office: New Bank of Commerce Bldg., 415 Pine St. Residence: 4615 Berlin Ave.

office: admitted brother, Stephen, to partnership in 1896, and firm became H. D. Sexton & Bro., which later changed to Sexton & Co.; president Southern Illinois National Bank, of East St Louis, since 1898; also president Southern Illinois Trust Co. Vice president East St Louis Light and Power Co.; director East St Louis & Carondelet Ry., East St Louis Connecting R. R., Terminal R. R. of East St Louis, Illinois Transfer R. R. Co. Republican. Member Business Men's League, St Louis. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday (St Louis), St. Clair County (East St Louis). Recreation: traveling. Office: Southern Illinois National Bank, East St Louis.
fullentry: SEXTON, Henry D., banker; born East St Louis, Ill., Nov. 18, 1854; son of Daniel and Mary (Brundy) Sexton; educated in public schools of St Louis and East St Louis; married, East St Louis, Ill., 1879, Jennie F. Hake. Began business career in 1869 in the law and real estate office of late ex-Mayor John B. Bowman, of East St Louis, continuing with him until 1879, when opened real estate and insurance office; admitted brother, Stephen, to partnership in 1896, and firm became H. D. Sexton & Bro., which later changed to Sexton & Co.; president Southern Illinois National Bank, of East St Louis, since 1898; also president Southern Illinois Trust Co. Vice president East St Louis Light and Power Co.; director East St Louis & Carondelet Ry., East St Louis Connecting R. R., Terminal R. R. of East St Louis, Illinois Transfer R. R. Co. Republican. Member Business Men's League, St Louis. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday (St Louis), St. Clair County (East St Louis). Recreation: traveling. Office: Southern Illinois National Bank, East St Louis. Residence: 417 N. 8th St., East St Louis.

residence: Kirkwood, Mo. SH_ALLER, Harry John, president St Louis House and Window Cleaning Co.; born New York, Oct. 15, 1866; son of George and Martha Shaller; educated in public schools of Philadelphia; married, Feb. 22, 1890, Marie Ruth Yore. Was engaged in brokerage business in Philadelphia, and was also, for three years, superintendent of the Lockwood Manufacturing Co., Philadelphia, manufacturers of folding boxes and envelopes; came to St Louis from Philadelphia, and in 1889, with associates, organized St Louis House and Window Cleaning Co., of which is president. Member Knights of Pythias. Club: Century Boat. Office: 915 Pine St. Residence: 320 Skinker Rd.
fullentry: SHALLCR088, Wyatt, president Shallcross Printing and Stationery Co.; born Louisville, Ky., Mar. 5, 1866; son of John W. and Caroline V. (Hyman) Shallcross; educated in public schools of Louisville, Ky.; married, St Louis, Oct. 28, 1896, Lavina H. Butler; children: Eleanor Curtis, Nan Butler, Lawrence Butler, Wyatt, Jr. Began business career in office of Louisville Lithographing Co., continuing one and one-half years; came to St Louis, 1885, and was in employ of Levison & Blythe Stationery Co. for three years; then eight years with the Buxton & Skinner Stationery Co. as office man and later secretary, until 1895, when organized Shallcross Printing and Stationery Co., of which has since been president. Episcopalian. Member A. F. & A. M., Missouri Chapter, R. A. M., Ascalon Commandery No. 16, Knights Templar, Knights of Honor. Club: Mercantile. Office: 419 N. 4th St. Residence: Kirkwood, Mo. SH_ALLER, Harry John, president St Louis House and Window Cleaning Co.; born New York, Oct. 15, 1866; son of George and Martha Shaller; educated in public schools of Philadelphia; married, Feb. 22, 1890, Marie Ruth Yore. Was engaged in brokerage business in Philadelphia, and was also, for three years, superintendent of the Lockwood Manufacturing Co., Philadelphia, manufacturers of folding boxes and envelopes; came to St Louis from Philadelphia, and in 1889, with associates, organized St Louis House and Window Cleaning Co., of which is president. Member Knights of Pythias. Club: Century Boat. Office: 915 Pine St. Residence: 320 Skinker Rd.

SHANER, James C., lawyer; born St. Francis Co., Mo., Mar. 3, 1862; son of Jackson and Loretta (Fields) Shaner; B.S., Normal School, Cape Girardeau, Mo., 1893; LL.B., Law Department, University of Missouri, 1896; married, Crawford Co., Mo., May 3, 1905, Mary Woods. Taught school at various times while securing education; in general practice at St Louis, 1896-1910; assistant circuit attorney since Nov. 1, 1910. Member St Louis Bar Association. First vice president West End Business Men's Association. Odd Fellow. Protestant. Recreations: hunting and ffshing. Office: Circuit Attorney's Office. Residence: 1422 McCausland Ave.

residence: St Louis Club, St Louis, Mo. Address: American Consulate-General, Mexico, D. F., Mexico.
memberships: ["American Society International Law","Missouri Bar Association","National Geographic Society; honorary member Army and Navy Union of America","Mexican Geographical and Statistical Society","Mexican Astronomical Society"]
fullentry: SHANKLIN, Arnold, consul general; born Carrollton, Mo., Jan. 29, 1866; son of Wesley Dunscombe and Locke (Arnold) S.; brother of William Arnold Shanklin, president of Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn.; educated public schools^ LL.B., Washington University, 1889; LL.D., Upper Iowa University, 1908; unmarried. Admitted to bar, 1889; more than ten years of active practice; attorney and counsellor of Supreme Court of United States; commissioner of St Louis Exposition to Mexico, 1903-04; member International Jury of Awards, St Louis Exposition, 1904; American Consul General at Panama, 1905-09, during the last two years of which he served as dean of the consular corps there; American consul general at Mexico City, since Feb. 19, 1909. Republican. Delivered Independence Day oration, July 4, 1909, at Mexico City, and though the United States has had diplomatic relations with Mexico since 1823, he is the first orator on such occasion to deliver a part of his oration in Spanish. Delegate to and addressed the Trans-Mississippi Commercial Congress at San Antonio, 1910; designated by Secretary of State Knox as official representative of the State Department to attend and address the Trans-Mississippi Commercial Congress at Kansas City, 1911. Member American Society International Law, Missouri Bar Association, National Geographic Society; honorary member Army and Navy Union of America, Mexican Geographical and Statistical Society, Mexican Astronomical Society. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Clubs: St Louis, University, Missouri Athletic (St Louis), University, Commercial (Panama), American, University, Country (Mexico City). Home Address: St Louis Club, St Louis, Mo. Address: American Consulate-General, Mexico, D. F., Mexico.

company: Shantz Real Estate and Investment Co.
fullentry: SHANTZ, Israel W., president Shantz Real Estate and Investment Co.; born Wellsville, Montgomery Co., Mo., July 8, 1865; son of Benjamin and Margarette (Swinton) Shantz; educated in Dallas Co. public schools; married, Dallas Co., Sept. 29, 1889, Mary I. Miller; eight children: Izora, Benjamin L., Swinton E., Abraham, Thelma, Miller, Mary E., Israel W., Jr. Traveling salesman, 1884-91; clerk Circuit Court, Dallas Co., 1S91-99; with Bank of Buffalo (Mo.) as cashier, 1898-1900; since engaged in real estate business, St Louis; president Shantz Real Estate and Investment Co. since 1906. Member Real Estate Exchange. Republican. Mason, Knight Templar; member Knights of Pythias, B. P. O. Elks. Club: Masonic. Recreations: fishing and outdoor life. Office: 103 N. 9th St. Residence: 3736 W. Pine Boul.

memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange","New Hampshire Society of the Cincinnati","Missouri Society Sons of Revolution","Society of Colonial Wars","Missouri Historical Society"]
fullentry: SHAPLEIGH, Alfred Lee, hardware merchant; born St Louis, Feb. 16, 1862; son of Augustus Frederick and Elizabeth Anne (Um-stead) Shapleigh; educated in academic department, and special course of two years in undergraduate department, Washington University, leaving in 1880; married, Cincinnati, Xov*. 21, 1888, Mina Wessel; children: Alexander Wessel, Jane. Began business career as clerk in the Merchants' National Bank, October, 1880; clerk Thomson & Taylor, wholesale coffee and spices, January, 1882; cashier Mound City Paint and Color Co., November, 1882; in July, 1885, became secretary of A. F. Shapleigh Hardware Co. (originally founded 1843, as Shapleigh, Day & Co.), and in July, 1901, when present corporation of Norvell-Shapleigh Hardware Co. succeeded, became treasurer of that company; chairman board of directors same since Jan. 1, 1912. Also president Shapleigh Investment Co., Union Lead Co., Washington Land and Mining Co.; vice president Merchants-Laclede National Bank, American Credit Indemnity Co. of New York; director St Louis Cotton Compress Co., United Elevator and Grain Co. Ex-president Mercantile Library Association; treasurer St Louis Light Artillery Armory Association; first vice president Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association; director Washington University; director and member executive committee Louisiana Purchase Exposition Co.; member executive committee Business Men's League, Civic League. Republican; served in National Guard of Missouri as lieutenant and captain about eight years. Presbyterian. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange, New Hampshire Society of the Cincinnati, Missouri Society Sons of Revolution, Society of Colonial Wars, Missouri Historical Society. Clubs: Commercial, St Louis, Noonday, Racquet, St Louis Country, Deer Plain, Harbor Point Country. Recreations: golfing, boating and automobiling. Office: corner 4th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: 3636 Delmar Boul.

SHAPLEIGH, John Blasdel, physician; born St Louis, Oct. 31, 1857; son of Augustus Frederick and Elizabeth Anne (Umstead) Shapleigh; A.B., Washington University, 1878; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1881; special work in ear diseases, Vienna, Austria, 188485; married, St Louis, Oct. 27, 1886, Anna T. Merritt; children: Blasdel, Margaret. Interne St Louis City Hospital, 1881-82; St Louis Female Hospital, 1882-83; since 1885 engaged in practice limited to diseases of the ear. Lecturer on diseases of the ear, St Louis Medical College, 1886-90; clinical professor diseases of the ear, St Louis Medical College (Medical Department, Washington University), 1890-95; since 1895, professor of otology, Medical Department, Washington University, and was dean of faculty of department, 1901-02; member staff of St. Luke's Hospital, St Louis Skin and Cancer Hospital; member Hospital Board since 1910. Member 8t. Louis Medical Society, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni (president, 1896), American Otological Society. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Normandie, St Louis Country, Bellerive. Recreation: golf. Office: Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 4950 Berlin Ave.

SHAPLEIGH, Richard Waldron, hardware merchant; born St Louis, Sept. 28, 1859; son of Augustus Frederick and Elizabeth Anne (Umstead) Shapleigh; educated at Professor Wyman's School and through Academic Department of Washington University; married, Newton, Mass., Sept. 22, 1886, to third cousin, Helen Shapleigh, of Philadelphia; one daughter, Dorothy (Mrs. Leo De Smet Carton). Entered employ of A. F. Shapleigh & Co., hardware jobbers, in 1876; has since served with that firm and its successors, the A. F, Shap-leigh-Cantwell Hardware Co., the A. F. Shapleigh Hardware Co. (of which was vice president), and as first vice president of the Nor-vell Shapleigh Hardware Co., 1901-January, 1911, since president. Director four years and president two years of Western Commercial Travelers' Association. Independent in politics. Was member Municipal Bridge and Terminal Commission, appointed by Mayor Wells. Enlisted in militia during strike of 1877; member Battery A, National Guard of Missouri, about ten years, being first sergeant when resigned. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, Country, Bellerive Country, Normandie Golf. Recreation: golf. Office: Washington Ave. and 4th St. Residence: 4471 W. Pine Boul.

SHARPE, Harry St. John, insurance; born Toronto, Can., June 24, 1870; son of Henry Edward and Eleanor (Urmston) Sharpe; was brought to America at two years of age; educated in public schools of St Louis and New York and under private tutelage; married, St Louis, Nov. 20, 1906, Miss Hannah Hardin, of Bardstown, Ky.; two children: David Hardin, Eleanor Urmston. Read law in office of father and finished course in office of Simon S. Bass, but never applied for admission to bar; admitted to membership in St Louis Typographical Union No. 8, Apr. 27, 1890; served in various offices and as secretary-treasurer for four and one-half years, ending Dec. 31, 1910; in general insurance business and also special agent Prudential Insurance Co. of America, since Jan. 1, 1911. For many years took an active part in cause of organized labor; appointed by Gov. Herbert S. Hadley as delegate representing state of Missouri at Child Labor Conference, Xew Orleans, April, 1909; also appointed by Governor Hadley as member of State Employers' Liability Commission, Xov. 28, 1910, and served during life of the commission; served as second vice president and member board of directors Million Population Club. Served as sergeant in Company K, First Missouri Volunteer Infantry, in Spanish-American War, 1898. Member Walker-.Tennings Camp Xo. 4, Spanish War Veterans. Favorite recreations: boxing and bicycling. Office: 512 Chemical Bldg. Residence: 4307 Maryland Ave.

memberships: ["Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni","St Louis Medical Society","Missouri State Medical Association; trustee St Louis Medical Library"]
fullentry: SHARPE, Norvelle Wallace, surgeon; born Memphis, Tenn., Jan. 21, 1869; son of James Boude and Mary Catherine (Bean) Sharpe; educated St Louis Seminary (St Louis County); St Louis public grammar and high schools; M.D., Beaumont Hospital Medical College (now Medical Department, St Louis University), 1890; New York Polycliuie, 1891. Married, Aug. 19, 1895, Daisy McClain Scott; two sons: Norvelle Wallace II, Donald Scott. Student interne, Missouri Pacific Railway Hospital, 1889; served, 1890-91, as interne St Louis City Hospital; entered private practice, 1891. Assistant in anatomy, Medical Department, St Louis University; surgeon to Home for the Friendless. Member Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni, St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association; trustee St Louis Medical Library. Democrat. Presbyterian. Office and Residence: 3520 Lucas Avenue.

SHATTINGER, Adam, music dealer; born in Bavaria, Germany, Sept. 3, 1844; son of Thomas and Barbara (Will) Shattinger; came to United States when six years of age; educated in public schools of Cincinnati and New Orleans; married, Cincinnati, 1865, Mary Kunkel; children: Charles, Mignon, Oliver. Settled in New Orleans in boyhood; thence went to Cincinnati, and taught music, and in 1869 came to St Louis. Established in piano and music business in 1876, and incorporated the business in 1896 as the Shattinger Piano and Music Co., general music dealers, wholesale and retail, and music publishers, of which he is president. Independent Republican. Protestant. Member Royal Arcanum, Legion of Honor, Royal League, A. O. U. W. Office: 910 Olive St. Residence: 4247 Laclede Ave.

SHATTINGER, Charles, physician; born Cincinnati, July 31, 1865; son of Adam and Mary (Kunkel) Shattinger; educated in public schools of St Louis, 1872-81; M.D., Medical Department, Washington University, 1886; married, St Louis, Sept. 25, 1889, Ada C. Brown. Assistant physician St Louis City Hospital, 1886-87; engaged in private practice since May, 1887; professor physiology, Beaumont Hospital Medical College, 1892-1901; professor physiology, Medical Department, St Louis University, 1901-04; professor physical therapy, American Medical College; member St Louis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni (ex-president). Independent in politics. Recreations: literature and music. Office: 2924 S. Grand Ave. Residence: 3553 Crittenden St.
