SHAUGHNESSY, Martin, capitalist; born in County Galway, Ireland, July 26, 1855; son of Michael and Mary (Mooney) Shaughnessy; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Sept. 9, 1891, Agnes Tivy. Came from Ireland to St Louis in 1866; began business in employ with uncle in American House; then with John C. Foley & Co., wholesale whisky commission merchants, for three years; in 1877 started on own account, succeeding uncle, John Mooney, wholesale and retail liquors, under own name of M. Shaugh-liessv, afterwards incorporated as Shaughnessy Distilling Co., of which is president. President and general manager of Lindell Hotel Co., proprietors of old Lindell Hotel (torn down in 1905), 1898-1910. Democrat. Catholic. Office: Ozark Bldg. Residence: 1 Washington Terrace.

memberships: ["Catholic Seminary Board","Catholic School Board; member Board Priests' Infirm Fund"]
fullentry: SHEA, Edward J., clergyman; born County Limerick, Ireland, Apr. 20, 1844; son of Thomas and Mary (Kennedy) Shea; educated St Louis University, Vincention Seminary, Cape Girardeau, Mo. Ordained priest Roman Catholic Church, bv Archbishop Kenrick, July 4, 1868; pastor Church of the Immaculate Conception since 1879; present church building erected at cost of $205,000 under his administration, and dedicated, May 14, 1908. Member Catholic Seminary Board, Catholic School Board; member Board Priests' Infirm Fund. Residence: 1511 Pennsylvania Ave.

SHELBY, William Harper, shoe manufacturer; born Brandon, Miss., June 29, 1861; son of Winchester Bledsoe and Margaret E. (Alexander) Shelby; educated in public schools to age of thirteen; married, Vicksburg, Miss., Dec. 2, 1885, Mariah Pegram Lindsey; five children: Lindsey, William L., Marion, Jacques P., Warren. Began active career, 1874, and for more than twenty-five years was traveling shoe salesman, being connected with the Hamilton Brown Shoe Co., Claflin, Allen & Co., and Shofer, Swarts & Co.; vice president Friedinan-Shelby Shoe Co., wholesale manufacturers, from 1906 to Jan. 1, 1912; now connected with the Peters branch, International Shoe Co.; also director Kirkwood Bank. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: Mercantile, Algonquin Golf. Recreation: golf. Office: Washington Ave. and 13th St. Residence: Kirkwood, Mo.

SHELDON, Frank E., lumberman; born Billerica, Mass., July 15, 1861; son of Oren and Jane (Wight) Sheldon; educated in public schools, Billerica, and McCoy's (private) School, Lowell, Mass.; married, St Louis, Sept. 29, 1892, Jennie Maude Hammett. Began at St. Paul, Minn., in 1880 and same year with a party locating the Northern Pacific through Yellowstone Valley; in exploration survey for Canadian Pacific Railroad, 1881-82; engineer in charge construction same road until 1S87. Member lumber firm of George E. Snell & Co., St. Paul, Minn., 1887-92; removed to Summer-town, Tenn., 1892, and organized Lawrence County Lumber Co., continuing to 1895; associated with T. H. Garrett Lumber Co., St Louis, since 1895. Director Grant Land & Timber Co., Grant Timber & Manufacturing Co., and Louisiana Railway Co., Selina, La.; also Boatmen's Bank, St Louis. Republican. Member Academy of Science. Clubs: Missouri Athletic, Noonday. Office: Suite 1220, 721 Olive St. Residence: 5315 Delmar Boul.

memberships: ["Society of Sons of the Revolution","Society of Colonial Wars"]
fullentry: SHELTON, Richard T., wholesale hats; born in Pettis County, Missouri, duly 7, 1871; son of Theodore and Jane Redd (Gentry) Shelton; educated in St Louis at Stoddard (public) School and Smith Academy, and at Princeton University, graduating A.B., 1893; married, St Louis, Apr. 26, 1899, Allouise Douglass; children: Caroline, Richard Douglas. Began business career, 1893, in employ of Gauss-Shelton Hat Co., serving as clerk and salesman until 1901; then became connected with the White-Branch-Shelton Hat Co., of which has been secretary since 1904. Member Society of Sons of the Revolution, Society of Colonial Wars. Clubs: Mercantile, University, Racquet, Bellerive Country, Normandie Golf (St Louis), University and Princeton (New York), Cap and Gown (Princeton). Recreations: hunting and golf. Office: 1511 Washington Ave. Residence: 4352 Westminster PI.

SHELTON, Theodore, wholesale hats; born Sheltonville, Ga., June 18, 1844; son of V. B. and Emily (Connelly) Shelton; educated in schools in Georgia and Boonville, Mo.; married, Pettis County, Missouri, Feb. 20, 1868, Jane Redd Gentry; children: Richard T., William Gentry. Began commercial career as clerk with Cloney, Crawford & Co., Sedalia, Mo.; came to St Louis, 1866, entering employ of Henderson, Ridgeley & Co., wholesale dry goods, and when the firm retired front business, March, 1807, entered employ of Gauss-Hunicke & Co., wholesale hats; became partner, 1874; firm later became Gauss-Shelton Hat Co., until 1901, when he sold interest and bought interest in White-Branch-Shelton Hat Co., of which he is vice president. Democrat. Club: Mercantile. Office: 1511 Washington Ave. Residence: 4467 Lindell Ave.

memberships: ["of St Louis and American Bar associations","Law Library Association"]
fullentry: SHEPLEY, Arthur Behn, lawyer; born St Louis, March 21, 1873; son of John R. and Mary A. (Clapp) Shepley; A.B., Yale University, 1895; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1897; married, St Louis, May 20, 1903, Emily Catlin; children: Emily, Arthur, Mary. Admitted to St Louis bar, June, 1897; practiced alone until entered office of Nagel & Kirby, 1901; member of that firm since January, 1903. Member of St Louis and American Bar associations, Law Library Association. Republican. dubs: University, Noonday, Florissant Valley, Country. Office: 700 Security Bldg. Residence: 50 Westmoreland PI.

memberships: ["St Louis Bar Association","Business Men's League","Civic League; trustee Missouri Botanical Garden","Bellefon-tain Cemetery; director Humane Society of Missouri"]
fullentry: SHEPLEY, John Foster, vice president St Louis Union Trust Co.; born St Louis, Oct. 11, 1858; son of John R. aud Mary A.*Shepley; educated at Washington University and Yale University, graduating B.A. in class of 1880; LL.B., St Louis Law' School, 1882; married, St Louis, May 18, 1893, Sarah Hitchcock; children: John R., Ethan A. H. and Margaret. Admitted to bar, 1882, and engaged in practice of law in St Louis; was member of law firm of Lionberger & Shepley until 1900, when entered the old Union Trust Co., and upon its consolidation with the St Louis Trust Co., 1903, became vice president of the St Louis Union Trust Co. Member St Louis Bar Association, Business Men's League, Civic League; trustee Missouri Botanical Garden, Bellefon-tain Cemetery; director Humane Society of Missouri. Democrat. Clubs: University, St Louis, Noonday, St Louis Country, Commercial, Round Table, Bellerive. Recreation: golf. Office: 401 Locust St. Residence: 50 Vandeventer PI.

SHIELDS, George Howell, jurist; born Bardstown, Ky., June 19, 1842; son of George W. and Martha A. (Howell) Shields; lived in Missouri since 1844; educated in private schools, Hannibal, Mo., and then in Westminster College, Fulton, Mo. (which conferred degree of LL.I)., 1892); graduated from Louisville Law School, LL.B., March, 1S65; married, Hannibal, Mo., Feb. 1, 1866, Mary Harrison Leighton; children: George Howell, Jr., Sara Bainbridge (Mrs. William M. Warren), and Leighton. Practiced law in Hannibal, 1865-73; in partnership with Hon. John B. Henderson, 1873-83, in St Louis; practiced alone, 1883-89; removed to Washington, I). C., 1889, and was assistant Attorney General of United States and counsel for Interior Department under the administration of President Harrison, 1889-93; returned to St Louis, 1894; law partner with Hon. John W. Noble, 18941903; member of the firm of Barclay, Shields & Fauntleroy, 1905-06; elected judge St Louis Circuit Court (leading his ticket) for term of six years, ending Jan. 1, 1913; Republican. Was captain 53d Regiment Enrolled Missouri Militia; city attorney of Hannibal, Mo., three terms; member General Assembly of Missouri from Marion County, 1871-72; member Missouri Constitutional Convention from St Louis, 1875; member and president St Louis Board of Freeholders which formed Scheme and Charter for St Louis; agent and counsel for United States before Chilean (Maims Commission, 1893-94; master in chancery, United States Circuit Court, 1880-1905. Candidate for Supreme Court of Missouri, 1872; chairman Republican State Committee, 1876-80. Presbyterian; elder Second Presbyterian Church. Member and four years president, Missouri .*>50 Society Sons of the American Revolution (vice president National Society one year); member F. P. Blair Post, G. A. R. Chambers: Court House. Residence: 3665 Delmar Boul.

memberships: ["Missouri State and St Louis Bar associations"]
fullentry: SHIELDS, Leighton, lawyer; born St Louis, July 12, 1883; son of George Howell and Mary Harrison (Leighton) Shields; educated in St Louis public schools; A. B., Harvard University, 1904; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1905; unmarried. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1905, since engaged in general practice; member firm of Shields & Orthwein. Was United States commissioner, 1909-10; member Missouri state legislature, 1910-12. Member Missouri State and St Louis Bar associations. Republican. Presbyterian. Mason. Clubs: St Louis, University, Million Population, St Louis Amateur Athletic, Harvard. Recreations: tennis, swimming. Office: 1200 Third Xational Bank Bldg. Residence: 3665 Delmar Boul.

residence: Washington University. Residence: 539 Hanley Road, Clayton, Mo.
memberships: ["Latin section Congress of Arts and Sciences","World's Fair","St Louis","1904 (secretary); member managing committee American School of Classical Studies in Rome"]
fullentry: SHIPLEY, Frederick William, professor Latin; born Cheltenham, Ontario, Can., Jan. 15, 1871; son of William and Harriet (Hage-mann) Shipley; educated public schools, Cheltenham; high school, Brampton; A.B., University of Toronto, 1892 (first class honors, and McCaul medal, in classics); classical master, Collegiate Institutes, Collingwood and Lindsay, Ont.; fellow in Latin, University of Chicago, 1894-97, spending nearly two years in study at Rome, in American School of Classical Studies and in Vatican Library; Ph.D., University of Chicago, 1901; married, Elyria, ()., Mar. 28, 1899, Antoinette Cary; children: Frederick Cary, Walter Cleveland. Assistant in Latin, 1897-1908, University of Chicago; head department of Latin, Lewis Institute, Chicago, 1898-1901; professor Latin, Washington University, since 1901. Member Latin section Congress of Arts and Sciences, World's Fair, St Louis, 1904 (secretary); member managing committee American School of Classical Studies in Rome. Member St Louis Society Archa*ological Institute of America (general secretary), Archa*ological Institute of America (vice president), American Philological Association, Classical Association of Middle West and South (first vice president, 191112), Language and Literature Club of Washington University (president, 1912-13*), Classical Club of St Louis (president, 1909-10), Washington University Association (secretary, 1902-04, president, 1905), Town and Gown (secretary, 1906-11), Contemporary Club (executive committee), Chi Psi. Author: Certain Sources of Corruption in Latin Mss., The Macmillan Co., 1904; also (monographs) Studies in Manuscripts of Livy; The Treatment of Dactytic Words in the Rhythmic Prose of Cicero, etc. Contributor to magazines and reviews. Club: City. Business Address: Washington University. Residence: 539 Hanley Road, Clayton, Mo.

residence: 4 ‘Overdale," Lucas PL, Normandy, St Louis Co.
memberships: ["Engineers' Club (New York and St Louis)","British Institute Electrical Engineers","Civic League","League of Electrical Interests","Quill and Dagger","Phi Kappa Psi (Cornell)","etc"]
fullentry: SHIRAS, Oliver, president International Supply & Engineering Co.; born Ottawa, Kan., Aug. 29, 1876; son of Peter and Rachel (Ellison) Shiras; educated at Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y., graduating with degree of E.E., 1897; married, Terre Haute, Ind., May 9, 1906, Sophia Wheeler; one daughter, Sarah Patterson. In engineering department of New York Telephone Co., 1897-1900; manager S. England and Colonial offices of the British Westinghouse Co., 1900-04; consulting electrical engineer International Nickel Co. of New York, 1904-05; president Wire & Telephone Co. of America, Rome, New York, 1905-OS; located in St Louis, 1908, and now president and treasurer International Supply & Engineering Co., Shiras Electric Co.; president St Louis Taxicab Co., White Motor Car Co. of Mo., Guaranteed Electric Storage Battery Co.; director People's National Bank of Ottawa, Kan. Member Engineers' Club (New York and St Louis), British Institute Electrical Engineers, Civic League, League of Electrical Interests, Quill and Dagger, Phi Kappa Psi (Cornell),etc. Clubs: St Louis, City, Bellerive Country, Automobile; also Cornell University (New York). While at Cornell was manager athletic teams; president Inter-Collegiate Association of Amateur Athletics; member Board of Governors of Amateur Athletic Union. Recreations: golf, tennis, motoring. Office: 921 Locust St. Residence: 4 ‘Overdale," Lucas PL, Normandy, St Louis Co.

SHOCK, Floyd, banker; born Big Pond Furnace, Pa., Aug. 9, 1853; son of M. P. and Caroline (Beeler-Floyd) Shock; parents returned to Virginia, 1885; resided there until close of war, and, owing to disturbed condition of country during school age, received only limited education; married, Graham, Tex., March 25,1878, Sallie R. Richards, of La Fayette, Ala.; children: Sally Floyd, Mary (Mrs. Vernon Walsh, Jacksonville, Fla.), Kenan C., Fretwill. Went to Texas in 1873; settled on frontier, engaged in stock raising; elected clerk of District Court in Young County, Tex., 1878; in 1880 entered employ of George D. Barnard & Co. of St Louis, manufacturing stationers, blank book manufacturers, etc., as traveling man, and in 1889 engaged in manufacturing stationery business at Dallas, Texas; in 1890 became a director in George D. Barnard & Co. Since 1905 has been actively engaged in looking after his own investments*; vice president Central National Bank and Vandeventer Trust Co. Episcopalian. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: fishing. Office: 3927 Olive St. Residence: 5534 Clemens Ave.

SHOENBERG, Moses, vice president of The May Department Stores Co.; born Dayton, O., Dec. 2, 1852; son of Elias and Fannie (Rothschild) Shoenberg; educated in public and high schools of Dayton, 0.; married, Quincy, Ill., Oct. 6, 1880, Dollie Bernheimer; one son, Sydney M. Began business career in 1874, in trade in men's wearing apparel, at Springfield; went to Leadville, Colo., where was in same line, as a member of the firm of May & Shoenberg, for seven years; removed to Kansas City and was a partner in department store of G. Bernheimer Bros. & Co. for seven years; came to St Louis in 1892 and was managing partner of 4 4 The Famous'' until Dec. 5, 1903, when he joined in the purchase of the business of D. Crawford & Co. and established The May Company department store, of which he was president; company incorporated, 1911, as The May Department Stores Co., of which is vice president; also officer and director in The May Company, Cleveland, O., and The May Company, Denver, Colo. Director Mechanics-American National Bank, Mortgage Trust Co., United Jewish Charities, and of the Jewish Hospital. Republican. Member Business Men's League, Civic League. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country, Mercantile, Noonday. Recreation: traveling in this and foreign countries. Office: 6th and Olive Sts. Residence: Washington Hotel.

SHOENBERG, Sydney Melville, dry goods; born, Leadville, Colo., Aug. 23, 1881; son of Moses and Dollie (Bernheimer) Shoenberg; educated at Smith Academy, St Louis, and . Washington University, to 1900; married, St Louis, Oct. 27, 1909, Stella Hays; one son, Sydney Melville, Jr. Entire business career has been as associate of father in department store business, beginning with The Famous, 1900; with The May Company, Dec. 5, 1903, to December, 1906, as treasurer of the company; treasurer Famous Department Store, 1906-09; treasurer of William Barr Dry Goods Co., 1910-12; now director The Famous, William Barr Dry Goods Co., May Department Stores Co., Southern Security Co., Commercial Credit & Investment Co., and Light & Development of St Louis. Republican. Clubs: Columbian, Missouri Athletic, Westwood Country, City. Recreations: hunting, golf. Office: (5th and Olive Sts. Residence: 8 Washington Terrace.

office: Republican. Protestant. Favorite recreations: outdoor exercises. Office: Chemical Bldg.
fullentry: SHOTWELL, James B., manager Maebeth-Evans Glass Co.; born, Cincinnati, Oct. 23, 1806; son of Cassius and Virginia I). (Bone) Shotwell; educated in Cincinnati public schools; married, Chicago, June 16, 1900, Alice M. Wilson; one daughter, Elsie (now deceased). Began business life at age of fourteen with Wm. A. McCall & Co., hardware merchants, Cincinnati, for six years; went to Chicago and was with Hibbard, Spencer, Bartlett & Co. for seven years; then at Chicago office of Macbeth-Evans Glass Co., as salesman, 1897-1902; came to St Louis, 1902, taking present position as manager of St Louis office. Republican. Protestant. Favorite recreations: outdoor exercises. Office: Chemical Bldg. Residence: 5108 Delmar Ave.

SHRODER, Samuel W.f clothing merchant; born Cincinnati, Dec. 3, 1860; son of William and Emily (Hoffheimer) Shroder; educated in public schools of Cincinnati; married, St Louis, Dec. 18, 1890, Stella Schiele; children: Ralph S., Edwin William. Engaged in wholesale and retail clothing business in St Louis since Mar. 15, 1890; now vice president and secretary of Schmitz & Shroder Clothing Co.; also vice president of the Lipphardt & Klie Clothing Co. of East St Louis, Ill., and the Lipphardt & Heyman Clothing Co. of Detroit, Mich. Republican. Hebrew. Clubs: Mercantile, Columbian, Westwood Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 8th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: 5077 Washington Boul.

SHULTZ, John Rhodes; born St Louis, Aug. 19, 1872; son of J. A. J. and Mary E. (Brown) Shultz; educated in public schools of St Louis until 1889, aud in Manual Training School of Washington University until 1892; married, St Louis, Nov. 22, 1905, Mary Stuart Henry. During part of 1892 was engaged in druggist supply business as agent; in 1893 was draughtsman and erecting engineer; began with Shultz Belting Co., November, 1893, as salesman, and was manager of the company, 1903-11. Member export committee, Furniture Board of Trade. Democrat. Lutheran. Member Sons of the Revolution. Club: Missouri Athletic. Residence: 4961 McPherson Ave.

company: Pilley Packing and Flue Brush Manufacturing Co.
fullentry: SHULTZ, Llewellyn Brown, secretary Pilley Packing and Flue Brush Manufacturing Co.; born Grantville, Md., Nov. 1, 1853; son of Chauncey F. and H. C. (Brown) Shultz; resident of St Louis since 1859; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, 1887, Mary Pilley; children: Helen, Chauncey F., Hadessa C. (deceased). Began business career with Norris-Taylor Grocer Co. as clerk for five years; then was with Shultz & Samples, hides and leather, as salesman for four years, then clerk in city assessor's office, three years; went west and engaged in mining in Xew Mexico, Arizona and Old Mexico until 1887, when returned to St Louis, and in 1888 joined in organizing the Pilley Packing and Flue Brush Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of packings, flue brushes and engineers' tools, of which is secretary, treasurer and general manager. Member Civic League. Democrat. Episcopalian. Recreation: athletic sports. Office 608 S. 3d St. Residence: 6019 Waterman Avenue.

SHUMATE, William C., secretary Barr & Widen Commercial Agency Co.; born St Louis County, Dec. 26, 1854; son of Rev. Walker D. Shumate; educated in public schools and Arcadia College, Iron Co., Mo.; married, St Louis, Apr. 30, 1889, Margaret Connon; two daughters. Engaged in general merchandise business in St Louis County and later as superintendent of agents for publishing house of St Louis; became connected with the Barr & Widen Commercial Agency Co. as general manager subscription department, 1885, and has ever since been identified with the company. Republican. Presbyterian. Member Legion of Honor. Office: 515 Commercial Bldg. Residence: 4418 McPherson Ave.

SHUTT, Cleveland H., physician and surgeon; born DeKalb Co., Ind., Aug. 9, 1881; son of Lewis C. and Elizabeth (Rummel) Hhutt; attended graded and high schools, Indiana; Ph.D., Northern Indiana College, 1900; M.D., St Louis College of Physicians and Surgeons, 1904; post-graduate work hospitals of Vieuna, Paris, Berlin and Loudon, 1910-11; unmarried. Junior interne City Hospital, St Louis, 1904-05; senior interne, same hospital, 1905-06; superintendent Emergency Hospital No. 2, 1906-07; assistant superintendent City Hospital, 1907-10; hospital commissioner, St Louis, since Nov. 9, 1911. Member Medical Reserve Corps, U. S. A., since 1911. Author of several monographs on medical and scientific subjects. Recreations: outdoor sports and travel. Office: Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 3953 Delmar Boul.

company: William Sicher & Sons Dry Goods Co.
fullentry: SICHER, William, president William Sicher & Sons Dry Goods Co.; born Bohemia, Austria, duly 14, 1835; son of Herman and Marie (Levi) Sicher; came to America, 1852; attended Lafavette School, St Louis; married, St Louis, dan. 27, 1864, Hannah Emanuel (died 1899); five children: Henry W., Mrs. Ben Saenger, Edward, Mrs. J. H. Friedman, Milton J. Began in St Louis as clerk for Singer & Weiss, 1852; started business, 1853, on own account; head of William Sicher & Sons Dry Goods Co.; is now the oldest dry goods merchant in St Louis. Served in Civil War as member Second Missouri Reserve Corps. Republican. Jewish religion. Member B'nai B'rith, Free Sons of Israel. Recreation: motoring. Office: 121(1 S. Broadway. Residence: 1912 Nebraska Ave.

SIDENER, Howard, prosecuting attorney of City of St Louis: born Crawfordsville, Ind.. Oct. 29, 1875; son of Charles and Minnie (Myers) Si doner; Ph.B., Wabash Coll., 1898; LL.B., St Louis Law School, 1901; married, St Louis, Oct. 8, 1908, Myrtle Grennalt. In general practice in St Louis, 1901-09; associate prosecuting attorney, City of St Louis, August, 1909-11; elected prosecuting attorney, November, 1910, for term of four years, extending from January, 1911-Januarv, 1915. Member St Louis Bar Association. Republican. Scottish Rite Mason, and Shriner; member Knights of Maccabees, Tribe Ben-Hur, Moose. Club: Masonic. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: Municipal Courts Bldg. Residence: 3933 Pine St.

SIEGEL, Alfred Jacob, secretary and general manager Huttig Sash and Door Co.; born Waterloo, Ill., Mar. 20, 1871; son of August and Mathilde (W'einel) Siegel; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, November, 1894, Anna Foegeding; children: Ralph W., Richard Roy. Began business career as clerk in the Commercial Bank, Waterloo, Ill., in which remained two and one-half years; came to St Louis, 1888, and entered employ of Huttig Sash and Door Co., of which was elected secretary and general manager, 1898; also director Manchester Bank. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Mason, Knight Templar. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Normandie Golf. Favorite recreations: golf, fishing, motoring. Office: 1206 S. Vandeventer Ave. Residence: 5223 Vernon Ave.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society"]
fullentry: SIEVING, Gustav William, physician; born St Louis, Jan. 24, 1872; son of C. H. and Anna (Broekschmidt) Sieving; graduated Lutheran High School; pursued two years' course St Louis College of Pharmacy, grad-• uating, 1893; M.D., Marion-Sims Medical College, 1898; married, St Louis, Dec. 12, 1911, Florence Toepfer. Practiced, 1898-99, then engaged in drug business for six years; resumed practice, 1905. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society. Republican. Lutheran. Recreation: hunting. Office and Residence: 3601 S. Jefferson Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Salesmanagers' Association","Congregation of Temple Israel"]
fullentry: SILVERSTEIN, Bernard M., president Delmar Manufacturing Co.; born Bukharest, Rou-mania, Aug. 15, 1866; son of Marcus and Bertha (Epstein) Silverstein; educated in public schools of Bukharest; married, Philadelphia, Mar. 27, 1887, Bertha Morrowitz. Began business career as a dry goods clerk at age of thirteen, continuing, 1879-84; came to America, July 24, 1884; followed trade as a cutter at Philadelphia, first with Joseph Shoneman & Co., clothing manufacturers, 1884-90, then with Abe Kirchbaum, 1S90-94. Removed to St Louis, 1894, and was with Rosenthal & Desberger Clothing Co., 1894-97, Gilmore & Ruhl, 1897-98, Schwab Clothing Co., 1898-1903; entered manufacturing business on own account, Nov. 11, 1903, at which time he organized, and became president of the Delmar Manufacturing Co., manufacturers of infants' and children's headwear, and novelties. Member St Louis Salesmanagers' Association, Congregation of Temple Israel. Independent Order B 'rith Abraham. Mason. Recreations: fishing and bowling. Office: 415 N. 8th St. Residence: 3203 Dodier St.

SILVERTHORNE, Albert Elijah, lumber manufacturer; born Davenport, Iowa, Dec. 3, 1863; son of Albert David and Fannie (Hodgkins) Silverthorne, of Bangor, Me.; educated in Allen Academy, Chicago; married, Chicago, May, 1893, Margaret Docker, of Cincinnati; children: Olga, Albert Elijah, Jr. Was manager for A. P. & W. E. Kelley & Co., Chicago, for twelve years; in 1896 entered lumber manufacturing business of the Summit Lumber Co. at Upland, Ark., and Randolph, La., of which is r.ow secretary and manager; also president and general manager Carrabelle Sawmill Co., Carrabelle, Fla.; vice president and general manager Interstate Lumber Co., of Columbus, Miss.; director Anchor Sawmill Co., Ellisville, Miss. Member Business Men's League, Civic League. Republican. Presbyterian. Clubs: Mercantile, Missouri Athletic. Recreation: athletics. Address: St Louis, Mo.

SIMMONS, Edward Campbell, hardware merchant; born Frederick, Md., Sept. 21, 1839; son of Zachariah T. and Louisa C. Simmons; educated in St Louis grammar and high schools; married, St Louis, Nov. 24,1866, Garrie Welch; children: Wallace D., Edward H., George W. Engaged in hardware business in St Louis since Jan. 1, 1856; incorporated Jan. 1, 1874, Simmons Hardware Co., wholesale, retail and manufacturing, and has since been at head of the company, now chairman of the board of directors; director Bank of Commerce, St Louis Refrigerating & Cold Storage Co. Police commissioner under Gov. Crittenden (member of Cupples Board), 1881. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, St Louis Country. Office: 9th and Spruce Sts. Residence: 21 Westmoreland PI.

memberships: ["Business Men's League (executive committee)","Civic League","City Plan Association"]
fullentry: SIMMONS, George Welch, vice president Simmons Hardware Co.; born St Louis, Aug. 12, 1878; son of Edward C. and Garrie (Welch) Simmons; graduated from Smith Academy with highest standing in class of 1895, and from Yale University, A.B., 1900; married, St Louis, Nov. 21, i903, Virginia Wright; children: Richard Wright, Virginia, Lulie. Began with Simmons Hardware Co. of St Louis, Jan. 1, 1901, at bottom, pushing trucks in warehouse at a salary of $20 a month; worked up through every department of house and went on the road; made general manager, January, 1904, the company being manufacturers and distributors of hardware, cutlery, sporting goods, harness, etc. Member Business Men's League (executive committee), Civic League, City Plan Association. Member Missouri Historical Society, Symphony Society (executive committee), St Louis Grand Opera Committee. Clubs: St Louis, Noonday, St Louis Country, Dramatic, Traffic, Round Table, City, Automobile. Recreations: polo, golf. Office: 900 Spruce St. Residence: Clayton, St Louis County.

SIMMONS, Wallace Delafield, president Simmons Hardware Co.; born St Louis, Nov. 24, 1867; son of Edward C. and Garrie (Welch) Simmons; graduated from Yale College, 1890; married St Louis, Oct. 31, 1900, .Jessamine Barstow; children: Eleanor, Edward C. Since leaving college time has been devoted, practically exclusively, to the hardware business; made director of Simmons Hardware Co., Mar. 8, 1892; elected president Jan. 3, 1898. Protestant-Episcopalian. Clubs: St Louis, University, Noonday, Mercantile, St Louis Country, Round Table, Amateur Athletic Association, Algonquin Golf, Yale (New York), Graduates (New Haven, Conn.). Office: 9th and Spruce Sts. Residence: 4638 Berlin Ave.

office: T)e Kalb St. and Geyer Ave.
fullentry: SIMON, Charles Albert, president St Louis Architectural Iron Co.; born Louisville, Ky., .June 6, 1855; son of Conrad and Sarah (Christopher) Simon; educated in private schools at Paducah, Ky.; married, Memphis, Tenn., May 22, 1883, Etta L. Burdick; children: Charles (died in infancy), Ramsay, Emory, Ruth, Daniel. Started on his 17th birthday to learn the trade of machinist in shops of Chesapeake & Ohio R. R.; three years later became foreman and in 1882 when the change was made from five feet to the standard gauge he was placed in charge of the road as superintendent of machinery; was with company altogether about ten years; in 1883 he resigned to become a member of the firm of Christopher & Simpson Architectural Iron Co.; sold out his interest in that company in 1900 ami organized the St Louis Architectural Iron Co., of which he has since been president. Member and trustee Lafayette Park M. E. Church. Recreation: European travel. Office: T)e Kalb St. and Geyer Ave. Residence: St Louis.

memberships: ["American Medical Association","Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society","Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni","Alumni Association of Washington University Medical School"]
fullentry: SIMON, Frederick Casimir, physician; born St Louis, Jan. 7, 1875; son of William and Rebecca (Bannann) Simon; attended high school, St Louis; graduated St Louis College of Pharmacy, degree of Ph.B., 1896; M.D., Missouri Medical College, 1899; post-graduate study, Berlin and Vienna, 1905; unmarried. Tn practice in St Louis since 1900, making a specialty of the ear. nose and throat. Director and member of staff St Louis Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Infirmary; surgeon to ear department St Louis Children's Hospital: lieutenant Medical Reserve Corps. U. S. A. Member American Medical Association, Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society, Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni, Alumni Association of Washington University Medical School. Evangelical. Club: City. Recreations: walking in the country and canoeing. Office: 825 Metropolitan Bldg. Residence: 1835 Cass Ave.

office: De Kalb St. and Geyer Ave.
fullentry: SIMON, George H., secretary and treasurer St Louis Architectural Iron Co.; born Louisville, Ky., May 25, 1850; son of Conrad and Sarah (Christopher) Simon; educated in public and private schools at Paducah. Ky.; married, Paducah, Kv., 1879, Annie L. Judd; ohildren: George J., Walter C., Raymond J.; married, 2d, St Louis, 1897, Charlotte I. Pilcher; oue daughter, Lillian May. Was printer in early youth and followed the trade from 1870 until 1882; during that time was connected with the Post (now Post-Dispatch), the Globe-Democrat, and other papers; came from Evansville, Ind., to St Louis, 1882, aud be-, came a member of the Christopher & Simpson Architectural Iron Co. until 1900, when resigned and promoted the St Louis Architectural Iron Co., of which has since been secretary and treasurer. Member of Mound City Council, National Union. Member of the Good Shepherd (Episcopal) Church. Favorite recrea-ations: bowling, traveling. Office: De Kalb St. and Geyer Ave. Residence: 5932 Julian Ave.

SIMON, Israel Mark, banker and broker; born Cincinnati, May 3, 1849; son of Mark and Lottie (Thurnauer) Simon; educated in public schools of Cincinnati; graduated from Woodward High School, Cincinnati; LL.B., Harvard Law School, 1871; married, St Louis, June 15, 1880, Alice Kohn; children: Mark, Frederick, Clara Louise, John E. Practiced law in Cincinnati, as member of firm of Christy, Wright & Simon; in 1880 organized firm of Simon & Huseman, afterwards changed to I. M. Simon & Co., and engaged in banking and brokerage business; organized Equitable Xational Bank, 1887; removed to St Louis, 1900, and succeeded to business of Kohn & Co., bankers and brokers; member of firm of Simon, Brookmire & Clifford since 1906. Member Xew York Stock Exchange. Republican. Jewish religion. Member Missouri Historical Society, Ohio Society. Clubs: Columbian, Noonday, Glen Echo Country, Contemporary, Westwood Country. Recreations: reading anti golf. Office: Security Bldg. Residence: 4168 W. Pine St.

office: 4000 Chouteau Ave., Chouteau Trust Co. Bldg.
memberships: ["Missouri State Medical Association","St Louis Medical Society; vicepresident International Tuberculosis Congress"]
fullentry: SIMON, John Henry, physician; born in old Camp Jackson, St Louis, Dec. 5, 1868; son of Anton and Anna Marie (Kiamer) Simon; graduated from St Louis University, A.B., 1887, A.M., 1888, Missouri Medical College, M.D., 1890; married, St Louis, Nov. 27, 1890, Mary J. Cummings (grand daughter of Peter Mead); children: Anton, Katherine, Marie, Jerome, Helen. Engaged in general practice of medicine since 1890; member staff Rebekali Hospital. Member Missouri State Medical Association, St Louis Medical Society; vicepresident International Tuberculosis Congress. Member Missouri Historical Society, St Louis University Alumni Association (expresident). Democrat. Roman Catholic. Office: 4000 Chouteau Ave., Chouteau Trust Co. Bldg. Residence: 1201 McCausland Ave.

SIMON, Nickolas, contractor and builder; born Luxemburg, Germany, Oct. 7, 1842; son of Peter and Marjorie (Keiger) Simon; educated in public schools; married, St Louis, 1884, Julia Coffey; four children: Bernard, Edward L., William M., Aurelia. Learned carpenter's trade and worked in home town, later at Reims, France; came to America, 1867; in 1870 became foreman bridge construction work on Iron Mountain R. R.; in business independently as contractor in St Louis since 1893. Catholic. Residence: 4332 Evans Ave.

SIMPSON, David Roderick, secretary John Ramming Machine Co.; born St. Lonis, May, 1875; son of David and Frederika (Steinman) Simpson; educated in public schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, April, 1901, Nellie Long; children: David W. and Violet. Has been connected with the John Ramming Machine Co., engineers, machinists, builders of Corliss engines and complete steam and power plants, since 1894, and since incorporation, December, 1903, has been secretary of the company. Republican. Office: corner 1st Stand Clark Ave. Residence: 3334 California Avenue.

office: Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co., 10th to 11th Sts., Washington Ave.
fullentry: SIMPSON, William Ephram, vice president Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co.; born, Dangerfield, Tex., Nov. 17, 1856; son of William Burton and Lucy Matilda (Bridges) Simpson; educated in public schools; unmarried. First experience in dry goods business was with Ne-vius & Co., Denison, Tex., 1874-79; was connected with R. G. Hall & Son, Gainesville, Tex., 1879-80, and Simon & Gregory Dry Goods Co., St Louis, 1881-85; became salesman with Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co., 1886, a director 1903, and has been vice president since 1908. Democrat. Member M. E. Church, South. Recreations: hunting, fishing and motoring. Office: Rice-Stix Dry Goods Co., 10th to 11th Sts., Washington Ave. Residence: 4262 Washington Ave.

SIMSON, Leslie Noble, public accountant; born Seneca Falls, N. Y., Apr. 13, 1868; son of Joseph F. and Caroline E. (Prince) Sim-son; educated in public schools and Mynderse Academy, Seneca Falls, graduating from latter, 1886; married, Cedar Falls, Ia., Mar. 30, 1903, Nellie Fairfield. Clerk in Exchange National Bank, Seneca Falls, 1886-90; traveling auditor, bookkeeper, and in various other accounting capacities, with Kansas City, Fort Scott & Memphis R. R. Co., 1890-1901; since with Haskins & Sells, certified public accountants, and now manager of St Louis offices of firm. Republican. Methodist. Member Missouri Society of Certified Public Accountants. Club: Glen Echo Country. Office: 1702 Third National Bank Bldg. Residence: 4 N. King's Highway.

memberships: ["United Spanish War Veterans","Order of Foreign Wars","Citizens' Industrial Association"]
fullentry: SINCLAIR, Clarence A.f painting contractor; born Savanna, Carrol Co., Ill., Nov. 29, 1858; son of Allen and Rachel (Connor) Sinclair; educated in public schools of St Louis and Johnson's Business College; married, St Louis, 1895, Miss E. La Tina Vance. Began with father, who established painting business in St Louis in 1858; purchased the business of father, Jan. 2, 1879, continuing as Sinclair & Co. until 1890, when incorporated as Sinclair Painting Co., of which is president and treasurer. Was member First regiment Police Reserves, and Third and First regiments, Xational Guard of Missouri, 18781903; served as major First Missouri Volunteers, May 13 to Sept. 21, 1898, and of Seventh U. S. Volunteers, Sept. 21, 1898, to Feb. 28, 1899, in War with Spain; captain First Regiment, 1884-99, colonel First Regiment, 1899-1903. Mason (32°), Knight Templar, Shriner. Member United Spanish War Veterans, Order of Foreign Wars, Citizens' Industrial Association. Recreation: as drillmas-ter. Office: 1108-1110 St. Charles Ave. Residence: 5654 Bartmer Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis Manufacturers' Association","St Louis Credit Men's Association"]
fullentry: SISSON, William Armstead, chief clerk R. G. Dun & Co.; born in Henderson Co., Ky., dune 9, 1851; son of Strawther aud Julia (Cheaney) Sisson; attended country school during winter months, helping father on the farm in the summer; took course in Evansville (Ind.) Business College, 1871; married, Sept. 16, 1874, Mary Catherine Walker; children: Rupert H., Vinton E., Julia DupreS. Engaged in grocery business at Geneva, Ky., in fall of 1878; became city reporter for the Bradstreet Co., at Evansville, Ind., Nov. 12, 1881; appointed superintendent of office at Evansville, Oct. 1, 1882; transferred to St Louis office as assistant superintendent, Apr. 1. 1886; made city solicitor, Sept. 28, 1888; resigned to fill similar office with R. G. Dun & Co., July 1, 1899, and was appointed to present position, Dec. 1, 1902. Member St Louis Manufacturers' Association, St Louis Credit Men's Association. Club: Mercantile. Office: 314 Pine St. Residence: Oak Eminence, Webster Groves, Mo.

office: S. E. eor. S. Grand and Shenandoah Aves.
fullentry: SKEEL, Samuel G., physician; born Jefferson Co., Mo., Nov. 16, 1839; son of Samuel and Sarah (King) .Skeel; educated public schools; M.D., Medical Department, Washington University, 1882, College of Physicians and Surgeons, 1884; married, Washington Co., Mo., Aug. 3, 1861, Margaret A. Long; one daughter (Mrs. William L. Rinehart) and two sons: Dr. William A., Dr. Clarence Skeel (Dr. Clarence Skeel died in 1897). Began practice in Washington Co., 1882; removed to St Louis, 1897, and has since specialized in rectal diseases. Democrat. Methodist. Member Tri-State Medical Association. Mason. Office: S. E. eor. S. Grand and Shenandoah Aves. Residence: 3455 S. Grand Ave.

office: TJ. S. Engineer's Office, Custom House.
memberships: ["American Society of Civil Engineers; member Civic League"]
fullentry: SHELLY, James William, civil engineer; born in Audrain Co., Mo., Apr. 14, 1873; son of John and Clementine McPherson (Weidler) Skelly; educated in public schools of Audrain Co., and at Missouri State University, graduating, B.S., 1896, C.E., 1898; married at Mexico, Mo., Dec. 13, 1899, to Miss Pearl Smith; children: Gladys Gertrude and Frank Howard. Began professional career as rodman with the Mississippi River Commission, August, 1896, and has been continuously engaged upon work for the improvement of the Mississippi River, except during the period, March, 1901, to July, 1902, during which time was connected with the Engineering Department of the Missouri Pacific Ry. Member American Society of Civil Engineers; member Civic League. Methodist. Mason (Royal Arch). Clubs: St Louis Engineers', St Louis Railway, Masonic. Recreation: fishing. Office: TJ. S. Engineer's Office, Custom House. Residence: 4231 Russell Ave.

SKINKER, Charles Rives, lawyer ; born St Louis Co., Mo., Dec. 18, 1870; son of Thomas Keith and Bertha (Rives) Skinker; educated, Smith Academy; University of Virginia; Washington University; Yale University, B.A., 1894; St Louis Law School, LL.B., 1896; married, Baltimore, Md., Oct. 27, 1904, Elizabeth Baldwin Selden; three children: Nancy Selden, Charlotte Keith, Charles Rives, Jr. Admitted to Missouri bar, 1896, and since in practice in St Louis; assistant city counselor, 1903-07. Member St Louis Bar Association. Democrat. Episcopalian. Member Scroll and Key, Yale, 1894. Club: Florissant Valley. Recreation: tennis. Office: 806 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 4931 Laclede Ave.

memberships: ["Board of Election Commissioners","City of St Louis","1905-09"]
fullentry: SKINKER, Thomas K., lawyer; born in St Louis Co., Mo., June 9, 1845; son of Thomas and Jane (Neilson) Skinker; educated in private schools, 1855-57; A.B., Washington University, St Louis, 1863; studied at University of Virginia, 1866-67; married, Charlottesville, Va., Dec. 8, 1869, Bertha Rives; children: Charles R., Isabella N., Bertha R., Alexander R., Jane N. (Mrs. Claude L. Matthews). Admitted to bar in Circuit Court, St Louis, Dec. 29, 1867. Supreme Court of United States, 1876; official reporter of decisions of Supreme Court of Missouri, 1877-84; engaged in general practice, but for many years has given special attention to municipal bonds, both litigating them in court and passing on the legality of new issues for municipal corporations and investors. Director and counsel Trust Co. of St Louis Co.; president Law Library Association of St Louis (director, 1887-1904); was president Clayton and Forest Park Electric Ry. Co. and built road in 1893. Democrat. Member Board of Election Commissioners, City of St Louis, 1905-09. Delegate to New York Conference for Reform of Primary and Election Laws, 1906. Member Missouri Bar Association, St Louis Bar Association, Washington University Alumni Association, University of Virginia Alumni As- 55G sociation, Sons of the Revolution, Delta Kappa Epsilon. Episcopalian. Club: Noonday. Recreation: gardening. Office: 1035 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 6464 Ellenwood Ave.

SKINNER, Warren; born, Union City, Tud., June 19, 1874; son of Frank R. and Alice (Studebaker) Skinner; educated in public schools of Indiana and Kansas; married, St Louis, Apr. 18, 1900, Ida Rose; one daughter, Esther Rose Skinner. Was elected secretary and director of the Skinner & Kennedy Stationery Co., 1900, and has served as president same company since September, 1908. Recreation: country tramps. Office: 312 N. Broadway. Residence: 5644 Chamberlain Ave.

memberships: ["United Confederate Veterans","Sons of American Revolution","Alumni of University of Virginia","Phi Kappa Psi; honorary member Battery A","St Louis Light Artillery"]
fullentry: SKIPWITH, Peyton Horatio, Jr., manager The Spool Cotton Co.; born Pebble Hills, Hardin Co., Tenn., June 8, 1848; son of Peyton Horatio and Catherine Adair (Anderson) Skipwith; attended preparatory school of Rev. Pike^Powers, Mt. Laurel, Halifax Co., Va., 1862-64; appointed cadet of Virginia Military Institute, September, 1864, and reported for duty at Camp Lee, Richmond, Va.; attached to Gen. Joseph R. Anderson's Division, and served on line of fortifications on north side of Janies River, south of Richmond, and surrendered at Appomattox, Va.; attended University of Virginia three years, beginning Oct. 1, 1805; graduated in Anglo-Saxon, French, German, chemistry, junior natural philosophv and mathematics; married, St Louis, Feb. 18, 1890, Lennie Powell; children: Mary Adair, Cornelia Greene, Emma Webster, Edith Powell. Began business career as a clerk in a general store at Oxford, Miss.; came to St Louis in September, 1874; bookkeeper for Alfred Veal & Co., cotton factors; employed as manager of The Spool Cotton Co. since 1890. Democrat. Member United Confederate Veterans, Sons of American Revolution, Alumni of University of Virginia, Phi Kappa Psi; honorary member Battery A, St Louis Light Artillery. Recreations: fishing, hunting and baseball. Office: 1113 Locust St. Residence: 4105 Westminster PL

SKRAINKA, Louis, general contractor; born St Louis, Aug. 27, 1859; son of Joseph and Katharine (Schmiedlinger) Skrainka; graduated from St Louis High School; unmarried. Began reading law at nineteen, then became drug clerk, and afterwards timekeeper for various contracting firms; since 1883 in contract business, and in 1884 joined in organizing the Skrainka Construction Co., of which is president. Also president Atlantic Quarry and Construction Co., Union Quarry Co.; vice president Big Bend Quarry Co. Clubs: Columbian, Missouri Athletic. Favorite recreation: athletics. Office: 800 Security Bldg. Residence: 4318 W. Pine St.

SKRAINKA, Morris, general contractor; born St Louis, Aug. 14, 185S; son of Joseph and Katharine (Schmiedlinger) Skrainka; educated in St Louis public and high schools: married, St Louis, Oct. 24, 1894. Blanche Scharff; children: Walter J., Ralph Nicholas. Began business career at eighteen years of age as clerk for Torlina, Endres & Co., then timekeeper for contracting firms; entered general contracting business, 1883, and in 1884 joined in organization of the Skrainka Construction Co., of which is secretary and treasurer. Also secretary and treasurer Atlantic (Quarry and Construction Co.; director Mound City Roofing Co., New Union Sand Co.; treasurer Big Beud Quarry Co.; secretary Union (Quarry and Construction Co. Mason. Clubs: Columbian, Westwood Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 806 Security Bldg. Residence: 4235 Lindell Ave.

SLAUGHTER, Charles Henry, president Sinclair Quarry and Construction Co.; born Augusta, Ill., Feb. 18, 1862; son of Henry H. and Mary J. (Denny) Slaughter; educated in public schools of Keokuk, Ia.; married, St Louis, 1900, Clara Vogelsang. Began business career in hardware establishment at Ottumwa, Ia.; traveling salesman for ten years; came to St Louis, 1901, and bought into the Sinclair Quarry and Construction Co., of which is president. Republican. Office: 407 N. 8th St. Residence; 4 Parkland PI.

memberships: ["Phi Delta Theta Society","Legion of Honor","Knights of Honor","Mason"]
fullentry: SLAUGHTER, John William, hardware; born Culpeper, Va., June 30, 183S; son of Dr. Philip Clayton and Mary Elizabeth (McDowell) Slaughter; educated in private schools, Culpeper, until July, 1855; entered sophomore class of University of Wisconsin, graduating A.B., 1858 (later A.M.); married, Webster Groves, Mo., Oct. 11, 1871, Alice Helfinstein; children: Mary Helfinstein, Alice Maude (Mrs. Glenn W. Hutchinson). Served as private Company B, Thirteenth Virginia Infantry, C. S. A., enrolled April, 1861, discharged on parole, May, 1860; entered railway supply house of Fowle & Co., New York City, to October, 1866; office manager J. Ill Franklin & Co., cotton and commission merchants, Selma, Ala., 1806-67; resigned on account of ill health and was in cotton business in New York on own account, 1867-77; entered service Missouri Glass Co., St Louis, 1877, and was secretary and treasurer of company, 1878-88; engaged in real estate business from 1888 until Jan. 1, 1894, when was appointed United States dep uty collector of internal revenue, first district of Missouri, serving until July 31, 1903; in Teal estate business until Jan. 10, 1905, then entered auditing department Simmons Hardware Co. (wholesale house); on May 26, 1905. was transferred to The Simmons Co., where remained until 1907; since connected with auditing department Simmons Hardware Co. Democrat. Episcopalian. Member Phi Delta Theta Society, Legion of Honor, Knights of Honor, Mason. Club: Tuesday Evening (Webster Groves). Recreations: fishing and hunting. Office: 9th and Spruce Sts. Residence: Webster Groves, Mo.

SLIEMAN, Anthony, pastor St. Anthony the Hermit's Church; born Ito, Mount Lebanon, Syria, July 18, 1870; son of Paul Anthony and Hand (Slieman) Slieman (cousins); educated in village school to 1880; graduated from high school, 1888; finished studies for priesthood at St. Anthony College, Mount Lebanon, 1891. Ordained, Nov. 20, 1892, by Archbishop Stevens, and assigned to Syrian Church of Saint Sarcas of Ito, continuing until 1902; came to America, 1903; organized and was pastor of first Syrian church at Minneapolis, Minn., continuing there until 1905; then removed to St Louis and established a Syrian school, the first in United States teaching that tongue; pastor the Hermit's Church since Oct. 1, 1905. Church: 617 S. Broadway. Residence: 1201 St. Ange Ave.

SLOAN, James Melmoth, director and sales manager Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co.; born Marshall Co., Miss., Dec. 4, 1850; son of Rev. James A. and Sarah (Moffatt) Sloan; educated in public schools of northern Mississippi; married, Oxford, Miss., Sept. 1, 1880, Molcie Carter; seven children: Isla, Lucia, Berkeley, Eugene W., Mildred, William Carter, Mary. Began business career as clerk iu country store, Taylor, Miss., 1870, and continued until 1.875; engaged as manager clothing and men's furnishing goods department, Oxford, Miss., 1882, which store was removed to Fort Smith, Ark.; remained with company to 1886, when engaged as traveling salesman, state of Arkansas, with Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co.; was eastern buyer for the company, 1900-10, since sales manager; also a director of the company. Democrat. Presbyterian. Member Mississippi Society and Southern Society. Clubs: St Louis, Mercantile, Glen Echo, Automobile. Recreations: golf and motoring. Office: 1144 Washington Ave. Residence: 36 Washington Terrace.

SLOAN, William George, retired; born Harrisburg, Ill., Jan. 23, 1800; son of William G. and Sallie E. (McKinney) Sloan; educated in public schools of Harrisburg, and commercial school at Evansville, Ind.; married, Harrisburg, April, 1881, Nellie Pearce; children: Inez (Mrs. Eugene L. Berg), Katherine (Mrs. Bernard H. Wood, Jr., of Xew York City). Was in retail dry goods business, Harrisburg, until 1889, also running, at same time, branch dry goods stores at Golconda, Eddyville and Elizabethtown, Til., aud two or three stores in Kentucky; then acquired interest in Swofford Bros, (wholesale dry goods), Kansas City, Mo., for two years; buyer for wholesale house of Wear & Boogher Dry Goods Co. (now Carleton Dry Goods Co.) until 1900; first vice president of Rosenthal-Sloan Millinery Co., 1900-11, retired. Republican. Recreation: whist. Residence: 5831 Clemens Ave.

SLOAN, William Moffatt, second vice president Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co.; born on farm in Marshall Co., Miss., Xov. 3, 18(53; son of Rev. James A. and Sarah A. (Moffatt) Sloan; attended public schools until age of fifteen; married, Shreveport, La., Feb. 14, 1894, Caro Wise. At age of sixteen took position as retail salesman in Holly Springs, Miss.; three years later moved with same firm to Fort Smith, Ark.; came to St Louis and secured position with Hamilton-Brown Shoe Co., November, 1885; filled position as house salesman until Jan. 1, 1887, then traveled for house in Louisiana for twelve years; quit traveling Jan. 1, 1899, to take charge of building and managing the company's ‘ Sunlight Factory,' which position held until October, 1911, when he changed his headquarters to 12th St. and Washington Ave. Member St. Jojitj's M. R. Church (South) and superintendent of its Sunday School. Founder and superintendent Sloan Mission (now “Kingdom House"), 8th aud Hickory Sts; president Church Extension and City Mission Society. Clubs: Methodist (vice president), Mercantile, Glen Echo Country. Recreations: golf, hunting and fishing. Office: 12th St. and Washington Ave. Residence: 5151 Washington Boul.

memberships: ["Missouri Historical Society","Kentucky Society","Legion of Honor","and Camp St Louis","No"]
fullentry: SMALL, George Henry, real estate; born in Mason Co., Kv., Apr. 10, 1843; son of David and Mary A. (Dollis) Small; educated in public schools of Lafayette Co., Mo., aud graduated from commercial school at Louisville, Kv ; served in Confederate Army from 1861 to' close of war in 1865, and about three years of the time was in the artillery service; married, Clinton, Ia., Feb. 14, 1877, Ida M.^ Wet-more. Came to St Louis, Jan. 13, 186/, and shortly after entered employ of S. A. Grantham & Co., commission merchants; about two vears later formed co-partnership with J. N. Crouch; dissolved partnership about three vears later and soon after became member of Charles P. Burr & Co.; withdrew from that firm, September, 1881, and entered commission business alone, continuing until 189o; firm of Small & Crouch, real estate, 1900-0S; since retired. Resident vice president National Surety Co., of Xew York. Democrat; appointed police commissioner by Governor Francis, 1889, to fill unexpired term of two years, and reappointed by him for full term of our vears in February, 1891; assistant treasurer of the United States at St Louis, 1905-09. Member Missouri Historical Society, Kentucky Society, Legion of Honor, and Camp St Louis, No. 731, Confederate Veterans. Bec-reation: reading. Residence: 423fi ^Vestmin-ster PI.

SMALL, Harold Rainey, lawyer; born Decatur, Ill., Feb. 19, 1877; son of Dr. Archibald Robertson and Minerva (Rainey) Small; educated in public schools of Decatur, Chicago and Belleville, Ill., graduating from Belleville Public High School, 1894; graduated from 8mith Academy, St Louis, 1896; LL.B., Law Department, University of Michigan, 1899; married, St Louis, Mar. 8, 1910, Edna W. Ramsay. Since 1899 has engaged in law practice in state and federal courts of Missouri and Illinois. Member of St Louis Bar Association. Democrat. Presbyterian. Club: St Louis Amateur Athletic Association (president, 1911-12). Recreation: tennis. Office: 1605-14 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 5415 Maple Avenue.

SMITH, Alexander Hamilton, retired; born Burlington, Lawrence Co., O., May 22, 1833; son of Russell and Matilda Miller (Runner) Smith; educated in district school in Farmington, Ia., and Jones Commercial College, St Louis; married, St Louis, Feb. 1, 1858, Ade-laine E. Proctor; children: Mary Isabel, Helen Churchill (wife of Jordon W. Lambert). Began business career at age of fourteen as clerk in country store at Farmington; after short course at commercial college, 1850, became clerk for George Pegram & Co., commission merchants, and was with their successors, Rhodes, Pegram & Co. until 1860. Began for self as flour manufacturer, and in 1801 joined with Mr. Pegram in consolidation of milling interests under firm name of Alex. II. Smith & Co.; in 1870, with S. G. Sears, formed Empire Mill Co.; in 1880 promoted the Victoria Mill Co., and built the Victoria Mill; severed connection with latter, 1899, and retired. Ilej11* oerat. Captain Enrolled Missouri Militia, commissioned by Governor Gamble, 1861; captain of Police Reserves in Strike of 1877. Member Merchants' Exchange, St Louis Millers' Club, Knobel Club (president). Office: Merchants' Exchange. Residence: 5108 S. Broadway.

company: The Great Eastern Coffee and Tea Co.
fullentry: SMITH, Charles August, manager of The Great Eastern Coffee and Tea Co.; born St Louis, Mar. 11, 1865; son of Charles A. and Christina (Wittich) Smith; educated in public schools of Belleville, Ill., and St Louis; married, St Louis, Nov. 30, 1893, Ottilie Koelle; children: Herbert, Doris. Began business career in shoe department of John P. Becker, East St Louis. 1879-81; in retail toy business, with Ernest Koelle, 1881-83, H. R. Krite & Co., wholesale toys, 1883-86; then traveling salesman for Charles Schmidt Toy and Notion Co., 1886-94, and for Kipo Bros., Indianapolis, 1894-97; now manager Great Eastern Coffee and Tea Co. Republican. Presbyterian. Recreation: home diversions. Office: 801 Franklin Ave. Residence: 4840 Cote Brilliante Ave.

company: St Louis district for R. G. Dun & Co.
memberships: ["St Louis Merchants' Exchange","Business Men's League","Civic League","Million Population Club"]
fullentry: SMITH, Charles Burgess, manager St Louis district for R. G. Dun & Co.; born Georgetown, O., Dec. 24, 1841; son of Abram and Mary (Jones) 8mith; educated in common schools; married, Chicago, July 26, 1868, Emma E. Fee. Worked on farm until 1863 and taught in country schools; enlisted in Ohio regiment, Civil War, May, 1864, saw active service in Maryland, under Gen. Lew Wallace, and was discharged, August, 1864. In employ of R. G. Dun & Co since 1S66, first at New York, then at Chicago; removed to St Louis, 1871, and assistant manager St Louis district until 1884, since manager. Member St Louis Merchants' Exchange, Business Men's League, Civic League, Million Population Club. Democrat. Member Christian (Disciples) Church. Member B. P. O. Elks. Clubs: Mercantile, St Louis Country. Recreation: shooting. Office: 314 Pine St. Residence: 4849 Cote Brilliante Ave.

SMITH, Clarence Norton, manager Burroughs Adding Machine Co.; born Muscatine, Ia., Mar. 15, 1868; son of John Jay and Fannie Mary (Brownwell) Smith; educated in public schools of Keokuk, Ia.; married, Chicago, Apr. 11, 1890, Bertha K. BuehlaT; one child, Dorothy Elizabeth. Began active career as clerk in a bank at Keokuk, 1882, and held various positions until 1884; with wholesale stationery house at Cedar Rapids, 188487; salesman for Standard Oil Co., at Omaha, Xeb., 1887-92; with Baker-Vawter Co., of Chicago, 1893-1900, and Xational Cash Register Co., 1902-04; manager system department Burroughs Adding Machine Co. at Detroit, Mich.. 1905-10; manager St Louis district same company since January, 1910. Member St Louis Credit Men's Association. Democrat. Episcopalian. Clubs: City, Missouri Athletic, Rotary. Recreations: baseball and bowling. Office: 312 X. 12th St. Residence: 6008 Washington Boul.

SMITH, Edward Ashwell, treasurer Perrin & Smith Printing Co.; born Sutton, Bedfordshire, England, May 19, 1846; son of Thomas and Elizabeth (Boston) Smith; came to America with parents, 1852; educated in public schools of Alton, Ill.; married, Boston, Mass.. .Tune 10, 1869, Edna Cushing Jewett (died 1907); eight children: Lucy Emery, Edna Cushing (Mrs. Allen Keiser), Frank Jewett (deceased), Edward Harris, .Tewfctt, Ruth Ashwell (Mrs. F. .T. Worden, of Muskogee, Okla.). Walter Morgan, Herbert Cushing. Began in printing business at Alton, Ill., in 1870, under firm name of E. A. Smith, later as Perrin & Smith; removed to St. Lonis, March, 1880. firm name became The Perrin & Smith Printing Co. (incorporated May 28. 1898), of which has since been treasurer. For a number of years firm owned the Alton Daily Democrat which was merged into the Alton Sentinel Democrat and sold in 1890. Independent in politics. Congregationalist; trustee Alton Church of the Redeemer. Vice president Alton Y. M. C. A. Clubs: Ben Franklin, Alton Country. Recreations: golf, fishing, hunting. Office: 217-219 Olive St. Residence: 520 Seminary Sq., Alton, Ill.

memberships: ["Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni (ex-president)","American and Missouri State Medical associations","St Louis Medical Society","St Louis Society of Internal Medicine (president)"]
fullentry: SMITH, Elsworth. Jr., physician; born St Louis, Jan. I, 1864; son of Dr. Elsworth F. and Isabella (Chenie) Smith; educated in St Louis public schools; A.B., St Louis University, 1884, A.M., 1899; M.D., St Louis Medical College, 1887; married, St Louis, Feb. 21, 1900, Grace, daughter of Henry S. Platt; children: Elizabeth Platt, Elsworth Alexander McDougal, Isabella Chenie, Phillip Platt. Served as junior and senior physician and assistant superintendent St Louis City Hospital, 1887-90; since engaged in private practice. Clinical professor of medicine, Medical Department of Washington University; physician St Louis Mullanphy Hospital, Barnard Free Skin and Cancer Hospital, O 'Fallon Dispensary. Member Medical Society of City Hospital Alumni (ex-president), American and Missouri State Medical associations, St Louis Medical Society, St Louis Society of Internal Medicine (president). Independent in politics. Roman Catholic. Clubs: St Louis, Racquet, Bellerive Country, University. Office: 505-511 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 4502 Maryland Ave.

SMITH, Eugene, secretary Merchants' Exchange; born Warrensburg, Mo., Oct. 8, 1869; son of William G. and Mary Virginia (Dillard) Smith; educated public and private schools, graduating from high school; Keatchie College, Keatchie, La., 1886-88; graduate commercial course, same college, 1887; married, Mexico, Mo., 1904, Frances Newman Karnes; one daughter, Eugenia. Reporter on Globe-Democrat, 1888-89; studied law but gave up law on account of father's health, and entered his brokerage office at Little Rock, Ark.; returned to St Louis after father's death and with Globe-Democrat, 1892-94, with Chronicle, 1894-1906; secretary St Louis Manufacturers' Association, 1905-06; assistant secretary Merchants' Exchange, 1906-12, since secretary and treasurer same. Democrat. Episcopalian. Mason (32°), Shriner. Club: Mercantile. Recreation: literature. Office: Merchants' Exchange. Residence: 6019 McPherson Ave.

SMITH, George E., lawyer; born Clermont Co., O., Mar. 20, 1839; son of Eratus and Martha (Hulick) Smith; educated Knox College, Galesburg, Ill., graduating with degree of A.B., 1861; married, Port Byron, Ill., Sept. 25, 1871, Mary P. Lyford; three children: Bell (Mrs. Charles D. Perrine), Clara L. and Reno. Entered Union Army immediately upon leaving college and served as first lieutenant and captain Company H, Thirty-third Regiment, Illinois Volunteers, from September, 1861, to Nov. 19, 1865, participating in many of the important battles and movements of the war; admitted to Missouri bar, November, 1867, and has since engaged in practice in St Louis. Republican. Member Missouri House of Representatives, 1880-81. Member Ransom Post, G. A. R. Recreations: books, flowers. Office: Laclede Bldg., 408 Olive St. Residence: 5953 Page Ave.

SMITH, George Kimball, lumberman; born Rosemond, Ill., Feb. 23, 1862; son of Brainard and Nancy O. (Hawley) Smith; educated ill public schools; married, Kansas City, Mo., June 3, 1885, Lora A. Allen. Engaged in lumber business from 1886; secretary of the Yellow Pine Manufacturers' Association since 1890; also secretary National Lumber Manufacturers' Association. Republican. Protestant. Clubs: Mercantile, Glen Echo Country. Favorite recreation: golf. Office: Wright Bldg. Residence: 4239 Delmar Ave.

SMITH, Henry M., produce and fruits; born in Hanover, Germany, Dec. 3, 1848; son of Wilhelm and Kate (Bonameyer) Smith; educated in public schools of Germany; married, St Louis, Feb. 1, 1872, Fredrica Hartman; seven children living, three deceased. Came to United States from Hanover in 1866; lived three years in Philadelphia, where learned the trade of cabinet maker; came to St Louis in 1869, and in 1870 established II. M. Smith & Co., general commission merchants and dealers in fruits and produce; incorporated the business, 1903, as H. M. Smith Produce Co., of which has since been president. Member St Louis Produce Exchange. Office: 819 N. 4th St. Residence: 4344 Hartford St.

SMITH, Irwin Z.; born, St Louis, Aug. 19, 1862; son of Irwin Z. and Elizabeth (Kerr) Smith; educated at Washington University, St Louis, and mining engineering course at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston; married, St Louis, Aug. 14, 1893, Emma Bailey; children: Frances, Marian. Began business career as manager of an orange grove in Florida, continuing for three years; then was with the Union Trust Co. of St Louis for seven years as clerk, secretary and director, resigning 1909; in real estate business as a member of the Junior Realty Co. until November, 1910; since looking after personal investments. Independent in politics. Clubs: St Louis, University, St Louis Country, Noonday, Racquet. Favorite recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 805 Chestnut St. Residence: 87 Vandeventer PL

memberships: ["of American Academy of Ophthalmology and Oto Laryngology","St"]
fullentry: SMITH, J. Campbell, physician; born Winchester, Va., Oct. 30, 1860; son of John Alfred and Elizabeth (Campbell) Smith; M.D., University of Maryland, 1885; married, St Louis, DEc. 7, 1S92, Georgians Anderson. Began practice of medicine at Dawson, Pa., 1886-89; then went to Clifton Springs, X. Y., where was on medical staff of Clifton Springs Sanitarium, 1889-94; after one year of travel abroad came, in 1896, to St Louis, where has since engaged in practice. Member of American Academy of Ophthalmology and Oto Laryngology, St. Lonis Medical Society, Missouri State Medical Association, American Medical Association. On medical staff St. Luke's Hospital, St Louis Skin and Cancer Hospital, Evangelical Deaconess Hospital. Episcopalian. Club: St Louis Country. Recreation: golf. Office: 505-511 Humboldt Bldg. Residence: 3750 Westminster PL

SMITH, J. Sheppard, member Francis, Brother & Co.; born St Louis, Feb. 3, 1871; son of Elsworth F. and Isabelle (de Mun Chenie) Smith; educated in public schools, and at St Louis University; married, St Louis, Oct. 11, 1893, Susan Mitchell Cabanne; five children: Susan, Elsworth F., J. Sheppard, Jr., Cabanne, Mary Ambrose. Began active career as clerk for Greeley-Burnham Grocer Co., 1888; became credit man, same company, 1889, and continued in that position four years; then was made director and manager credit department of Scudders-Gale Grocer Co., continuing, 1893-1902; member Francis, Brother & Co. since 1902, and manager bond department same; director St Louis Dairy Co. Republican. Catholic. Club: St Louis Country. Recreations: golf, baseball. Office: 214 X. 4th St. Residence: 4516 Westminster PL

SMITH, James Elwood, president Equitable Surety Co.; born Schellsburg, Bedford Co., Pa., Feb. 12, 1851; son of John and Jane (Rea) Smith; educated in public schools of Schellsburg; married, Pottsville, Pa., Dec. 15, 1-880, Sallie Bryant; children: James Elwood, dr.. Gladys Bryant. Clerk in hardware house in Bedford, Pa., until 1870, when removed to St. Joseph, Mo., becoming traveling salesman with William Fairleigh & Co., wholesale hardware; removed to St Louis, 1875, and became connected with the Simmons Hardware Co.; elected a director of the company in 1889, secretary, 1893, vice president, 1898, which latter position he held until Apr. 1, 1911, when he became president of the Equitable Surety Co. of St Louis. In 1902 was sent to Japan as honorary commissioner to invite that country to participate in the Louisiana Purchase Exposition. Japanese Consul for St Louis; decorated by the Emperor of Japan with Crder of the Rising Sun. Director, chairman of committee on electricity, member committee of fine arts and member of International Jury of Awards, Louisiana Purchase Exposition. Member Business Men's League. Democrat. Presbyterian. Clubs: St Louis, Commercial, Glen Echo. Recreation: golf. Office: Third Xational Bank Bldg. Residence: 8 Lenox PI.

company: Supreme Recorder Legion of Honor of Missouri
fullentry: SMITH, James Michael, Supreme Recorder Legion of Honor of Missouri; born Chillicothe, O., Mar. 12, 1856; son of Matthew and Johanna (Parle) Smith; educated in Christian Brothers School, principally in St. Patrick's Academy (left before graduating); married, St Louis, Feb. 18, 1890, Mary C. Meaney, of Litchfield, Ill.; one daughter, Mary Margaret. Held clerical position with Wheeler & Wilson Sewing Machine Co., 1871-76; associated with L. Kenny, in manufacture and sale of ice cream, 1877-81; entered accounting department of St Louis Transfer Co., 1881, and was chief accountant for eighteen years prior to Jan. 23, 1903, when was elected as Supreme Recorder, Legion of Honor of Missouri. Catholic. Democrat. Member Knights of Columbus. Favorite recreation: baseball. Office: 211 Granite Blk. Residence: 4390 Gibson Ave.

SMITH, Jay Herndon, stock and bond broker; born Urbana, Ill., Apr. 8, 1871; son of William H. and Mary (Herndon) Smith; educated in public schools of Urbana and Champaign, Ill., and University of Illinois, but was not graduated; married, St Louis, 1899, Lida Brookings Wallace, daughter of A. A. Wallace; children: Wallace Herndon, Robert Brookings, Katherine Herndon. With Lobdell, Farwell & Co., bankers and brokers, Chicago, 1890-96; in business for self at Chicago, 1896-99; came to St Louis in 1899, and has since been member of firm of A. G. Edwards & Sons, stock and bond brokers; vice president A. G. Edwards & Sons Brokerage Co. Member Business Men's League, Civic League. Member St. John's Methodist Church. Clubs: Racquet, City, Noonday, St Louis Country. Recreations: golf and horseback riding. Office: 412 Olive St. Residence: 6500 Ellenwood Ave. ,

SMITH, Lansing Furman, president American Educational Society, publishers; born Mousey, N. Y., Mar. 8, 1873; descendant of Revolutionary ancestry; son of Nelson and Marietta (Furman) Smith; educated in district school, Township of Ramapo, Rockland Co., N. Y.; left school at seventeen to take position in Xew York City and has attended no other school except that of experience; married, St Louis, Dec. 7, 1898, Fannie Belle Biggers. Began business career as clerk with Dunham, Buckley & Co., dry goods, New York, 1890; became subscription book salesman, 1893; entered business on own account at Indianapolis as member of firm of Tichenor & Smith, 1896, later L. F. Smith & Co., and moved to St Louis, 1897; organized the American Educational Society, 1907, of which has since been president. Independent in politics. Presbyterian; elder Second Presbyterian Church. Secretary of Good Citizenship League of Missouri; interested in Sunday School and Brotherhood Work; and member of executive committee of city and state Sunday School associations. Member Missouri Historical Society, Sons American Revolution. Office: 625 Locust St. Residence: 5514 Cabanne Ave.

memberships: ["St Louis","Missouri State and American Bar associations"]
fullentry: SMITH, Luther Ely, lawyer; born Downer's Grove, Du Page Co., Ill., June 11, 1873; son of Luther R. and Adaline (Ely) Smith; educated in public schools of Monmouth Co., X. J., and Washington, D. C., Emerson Institute, Washington, D. C.; graduated Wi llist on Seminary, Easthampton, Mass., 1890, Amherst College, 1894, and St Louis Law School, 1897; married, St Louis, Nov. 17, 1909, SaLees Kennard; one daughter, Adeline Ely. Was teacher in Smith Academy, St Louis, 1894-98; began practice of law in St Louis in 1899; lecturer St Louis Institute of Law since 1908. Member St Louis, Missouri State and American Bar associations. Republican. Served in United States and Cuba in Third Uuited States Volunteer Engineers, 1898-99. Baptist. Clubs: University, City. Office: Pierce Bldg. Residence: 5321 Waterman Ave.

memberships: ["United Irish Land League","Irish-American Society","Knights of Columbus"]
fullentry: SMITH, Michael E., president Nash-Smith Tea and Coffee Co.; born in County Cavan, Ireland, Aug. 14, 1841; son of Michael and Margaret (McCabe) Smith; educated in National Schools in Ireland; married, St Louis, 1871, Marv A. Riley (now deceased); children: Margaret A. (Mrs. S. J. Smith), Walter M., Cecelia (Mrs. Phil. A. Broadhurst), Mary A. Came direct from Ireland to St Louis, in spring of 1865; began business career in city as clerk in the grocery house of Nash Brothers until 1870, when with George Nash and Charles Espenschied established in the importing and jobbing trade in teas, coffees and spices, as Nash, Smith & Espenschied; latter withdrew in 1878, and firm continued as Nash & Smith until 1887, when business was incorporated as Nash-Smith Tea and Coffee Co., of which is president. Independent in politics. Catholic. Member United Irish Land League, Irish-American Society, Knights of Columbus. Office: 918-920 N. 6th St. Residence: 5202 Vernon Ave.

SMITH, Richard Francis Xaviour, paper merchant; born St Louis, Doc. 4, 1866; son of Philip and Julia (Farrell) Smith; educated in schools of St Louis; married, St Louis, Sept. 18, 1901, Marie A. Luke; four children: Gertrude, Veronica, Mary Agnes, Richard F. Began business career with F. O. Sayer Paper Co., 1880, advancing to secretary of the company; organized the National Paper Co., February, 1904, and is president same. Office: 9-11 S. 3d St. Residence: 5136 Minerva Ave.

SMITH, Samuel T. G., lawyer; born Kansas City, Mo., Dec. II, 1869; son of Charles J. and Carrie E. (Parkinson) Smith; educated in Leavenworth, Kan., public schools and St Louis Law School; married, Sept. 2, 1908, Anna L. Force, of St Louis. Continuously engaged in the general practice of law in St Louis since admission to bar on Dec. 1, 1892. Club: Glen Echo Country. Office: 821 Mer-chauts-Laclede Bldg. Residence: 4931 McPherson Ave.

memberships: ["American Hospital Association (ex-vice president)","Phi Delta Theta","Nu Sigma Nu; honorary member Canadian Hospital Association","British Hospital Association"]
fullentry: SMITH, Wayne, physician; born Salt Lake City, Utah, Jan. 31, 1870; son of Amos K. and Cordelia Tyrell (Allen) Smith; educated in Salt Lake City High School; University of Utah; Washington University Medical School, degree of M.D., 1902; married, St Louis, Nov. 26, 1901, Elizabeth Bell; three children. Began practice in St Louis, 1902; registrar Washington University Medical Scnool, 1903-11, and secretary same, 1908-11; superintendent Washington University Hospital, January, 1904-Deeember, 1911; since superintendent City Hospital. Republican. Episcopalian. Member American Hospital Association (ex-vice president), Phi Delta Theta, Nu Sigma Nu; honorary member Canadian Hospital Association, British Hospital Association. Mason. Office and Residence: City Hospital.

SMITH, William Adolphus, civil engineer; born Upperville, Loudoun Co., Va., Dec. 2, 1868; son of Channing Meade and Lucy (Davenport) Smith; educated under private tutelage and later general course and civil engineering, Bethel Academy, Virginia; married, St Louis, Sept. 26, 1904, Ida S. Stevens; one son, Channing. Taught school in Virginia, 1884-86; with surveyor's office, St Louis Co., under B. E. Johnson, 1886-90; also in city surveying work, and ran level line to Chicago and line for electric railway under Dr. Adams; assistant editor Clayton Argus one year; traveled for Liggett & Myers, 1891-97; entered employ of Laclede Power Co. as contract agent, 1901, continuing until absorption of same by the Union Electric Co.; an incorporator of the Light and Development Co., 1908, and now vice president; director Paris Light and Power Co., Cape Girardeau Water Works and Electric Co. Democrat. Episcopalian. Recreations: ffy ffshing and hunting. Office: 1116 Wright Bldg. Residence: 3516 Victor St.

SMITH, William John, president J. R. Smith Cork Co.; born Elkton, Washington Co., Ill., Aug. 6, 1847; son of William and Jane (Hind- 5G2 man) Smith; educated at the Gamble (public) School, 20th and Randolph Sts., St Louis, until breaking out of Civil War; unmarried. Associated with brother, J. R. Smith, in cork business, 1880; brother died, 1902, and the business was incorporated as the J. R. Smith Cork Co., of which is president and treasurer. Served as orderly sergeant Company A, Eleventh Enrolled Missouri Militia. Republican. Member Reformed Presbyterian Church. Club: Horseshoe Hunting and Fishing. Recreations: hunting and fishing. Office: 110 Walnut St. Residence: 1401 X. Euclid Ave.

SMITHER, Alexander C., clergyman; born Frankfort, Ky., dune 10, 1805; son of L. X. aud Keziah (Curry) Smither; student Kentucky University, Lexington, Ky., 1882-8(5; studied two years at Butler University, Indianapolis, graduating, degree of A.B., 1890; married, Los Angeles, Cal., July 29, 1911, Miss Gertrude Clough; one child, Chester Campbell. Ordained Christian (Disciples) ministry, 1890; pastor First Christian Church, Los Angeles, 1890-1911; general manager Christian Board of Publication, St Louis (a corporation controlled bv the Disciples of Christ), since October, 1911. Trustee Pomona College, Claremont, Cal. Office: 2712 Pine St. Residence: Usona Hotel.

memberships: ["Knights of Pythias","Royal Arcanum","Knights of Maccabees","Modern Maccabees","Fraternal Order of Eagles"]
fullentry: SMYTHE, Edgar Rutherford, fire underwriter; born London, Ont., Can., Mat 10, 1877; son of Charles E. and Mary E. (Young) Smythe: educated in St Louis public schools, graduating from Pope School, January, 1895; married, St Louis, Dec. 17, 1897, Meta E. Davis, of San Francisco; one daughter, Mary Adelaide. Since leaving school has been continuously and exclusively eugaged in the fire . insurance business; established business for self, Jan. 1, 1900, under style of Edgar R. Smythe & Co., continuing until May 1, 1911,* when consolidated with Atwood & Johnson under firm name of Atwood, Johnson & Smythe (Mercantile Insurance Agency, Inc.); now in business alone. Democrat; member of House of Delegates of St Louis from Twenty-seventh Ward, 1905-09. Episcopalian. Member Knights of Pythias, Royal Arcanum, Knights of Maccabees, Modern Maccabees, Fraternal Order of Eagles. Favorite recreation: automobiling. Office: 1144 Pierce Bldg. Residence: 5899 Theodosia Ave.

SNIDER, Denton Jaques, lecturer, author; born Mount Gilead, O., Jan. 9, 1841; son of John R. and Catherin (Prather) Snider; graduated Oberlin College, 1862; unmarried. Author: Commentaries on the Literary Bibles (9 volumes—3 on Shakespeare and 2 each on Goethe, Dante and Homer), 1877-93; Walk in Hellas, 1882; The Freeburgcrs (novel), 1889; World's Fair Studies, 1895; Commentaries on Froebel's Play-Songs, 1895; Psychology and the Psychosis, 1896; The Will and Its World, 1899; The Psychology of Froebel's Play-Gifts, 1900; The Life of Frederick Froebel; The Father of History, Herodotus; Social Institutions, 1901; The State, 1902. Also (verse): Delphic Days, 1878; Agamemnon's Daughter, 1885; Prorsus Retrorsus, 1890; Homer in Chios, 1891; Johnny Appleseed's Rhymes, 1894; Ancient European Philosophy, 1903; Modern European Philosophy, 1904; Architecture, 1905; The Psychology of Feeling; The American Ten Years' War, 1906; European History, 1907; The Father of History, 1907; A Tour in Europe, 1908; Abraham Lincoln, 1908; A Writer of Books, 1909; Cosmos and Dracosmos, 1909; Lincoln in the Black Hawk War, 1910; The Brocosmos, 1911. Address: 210 Pine St.

memberships: ["Missouri Historical Society (president 18941900)","New Hampshire Historical Society","Minnesota Historical Society","American Historical Association","American Economic Association"]
fullentry: SNOW, Marshall Solomon, educator; born Hyannis, Mass., Aug. 17, 1842; son of Rev. Solomon P. and Maria J. (Pratt) Snow; educated at Phillips Exeter Academy, 1858-62; graduated Harvard, A.B., 1865, A.M., 18(TS; LL.D., Washington University, 1905; married, July 9, 1867, Ellen Frances Jewell, Exeter, X. H. Submaster High School, Worcester, Mass., 1865-66; principal High School, Xash ville, Tenn., 1866-67; professor Latin and principal of Montgomery Bell Academy, Xashville University, 1867-70.
